Then , sometimes the farmers use the handles of their whips ; it 's the only way they can get through . And then the miners curse behind us . Ugh ! I 've been so terribly frightened sometimes !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And is n't it strange that I have come here for the sake of these very people of whom you are so much afraid .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , surely not ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Quite seriously . These people interest me more than any one else here .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No one excepted ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No one .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Not even my brother-in-law ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No ! For my interest in these people is different and of an altogether higher nature . But you must forgive me ... You can n't be expected to follow me there .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And why not ? Indeed , I understand you very well ...She drops a letter inadvertently which LOTH stoops to pick up .Do n't bother ... it 's of no importance ; only an indifferent boarding-school correspondence .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So you went to boarding-school ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , in Herrnhut . You must n't think that I 'm so wholly ... No , no , I do understand .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You see , these workingmen interest me for their own sake .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: To be sure . And a miner like that is very interesting , if you look upon him in that way . Why , there are places where you never see one ; but If you have them daily before your eyes ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Even if you have them daily before your eyes , Miss Krause . Indeed . I think that is necessary if one is to discover what is truly interesting about them .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Dear me ! If it 's so hard to discover — I mean what is interesting about them !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well ; it is interesting , for instance that these people , as you say , always look so menacing and so morose .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why do you think that that is particularly interesting ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Because it is not the usual thing . The rest of us look that way only sometimes and by no means always .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , but why do they always look so ... so full of hatred and so surly ? There must be some reason for that .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Just so . And it is this very reason that I am anxious to discover .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , do n't !... Now you 're making fun of me ! What good would it do you , even if you knew that ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: One might perhaps find ways and means to remove the cause that makes these people so joyless and so full of hatred ; one might perhaps make them happier .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Slightly confused .I must confess freely that now ... And yet perhaps just now I begin to understand you a little . Only it is so strange , so new , so utterly new ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Entering through the door at the right . He has a number of letters in his hand .Well , here I am again .— Edward , see to it that these letters reach the post-office before eight o'clock .He hands the letters to the servant , who withdraws .Well , dear people , now we can eat ! Outrageously hot here ! September and such heat !He lifts a bottle of champagne from the cooler .Veuve Cliquot ! Edward knows my secret passions !He turns to LOTH .You 've had quite a lively argument , eh ?Approaches the table , which has now been laid and which groans under delicacies . Rubbing his hands .Well , that looks very good indeed !With a sly look in LOTH 'S direction .Do n't you think it does ?— By the way , sister ! We 're going to have company : William Kahl . He has been seen in the yard .

sp.speaker: HELEN makes a gesture of disgust

lg.l: HOFFMANN
My dear girl ! You almost act as if I ... How can I help it ? D'you suppose
I invited him ?
lg.stage: Heavy steps are heard in the outer hall .
lg.l: Ah !
“ Misfortune strides apace ! ”

sp.speaker: KAHL enters without having first knocked . He is twenty-four years
sp.p: old : a clumsy peasant who is evidently concerned , so far as possible , to make a show not only as a refined but , more especially , as a wealthy man . His features are coarse ; his predominant expression is one of stupid cunning . He wears a green jacket , a gay velvet waist-coat , dark trousers and patent-leather top-boots . His head-covering is a green forester 's hat with a cock 's feather . His jacket has buttons of stag 's horn and stag 's teeth depend from his watch-chain . He stammers .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: G-good evening everybody !

div.stage: He sees LOTH , is much embarrassed and , standing still , cuts a rather sorry figure .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Steps up to him and shakes hands with him encouragingly .Good evening , Mr. Kahl .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ungraciously .Good evening .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Strides with heavy steps diagonally across the room to HELEN and takes her hand .Evenin ’ t'you , Nellie .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: To LOTH .Permit me to introduce our neighbour 's son , Mr. Kahl .

div.stage: KAHL grins and fidgets with his hat . Constrained silence .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Come , let 's sit down , then . Is anybody missing ? Ah , our mama ! Miele , request Mrs. Krause to come to supper .

div.stage: MIELE leaves by the middle door .

sp.speaker: MIELE
sp.p: Is heard in the hall , calling out .Missus ! Missus !! You 're to come down — to come'n eat !

div.stage: HELEN and HOFFMANN exchange a look of infinite comprehension and laugh . Then , by a common impulse , they look at LOTH .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: To LOTH .Rustic simplicity !

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE appears , incredibly overdressed . Silk and costly jewels
sp.p: Her dress and bearing betray hard arrogance , stupid pride and half-mad vanity .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Ah , there is mama ! Permit me to introduce to you my friend Dr. Loth .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Half-curtsies , peasant-fashion .I take the liberty !After a brief pause .Eh , but Doctor , you must n't bear me a grudge , no , you must n't at all . I 've got to excuse myself before you right away —she speaks with increasing fluency— excuse myself on account o ’ the way I acted a while ago . You know , y'understan ’ , we ’ get a powerful lot o ’ tramps here right along ... ‘ Tai n't reasonable to believe the trouble we has with them beggars . And they steals exackly like magpies . It ai n't as we 're stingy . We do n't have to be thinkin ’ and thinkin ’ before we spends a penny , no , nor before we spends a pound neither . Now , old Louis Krause 's wife , she 's a close one , worst kind you see , she would n't give a crittur that much ! Her old man died o ’ rage because he lost a dirty little two-thousand , playin ’ cards . No , we ai n't that kind . You see that sideboard over there . That cost me two hundred crowns , not countin ’ the freight even . Baron Klinkow hisself could n't have nothin ’ better .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER has entered shortly after MRS. KRAUSE . She is small ,
sp.p: slightly deformed and gotten up in her mistress 's cast-off garments . While MRS. KRAUSE is speaking she looks up at her with a certain devout attention . She is about fifty-five years old . Every time she exhales her breath she utters a gentle moan , which is regularly audible , even when she speaks , as a soft — m .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: In a servile , affectedly melancholy , minor tone . Very softly .His lordship has exactly the identical sideboard — m —.

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: To MRS. KRAUSE .Mama , do n't you think we had better sit down first and then —

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Turns with lightning-like rapidity to HELEN and transfixes her with a withering look ; harshly and masterfully .Is that proper ?

div.stage: She is about to sit down but remembers that grace has not been said . Mechanically she folds her hands without , however , mastering her malignity .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Come , Lord Jesus , be our guest . May thy gifts to us be blest .

div.stage: All take their seats noisily . The embarrassing situation is tided over by the passing and repassing of dishes , which takes some time .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: To LOTH .Help yourself , old fellow , wo n't you ? Oysters ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I 'll try them . They 're the first I 've ever eaten .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Has just sucked down an oyster noisily .This season , you mean .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No , I mean at all .

div.stage: MRS. KRAUSE and MRS. SPILLER exchange a look .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: To KAHL , who is squeezing a lemon with his teeth .Have n't seen you for two days , Mr. Kahl . Have you been busy shooting mice ?

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: N-naw ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: To LOTH .Mr. Kahl , I must tell you , is passionately fond of hunting .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: M-m-mice is i-infamous amphibies .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Bursts out .It 's too silly . He can n't see anything wild or tame without killing it .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Las ’ night I sh-shot our ol ’ s-sow .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Then I suppose that shooting is your chief occupation .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Mr. Kahl , he just does that fer his own private pleasure .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Forest , game and women — as his Excellency the Minister von Schadendorf often used to say .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: ‘ N d-day after t-t'morrow we 're g-goin ’ t ’ have p-pigeon sh-sh-shooting .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What is that — pigeon shooting ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , I can n't bear such things . Surely it 's a very merciless sport . Rough boys who throw stones at window panes are better employed .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: You go too far , Helen .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I do n't know . According to my feeling it 's far more sensible to break windows , than to tether pigeons to a post and then shoot bullets into them .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , Helen , after all , you must consider ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Using his knife and fork with energy .It is a shameful barbarity .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Aw ! Them few pigeons !

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: To LOTH .Mr. Kahl , you know , has m-more than two-hundred of them in his dove-cote .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: All hunting is barbarity .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: But an ineradicable one . Just now , for instance , five hundred live foxes are wanted in the market , and all foresters in this neighbourhood and in other parts of Germany are busy snaring the animals .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What are all those foxes wanted for ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: They are sent to England , where they will enjoy the honour of being hunted from their very cages straight to death by members of the aristocracy .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Mohammedan or Christian — a beast 's a beast .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: May I pass you some lobster , mother ?

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: I guess so . They 're good this here season .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Madame has such a delicate palate .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: To LOTH .I suppose you ai n't ever et lobsters neither , Doctor ?

lg.l: Yes , I have eaten lobsters now and then — in the North , by the sea , in
Warnemuende , where I was born .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: To KAHL .Times an ’ times a person do n't know what to eat no more . Eh , William .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Y-y 're r-right there , cousin , G-God knows .

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Is about to pour champagne into LOTH 'S glass .Champagne , sir .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Covers his glass with his hand .No , thank you .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Come now , do n't be absurd .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What ? Do n't you drink ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No , Miss Krause .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , now , look here , old man . That is , you must admit , rather tiresome .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: If I were to drink I should only grow more tiresome .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: That is most interesting , Doctor .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Untactfully .That I grow even more tiresome when I drink wine ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Somewhat taken aback .No , oh , no . But that you do not drink ... do not drink at all , I mean .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And why is that particularly interesting ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Blushing .It is not the usual thing .

div.stage: She grows redder and more embarrassed .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Clumsily .You are quite right , unhappily .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: To LOTH .It costs us fifteen shillin 's a bottle . You need n't be scared to drink it . We gets it straight from Rheims ; we ai n't givin ’ you nothin ’ cheap ; we would n't want it ourselves .

lg.l: Ah , you can believe — m-me , Doctor : if his Excellency , the Minister von
Schadendorf , had been able to keep such a table ...

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: I could n't live without my wine .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: To LOTH .Do tell us why you do n't drink ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I 'll do that very gladly , I ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oh , pshaw , old fellow .He takes the bottle from the servant in order to press the wine upon LOTH .Just think how many merry hours we used to spend in the old days ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Please do n't take the trouble ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Drink to-day — this one time .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It 's quite useless .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: As a special favour to me .

div.stage: HOFFMANN is about to pour the wine ; LOTH resists . A slight conflict ensues .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No , no ... as I said before ... No !... no , thank you .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Do n't be offended , but that , surely , is a mere foolish whim .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: To MRS. SPILLER .A man that do n't want nothin ’ has had enough .

div.stage: MRS. SPILLER nods resignedly .

lg.l: Anyhow , if you let a man have his will what more can you do for him . But
I can tell you this much : without a glass of wine at dinner ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And a glass of beer at breakfast ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Very well ; why not ? A glass of beer is a very healthy thing .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And a nip of brandy now and then ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Ah , well , if one could n't get that much out of life ! You 'll never succeed in making an ascetic of me . You can n't rob life of every stimulus .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I 'm not so sure of that . I am thoroughly content with the normal stimuli that reach my nervous system .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: And a company that sit together with dry throats always has been and always will be a damnably weary and boresome one — with which , as a rule , I 'd care to have very little to do .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: An ’ all them aristocrats drinks a whole lot .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Devoutly confirming her mistress ’ remark by an inclination of her body .It is easy for gentlemen to drink a great deal of wine .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To HOFFMANN .My experience is quite to the contrary . As a rule , I am bored at a table where a great deal is drunk .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oh , of course , it 's got to be done in moderation .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What do you call moderation ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , so long as one is in possession of one 's senses ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Aha ! Then you do admit that , in general , the consumption of alcohol does endanger the possession of one 's senses ? And for that reason , you see , I find tavern parties such a bore .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Are you afraid of losing possession of your senses so easily ?

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: T ’ - t'other dhYpppHeNday I drank a b-bottle o ’ R-Rhine-wine , an ’ another o ’ ch-champagne . An ’ on top o ’ that an-n-nother o ’ B-Bordeaux — an ’ I wa n't drunk by half .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To HOFFMANN .Oh no . You know well enough that it was I who took you fellows home when you 'd been taking too much . And I still have the same tough old system . No , I 'm not afraid on that account .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , then , what is it ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , why is it really that you do n't drink ? Do tell us !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To HOFFMANN .In order to satisfy you then : I do not drink to-day , if for no other reason but because I have given my word of honour to avoid spirituous liquors .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: In other words , you 've sunk to the level of a temperance fanatic .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I am a total abstainer .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: And for how long , may one ask , have you gone in for this —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: For life .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Throws down his knife and fork and half starts up from his chair .Well , I 'll be ...He sits down again .Now , frankly , you must forgive me , but I never thought you so — childish .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You may call it so if you please .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: But how in the world did you get into that kind of thing ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Surely , for such a resolution you must have a very weighty cause — it seems so to me , at least .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Undoubtedly such a reason exists . You probably do not know , Miss Krause , nor you either , Hoffmann , what an appalling part alcohol plays in modern life ... Read Bunge , if you desire to gain an idea of it . I happen to remember the statements of a writer named Everett concerning the significance of alcohol in the life of the United States . His facts cover a space of ten years . In these ten years , according to him , alcohol has devoured directly a sum of three thousand millions of dollars and indirectly of six hundred millions . It has killed three hundred thousand people , it has driven thousands of others into prisons and poor-houses ; it has caused two thousand suicides at the least . It has caused the loss of at least ten millions through fire and violent destruction ; it has rendered no less than twenty thousand women , widows , and no less than one million children , orphans . Worst of all , however , are the far-reaching effects of alcohol which extend to the third and fourth generation .— Now , had I pledged myself never to marry , I might perhaps drink , but as it is — My ancestors , as I happen to know , were all not only healthy and robust but thoroughly temperate people . Every movement that I make , every hardship that I undergo , every breath that I draw brings what I owe them more deeply home to me . And that , you see , is the point ; I am absolutely determined to transmit undiminished to my posterity this heritage which is mine .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Look here , son-in-law , them miners o ’ ours do drink a deal too much . I guess that 's true .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: They swills like pigs .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And such , things are hereditary ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: There are families who are ruined by it — families of dipsomaniacs .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Half to MRS. KRAUSE ; half to HELEN .Your old man — he 's goin ’ it pretty fast , too .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: White as a sheet , vehemently .Oh , do n't talk nonsense .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Eh , but listen to the impident hussy . You might think she was a princess ! You 're tryin ’ to play bein ’ a grand lady , I s'ppose ! That 's the way she goes fer her future husband .To LOTH , pointing to KAHL .That 's him , you know ; they 're promised ; it 's all arranged .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Jumping up .Stop ! or ... Stop , mother , or I ...

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Well , I do declare ! Say , Doctor , is that what you call eddication , eh ? God knows , I treat her as if she was my own child , but that 's a little too much .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Soothingly .Ah , mother , do me the favour ....

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: No-o ! I do n't see why . Such a goose like that ... That 's an end o ’ all justice ... such a sl ...!

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oh , but mother , I must really beg of you to control —

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Doubly enraged .Instead o ’ sich a crittur takin ’ a hand on the farm .... God forbid ! She pulls her sheets ‘ way over her ears . But her Schillers and her Goethes and sich like stinkin ’ dogs — that can n't do nothin ’ but lie ; they c'n turn her head . It 's enough to make you sick !

div.stage: She stops , quivering with rage .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Trying to pacify her .Well , well — she will be all right now ... perhaps it was n't quite right ... perhaps ....

div.stage: He beckons to HELEN , who in her excitement has drawn aside , and the girl , fighting down her tears , returns to her place .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Interrupting the painful silence that has followed , to LOTH .Ah , yes ... what were we talking about ? To be sure , of good old alcohol .He raises his glass .Well , mother , let us have peace . Come ,— we 'll drink a toast in peace , and honour alcohol by being peaceful .MRS. KRAUSE , although somewhat rebelliously , clinks glasses with him .What , Helen , and your glass is empty .... I say , Loth , you 've made a proselyte .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: But , dear Miss Helen , that looks sus —

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: You were n't always so very particular .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Pertly .I simply have no inclination to drink to-day . That 's all .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oh , I beg your pardon , very humbly indeed ... Let me see , what were we talking about ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: We were saying that there were whole families of dipsomaniacs .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Embarrassed anew .To be sure , to be sure , but ... er ....

div.stage: Growing anger is noticeable in the behaviour of MRS. KRAUSE . KAHL is obviously hard put to it to restrain his laughter concerning something that seems to furnish him immense inner amusement . HELEN observes KAHL with burning eyes and her threatening glance has repeatedly restrained him from saying something that is clearly on the tip of his tongue . LOTH , peeling an apple with a good deal of equanimity , has taken no notice of all this .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What is more , you seem to be rather blessed with that sort of thing hereabouts .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Almost beside himself .Why ? How ? Blessed with what ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: With drunkards , of course .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: H-m ! Do you think so ... ah ... yes ... I dare say — the miners ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Not only the miners . Here , in the inn , where I stopped before I came to you , there sat a fellow , for instance , this way .

div.stage: He rests both elbows on the table , supports his head , with his hands and stares at the table .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Really ?

div.stage: His embarrassment has now reached its highest point ; MRS. KRAUSE coughs ; HELEN still commands KAHL with her eyes . His whole body quivers with internal laughter , but he is still capable of enough self-command not to burst out .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I 'm surprised that you do n't know this , well , one might almost say , this matchless example of his kind . It 's the inn next door to your house . I was told that the man is an immensely rich farmer of this place who literally spends his days and years in the same tap-room drinking whiskey . Of course he 's a mere animal to-day . Those frightfully vacant , drink-bleared eyes with which he stared at me !

div.stage: KAHL , who has restrained himself up to this point , breaks out in coarse , loud , irrepressible laughter , so that LOTH and HOFFMANN , dumb with astonishment , stare at him .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Stammering out through his laughter .By the Almighty , that was .... Oh , sure , sure — that was the ol ’ man .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Jumps up , horrified and indignant . She crushes her napkin and flings it on the table .You are ....With a gesture of utter loathing .Oh , you are ....

div.stage: She withdraws swiftly .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Violently breaking through the constraint which arises from his consciousness of having committed a gross blunder .Oh , pshaw !... It 's too dam ’ foolish ! I 'm goin ’ my own ways .He puts on his hat and says , without turning back :Evenin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Calls out after him .Don ’ know 's I c'n blame you , William .She folds her napkin and calls :Miele !MIELE enters .Clear the table !To herself , but audibly .Sich a goose !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Somewhat angry .Well , mother , honestly , I must say ....

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: You go and ...!

div.stage: Arises ; exits quickly .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Madame — m — has had a good many domestic annoyances to-day — m —. I will now respectfully take my leave .

div.stage: She rises , prays silently with upturned eyes for a moment and then leaves .

sp.speaker: MIELE and EDWARD clear the table . HOFFMANN has arisen and comes to
sp.p: the foreground . He has a toothpick in his mouth . LOTH follows him .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , you see , that 's the way women are .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I can n't say that I understand what it was about .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: It is n't worth mentioning . Things like that happen in the most refined families . It must n't keep you from spending a few days with us ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I should like to have made your wife 's acquaintance . Why does n't she appear at all ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Cutting off the end of a fresh cigar .Well , in her condition , you understand ... women wo n't abandon their vanity . Come , let 's go and take a few turns in the garden .— Edward , serve coffee in the arbour !

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Very well , sir .

div.stage: HOFFMANN and LOTH disappear by way of the conservatory . EDWARD leaves by way of the middle door and MIELE , immediately thereafter , goes out , carrying a tray of dishes , by the same door . For a few seconds the room is empty . Then enters

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Wrought up , with tear-stained eyes , holding her handkerchief against her mouth . From the middle door , by which she has entered , she takes a few hasty steps to the left and listens at the door of HOFFMANN 'S room .Oh , do n't go !Hearing nothing there , she hastens over to the door of the conservatory , where she also listens for a few moments with tense expression . Folding her hands and in a tone of impassioned beseeching .Oh , do n't go ! Do n't go !

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE SECOND ACT It is about four o'clock in the morning . The windows in the inn are still lit . Through the gateway comes in the twilight of a pallid dawn which , in the course of the action , develops into a ruddy glow , and this , in its turn , gradually melts into bright daylight . Under the gateway , on the ground , sits BEIPST and sharpens his scythe . As the curtain rises , little more is visible than his dark outline which is defined against the morning sky , but one hears the monotonous , uninterrupted and regular beat of the scythe hammer on the anvil . For some minutes this is the only sound audible . Then follows the solemn silence of the morning , broken by the cries of roysterers who are leaving the inn . The inn-door is slammed with a crash . The lights in the windows go out . A distant barking of dogs is heard and a loud , confused crowing of cocks . On the path from the inn to the house a dark figure becomes visible which reels in zigzag lines toward the farmyard . It is FARMER KRAUSE , who , as always , has been the last to leave the inn .

sp.speaker: FARMER KRAUSE
sp.p: Has reeled against the fence , clings to it for support with both hands , and roars with a somewhat nasal , drunken voice back at the inn .The garden'sh mine ... the inn'sh mihYpppHeNine ... ash of a ’ inn-keeper ! Hi-hee !After mumbling and growling unintelligibly he frees himself from the fence and staggers into the yard , where , luckily , he gets hold of the handles of a plough .The farm'sh mi'ine .He drivels , half singing .Drink ... o ... lil ’ brother , drink ... o ... lil ’ brother ... brandy'sh good t ’ give courash . Hi-hee —roaring aloud— ain ’ I a han'some man ... Ain ’ I got a han'some wife ?... Ain ’ I got a couple o ’ han'some gals ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Comes swiftly from the house . It is plain that she has only slipped on such garments as , in her hurry , she could find .Papa !... dear papa !! Do come in !She supports him by one arm , tries to lead him and draw him toward the house .Oh , do come ... do please come ... quick ... quick ... Come , oh , do , do come !

sp.speaker: FARMER KRAUSE
sp.p: Has straightened himself up and tries to stand erect . Fumbling with both hands he succeeds , with great pains , in extracting from his breeches-pocket a purse bursting with coins . As the morning brightens , it is possible to see the shabby garb of KRAUSE , which is in no respects better than that of the commonest field labourer . He is about fifty years old . His head is bare , his thin , grey hair is uncombed and matted . His dirty shirt is open down to his waist . His leathern breeches , tied at the ankles , were once yellow but are now shiny with dirt . They are held up by a single embroidered suspender . On his naked feet he wears a pair of embroidered bedroom slippers , the embroidery on which seems to be quite new . He wears neither coat nor waist-coat and his shirtsleeves are unbuttoned . After he has finally succeeded in extracting the purse , he holds it in his right hand and brings it down repeatedly on the palm of his left so that the coins ring and clatter , At the same time he fixes a lascivious look on his daughter .Hi-hee ! The money'sh mihYpppHeNine ! Hey ? How 'd y ’ like couple o ’ crownsh ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , merciful God !She makes repeated efforts to drag him with her . At one of these efforts he embraces her with the clumsiness of a gorilla and makes several indecent gestures . HELEN utters suppressed cries for help .Let go ! This minute ! Let go-o !! Oh , please , papa , Oh-o ! !She weeps , then suddenly cries out in an extremity of fear , loathing and rage :Beast ! Swine !

div.stage: She pushes him from her and KRAUSE falls to his full length on the ground . BEIPST comes limping up from his seat under the gateway . He and HELEN set about lifting KRAUSE .

sp.speaker: FARMER KRAUSE
sp.p: Stammers .Drink ... o ... lil ’ brothersh ... drrr ...

div.stage: KRAUSE is half-lifted up and tumbles into the house , dragging BEIPST and HELEN with him . For a moment the stage remains empty . In the house voices are heard and the slamming of doors . A single window is lit , upon which BEIPST comes out of the house again . He strikes a match against his leathern breeches in order to light the short pipe that rarely leaves his mouth . While he is thus employed , KAHL is seen slinking out of the house . He is in his stocking feet , but has slung his coat loosely over his left arm and holds his bedroom slippers in his left hand . In his right hand he holds his hat and his collar in his teeth . When he has reached the middle of the yard , he sees the face of BEIPST turned upon him . For a moment he seems undecided ; then he manages to grasp his hat and collar also with his left hand , dives into his breeches ’ pocket and going up to BEIPST presses a coin into the latter 's hand .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: There , you got a crown ... but shut yer mouth !

div.stage: He hastens across the yard and climbs over the picket fence at the right .

BEIPST has lit his pipe with a fresh match . He limps to the gate , sits down and begins sharpening his scythe anew . Again nothing is heard for a time but the monotonous hammer blows and the groans of the old man , which he interrupts by short oaths when his work will not go to his liking . It has grown considerably lighter .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Steps out of the house door , stands still , stretches himself , and breathes deeply several times .Ah ! The morning air .Slowly he goes toward the background until he reaches the gateway . To BEIPST .Good morning ! Up so early ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Squinting at LOTH suspiciously . In a surly tone .‘ Mornin ’ .A brief pause , whereupon BEIPST addresses his scythe which he pulls to and fro in his indignation .Crooked beast ! Well , are ye goin ’ to ? Eksch ! Well , well , I 'll be ...

div.stage: He continues to sharpen it .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Has taken a seat between the handles of a cultivator .I suppose there 's hay harvesting to-day ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Roughly .Dam ’ fools go a-cuttin ’ hay this time o ’ year .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , but you 're sharpening a scythe ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: To the scythe .Eksch ! You ol ’ ...!

div.stage: A brief pause .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Wo n't you tell me , though , why you are sharpening your scythe if it is not time for the hay harvest ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Eh ? Do n't you need a scythe to cut fodder ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So that 's it . You 're going to cut fodder ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Well , what else ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And is it cut every morning ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Well , d ’ you want the beasts to starve ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You must show me a little forbearance . You see , I 'm a city man ; and it is n't possible for me to know things about farming very exactly .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: City folks ! Eksh ! All of ‘ em I ever saw thought they knew it all — better'n country folks .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That is n't the case with me .— Can you explain to me , for instance , what kind of an implement this is ? I have seen one like it before , to be sure , but the name —

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: That thing that ye 're sittin ’ on ? Why , they calls that a cultivator .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To be sure — a cultivator . Is it used here ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Naw ; more 's the pity . He lets everything go to hell ... all the land ... lets it go , the farmer does . A poor man would like to have a bit o ’ land — you can n't have grain growin ’ in your beard , you know . But no ! He 'd rather let it go to the devil ! Nothin ’ grows excep ’ weeds an ’ thistles .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , but you can get those out with the cultivator , too . I know that the Icarians had them , too , in order to weed thoroughly the land that had been cleared .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Where 's them I-ca ... what d'you , call ‘ em ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: The Icarians ? In America .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: They 've got things like that there , too ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: What kind of people is them I-I-ca ...?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: The Icarians ? They are not a special people at all , but men of all nations who have united for a common purpose . They own a considerable tract of land in America which they cultivate together . They share both the work and the profits equally . None of them is poor and there are no poor people among them .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Whose expression had become a little more friendly , assumes , during LOTH 'S last speech , his former hostile and suspicious look . Without taking further notice of LOTH he has , during the last few moments , given his exclusive attention to his work .Beast of a scythe !LOTH , still seated , first observes the old man with a quiet smile and then looks out into the awakening morning .Through the gateway are visible far stretches of clover field and meadow . Between them meanders a brook whose course is marked by alders and willows . A single mountain peak towers on the horizon . All about , larks have begun their song , and their uninterrupted trilling floats , now from near , now from far , into the farm yard .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Getting up .One ought to take a walk . The morning is magnificent .

div.stage: The clatter of wooden shoes is heard . Some one is rapidly coming down the stairs that lead from the stable loft . It is GUSTE .

sp.speaker: GUSTE
sp.p: A rather stout maid-servant . Her neck is bare , as are her arms and legs below the knee . Her naked feet are stuck in wooden shoes . She carries a burning lantern .Good morning father Beipst !

div.stage: BEIPST growls .

lg.stage: Shading her eyes with her hand looks after LOTH through the gate .
lg.l: What kind of a feller is that ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Embittered .He can make fools o ’ beggars ... He can lie like a parson ... Jus ’ let him tell you his stories .He gets up .Get the wheelbarrows ready , girl !

sp.speaker: GUSTE
sp.p: Who has been washing her legs at the well gets through before disappearing into the cow stable .Right away , father Beipst .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Returns and gives BEIPST a tip .There 's something for you . A man can always use that .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Thawing at once , quite changed and with sincere companionableness .Yes , yes , you 're right there , and I thank ye kindly .— I suppose you 're the company of the son-in-law over there ?Suddenly very voluble .You know , if you want to go walkin ’ out there , you know , toward the hill , then you want to keep to the left , real close to the left , because to the right , there 's clefts . My son , he used to say , the reason of it was , he used to say , was because they did n't board the place up right , the miners did n't . They gets too little pay , he used to say , and then folks does things just hit or miss , in the shafts you know .— You see ? Over yonder ? Always to the left ! There 's holes on t'other side . It was n't but only last year and a butter woman , just as she was , sudden , sunk down in the earth , I do n't know how many fathoms down . Nobody knew whereto . So I 'm tellin ’ you — go to the left , to the left and you 'll be safe .

div.stage: A shot is heard . BEIPST starts up as though he had been struck and limps out a few paces into the open .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Who , do you think , is shooting so early ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Who would it be excep ’ that rascal of a boy ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What boy ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Will Kahl — our neighbour 's son here ... You just wait , you ! I 've seen him , I tell you . He shoots larks .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Why , you limp !

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Yes , the Lord pity me .He shakes a threatening fist toward the fields .Eh , wait , you ... you ...!

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What happened to your leg ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: My leg ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Eh ? Somethin ’ got into it .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Do you suffer pain ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Grasping his leg .There 's a tugging pain in it , a confounded pain .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Do you see a doctor about it ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Doctors ? Eh , you know , they 're all monkeys — one like another . Only our doctor here — he 's a mighty good man .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And did he help you ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: A little , maybe , when all 's said . He kneaded my leg , you see , he squeezed it , an ’ he punched it . But no ,' t'ain ' t on that account . He is ... well , I tell you , he 's got compassion on a human bein ’ , that 's it . He buys the medicine an ’ asks nothin ’ . An ’ he 'll come to you any time ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Still , you must have come by that trouble somehow . Or did you always limp ?

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Not a bit of it !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Then I do n't think I quite understand . There must have been some cause ...

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: How do I know ?Once more he raises a menacing fist .You jus ’ wait , you — with your rattling !

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Appears within his own garden . In his right hand he carries a rifle by the barrel , his left hand is closed . He calls across .Good mornin ’ , Doctor !

sp.speaker: LOTH walks diagonally across the yard up to KAHL . In the meantime
sp.p: GUSTE as well as another maid-servant named LIESE have each made ready a wheel-barrow on which lie rakes and pitch-forks . They trundle their wheel-barrows past BEIPST out into the fields . The latter , sending menacing glances toward KAHL and making furtive gestures of rage , shoulders his scythe and limps after them . BEIPST and the maids disappear .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To KAHL .Good morning .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: D'you want for to see somethin ’ fine ?

div.stage: He stretches his closed hand across the fence .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Going nearer .What have you there ?

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Guess !

div.stage: He opens his hand at once .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What ? Is it really true — you shoot the larks . You good for nothing ! Do you know that you deserve to be beaten for such mischief ?

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Stares at LOTH for some seconds in stupid amazement . Then , clenching his fist furtively he says :You son of a ...!

div.stage: And swinging around , disappears toward the right .
For some moments the yard remains empty .

sp.speaker: HELEN steps from the house door . She wears a light-coloured summer
sp.p: dress and a large garden hat . She looks all around her , walks a few paces toward the gate-way , stands still and gazes out . Hereupon she saunters across the yard toward the right and turns into the path that leads to the inn . Great bundles of various tea-herbs are slung across the fence to dry . She stops to inhale their odours . She also bends downward the lower boughs of fruit trees and admires the low hanging , red-cheeked apples . When she observes LOTH coming toward her from the inn , a yet greater restlessness comes over her , so that she finally turns around and reaches the farm yard before LOTH . Here she notices that the dove-cote is still closed and goes thither through the little gate that leads into the orchard . While she is still busy pulling down the cord which , blown about by the wind , has become entangled somewhere , she is addressed by LOTH , who has come up in the meantime .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Good morning , Miss Krause .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Good morning . See , the wind has blown the cord up there !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Let me help you .

div.stage: He also passes through the little gate , gets the cord down and opens the dove-cote . The pigeons flutter out .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Thank you so much !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Has passed out by the little gate once more and stands there , leaning against the fence . HELEN is on the other side of it . After a brief pause .Do you make a habit of rising so early ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I was just going to ask you the same thing .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I ? Oh , no ! But after the first night in a strange place it usually happens so .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why does that happen ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I have never thought about it . To what end ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , would n't it serve some end ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: None , at least , that is apparent and practical .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And so everything that you do or think must have some practical end in view .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Exactly . Furthermore ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I would not have thought that of you .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What , Miss Krause ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: It was with those very words that , day before yesterday , my stepmother snatched “ The Sorrows of Werther ” from my hand .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It is a foolish book .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , do n't say that .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Indeed , I must repeat it , Miss Krause . It is a book for weaklings .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: That may well be .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How do you come across just that book ? Do you quite understand it ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I hope I do — at least , in part . It rests me to read it .After a pause .But if it is a foolish book , as you say , could you recommend me a better one ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Read ... well , let me see ... do you know Dahn 's “ Fight for Rome ” ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No , but I 'll buy the book now . Does it serve a practical end ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No , but a rational one . It depicts men not as they are but such as , some day , they ought to be . Thus it sets up an ideal for our imitation .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Deeply convinced .Ah , that is noble .A brief pause .But perhaps you can tell me something else . The papers talk so much about Zola and Ibsen . Are they great authors ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: In the sense of being artists they are not authors at all , Miss Krause . They are necessary evils . I have a genuine thirst for the beautiful and I demand of art a clear , refreshing draught .— I am not ill ; and what Zola and Ibsen offer me is medicine .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Quite involuntarily .Ah , then perhaps , they might help me .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Who has become gradually absorbed in his vision of the dewy orchard and who now yields to it wholly .How very lovely it is here . Look , how the sun emerges from behind the mountain peak .— And you have so many apples in your garden — a rich harvest .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Three-fourths of them will be stolen this year just as last . There is such great poverty hereabouts .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I can scarcely tell you how deeply I love the country . Alas , the greater part of my harvest must be sought in cities . But I must try to enjoy this country holiday thoroughly . A man like myself needs a bit of sunshine and refreshment more than most people .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Sighing .More than others ... In what respect ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It is because I am in the midst of a hard conflict , the end of which I will not live to see .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But are we not all engaged in such a conflict ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Surely we are all engaged in some conflict ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Naturally , but in one that may end .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: It may . Yon are right . But why cannot the other end — I mean the one in which you are engaged , Mr. Loth ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Your conflict , after all , can only be one for your personal happiness . And , so far as is humanly speaking possible , the individual can attain this . My struggle is a struggle for the happiness of all men . The condition of my happiness would be the happiness of all ; nothing could content me until I saw an end of sickness and poverty , of servitude and spiritual meanness . I could take my place at the banquet table of life only as the last of its guests .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: With deep conviction .Ah , then you are a truly , truly good , man !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Somewhat embarrassed .There is no merit in my attitude : it is an inborn one . And I must also confess that my struggle in the interest of progress affords me the highest satisfaction . And the kind of happiness I thus win is one that I estimate far more highly than the happiness which contents the ordinary self-seeker .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Still there are very few people in whom such a taste is inborn .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Perhaps it is n't wholly inborn . I think that we are constrained to it by the essential wrongness of the conditions of life . Of course , one must have a sense for that wrongness . There is the point . Now if one has that sense and suffers consciously under the wrongness of the conditions in question — why , then one becomes , necessarily , just what I am .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , if it were only clearer to me ... Tell me , what conditions , for instance , do you call wrong ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , it is wrong , for instance , that he who toils in the sweat of his brow suffers want while the sluggard lives in luxury . It is wrong to punish murder in times of peace and reward it in times of war . It is wrong to despise the hangman and yet , as soldiers do , to bear proudly at one 's side a murderous weapon whether it be rapier or sabre . If the hangman displayed his axe thus he would doubtless be stoned . It is wrong , finally , to support as a state religion the faith of Christ which teaches long-suffering , forgiveness and love , and , on the other hand , to train whole nations to be destroyers of their own kind . These are but a few among millions of absurdities . It costs an effort to penetrate to the true nature of all these things : one must begin early .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But how did you succeed in thinking of all this ? It seems so simple and yet one never thinks of it .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: In various ways : the course of my own personal development , conversation with friends , reading and independent thinking . I found out the first absurdity when I was a little boy . I once told a rather flagrant lie and my father flogged me most soundly . Shortly thereafter I took a railroad journey with my father and I discovered that my father lied , too , and seemed to take the action quite as a matter of course . I was five years old at that time and my father told the conductor that I was not yet four in order to secure free transportation for me . Again , our teacher said to us : be industrious , be honourable and you will invariably prosper in life . But the man had uttered folly , and I discovered that soon enough . My father was honourable , honest , and thoroughly upright , and yet a scoundrel who is alive and rich to-day cheated him of his last few thousands . And my father , driven by want , had to take employment under this very scoundrel who owned a large soap factory .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: People like myself hardly dare think of such a thing as wrong . At most one feels it to be so in silence . Indeed , one feels it often — and then — a kind of despair takes hold of one .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I recall one absurdity which presented itself to me as such with especial clearness . I had always believed that murder is punished as a crime under whatever circumstances . After the incident in question , however , it grew to be clear to me that only the milder forms of murder are unlawful .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: How is that possible ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: My father was a boilermaster . We lived hard by the factory and our windows gave on the factory yard . I saw a good many things there . There was a workingman , for instance , who had worked in the factory for five years . He began to have a violent cough and to lose flesh ... I recall how my father told us about the man at table . His name was Burmeister and he was threatened with pulmonary consumption if he worked much longer in the soap factory . The doctor had told him so . But the man had eight children and , weak and emaciated as he was , he could n't find other work anywhere . And so he had to stay In the soap factory and his employer was quite self-righteous because he kept him . He seemed to himself an extraordinarily humane person .— One August afternoon — the heat was frightful — Burmeister dragged himself across the yard with a wheelbarrow full of lime . I was just looking out of the window when I noticed him stop , stop again , and finally pitch over headlong on the cobblestones . I ran up to him — my father came , other workingmen came up , but he could barely gasp and his month was filled with blood . I helped carry him into the house . He was a mass of limy rags , reeking with all kinds of chemicals . Before we had gotten him into the house , he was dead .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , that is terrible .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Scarcely a week later we pulled his wife out of the river into which the waste lye of our factory was drained . And , my dear young lady , when one knows things of that kind as I know them now — believe me — one can find no rest . A simple little piece of soap , which makes no one else in the world think of any harm , even a pair of clean , well-cared-for hands are enough to embitter one thoroughly .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I saw something like that once . And oh , it was frightful , frightful !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What was that ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: The son of a workingman was carried in here half-dead . It 's about — three years ago .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Had he been injured ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , over there in the Bear shaft .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So it was a miner ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , yes . Most of the young men around here go to work in the mines . Another son of the same man was also a trammer and also met with an accident .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And were they both killed ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , both ... Once the lift broke ; the other time it was fire damp .— Old Beipst has yet a third son and he has gone down to the mine too since last Easter .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Is it possible ? And does n't the father object ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No , not at all . Only he is even more morose than he used to be . Have n't you seen him yet ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How could I ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why , he sat near here this morning , under the gateway .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Oh ! So he works on the farm here ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: He has been with us for years .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Does he limp ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , quite badly , indeed .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Ah — ha ! And what was it that happened to his leg ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: That 's a delicate subject . You have met Mr . Kahl ?... But I must tell you this story very softly .She draws nearer to LOTH .His father , you know , was just as silly about hunting as he is . When wandering apprentices came into his yard he shot at them — sometimes only into the air in order to frighten them . He had a violent temper too , and especially when he had been drinking . Well , I suppose Beipst grumbled one day — he likes to grumble , you know — and so the farmer snatched up his rifle and fired at him . Beipst , you know , used to be coachman at the Kahls .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Outrage and iniquity wherever one goes .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Growing more uncertain and excited in her speech .Oh , I 've had my own thoughts often and often ... and I 've felt so sick with pity for them all , for old Beipst and ... When the farmers are so coarse and brutish like — well , like Streckmann , who — lets his farm hands starve and feeds sweetmeats to the dogs . I 've often felt confused in my mind since I came home from boarding-school ... I have my burden too !— But I 'm talking nonsense . It can n't possibly interest you , and you will only laugh at me to yourself .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But , my dear Miss Krause , how can you think that ? Why should I ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: How can you help it ? You 'll think anyhow : she 's no better than the rest here !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I think ill of no one .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , you can n't make me believe that — ever !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But what occasion have I given , you to make you ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Almost in tears .Oh , do n't talk . You despise us ; you may be sure that you do . Why , how can you help despising us —tearfully— even my brother-in-law , even me . Indeed , me above all , and you have — oh , you have truly good reasons for it !

div.stage: She quickly turns her back to LOTH , no longer able to master her emotion , and disappears through the orchard into the background . LOTH passes through the little gate and follows her slowly .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: In morning costume , ridiculously over-dressed , comes out of the house . Her face is crimson with rage . She screams .The low-lived hussy ! Marie ! Marie !! Under my roof ! Out with the brazen hussy !

div.stage: She runs across the yard and disappears in the stable . MRS. SPILLER appears in the house-door ; she is crocheting . From within the stable resound scolding and howling .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Comes out of the stable driving the howling maid before her .Slut of a wench !—The maid almost screams .— Git out o ’ here this minute ! Pack yer things ‘ n then git out !

sp.speaker: THE MAID
sp.p: Catching sight of MRS. SPILLER , hurls her milking stool and pail from her .That 's your doin ’ ! I 'll git even with you !

div.stage: Sobbing , she runs up the stairs to the loft .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Joining MRS. KRAUSE .Why , what did she do ?

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Roughly .Any o ’ your business ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Passionately , almost weeping .Yes , it is my business .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Coming up quickly .Dear Miss Helen , it 's nothing fit for the ear of a young lady ...

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: An ’ I 'd like to know why not ! She ai n't made o ’ sugar . The wench lay abed with the hired man . Now you know it !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: In a commanding voice .The maid shall stay for all that !

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Wench !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Good ! Then I 'll tell father that you spend your nights just the same way with William Kahl .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Strikes her full in the face .There you got a reminder !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Deathly pale , but even more firmly .And I say the maid shall stay ! Otherwise I 'll make it known — you ... with William Kahl ... your cousin , my betrothed ... I 'll tell the whole world .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Her assurance breaking down .Who can say it 's so !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I can . For I saw him this morning coming out of your bed-room ...

div.stage: She goes swiftly into the house .
MRS. KRAUSE totters , almost fainting . MRS. SPILLER hurries to her with smelling-salts .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Oh , Madame , Madame !

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Sp — iller ; the maid c'n sshYpppHeNstay !

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS QUICKLY
sp.p: THE THIRD ACT Time : a few minutes after the incident between HELEN and her step-mother in the yard . The scene is that of the first act . Dr. SCHIMMELPFENNIG sits at the table in the foreground to the left . He is writing a prescription . His slouch hat , cotton gloves and cane lie on the table before him . He is short and thick-set of figure ; his hair is black and clings in small , firm curls to his head ; his moustache is rather heavy . He wears a black coat after the pattern of the Jaeger reform garments . He has the habit of stroking or pulling his moustache almost uninterruptedly ; the more excited he is , the more violent is this gesture . When he speaks to HOFFMANN his expression is one of enforced equanimity , but a touch of sarcasm hovers about the corners of his mouth . His gestures , which are thoroughly natural , are lively , decisive and angular . HOFFMANN walks up and down , dressed in a silk dressing-gown and slippers . The table in the background to the right is laid for breakfast : costly porcelain , dainty rolls , a decanter with rum , etc .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Are you satisfied with my wife 's appearance , doctor ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: She 's looking well enough . Why not ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: And do you think that everything will pass favourably ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I hope so .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: After a pause , with hesitation .Doctor , I made up my mind — weeks ago — to ask your advice in a very definite matter as soon as I came here .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Who has hitherto talked and written at the same time , lays his pen aside , arises , and hands HOFFMANN the finished prescription .Here ... I suppose you 'll have that filled quite soon .Taking up his hat , cane and gloves .Your wife complains of headaches , and so —looking into his hat and adopting a dry , business-like tone— and so , before I forget : try , if possible , to make it clear to your wife that she is in a measure responsible for the new life that is to come into the world . I have already said something to her of the consequences of tight lacing .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Certainly , doctor ... I 'll do my very best to make it clear to her that ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Bowing somewhat awkwardly .Good morning .He is about to go but stops again .Ah , yes , you wanted my advice ...

div.stage: He regards HOFFMANN coldly .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: If you can spare me a little while ...With a touch of affectation .You know about the frightful death of my first boy . You were near enough to watch it . You know also what my state of mind was .— One does n't believe it at first , but — time does heal !... And , after all , I have cause to be grateful now , since it seems that my dearest wish is about to be fulfilled . You understand that I must do everything , everything — it has cost me sleepless nights and yet I do n't know yet , not even yet , just what I must do to guard the unborn child from the terrible fate of its little brother . And that is what I wanted to ask ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Dryly and business-like .Separation from the mother is the indispensable condition of a healthy development .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: So it is that ! Do you mean complete separation ?... Is the child not even to be in the same house with its mother ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Not if you are seriously concerned for the preservation of your child . And your wealth permits you the greatest freedom of movement in this respect .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Yes , thank God . I have already bought a villa with a very large park in the neighbourhood of Hirschberg . Only I thought that my wife too ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Pulls at his moustache and stares at the floor . Thoughtfully .Why do n't you buy a villa somewhere else for your wife ?

div.stage: HOFFMANN shrugs his shoulders .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: As before .Could you not , perhaps , engage the interest of your sister-in-law for the task of bringing up this child ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: If you knew , doctor , how many obstacles ... and , after all , she is a young , inexperienced girl , and a mother is a mother .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: You have my opinion . Good morning .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Overwhelming the doctor with excessive courtesy .Good morning . I am extremely grateful to you ...

div.stage: Both withdraw through the middle door .

sp.speaker: HELEN enters . Her handkerchief is pressed to her mouth ; she is
sp.p: sobbing , beside herself , and lets herself fall on the sofa in the foreground to the left . After a few moments , HOFFMANN reenters , his hands full of newspapers .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Why , what is that ? Tell me , sister , are things to go on this way much longer ? Since I came here not a day has passed on which I have n't seen you cry .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh !— what do you know ? If you had any sense for such things you 'd be surprised that you ever saw me when I did n't cry !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: That is n't clear to me .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , but it is to me !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Look here , something must have happened !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Jumps up and stamps her foot .Ugh ... but I wo n't bear it any longer ... it 's got to stop ! I wo n't endure such things any more ! I do n't see why ... I ...

div.stage: Her sobs choke her .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Wo n't you tell me at least what the trouble is , so that I ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Bursting out with renewed passion .I do n't care what happens to me ! Nothing worse could . I 've got a drunkard for a father , a beast — with whom his ... his own daughter is n't safe .— An adulterous step-mother who wants to turn me over to her lover ... And this whole life .— No , I do n't see that anyone can force me to be bad in spite of myself . I 'm going away ! I 'll run away ! And if the people here wo n't let me go , then ... rope , knife , gun ... I do n't care ! I do n't want to take to drinking brandy like my sister .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Frightened , grasps her arm .Nellie , keep still , I tell you ; keep still about that .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I do n't care ; I do n't care one bit ! I ... I 'm ashamed of it all to the very bottom of my soul . I wanted to learn something , to be something , to have a chance — and what am I now ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Who has not released her arm , begins gradually to dram the girl over toward the sofa . The tone of his voice now takes on an excessive softness , an exaggerated , vibrant gentleness .Nellie ! Ah , I know right well that you have many things to suffer here . But be calm ...! You need not tell one who knows .He puts his right hand caressingly upon her shoulder and brings his face close to hers .I can n't bear to see you weep . Believe me — it hurts me . But do n't , do n't see things in a worse light than is needful —; and then : have you forgotten , that we are both — you and I — so to speak — in the same position ?— I have gotten into this peasant atmosphere — do I fit into it ? As little as you do yourself , surely .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: If my — dear little mother had suspected this — when she ... when she directed — that I should be — educated at Herrnhut ! If she had rather ... rather left me at home , then at least ... at least I would n't have known anything else , and I would have grown up in this corruption , But now ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Has gently forced HELEN down upon the sofa and now sits , pressed close , beside her . In his consolations the sensual element betrays itself more and more strongly .Nellie ! Look at me ; let those things be . Let me be your consolation , I need n't talk to you about your sister .He embraces her more firmly . Passionately and feelingly .Oh , if she were what you are !... But as it is ... tell me : what can she be to me ? Did you ever hear of a man , Nellie , of a cultured man whose wife —he almost whispers— is a prey to such an unhappy passion ? One is afraid to utter it aloud : a woman — and — brandy ... Now , do you think I am any happier ?... Think of my little Freddie ! Well , am I , when all 's said , any better off than you are ?...With increasing passion .And so , you see , fate has done us one kindness anyhow . It has brought us together . And we belong together . Our equal sorrows have predestined us to be friends . Is n't it so , Nellie ?

div.stage: He puts his arms wholly around her . She permits it but with an expression which shows that she forces herself to mere endurance . She has grown quite silent and seems , with quivering tension of soul , to be awaiting some certainty , some consummation that is inevitably approaching .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Tenderly .You should consent to my plan ; you should leave this house and live with us . The baby that is coming needs a mother . Come and be a mother to it ; otherwise —passionately moved and sentimentally— it will have no mother . And then : bring a little , oh , only a very little brightness into my life ! Do that ! Oh , do that !

div.stage: He is about to lean his head upon her breast . She jumps up , indignant . In her expression are revealed contempt , surprise , loathing and hatred .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , but you are , you are ... Now I know you thoroughly ! Oh , I 've felt it dimly before . But now I am certain .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Surprised , put out of countenance .What ? Helen ... you 're unique — really .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Now I know that you 're not by one hair 's breadth better ... indeed , you 're much worse — the worst of them all here !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Arises . With assumed coldness .D'you know , your behaviour to-day is really quite peculiar .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Approaches him .You have just one end in view .Almost whispering .But you have very different weapons from father and from my stepmother , or from my excellent betrothed — oh , quite different . They are all lambs , all of them , compared to you . Now , now , suddenly , that has become clear as day to me .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: With hypocritical indignation .Helen , you seem really not to be in your right mind ; you 're , suffering under a delusion ....He interrupts himself and strikes his forehead .Good Lord , of course ! I see it all . You have ... it 's very early in the day , to be sure , but I 'd wager ... Helen ! Have you been talking to Alfred Loth this morning ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And why should I not have been talking to him ? He is the kind of man before whom we should all be hiding in shame if things went by rights .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: So I was right !... That 's it ... Aha ... well , to be sure ... then I have no further cause for surprise . So he actually used the opportunity to go for his benefactor a bit . Of course , one should really be prepared for things of that kind .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do you know , I think that is really caddish .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: I 'm inclined to think so myself .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: He did n't breathe one syllable , not one , about you .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Slurring HELEN 'S argument .If things have reached that pass , then it is really my duty , my duty , I say , as a relative toward an inexperienced young girl like you ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Inexperienced girl ! What is the use of this pretence ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Enraged .Loth came into this house on my responsibility . Now I want you to know that he is , to put it mildly , an exceedingly dangerous fanatic — this Mr. Loth .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: To hear you saying that of Mr. Loth strikes me as so absurd , so laughably absurd !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: And he is a fanatic , furthermore , who has the gift of muddling the heads not only of women , but even of sensible people ,

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Well , now , you see , that again strikes me as so absurd . I only exchanged a few words with Mr. Loth and ever since I feel a clearness about things that does me so much good ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: In a rebukeful tone .What I tell you is by no means absurd !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: One has to have a sense for the absurd , and that 's what you have n't .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: In the same manner .That is n't what we 're discussing . I assure you once more that what I tell you is not at all absurd , but something that I must ask you to take as actually true ... I have my own experience to guide me . Notions like that befog one 's mind ; one rants of universal brotherhood , of liberty and equality and , of course , transcends every convention and every moral law .... In those old days , for the sake of this very nonsense , we were ready to walk over the bodies of our parents to gain our ends ... Heaven knows it . And he , I tell you , would be prepared , in a given case , to do the same thing to-day .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And how many parents , do you suppose , walk year in and out over the bodies of their children without anybody 's ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Interrupting her .That is nonsense ! Why , that 's the end of all .... I tell you to take care , in every ... I tell you emphatically , in every respect . You wo n't find a trace of moral scrupulousness in that quarter .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , dear , how absurd that sounds again . I tell you , when once you begin to take notice of things like that ... it 's awfully interesting .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: You may say what you please . I have warned you . Only I will tell you quite in confidence : at the time of that incident I very nearly got into the same damnable mess myself .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But if he 's such a dangerous man , why were you sincerely delighted yesterday when he ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Good Lord , I knew him when I was young . And how do you know that I did n't have very definite reasons for ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Reasons ? Of what kind ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Never mind .— Though , if he came ; to-day , and if I knew what I do know to-day —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What is it that you know ? I 've told you already that he did n't utter one word about you .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , you may depend on it that if that had been the case , I would have thought it all over very carefully , and would probably have taken good care not to keep him here . Loth is now and always will be a man whose acquaintance compromises you . The authorities have an eye on him .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why ? Has he committed a crime ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: The less said about it the better . Just let this assurance be sufficient for you : to go about the world to-day , entertaining his opinions , is far worse and , above all , far more dangerous than stealing .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I will remember .— But now — listen ! After all your talk about Mr. Loth , you need n't ask me any more what I think of you .— Do you hear ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: With cold cynicism .Do you suppose that I 'm so greatly concerned to know that ?He presses the electric button .And , anyhow , I hear him coming in .

lg.l: HOFFMANN
Hallo ! Did you sleep well , old man ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , but not long . Tell me this , though : I saw a gentleman leaving the house a while ago .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Probably the doctor . He was here a while ago . I told you about him , did n't I ?— this queer mixture of hardness and sentimentality .

sp.speaker: HELEN gives instructions to EDWARD , who has just entered . He leaves
sp.p: and returns shortly , serving tea and coffee .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: This mixture , as you call him , happened to resemble an old friend of my student days most remarkably . In fact , I could have taken my oath that it was a certain — Schimmelpfennig .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Sitting down at the breakfast table .That 's quite right — Schimmelpfennig .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Quite right ? You mean ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: That his name is really Schimmelpfennig .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Who ? The doctor here ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Yes , certainly , the doctor .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Now that is really strange enough . Then of course , it 's he ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , you see , beautiful souls find each other on sea and shore . You 'll pardon me , wo n't you , if I begin ? We were just about to sit down to breakfast . Do take a seat yourself . You have n't had breakfast anywhere else , have you ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Very well . Then sit down .Remaining seated himself he draws out a chair for LOTH hereupon addressing EDWARD , who enters with tea and coffee .Ah , by the way , is Mrs. Krause coming down ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: The madame and Mrs. Spiller are taking their breakfast upstairs .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Why , that has never before ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Pushing the dishes to rights .Never mind . There 's a reason .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Is that so ?... Loth , help yourself !... Egg ? Tea ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I wonder if I could have a glass of milk ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: With all the pleasure in the world .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Edward , tell Miele to get some fresh milk .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Peeling an egg .Milk — brrr ! Horrible !Helping himself to salt and pepper .By the way , Loth , what brings you into these parts ? Up to now I 've forgotten to ask you .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Spreading butter on a roll .I would like to study the local conditions .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Looking up sharply .That so ?... What kind of conditions ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To be precise : I want to study the condition of your miners .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Ah ! In general that condition is a very excellent one , surely .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Do you think so ?— That would be a very pleasant fact ... Before I forget , however . You can be of some service to me in the matter . You will deserve very well of political economy , if you ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: I ? How exactly ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , you have the sole agency for the local mines ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Yes ; and what of it ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It will be very easy for you , in that case , to obtain permission for me to inspect the mines . That is to say : I would like to go down into them daily for at least a month , in order that I may gain a fairly accurate notion of the management .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Carelessly .And then , I suppose , you will describe what you 've seen down there ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes , my work is to be primarily descriptive .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: I 'm awfully sorry , but I 've nothing to do with that side of things . So you just want to write about the miners , eh ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That question shows how little of an economist you are .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Whose vanity is stung .I beg your pardon ! I hope you do n't think ... Why ? I do n't see why that is n't a legitimate question ?... And , anyhow : it would n't be surprising . One can n't know everything .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Oh , calm yourself . The matter stands simply thus : if I am to study the situation of the miners in this district , it is of course unavoidably necessary that I touch upon all the factors that condition their situation .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Writings of that kind are sometimes full of frightful exaggerations .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That is a fault which I hope to guard against .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: That will be very praiseworthy .He has several times already cast brief and searching glances at HELEN , who hangs with naive devoutness upon LOTH 'S lips . He does so again now and continues .I say ... it 's just simply too queer for anything — how things will suddenly pop into a man 's mind . I wonder how things like that are brought about in the brain ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What is it that has occurred to you so suddenly ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: It 's about you .— I thought of your be —... No , maybe it 's tactless to speak of your heart 's secrets in the presence of a young lady .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Perhaps it would be better for me to ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Please stay . Miss Krause ! By all means stay , at least as far as I 'm concerned . I 've seen for some time what he 's aiming at . There 's nothing in the least dangerous about it .To HOFFMANN .You 're thinking of my betrothal , eh ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Since you mention it yourself , yes . I was , as a matter of fact , thinking of your betrothal to Anna Faber .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That was broken off , naturally , when I was sent to prison .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: That was n't very nice of your ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It was , at least , honest in her ! The letter in which she broke with me showed her true face . Had she shown that before she would have spared herself and me , too , a great deal .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: And since that time your affections have n't taken root anywhere ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Of course ! I suppose you 've capitulated along the whole line — forsworn marriage as well as drink , eh ? Ah , well , a chacun son gout .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It 's not my taste that decides in this matter , but perhaps my fate . I told you once before , I believe , that I have made no renunciation in regard to marriage . What I fear is this , that I wo n't find a woman who is suitable for me ,

sp.speaker: HOFFMAN
sp.p: That 's a big order , Loth !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I 'm quite serious , though . It may be that one grows too critical as the years go on and possesses too little healthy instinct . And I consider instinct the best guarantee of a suitable choice .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Frivolously .Oh , it 'll be found again some day —laughing— the necessary instinct , I mean .

sp.speaker: LOTH
