sp.p: And , after all , what have I to offer a woman ? I doubt more and more whether I ought to expect any woman to content herself with that small part of my personality which does not belong to my life 's work . Then , too , I 'm afraid of the cares which a family brings .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Wh-at ? The cares of a married man ? Have n't you a head , and arms , eh ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Obviously . But , as I 've tried to tell you , my productive power belongs , for the greater part , to my life 's work and will always belong to it . Hence it is no longer mine . Then , too , there would be peculiar difficulties ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Listen ! Has n't some one been sounding a gong ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You consider all I 've said mere phrase-making ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Honestly , it does sound a little hollow . After all , other people are not necessarily savages , even if they are married . But some men act as though they had a monopoly of all the good deeds that are to be done in the world .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: With some heat .Not at all ! I 'm not thinking of such a thing . If you had n't abandoned your life 's work , your happy material situation would be of the greatest assistance ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Ironically .So that would be one of your demands , too ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Demands ? How ? What ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: I mean that , in marrying , you would have an eye on money .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Unquestionably .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: And then — if I know you at all — there 's quite a list of demands still to come .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So there is . The woman , for instance , must have physical and mental health . That 's a conditio sine qua non .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Laughing .Better and better ! I suppose then that a previous medical examination of the lady would be necessary .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Quite seriously .You must remember that I make demands upon myself too .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: More and more amused .I know , I know ! I remember your going through all the literature of love once in order to determine quite conscientiously whether that which you felt at that time for a certain lady was really the tender passion . So , let 's hear a few more of your demands .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: My wife , for instance , would have to practice renunciation .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: If ... if ... Ah , I do n't know whether it 's right to ... but I merely wanted to say that women , as a rule , are accustomed to renounce .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: For heaven 's sake ! You understand me quite wrongly . I did not mean renunciation in the vulgar sense . I would demand renunciation only in so far , or , rather , I would simply ask my wife to resign voluntarily and gladly that part of myself which belongs to my chosen work . No , no , in regard to every thing else , it is my wife who is to make demands — to demand all that her sex has forfeited in the course of thousands of years .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oho , oho ! Emancipation of woman ! Really , that sudden turn was admirable — now you are in the right channel . Fred Loth , or the agitator in a vest-pocket edition . How would you formulate your demands in this respect , or rather : to what degree would yam wife have to be emancipated ?— It really amuses me to hear you talk ! Would she have to smoke cigars ? Wear breeches ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Hardly that . I would want her , to be sure , to have risen above certain social conventions . I should not want her , for instance , to hesitate , if she felt genuine love for me , to be the first to make the avowal .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Has finished his breakfast . He jumps up in half-humorous , half-serious indignation .Do you know ? That ... that is a really shameless demand . And I prophesy , too , that you 'll go about with it unfulfilled to your very end — unless you prefer to drop it first .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Mastering her deep emotion with difficulty .If you gentlemen will excuse me now — the household ... You knowto HOFFMANNthat mama is upstairs and so ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Do n't let us keep you .

sp.speaker: HELEN bows and withdraws
sp.p: HOFFMANN

div.stage: Holding a match case in his hand and walking over to the cigar-box which stands on the table . ] There 's no doubt ... you do get a man excited ... it 's almost uncanny . [ He takes a cigar from the box and sits down on the sofa in the foreground , left . He cuts off the end of his cigar , and , during what follows , he holds the cigar in his left , the severed end between the fingers of his right hand . ] In spite of all that ... it does amuse me . And then , you do n't know how good it feels to pass a few days in the country this way , away from all business matters . If only to-day this confounded ... how late is it anyhow ? Unfortunately I have to go into town to a dinner to-day . It could n't be helped : I had to give this banquet . What are you going to do as a business man ? Tit for tat . The mine officials are used to that sort of thing .— Well , I 've got time enough to smoke another cigar — quite in peace , too .
He carries the cigar end to a cuspidor , sits down on the sofa again and lights his cigar .

lg.stage: Stands at the table and turns the leaves of a deluxe volume .
lg.l: “ The
Adventures of Count Sandor . ”

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: You 'll find that trash among all the farmers in the neighbourhood .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Still turning the leaves .How old is your sister-in-law ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: She was twenty-one last August .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Is she in delicate health ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Do n't know . I hardly think so , though . Does she make that impression on you ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: She really looks rather worried than ill .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well , if you consider all the miseries with her step-mother ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: She seems to be rather excitable , too .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: In such an environment ... I should like to see any one who would n't become excitable .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: She seems to possess a good deal of energy .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Stubbornness .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Deep feeling , too ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Too much at times ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But if the conditions here are so unfortunate for her , why does n't your sister-in-law live with your family ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: You 'd better ask her that ! I 've often enough made her the offer . Women have these fancies , that 's all .Holding the cigar in his mouth , HOFFMANN takes out a note-book and adds a fete items .You 'll forgive me , wo n't you , if I have to leave you alone after a while ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Assuredly .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: How long do you think of stay —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I mean to look for a lodging very soon . Where does Schimmelpfennig live ? The best thing would be to go to see him . He would probably be able to secure one for me . I hope that I 'll soon find a suitable place , otherwise I 'll spend the night at the inn next door .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Why should you ? Of course you 'll stay with us till morning , at least . To be sure , I 'm only a guest in this house myself , otherwise I 'd naturally ask you to ... you understand ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Perfectly .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: But do tell me , were you really quite serious when you said ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That I would spend the night at an inn ...?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Nonsense ... Of course not !... I mean what you mentioned a while ago — that business about your ridiculous descriptive essay ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: I must confess that I thought you were jesting .He gets up and speaks confidentially and half-humorously .Now , you do n't mean to say you 're really capable of undermining the ground here where a friend of yours has been fortunate enough to get a firm foothold ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You may take my word for it , Hoffmann ; I had no idea that you were here . If I had known that ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Jumps up , delighted .Very well , then ; very well . If that 's the way things are . And I assure you I 'm more than glad that I was not mistaken in you . So now you do know that I am here . It goes without saying that I 'll make up to you all your travelling expenses and all extras . No , you need n't be so excessively delicate . It 's simply my duty as a friend ... Now I recognise my excellent old friend again . But I tell you : for a time I had very serious suspicions of you ... Now you ought to know this , however . Frankly , I 'm not as bad as I sometimes pretend to be , not by any means . I have always honoured you , you and your sincere , single-minded efforts . And I 'm the last man to fail to attach weight to certain demands of the exploited , oppressed masses , demands which are , most unfortunately , only too well justified .— Oh , you may smile . I 'll go further and confess that there is just one party in parliament that has any true ideals , and that 's the party to which you belong ! Only — as I said before — we must go slowly , slowly !— not try to rush things through . Everything is coming , surely coming about exactly as it ought to . Only patience ! Patience ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: One must have patience . That is certain . But one is n't justified on that account in folding one 's hands in idleness .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Exactly my opinion .— As a matter of fact my thoughts have oftener been in accord with you than my words . It 's a bad habit of mine , I admit , I fell into it in intercourse with people to whom I did n't always want to show my hand .... Take the question , of woman , for instance ... You expressed a good many things quite strikingly .He has , in the meantime , approached the telephone , taken up the receiver and now speaks alternately into the telephone and to LOTH .My little sister-in-law , by the way , was all ear ...Into the telephone .Frank ! I want the carriage in ten minutes ...To LOTH .You made an impression on her ...Into the telephone .What — oh , nonsense !— well , that beats everything ... Then hitch up the black horses at once ...To LOTH .And why should n't you ?...Into the telephone .Well , upon my ...! To the milliner , you say ? The madame ? The ma —! Well , very well , then . But at once ! Oh , very well ! Yes ! What 's the —!He presses the button of the servants ’ bell . To LOTH .You just wait . Give me a chance to heap up the necessary mountain of shekels , and maybe you 'll see something happen ...EDWARD has entered .Edward , my leggings , my walking-coat !EDWARD withdraws .Maybe something will happen then that you fellows would n't believe of me now ... If , at the end of two or three days — you must stay with us so long by all means — I 'd consider it a real insult if you did n't —he slips out of his dressing-gown— if , at the end of two or three days , you 're ready to go . I 'll drive you over to the train .

sp.speaker: EDWARD enters carrying gaiters and walking-coat
sp.p: HOFFMANN

div.stage: Permitting himself to be helped on with the coat . ] So-o ! [ Sitting down on a chair . ] Now the boots . [ After he has pulled on one of them . ] There 's number one !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Perhaps you did n't quite understand me after all .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Surely , that 's quite possible . A fellow gets out of touch with things . Nothing but musty business affairs . Edward , has n't the mail come yet ? Wait a minute !— Do go up into my room . You 'll find a document in a blue cover on the left side of my desk . Get that and put it into the carriage .

sp.speaker: EDWARD goes through the door at the right , reappears through the
sp.p: middle-door and then withdraws .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I simply meant that you had n't understood me in one particular respect .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Worrying his foot into the other shoe .Ouch ! There !He rises and stamps his feet .There we are . Nothing is more disagreeable than tight shoes ... What were you saying just now ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You were speaking of my departure ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Well ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But I thought I had explained that I must stay here for a specific purpose .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: In extreme consternation and thoroughly indignant at once .Look here !... That comes near being caddish !— Do n't you know what you owe me as your friend ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Not , I hope , the betrayal of my cause !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Beside himself .Well then — in that case — I have n't the slightest motive for treating you as a friend . And so I tell you that I consider your appearance and demeanour here — to put it mildly — incredibly impudent .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Quite calmly .Perhaps you 'll explain what gives you the right to use such epithets ...

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Yon want an explanation of that ? That is going to an extreme ! Not to feel a thing like that it 's necessary to have a rhinoceros-hide instead of skin on one 's back ! You come here , enjoy my hospitality , thresh out a few of your thread-bare phrases , turn my sister-in-law 's head , go on about old friendship and other pleasant things , and then you tell me quite coolly : you 're going to write a descriptive pamphlet about the local conditions . Why , what do you take me to be , anyhow ? D'you suppose I do n't know that these so-called essays are merely shameless libels ?... You want to write a denunciation like that , and about our coal district , of all places ! Are you so blind that you can n't see whom such a rag would harm most keenly ? Only me , of course ! I tell you , the trade that you demagogues drive ought to be more firmly stamped out than has been done up to now ! What is it you do ? You make the miners discontented , presumptuous ; you stir them up , embitter them , make them rebellious , disobedient , wretched ! Then you delude them with promises of mountains of gold , and , in the meantime , grab out of their pockets the few pennies that keep them from starving !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Do you consider yourself unmasked now ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Brutally .Oh , pshaw ! You ridiculous , pompous wind-bag ! What do you suppose I care about being unmasked by you ?— Go to work ! Leave off this silly drivelling !— Do something ! Get ahead ! I do n't need to sponge on any one for two-hundred marks !He rushes out through the middle door .For several moments LOTH looks calmly after him . Then , no less calmly , he draws a card case out of his inner pocket , takes a slip of paper therefrom — HOFFMANN 'S cheque — and tears it through several times . Then he drops the scraps slowly into the coal-bin . Hereupon he takes his hat and cane and turns to go . At this moment HELEN appears on the threshold of the conservatory .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Softly .Mr. Loth !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Quivers and turns .Ah , it is you .— Well , then I can at least say farewell to you .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: In spite of herself .Did you feel the need of doing that ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes ! I did feel it , indeed . Probably , if you were in there , you heard what has taken place here , and — in that case ....

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I heard everything .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: In that case it wo n't astonish you to see me this house with so little ceremony .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No-o ! I do understand —! But I should like you to feel less harshly toward my brother-in-law . He always repents very quickly . I have often ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Quite possibly . But for that very reason what he has said just now probably expresses his true opinion of me .— In fact , it is undoubtedly his real opinion .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do you seriously believe that ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Oh , yes , quite seriously . And so ....He walks toward her and takes her hand .I hope that life will be kind to you .He turns but at once stops again .I do n't know ...! or rather :—he looks calmly and directly into HELEN 'S face— I do know , I know — at this moment the knowledge becomes clear — that it is not so easy for me to go away from here ... and ... yes ... and ... well , yes ...!

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But if I begged you — begged you truly — from my heart ... to stay a little longer —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So you do not share Hoffmann 's opinion ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No !— and that — that is just what I wanted to be sure — quite sure to tell you , before ... before — you — went .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Grasps her hand once more .It helps me much to hear you say that .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Struggling with herself . Her excitement mounts rapidly and to the point of unconsciousness . She stammers out half-chokingly .And more , oh , more I wanted to ... to tell you ... that I esteem and ... and ... honour you as ... I 've done no ... man before ... that I trust ... you ... that I 'm ready to ... to prove that ... that I feel toward you ...

div.stage: She sinks , swooning into his arms .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Helen !

lg.l: THE FOURTH ACT
The farmyard , as in the second act . Time : a quarter of an hour after
HELEN 'S avowal .

sp.speaker: MARIE and GOLISCH the cowherd drag a wooden chest down the stairs
sp.p: that lead to the loft . LOTH comes from the house . He is dressed for travelling and goes slowly and thoughtfully diagonally across the yard . Before he turns into the path that leads to the inn , he comes upon HOFFMANN , who is hurrying toward him through the gateway .

lg.stage: In top hat and kid gloves .
lg.l: Do n't be angry with me .
lg.stage: He obstructs LOTH 'S way and grasps both of his hands .
lg.l: I take it all back herewith
... Mention any reparation you demand ... I am ready to give you any !...
I 'm most truly , most sincerely sorry .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That helps neither of us very much .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oh , if you would just ... Look here , now ...! A man can n't well do more than that . I assure you that my conscience gave me no rest ! I turned back just before reaching Jauer .... That should convince you of the seriousness of my feeling . Where were you going ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To the inn — for the moment .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oh , that 's an affront you simply can n't offer me ... no , you must n't — simply , I believe that I did hurt you badly , of course . And probably it 's not the kind of thing that can be wiped out with just a few words . Only do n't rob me of any chance ... of every possibility to prove to you ... D'you hear ? Now turn back and stay at least — at least until to-morrow . Or till ... till I come back . I want to talk it all over with you at leisure . You can n't refuse me that favour .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: If you set so much store by it all ....

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: A great deal !... on my honour !... I care immensely . So come , come ! Do n't run away !He leads LOTH , who offers no further resistance , back into the house .The dismissed maid and the boy have , in the meantime , placed the chest on a wheelbarrow and GOLISCH has put on the shoulder strap .

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: Slipping a coin into GOLISCH 'S hand .There 's somethin ’ fer you .

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: Refusing it .Keep yer penny .

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: Aw ! Ye donkey !

sp.speaker: GOLISCH
sp.p: Well , I do n't care .

div.stage: He takes the coin and puts it into his leathern purse .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Appears at one of the windows of the house and calls out :Marie .

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: What d'ye want now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Appearing almost immediately at the door of the house .The madame 's willing to keep you , if you promise ....

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: A stinkin ’ lot I 'll promise her . Go on , Golisch !

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Approaching .The madame is willing to increase your wages , if you ....Whispering suddenly .What d'ye care , girl ! She just gits kinder rough now an ’ then .

sp.speaker: MARIE
sp.p: Furiously .She c'n keep her dirty money to herself !—Tearfully .I 'd rather starve !She follows GOLISCH , who has preceded her with the wheelbarrow .Naw , just to think of it !— It 's enough to make you ....She disappears , as does MRS. SPILLER .Through the great gate comes BAER called HOPPING BAER . He is a lank fellow with a vulture 's neck and goitre . His feet and head are bare . His breeches , badly ravelled at the bottom , scarcely reach below the knee . The top of his head is bald . Such hair as he has , brown , dusty , and clotted , hangs down over his shoulders . His gait is ostrich-like . By a cord he draws behind him a child 's toy waggon full of sand . His face is beardless . His whole appearance shows him to be a god-forsaken peasant lad in the twenties .

sp.speaker: BAER
sp.p: With a strangely bleating voice .Sa — a — and ! Sa — a — and ! He crosses the yard and disappears between the house and the stables . HOFFMANN and HELEN come from the house . HELEN is pale and carries an empty glass in her hand .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: To HELEN .Entertain him a bit ! You understand ? Do n't let him go . I should hate to have him .— Injured vanity like that !... Good-bye !... Oh , maybe I ought n't to go at all ? How is Martha doing ?— I 've got a queer kind of feeling as if pretty soon .... Nonsense !— Good-bye ! ... awful hurry !...Calls out .Franz ! Give the horses their heads !

div.stage: Leaves rapidly through the main gate .

sp.speaker: HELEN goes to the pump , fills her glass and empties it at one
sp.p: draught . She empties half of another glass . She then sets the glass on the pump and then strolls slowly , looking backward from time to time , through the gate-may . BAER emerges from between the house and the stables and stops with his waggon before the house door , where MIELE takes some sand from him . In the meantime KAHL has become visible at the right , beyond the dividing fence . He is in conversation with MRS. SPILLER , who is on the hither side of the fence and therefore close to the entrance of the yard . As the conversation proceeds , both walk slowly along the fence .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Mildly agonised .Ah yes — m — Mr. Kahl ! I have — m — many a time thought of — m — you when ... when our — m — dear Miss Helen ... She is so to — m — speak betrothed to you and so — m — ah ! I — m — must say ... in my time ...!

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Mounts a rustic bench under the oak-tree and fastens a bird trap to the lowest branch .When is th-that b-beast of a doctor goin ’ to git out o ’ here ? Ha ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Ah , Mr. Kahl ! I do n't — m — think so very soon .— Ah , Mr. Kahl , I — m — have , so to speak , come — m — down in the world , but I — m — know — m — what refinement is . In this respect , Mr. Kahl , I — must say — dear Miss Helen is n't — m — acting quite right toward you . No — m — in that respect , so to speak — m — I 've never had anything with which to — m — reproach myself — m — my conscience , dear Mr. Kahl , is as pure in that — m — respect — so to speak , as new-fallen snow .

sp.speaker: BAER has finished the sale of his sand and , at this moment , passes
sp.p: by KAHL in order to leave the yard .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Discovers BAER and calls out .Heres hopping Baer ! Hop a bit !

sp.speaker: BAER takes a , huge leap
sp.p: KAHL

div.stage: Bellowing with laughter . ] Here , hopping Baer ! Hop again !

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Well — m — Mr. Kahl , what I want to say is — m — I have the best — m — intentions toward you . You ought to observe very — m — carefully . Something — m — is going on between our young lady and — m —

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: If I could j-jist git my d-dogs on that son of a —... Jist once !

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Mysteriously .And I 'm afraid you — m — do n't know what kind of an individual that — m — is . Oh , I am so — m — truly sorry for our dear young lady . The wife of the bailiff — she has it straight from the office , I think . He is said to be a — m — really dangerous person . The woman said her husband had — m — orders , just think ! actually — m — to keep his eye on him .

sp.speaker: LOTH comes from the house and looks about
sp.p: MRS. SPILLER You see , now he is going — m — after our young lady . Oh , it 's too sad — m — for anything .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Aw ! You wait an ’ see !

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER goes to the door of the house . In passing LOTH she
sp.p: makes a deep bow . Then she disappears into the house .

sp.speaker: LOTH disappears slowly through the gateway . The coachman 's wife , an
sp.p: emaciated , worried , starved woman , emerges from between the house and the stables . She carries a large pot hidden under her apron and slinks off toward the cow-shed , looking about fearfully at every moment . She disappears into the door of the stable . The two MAIDS , each before her a wheel-barrow laden with clover , enter by the gate . BEIPST , his pipe in his mouth and his scythe across his shoulder , follows them , LIESE has wheeled her barrow in front of the left , AUGUSTE hers in front of the right door of the barn , and both begin to carry great armfuls of clover into the building .

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: Coming back out of the stable .Guste ! D'ye know , Marie is gone .

sp.speaker: AUGUSTE
sp.p: Aw , don ’ tell me !

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: Go in there'n ask the coachman 's wife . She 's gittin ’ her a drop o ’ milk .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Hangs up his scythe on the wall .Ye 'd better not let that Spiller creature get wind o ’ it .

sp.speaker: AUGUSTE
sp.p: Oh , Lord , no ! Who 'd think o ’ it !

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: A poor woman like that with eight —

sp.speaker: AUGUSTE
sp.p: Eight little brats . They wants to be fed !

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: An ’ they would n't give her a drop o ’ milk even . It 's low , that 's what I calls it .

sp.speaker: AUGUSTE
sp.p: Where is she milkin ’ ?

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: Way back there .

lg.stage: Fills his pipe . Holding his tobacco-pouch with his teeth he mumbles .
lg.l: Ye say Marie 's gone ?

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: Yes , it 's true an ’ certain . The parson 's hired man slept with her .

sp.speaker: BEIPST
sp.p: Replacing the tobacco-pouch in his pocket .Everybody feels that way sometimes — even a woman .He lights his pipe and disappears through the gateway . In going :I 'm goin ’ fer a bit o ’ breakfast .

sp.speaker: THE COACHMAN 'S WIFE
sp.p: Hiding the pot full of milk carefully under her apron , sticks her head out of the stable door .Anybody in sight ?

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: Ye c'n come if ye 'll hurry . There ai n't nobody . Come ! Hurry !

sp.speaker: THE COACHMAN 'S WIFE
sp.p: Passing by the maids .It 's fer the nursin ’ baby .

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: Calling out after her .Hurry ! Some one 's comin ’ .

sp.speaker: THE COACHMAN 'S WIFE disappears between the house and the stable
sp.p: AUGUSTE It 's only the young Miss . The maids now finish unloading their wheelbarrows and then thrust them under the doorway . They both go into the cow-shed .

sp.speaker: HELEN and LOTH enter by the gate

lg.l: LOTH
A disgusting fellow — this Kahl — an insolent sneak .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I think in the arbour in front —They pass through the small gate into the little garden by the house and into the arbour .It 's my favourite place , I 'm less disturbed there than anywhere if , sometimes , I want to read something .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It 's a pretty place .— Really .Both sit down in the arbour , consciously keeping at some distance from one another . An interval of silence . Then LOTH .You have very beautiful and abundant hair .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , my brother-in-law says so too . He thought he had scarcely seen anyone with so much — not even in the city ... The braid at the top is as thick as my wrist ... When I let it down , it reaches to my knees . Feel it . It 's like silk , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It is like silk .

div.stage: A tremour passes through him . He bends down and kisses her hair .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Frightened .Ah , do n't . If ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Helen ! Were you in earnest a while ago ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , I am so ashamed — so deeply ashamed . What have I done ? Why , I 've thrown myself at you . That 's what I 've done . I wonder what you take me for ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Draws nearer to her and takes her hand in his .Ah , you must n't let that trouble you .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Sighing .Oh , if Sister Schmittgen knew of that — I dare not imagine it .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Who is Sister Schmittgen ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: One of my teachers at boarding-school .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How can you worry about Sister Schmittgen !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: She was very good .

div.stage: Laughing heartily to herself suddenly .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Why do you laugh all at once ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Half between respect and jest .Oh , when she stood in the choir and sang — she had only one long tooth left — then she was supposed to sing : “ Trouble yourselves not , my people ! ” — and it always sounded like : “ ‘ Rouble , ‘ rouble yourselves not , my people ! ” It was too funny . And we always had to laugh so ... when it sounded through the chapel : “ ‘ Rouble , ‘ rouble ! ”She laughs more and more heartily . LOTH becomes infected by her mirth . She seems so sweet to him at this moment that he wants to take the opportunity to put his arms about her . HELEN wards him off .An , no ! no ! Just think ! I threw myself at you !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Oh , do n't say such things !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But it is n't my fault ; you have only yourself to blame for it . Why do you demand ...

sp.speaker: LOTH puts his arm about her once more and draws her closer to him
sp.p: At first she resists a little , then she yields and gazes , with frank blessedness , into the joyous face of LOTH which bends above her . Involuntarily , in the awkwardness of her very timidity , she kisses his mouth . Both grow red ; then LOTH returns her kiss . His caress is long and heartfelt . A giving and taking of kisses — silent and eloquent at once — is , for a time , all that passes between them . LOTH is the first to speak .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Nellie , dearest ! Nellie is your name , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Kisses him .Call me something else ... call me what you like best ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Dearest !... The exchange of kisses and of mutual contemplation is repeated .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Held tight in LOTH 'S arms , resting her head on his shoulder , looking up at him with dim , happy eyes , whispers ecstatically .Oh , how beautiful ! How beautiful !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To die with you — thus ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Passionately .To live !...She disengages herself from his embrace .Why die now ?... now ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yon must not misunderstand me . Always , in happy moments , it has come over me with a sense of intoxication — the consciousness of the fact that it is in our power , in my power , to embrace — you understand ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: To embrace death , if you desired it ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Quite devoid of sentimentality .Yes ! And the thought of death has nothing horrible in it for me . On the contrary , it seems like the thought of a friend . One calls and knows surely that death will come . And so one can rise above so many , many things — above one 's past , above one 's future fate ...Looking at HELEN 'S hand .What a lovely hand you have .

div.stage: He caresses it .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Ah , yes !— so !...

div.stage: She nestles anew in his arms .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No , do you know , I have n't really lived — until now !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do you think I have ?... And I feel faint — faint with happiness . Dear God , how suddenly it all came ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes , it came all at once ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Listen , I feel this way : all the days of my life are like one day ; but yesterday and to-day are like a year — a whole year !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Did n't I come till yesterday ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Of course not ! Naturally ! That 's just it !... Oh , and you do n't even know it !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And surely it seems to me ...

lg.l: Does n't it ? Like a whole , long year ! Does n't it ?
lg.stage: Half jumping up .
lg.l: Wait ...! Do n't you hear ...
lg.stage: They move away from each other .
lg.l: Oh , but
I do n't care one bit ! I am so full of courage now .

div.stage: She remains seated and invites LOTH with her eyes to move nearer , which he does .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: In LOTH 'S arms .Dear , what are we going to do first ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Your step-mother , I suppose , would send me packing .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , my step-mother ... that wo n't matter ... it does n't even concern her ! I do as I please ! I have my mother 's fortune , you must know .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Did you think on that account ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I am of age ; father will have to give me my share .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You are not , then , on good terms with everyone here ?— Where has your father gone to ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Gone ? You have ?... Oh , you have n't seen my father yet ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No ; Hoffmann told me ....

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Surely , you saw him once .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Not that I know of . Where , dearest ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I ....She bursts into tears .No , I can n't . I can n't tell you ... it 's too , too fearful !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So fearful ? But , Helen , is anything wrong with your father ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , do n't ask me ! Not now , at least ! Some time ...!

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I will not urge you to tell me anything , dear , that you do n't voluntarily speak of . And , look , as far as the money is concerned ... if the worst came ... though I do n't exactly earn superfluous cash with my articles — still , in the end , we could both manage to exist on it .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And I would n't be idle either , would I ? But the other way is better . My inheritance Is more than enough .— And there 's your life work ... no , you 're not to give that up under any circumstances ... now less than ever ...! Now you 're to have your real chance to pursue it !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Kissing her tenderly .Dearest , best ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , do you truly care ...? Truly ? Truly ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Truly .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: You must say truly a hundred times .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Truly and truly and truthfully .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , now , you 're not playing fair !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I am , though . That truthfully is equal to a hundred trulys .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh ? Is that the custom in Berlin ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No , but it is here in Witzdorf .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh ! But now , look at my little finger and do n't laugh .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Gladly .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Did you ever love any one before your first betrothed ? Oh , now you are laughing !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I will tell you in all seriousness , dearest ; indeed , I think it is my duty .... In the course of my life a considerable number of women ....

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: With a quick and violent start , pressing her hand over his mouth .For the love of .... Tell me that some day , later , when we are old , when the years have passed , when I shall say to you : “ now ! ” Do you hear ! Not before !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Just as you will .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Rather tell me something sweet now !... Listen : repeat after me :

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: I have loved —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I have loved —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Always you only —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Always you only —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: All the days of my life —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: All the days of my life —

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And will love you only as long as I live —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And will love you only as long as I live — and that is true so surely as I am an honest man .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Joyfully .I did n't add that !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But I did .

div.stage: They kiss each other .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Hums very softly .“ Thou in my heart art lying ... ”

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But now you must confess too .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Anything you like .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Confess now ! Am I the first ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Who ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Laughing out in the fullness of her joy .Willy Kahl !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Laughing .Who else ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , no , there 's no one else really . You must believe me ... Truly there was n't . Why should I tell you a falsehood ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So there was someone else ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Passionately .Oh , please , please , please , do n't ask me now .

div.stage: She hides her face in her hands and weeps apparently without any reason .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But ... but Nellie ! I 'm not insistent ; I do n't want to ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Later ... I 'll tell you later ... not now !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: As I said before , dearest .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: There was some one — I want you to know — whom I ... because ... because among wicked people he seemed the least wicked . Oh , it is so different now .Weeping against LOTH 'S neck : stormily .Ah , if I only did n't have to leave you at all any more ! Oh , if I could only go away with you right here on the spot !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I suppose you have a very unhappy time in the house here ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , dear !— It 's just frightful — the things that happen here . It 's a life like — that ... like that of the beasts of the field — Oh , I would have died without you . I shudder to think of it !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I believe it would calm you , dearest , if you would tell me everything quite openly .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Yes , to be sure . But I do n't think I can bear to . Not now , at least , not yet . And I 'm really afraid to .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You were at boarding-school , were n't you ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: My mother decided that I be sent — on her death-bed .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Was your sister there with you ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No , she was always at home ... And so when , four years ago , I came back from school , I found a father — who ... a step-mother — who ... a sister ... guess , can n't you guess what I mean !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I suppose your step-mother is quarrelsome ? Perhaps jealous ? unloving ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: My father ...?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , in all probability he dances to her music . Perhaps she tyrannises over him ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , if it were nothing else ?... No ! It is too frightful !— You can n't possibly guess that that ... my father ... that it was my father whom you ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Do n't weep , Nellie !... Look , you almost make me feel as though I ought to insist that you tell ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: No , no , it is n't possible . I have n't the strength !— not yet !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But you 're wearing yourself out this way !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But I 'm so ashamed , so boundlessly ashamed ! Why , you will drive me from you in horror ...! It 's beyond anything ...! It 's loathsome !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Nellie , dear , you do n't know me if you can think such things of me ! Repulse you ! Drive you from me ! Do I seem such a brute to you ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: My brother-in-law said that you would quite calmly ... But no , no , you would n't ? Would you ?— You would n't just ruthlessly walk over me ? Oh ! you wo n't ! You must n't ! I do n't know what would become of me !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But , dear , it 's senseless to talk so . There 's no earthly reason !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But if there were a reason , it might happen !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: No ! Not at all !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But if you could think of a reason ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: There are reasons , to be sure ; but they 're not in question .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And what kind of reasons ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I would have to be ruthless only toward some one who would make me betray my own most ideal self .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And surely , I would n't want to do that ! And yet I can n't rid myself of the feeling —

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What feeling , dearest ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Perhaps it 's just because I 'm nothing but a silly girl . There 's so little to me — Why , I do n't even know what it is — to have principles ! Is n't that frightful ? But I just simply love you so ! And you 're so good , and so great , and so very wise ! I 'm so afraid that you might , sometime , discover — when I say something foolish , or do something — that it 's all a mistake , that I 'm much too silly for you ... I 'm really as worthless and as silly as I can be !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What shall I say to all that ? You 're everything to me , just everything in the whole world . I can n't say more !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: And I 'm very strong and healthy , too ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Tell me , are your parents in good health ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Indeed they are . That is , mother died in childbirth . But father is still well ; in fact he must have a very strong constitution . But ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , you see . Everything is ...

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But if my parents were not strong —;

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Kissing HELEN .But then , they are , dear .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: But suppose they were not —?

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE pushes open a window in the house and calls out into the
sp.p: yard .

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Hey ! Girls ! Gi — rls !

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: From within the cow-shed .Yes , Missis ?

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Run to Mueller 's ! It 's startin ’ !

sp.speaker: LIESE
sp.p: What ! To the midwife , ye mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: Are ye standin ’ on your ear ?

div.stage: She slams the window .

sp.speaker: LIESE runs out of the cow-shed with a little shawl over her head and
sp.p: then out of the yard .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Calls .Miss Helen ! Oh , Miss Helen !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What do you suppose is —?

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Approaching the arbour .Miss Helen !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , I know . It 's my sister who — You must go , ‘ round that way !

div.stage: LOTH withdraws rapidly by the right foreground . HELEN steps out from the arbour .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Oh , Miss , there you are at last !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Ah — m — your sister .

div.stage: She whispers into HELEN 'S ear .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: My brother-in-law ordered that the doctor be sent for at any sign of —

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: Oh — m — dear Miss Helen — m — she does n't really want a doctor . These doctors — m — oh , these doctors — m — with God 's help ...

lg.l: HELEN
Miele , go at once for Dr. Schimmelpfennig !

sp.speaker: MRS. KRAUSE
sp.p: From the window , arrogantly .Miele ! You come up here !

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: In a tone of command .Miele , you go for the doctor !MIELE withdraws into the house .Well , then I must go myself ...

div.stage: She goes into the house and comes back out at once carrying her straw hat .

sp.speaker: MRS. SPILLER
sp.p: It 'll go wrong — m — If you call the doctor , dear Miss Helen ,— m — it will surely go wrong !

sp.speaker: HELEN passes her by . MRS. SPILLER withdraws into the house , shaking
sp.p: her head . As HELEN turns at the driveway KAHL is standing at the boundary fence .

sp.speaker: KAHL
sp.p: Calls out to HELEN .What 's the matter over at your place ?

sp.speaker: HELEN does not stop , nor does she deign to notice or answer KAHL
sp.p: KAHL

div.stage: Laughing . ] I guess ye got a pig killin ’ ?
CURTAIN

sp.speaker: THE FIFTH ACT
sp.p: The same room , as in the first act . Time : toward two o'clock in the morning . The room is in complete darkness . Through the open middle door light penetrates into it from the illuminated hall . The light also falls clearly upon the wooden stairway that leads to the upper floor . The conversation in this act — with very few exceptions — is carried on in a muffled tone .

sp.speaker: EDWARD enters through the middle door , carrying a light . He lights
sp.p: the hanging lampit is a gas lampover the corner table . While he is thus employed , LOTH also enters by the middle door .

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: O Lord ! Such goin 's on ! It 'd take a monster to be able to close a eye here !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I did n't even try to sleep . I have been writing .

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: You do n't say !He succeeds in lighting the lamp .There ! Well , sure , I guess it 's hard enough , too ... Maybe you 'd like to have paper and ink , sir ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Perhaps that would be ... If you would be so good , then , Mr. Edward ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Placing pen and ink on the table .I 'm always thinkin ’ that any honest fellow has got to get all the work there 's in every bone for every dirty penny . You can n't even get your rest o ’ nights .More and more confidentially .But this crew here ! They do n't do one thing — a lazy , worthless crew , a —... I suppose , sir , that you 've got to be at it early and late too , like all honest folks , for your bit o ’ bread .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I wish I did n't have to .

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Me too , you betcher .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I suppose Miss Helen is with her sister ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Yes , sir , an ’ , honestly , she 's a good girl , she is ; has n't budged since it started .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Looking at his watch .The pains began at eleven o'clock in the morning . So they 've already lasted fifteen hours — fifteen long hours —!

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Lord , yes !— And that 's what they calls the weaker sex . But she 's just barely gaspin ’ .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And is Mr. Hoffmann upstairs , too ?

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: Yes , an ’ I can tell you , he 's goin ’ on like a woman .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , I suppose it is n't very easy to have to watch that .

sp.speaker: EDWARD
sp.p: You 're right there , indeed . Dr. Schimmelpfennig came just now . There 's a man for you : rough as rough can be — but sugar ai n't nothing to his real feelings . But just tell me what 's become of little , old Berlin in all this ...

div.stage: He interrupts himself with a Gee-rusa-lem ! as HOFFMANN and the DOCTOR are seen coming down the stairs .

lg.l: HOFFMANN
Surely — you will stay with us from now on .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Yes , I suppose I will stay now .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: That 's a very , very great consolation to me .— Will you have a glass of wine ? Surely you 'll drink a glass of wine , Doctor ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: If you want to do something for me , have a cup of coffee prepared .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: With pleasure . Edward ! Coffee for the doctor !EDWARD withdraws .Are you ...? Are you satisfied with the way things are going ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: So long as your wife 's strength keeps up there is , at all events , no direct danger . But why did n't you call in the young midwife ? I remember having recommended her to you .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: My mother-in-law ...! What is one to do ? And , to be frank with you , my wife has no confidence in the young woman either .

lg.l: But your ladies place confidence in this old fossil ? Well , I hope they 'll
... And I suppose you would like to go back upstairs ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Yes , honestly , I can n't get much rest down here .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: It would be better undoubtedly if you were to go somewhere — out of the house .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: With the best will in the world , I —.LOTH arises from the sofa in the dim foreground and approaches the two .Hallo , Loth , there you are too !

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Surprised in the extreme .Well , I 'll be —!

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I heard that you were here . I would have looked you up to-morrow without fail .

div.stage: They shake hands cordially . HOFFMANN takes the opportunity to mash down a glass of brandy at the side-board and then to creep back upstairs on tiptoe .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: So you 've evidently forgotten — ha , ha , ha — that ridiculous old affair ?

div.stage: He lays aside his hat and cane .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Long ago , Schimmel !

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Well , so have I , as you can well imagine .They shake hands once more .I 've had so few pleasant surprises in this hole , that this one seems positively queer to me . And it is strange that we should meet just here . It is .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And you faded clear out of sight . Otherwise I 'd have routed you out long ago .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Oh , I just dived below the surface like a seal . Made deep-sea investigations . In about a year and a half I hope to emerge once more . A man must be financially independent — do you know that ?— In order to achieve anything useful .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So you , too , are making money here ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Naturally and as much as possible . What else is there to do here ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You might have let some one hear from you !

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I beg your pardon . But if I had been heard from , I would have heard from you fellows — and I absolutely did n't want to hear . Nothingnothing . That would simply have kept me from exploiting my diggings here . The two men walk slowly up and down the room .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I see . But then you must n't be surprised to hear that ... well , they all , without an exception , really gave you up as hopeless .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: That 's like them — the scamps ! They 'll be made to take notice .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Schimmel — otherwise the “ rough husk ” !

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I wish you had had to live here among the farmers for six years . Hellhounds — every one of them .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I can imagine that .— But how in the world did you get to Witzdorf ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: The way such things do happen ! You remember I had to skin out from Jena that time .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Was that before my crash ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Yes , a short time after we 'd given up living together . So I took up medicine at Zuerich , first simply so as to have something against a time of need . But then the thing began to interest me , and now I 'm a doctor , heart and soul .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And about this place . How did you get here ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Very simply . When I got through I said to myself : first of all you 've got to have a sufficient pile . I thought of America , South and North America , of Africa , Australia and the isles of the sea ... In the end it occurred to me , however , that my escapade had become outlawed ; and so I made up my mind to creep back into the old trap .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: And how about your Swiss examinations ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Why , I simply had to go through the whole rigmarole once more .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Man ! You passed the state medical examination twice over ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Yes , luckily I then discovered this fat pasture here .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Your toughness is certainly enviable .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: All very well , unless one collapses suddenly .— Well , it would n't matter so greatly after all .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Have you a very large practice ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Oh , yes . Occasionally I do n't get to bed till five o'clock in the morning . And at seven my consultation hour begins again .

sp.speaker: EDWARD comes in , bringing coffee
sp.p: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG

div.stage: Sitting down at the table , to EDWARD . ] Thank you , Edward .— [ To LOTH . ] — The way I swill coffee is — uncanny .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You 'd better give that up .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: What is one to do ?He takes small swallows .As I told you awhile ago — another year ; then — all this stops . At least , I hope so .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Do n't you intend to practice after that at all ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Do n't think so . No — no more .He pushes back the tray with the dishes and wipes his mouth .By the way , let 's see your hand .LOTH holds up both his hands for inspection .I see . You 've taken no wife to your bosom yet . Have n't found one , I suppose . I remember you always wanted primaeval vigour in the woman of your choice on account of the soundness of the strain . And you 're quite right , too . If one takes a risk , it ought to be a good one . Or maybe you 've become less stringent in that respect .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Not a bit ! You may take your oath .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I wish the farmers around here had such notions . But they 're in a wretched condition — degeneration along the whole line ...He has half taken his cigar case from his inner pocket but lets it slip back and arises as a sound penetrates through the door which is only ajar .Wait a moment !He goes on tiptoe to the door leading to the hall and listens . A door is heard to open and close , and for several moments the moans of the woman in labour are audible . The DOCTOR , turning to LOTH , says softly .Excuse me !And goes out .For several seconds , while the slamming of doors is heard and the sound of people running up and down the stairs , LOTH paces the room . Then he sits down in the arm-chair in the foreground , right . HELEN slips in and throws her arms about LOTH , who has not observed her coming from , behind .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Looking around and embracing her in turn .Nellie !He drams her down upon his knee in spite of her gentle resistance . HELEN weeps under his kisses .Do n't cry , Nellie ! Why are you crying so ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Why ? Oh , if I knew !... I keep thinking that I wo n't find you here . Just now I had such a fright ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But why ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Because I heard you go out of your room — Oh , and my sister — we poor , poor women !— oh , she 's suffering too much !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: The pain is soon forgotten and there is no danger of death .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Oh , but she is praying so to die . She wails and wails : Do let me die !... The doctor !

div.stage: She jumps up and slips into the conservatory .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: On entering .I do really wish now that that little woman upstairs would hurry a bit !He sits down beside the table , takes out his cigar case again , extracts a cigar from it and lays the latter down on the table .You 'll come over to my house afterward , wo n't you ? I have a necessary evil with two horses standing out there in which we can drive straight over .He taps his cigar against the edge of the table .Oh , the holy state of matrimony ! O Lord !Striking a match .So you 're still pure , free , pious and merry ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You might better have waited a few more days with that question .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: His cigar is lit now .Oho ! I see !—laughing— so you 've caught on to my tricks at last !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Are you still so frightfully pessimistic in regard to women ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Frightfully !Watching the drifting smoke of his cigar .In other years I was a pessimist , so to speak , by presentiment ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Have you had very special experiences in the meantime ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: That 's just it . My shingle reads : Specialist for Diseases of Women .— The practice of medicine , I assure you , makes a man terribly wise ... terribly ... sane ...; it 's a specific against all kinds of delusions .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Laughing .Well , then we can fall back into our old tone at once . I want you to know ... I have n't caught on to your tricks at all . Less than ever now ... But I am to understand , I suppose , that you 've exchanged your old hobby ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Hobby ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: The question of woman was in those days in a certain way your pet subject .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I see ! And why should I have exchanged it ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: If you think even worse of women than ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Somewhat aroused . He gets up and walks to and fro while he is speaking .I do n't think evil of women .— Not a bit !— I think evil only of marrying ... of marriage ... of marriage and — at most , of men ... The woman question , you think , has ceased to interest me ? What do you suppose I 've worked here for , during six years , like a cart horse ? Surely in order to devote at last all the power that is in me to the solution of that question . Did n't you know that from the beginning ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How do you suppose I could have known it ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Well , as I said ... and I 've already gathered a lot of very significant material that will be of some service to me ! Sh ! I 've got the bad habit of raising my voice .He falls silent , listens , goes to the door and comes back .But what took you among these gold farmers ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I would like to study the local conditions .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: In a repressed tone .What a notion !Still more softly .I can give you plenty of material there too .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: To be sure . You must be thoroughly informed as to the conditions here . How do things look among the families around here ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Miserable ! There 's nothing but drunkenness , gluttony , inbreeding and , in consequence ,— degeneration along the whole line .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: With exceptions , surely ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Hardly .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Disquieted .Did n't the temptation ever come to you to ... to marry a daughter of one of these Witzdorf gold farmers ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: The devil ! Man , what do you take me for ? You might as well ask whether I ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Very pale .But why ... why ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Because ... Anything wrong with you ?

div.stage: He regards LOTH steadily for several moments .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Certainly not . What should be wrong ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Has suddenly become very thoughtful . He stops in his walking suddenly and whistles softly , glances at LOTH and then mutters to himself .That 's bad !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You act very strangely all of a sudden .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Sh !

div.stage: He listens carefully and then leaves , the room quickly by the middle door .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Comes at the end of several seconds from the middle door . She cries out .Alfred !— Alfred !... You 're here . Oh , thank God !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well , dear , did you suppose I had run away ?

div.stage: They embrace each other .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Bends back . With unmistakable terror in her face .Alfred !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What is it , dearest ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Nothing , nothing ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But there must be something .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: You seemed so cold ... Oh , I have such foolish fancies ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How are things going upstairs ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: The doctor is quarreling with the midwife .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Is n't it going to end soon ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: How do I know ? But when it ends , when it ends — then ....

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What then ?... Tell me , please , what were you going to say ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Then we ought soon to go away from here . At once ! Oh , right away !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: If you think that would really be best , Nellie —

lg.l: It is ! it is ! We must n't wait ! It 's the best thing — for you and for me .
If you do n't take me soon , you 'll just leave me quite , and then , and then
... It would just be all over with me .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How distrustful you are , Nellie .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Do n't say that , dearest . Anybody would trust you , would just have to trust you !... When I am your own , oh , then ... then , you surely would n't leave me .As if beside herself .I beseech you ! Do n't go away ! Only do n't leave me ! Do n't — go , Alfred ! If you go away without me , I would just have to die , just have to die !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: But you are strange !... And you say you 're not distrustful ! Or perhaps they 're worrying you , torturing you terribly here — more than ever ... At all events we 'll leave this very night . I am ready . And so , as soon as you are — we can go .

lg.stage: Falling around his neck with a cry of joyous gratitude .
lg.l: Dear — dearest !

div.stage: She kisses him madly and hurries out .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG comes in through the middle door and catches a
sp.p: glimpse of HELEN disappearing into the conservatory .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Who was that ?— Ah , yes !To himself .Poor thing !

div.stage: He sits down beside the table with a sigh , finds his old cigar , throws it aside , takes a new cigar from the case and starts to knock it gently against the edge of the table . Thoughtfully he looks away across it .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Watching him .That 's just the way you used to loosen every cigar before smoking it eight years ago .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: It 's possible —When he has lit and begun to smoke the cigar .Listen to me !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes ; what is it ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I take it that , so soon as the affair is over , you 'll come along with me .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Ca n't be done . I 'm sorry .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Once in a while , you know , one does feel like talking oneself out thoroughly .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I feel that need quite as much , as you do . But you can see from just that how utterly out of my power it is to go ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: But suppose I give you my emphatic and , in a way , solemn assurance that there is a specific , an extremely important matter that I 'd like — no , that I must discuss with you to-night , Loth !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Queer ! You do n't expect me to take that in deadly earnest . Surely not !— You 've waited to discuss that matter so many years and now it can n't wait one more day ? You know me — I 'm not pretending .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: So I am right ! Well , well ...

div.stage: He gets up and walks about .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What are you right about ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Standing still before LOTH and looking straight into his eyes .So there is really something between you and Helen Krause ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Who said —?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: How in the world did you fall in with this family ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How do you know that , Schimmel ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: It was n't so hard to guess .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Well then , for heaven 's sake , do n't say a word , because ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: So you 're quite regularly betrothed ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Call it that . At all events , we 're agreed .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: But what I want to know is : how did you fall in with this particular family ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Hoffmann 's an old college friend of mine . Then , too , he was a member — though only a corresponding one — of my colonisation society .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I heard about that business at Zuerich .— So he was associated with you . That explains the wretched half-and-half creature that he is .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That describes him , no doubt .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: He is n't even that , really .— But , look here , Loth ! Is that your honest intention ? I mean this thing with the Krause girl .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Of course it is ! Can you doubt it ? You do n't think me such a scoundrel —?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Very well ! Do n't exert yourself ! You 've probably changed in all this long time . And why not ? It need n't be entirely a disadvantage . A little bit of humour could n't harm you . I do n't see why one must look at all things in that damnably serious way .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I take things more seriously than ever .He gets up and walks up and down with SCHIMMELPFENNIG , always keeping slightly behind the latter .You can n't possibly know , and I can n't possibly explain to you , what this thing means to me .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Hm !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Man , you have no notion of the condition I 'm in . One does n't know it by simply longing for it . If one did , one would simply go mad with yearning .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Let the devil try to understand how you fellows come by this senseless yearning .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You 're not safe against an attack yourself yet .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I 'd like to see that !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: You talk as a blind man would of colour .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I would n't give a farthing for that bit of intoxication . Ridiculous ! And to build a life-long union on such a foundation . I 'd rather trust a heap of shifting sand .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Intoxication ! Pshaw ! To call it that is simply to show your utter blindness to it . Intoxication is fleeting . I 've had such spells , I admit . This happens to be something different .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Hm !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I 'm perfectly sober all through it . Do you imagine that I surround my darling with a kind of a — well , how shall I put it — a kind of an aureole ? Not In the least . She lias her faults ; she is n't remarkably beautiful , at least — well , she 's certainly not exactly homely either . Judging her quite objectively — of course it 's entirely a matter of taste — I have n't seen such a sweet girl before in my life . So when you talk of mere intoxication — nonsense ! I am as sober as possible . But , my friend , this is the remarkable thing : I simply can n't imagine myself without her any longer . It seems to me like an amalgam , as when two metals are so intimately welded together that you can n't say any longer , here 's the one , there 's the other . And it all seems so utterly inevitable . In short — maybe I 'm talking rot — or what I say may seem rot to you , but so much is certain : a man who does n't know that is a kind of cool-blooded fishy creature . That 's the kind of creature I was up till now , and that 's the kind of wretched thing you are still .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: That 's a very complete set of symptoms . Queer how you fellows always slide up to the very ears into the particular things that you 've long ago rejected theoretically — like yourself into marriage . As long as I 've known you , you 've struggled with this unhappy mania for marriage .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It 's instinct with me , sheer instinct . God knows , I can wriggle all I please — there it is .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: When all 's said and done one can fight down even an instinct .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Certainly , if there 's a good reason , why not ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Is there any good reason for marrying ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I should say there is . It has a purpose ; it has for me ! You do n't know how I 've succeeded in struggling along hitherto . I do n't want to grow sentimental . Perhaps I did n't feel it quite so keenly either ; perhaps I was n't so clearly conscious of it as I am now , that in all my endeavour I had taken on something desolate , something machine-like . No spirit , no fire , no life ! Heaven knows whether I had any faith left ! And all that has come back to me to-day — with such strange fullness , such primal energy , such joy ... Pshaw , what 's the use ... You do n't understand .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: The various things you fellows need to keep you going — faith , love , hope . I consider all that trash . The thing is simply this : humanity lies in its death throes and we 're merely trying to make the agony as bearable as we can by administering narcotics .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Is that your latest point of view ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: It 's five or six years old by this time and I see no reason to change it .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I congratulate you on it .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Thank you . A long pause ensues .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: After several disquieted and unsuccessful beginnings .The trouble is just this . I feel that I 'm responsible ... I absolutely owe you an elucidation . I do n't believe that you will be able to marry Helen Krause .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Frigidly .Oh , is that what you think ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Yes , that 's my opinion . There are obstacles present which just you would ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Look here ! Do n't for heaven 's sake have any scruples on that account . The conditions , as a matter of fact , are n't so complicated as all that . At bottom they 're really terribly simple .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Simply terrible , you 'd better say .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I was referring simply to the obstacles .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: So was I , very largely . But take it all in all , I can n't imagine that you really know the conditions as they are .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Please , Schimmel , express yourself more clearly .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: You must absolutely have dropped the chief demand which you used to make in regard to marriage , although you did give me to understand that you laid as much weight as ever on the propagation of a race sound in mind and body .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Dropped my demand ...? Dropped it ? But why should I ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I see . Then there 's nothing else left me but to ... Then you do n't know the conditions here . You do not know , for instance , that Hoffmann had a son who perished through alcoholism at the age of three .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Wha ... what d'you say ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I 'm sorry , Loth , but I 've got to tell you . You can do afterward as you please . But the thing was no joke . They were visiting here just as they are now . They sent for me — half an hour too late . The little fellow had bled to death long before I arrived .

sp.speaker: LOTH drinks in the DOCTOR 'S words with every evidence of profound
sp.p: and terrible emotion .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: The silly little chap grabbed for the vinegar bottle , thinking his beloved rum was in it . The bottle fell and the child tumbled on the broken glass . Down here , you see , the vena saphena , was completely severed .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Whose , whose child was that ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: The child of Hoffmann and of the same woman who again , up there ... And she drinks too , drinks to the point of unconsciousness , drinks whatever she can get hold of !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: So it 's not , it 's not inherited from Hoffmann ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Not at all . That 's the tragic aspect of the man ! He suffers under it as much as he is capable of suffering . To be sure , he knew that he was marrying into a family of dipsomaniacs . The old farmer simply spends his life in the tavern .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Then , to be sure — I understand many things — No , everything , rather ... everything !After a heavy silence .Then her life here , Helen 's life , is a ... how shall I express it ? I have no words for it ; it 's ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Utterly horrible . I can judge of that . And I understood from the beginning how you should cling to her . But , as I said ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: It 's enough . I understand ... But does n't ...? Could n't one perhaps persuade Hoffmann to do something ? She ought to be removed from all this foulness .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Hoffmann ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes , Hoffmann .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: You do n't know him . I do n't believe that he has ruined her already , but he has ruined her reputation even now .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Flaring up .If that 's true , I 'll murder ...! D'you really believe that ? Do you think Hoffmann capable ...?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: Of anything ! I think him capable of anything that might contribute to his own pleasure .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Then she is — the purest creature that ever breathed ...

sp.speaker: LOTH slowly takes up his hat and cane and hangs his mallet over his
sp.p: shoulder .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: What do you think of doing , Loth ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I must n't meet her ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: So you 're determined ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Determined to what ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: To break the connection .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: How is it possible for me to be other than determined ?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I may add , as a physician , that cases are known in which such inherited evils have been suppressed . And of course you would give your children a rational up-bringing .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Such cases may be known .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: And the chances are not so small but that ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: That kind of thing can n't help me , Schimmel . There are just three possibilities in this affair : Either I marry her and then ... no , that way out simply does n't exist . Or — the traditional bullet . Of course , that would mean rest , at least . But we have n't reached that point yet awhile ; can n't indulge in that luxury just yet . And so : live ! fight !— Farther , farther !His glance falls on the table and he observes the writing-materials that have been placed there by EDWARD . He sits down , hesitates and says :And yet ...?

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I promise you that I 'll represent the situation to her as clearly as possible .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes , yes ! You see — I can n't do differently .He writes , places his paper in an envelope and addresses it . Then he arises and shakes hands with SCHIMMELPFENNIG .For the rest — I depend on you .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: You 're coming over to my house , are n't , you ? Let my coachman drive you right over .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Look here ! Ought n't one to try , at least , to get her out of the power of this ... this person ? ... As things are she is sure to become his victim .

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: My dear , good fellow ! I 'm sorry for you . But shall I give you a bit of advice ? Do n't rob her of the — little that you still leave her .

lg.stage: With a deep sigh .
lg.l: Maybe you 're right — perhaps certainly .
Hasty steps are heard descending the stairs . In the next moment
HOFFMANN rushes in .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Doctor , I beg you , for heaven 's sake ... she is fainting ... the pains have stopped ... wo n't you at last ...

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: I 'm coming up .To LOTH significantly .We 'll see each other later . Mr. Hoffmann , I must request you ... any interference or disturbance might prove fatal ... I would much prefer to have you stay here .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: You ask a great deal , but ... well !

sp.speaker: DR. SCHIMMELPFENNIG
sp.p: No more than is right .

div.stage: He goes .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN remains behind
sp.p: HOFFMANN

div.stage: Observing LOTH . ] I 'm just trembling in every limb from the excitement . Tell me , are you leaving ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Now in the middle of the night ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I 'm only going as far as Schimmelpfennig 's .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Ah , yes . Well ... as things have shaped themselves , it 's of course no pleasure staying with us any longer ... So , good luck !

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: I thank you for your hospitality .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: And how about that plan of yours ?

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: What plan ?

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: I mean that essay of yours , that economic description of our district . I ought to say ... in fact , as a friend , I would beg of you as insistently as possible ...

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Do n't worry about that any more . I 'll be far away from here by to-morrow .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: That is really —

div.stage: He interrupts himself .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Kind of you , you were going to say .

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know . Well , in a certain respect , yes ! And anyhow you must forgive me ; I 'm so frightfully upset . Just count on me . Old friends are always the best ! Good-bye , good-bye .

div.stage: He leaves through the middle door .

sp.speaker: LOTH
sp.p: Before going to the door , turns around once more with a long glance as if to imprint the whole room on his memory . Then to himself :I suppose I can go now ...After a last glance he leaves .The room remains empty for some seconds . The sound of muffled voices and the noise of footfalls is heard . Then HOFFMANN appears . As soon as he has closed the door behind him , he takes out his note-book and runs over some account with exaggerated calm . He interrupts himself , listens , becomes restless again , advances to the door and listens there . Suddenly some one runs down the stair and HELEN bursts in .

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Still without .Brother !At the door .Brother !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: HELEN
sp.p: Be brave : still-born !

sp.speaker: HOFFMANN
sp.p: O my God !

div.stage: He rushes out .

sp.speaker: HELEN alone
sp.p: She looks about her and calls softly : Alfred ! Alfred ! As she receives no answer , she calls out again more quickly : Alfred ! Alfred ! She has hurried to the door of the conservatory through which she gazes anxiously . She goes into the conservatory , but reappears shortly . Alfred ! Her disquiet increases . She peers out of the window . Alfred ! She opens the window and mounts a chair that stands before it . At this moment there resounds clearly from the yard the shouting of the drunken farmer , her father , who is coming home from the inn , Hay-hee ! Ain ’ I a han'some feller ? Ain ’ I got a fine-lookin ’ wife ? Ain ’ I got a couple o ’ han'some gals ? Hay-hee ! HELEN utters a short cry and runs , like a hunted creature , toward the middle door . From there she discovers the letter which LOTH has left lying on thee table . She runs to it , tears it open , feverishly takes in the contents , of which she audibly utters separate words . “ Insuperable ! ” ... “ Never again . ” ... She lets the letter fall and sways .
