It 's over ! She steadies herself , holds her head with both hands and cries out in brief and piercing despair . It 's over ! She rushes out through the — middle door . The farmer 's voice without , drawing nearer . Hay-hee ! Ain ’ the farm mine ? Ain ’ I got a han'some wife ? Ain ’ I a han'some feller ? HELEN , still seeking LOTH half-madly , comes from the conservatory and meets EDWARD , who has come to fetch something from HOFFMANN 'S room . She addresses him : Edward ! He answers : Yes , Miss Krause . She continues : I 'd like to ... like to ... Dr. Loth ... EDWARD answers : Dr. Loth drove away in Dr. Schimmelpfennig 's carriage . He disappears into HOFFMANN 'S room . True ! HELEN cries out and holds herself erect with difficulty . In the next moment a desperate energy takes hold of her . She runs to the foreground and seizes the hunting knife with its belt which is fastened to the stag 's antlers above the sofa . She hides the weapon and stays quietly in the dark foreground until EDWARD , coming from HOFFMANN 'S room , has disappeared through the middle door . The farmer 's voice resounds more clearly from moment to moment . Hay-hee ! Ain ’ I a han'some feller ? At this sound , as at a signal , HELEN starts and runs , in her turn , into HOFFMANN 'S room . The main room is empty but one continues to hear the farmer 's voice : Ain ’ I got the finest teeth ? Ain ’ I got a fine farm ? MIELE comes through the middle door and looks searchingly about . She calls : Miss Helen ! Miss Helen ! Meanwhile the farmer 's voice : The money ‘ sh mi-ine ! Without further hesitation MIELE has disappeared into HOFFMANN 'S room , the door of which she leaves open . In the next moment she rushes out with every sign of insane terror . Screaming she spins around twice — thrice — screaming she flies through the middle door . Her uninterrupted screaming , softening as it recedes , is audible for several seconds . Last there is heard the opening and resonant slamming of the heavy house door , the tread of the farmer stumbling about in the hall , and his coarse , nasal , thick-tongued drunkard 's voice echoes through the room : Hay-hee ! Ain ’ I got a couple o ’ han'some gals ?

div.stage: CURTAIN

sp.speaker: THE WEAVERS
sp.p: I DEDICATE THIS DRAMA TO MY FATHER

sp.speaker: ROBERT HAUPTMANN
sp.p: You , dear father , know what feelings lead me to dedicate this work to you , and I am not called upon to analyse them here . Your stories of my grandfather , who in his young days sat at the loom , a poor weaver like those here depicted , contained the germ of my drama . Whether it possesses the vigour of life or is rotten at the core , it is the best , “ so poor a man as Hamlet is ” can offer .

sp.speaker: Your
sp.p: GERHART

lg.l: A WEAVER 'S WIFE .
A number of weavers , young and old , of both sexes .
The action passes in the Forties , at Kaschbach , Peterswaldau and
Langenbielau , in the Eulengebirge .

sp.speaker: THE FIRST ACT
sp.p: A large whitewashed room on the ground floor of DREISSIGER 'S house at Peterswaldau , where the weavers deliver their finished webs and the fustian is stored . To the left are uncurtained windows , in the back mall there is a glass door , and to the right another glass door , through which weavers , male and female , and children , are passing in and out . All three walls are lined with shelves for the storing of the fustian . Against the right wall stands a long bench , on which a number of weavers have already spread out their cloth . In the order of arrival each presents his piece to be examined by PFEIFER , DREISSIGER 'S manager , who stands , with compass and magnifying-glass , behind a large table , on which the web to be inspected is laid . When PFEIFER has satisfied himself , the weaver lays the fustian on the scale , and an office apprentice tests its weight . The same boy stores the accepted pieces on the shelves . PFEIFER calls out the payment due in each case to NEUMANN , the cashier , who is seated at a small table . It is a sultry day towards the end of May . The clock is on the stroke of twelve . Most of the waiting work-people have the air of standing before the bar of justice , in torturing expectation of a decision that means life or death to them . They are marked too by the anxious timidity characteristic of the receiver of charity , who has suffered many humiliations , and , conscious that he is barely tolerated , has acquired the habit of self-effacement . Add to this a rigid expression on every face that tells of constant , fruitless brooding . There is a general resemblance among the men . They have something about them of the dwarf , something of the schoolmaster . The majority are flat-breasted , short-minded , sallow , and poor looking — creatures of the loom , their knees bent with much silting . At a , first glance the women show fewer typical traits . They look over-driven , worried , reckless , whereas the men still make some show of a pitiful self-respect ; and their clothes are ragged , while the men 's are patched and mended . Some of the young girls are not without a certain charm , consisting in a wax-like pallor , a slender figure , and large , projecting , melancholy eyes .

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: Counting out money .Comes to one and seven-pence halfpenny .

lg.stage: About thirty , emaciated , takes up the money with trembling fingers .
lg.l: Thank you , sir .

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: Seeing that she does not move on .Well , something wrong this time , too ?

sp.speaker: WEAVER 'S WIFE
sp.p: Agitated , imploringly .Do you think I might have a few pence in advance , sir ? I need it that bad .

lg.l: And I need a few pounds . If it was only a question of needing it —!
lg.stage: Already occupied in counting out another weaver 's money , gruffly .
lg.l: It 's Mr. Dreissiger who settles about pay in advance .

sp.speaker: WEAVER 'S WIFE
sp.p: Could n't I speak to Mr. Dreissiger himself , then , sir ?

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Now manager , formerly weaver . The type is unmistakable , only he is well fed , well dressed , clean shaven ; also takes snuff copiously . He calls out roughly .Mr. Dreissiger would have enough to do if he had to attend to every trifle himself . That 's what we are here for .He measures , and then examines through the magnifying-glass .Mercy on us ! what a draught !Puts a thick muffler round his neck .Shut the door , whoever comes in .

sp.speaker: APPRENTICE
sp.p: Loudly to PFEIFER .You might as well talk to stocks and stones .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: That 's done !— Weigh !The weaver places his web on the scales .If you only understood your business a little better ! Full of lumps again .... I hardly need to look at the cloth to see them . Call yourself a weaver , and “ draw as long a bow ” as you 've done there !

sp.speaker: BECKER has entered . A young , exceptionally powerfully-built weaver ;
sp.p: offhand , almost bold in manner . PFEIFER , NEUMANN , and the APPRENTICE exchange looks of mutual understanding as he comes in .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Devil take it ! This is a sweatin ’ job , and no mistake .

sp.speaker: FIRST WEAVER
sp.p: In a low voice .This blazin ’ heat means rain .

div.stage: OLD BAUMERT forces his way in at the glass door on the right , through which the crowd of weavers can be seen , standing shoulder to shoulder , waiting their turn . The old man stumbles forward and lays his bundle on the bench , beside BECKER 'S . He sits down by it , and wipes the sweat from his face .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: A man has a right to a rest after that .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Rest 's better than money .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Yes , but we needs the money too . Good mornin ’ to you , Becker !

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Mornin ’ , father Baumert ! Goodness knows how long we 'll have to stand here again .

sp.speaker: FIRST WEAVER
sp.p: That do n't matter . What 's to hinder a weaver waitin ’ for an hour , or for a day ? What else is he there for ?

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Silence there ! We can n't hear our own voices .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: In a low voice .This is one of his bad days .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: To the weaver standing before him .How often have I told you that you must bring cleaner cloth ? What sort of mess is this ? Knots , and straw , and all kinds of dirt .

sp.speaker: REIMANN
sp.p: It 's for want of a new picker , sir .

sp.speaker: APPRENTICE
sp.p: Has weighed the piece .Short weight , too .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: I never saw such weavers . I hate to give out the yarn to them . It was another story in my day ! I 'd have caught it finely from my master for work like that . The business was carried on in different style then . A man had to know his trade — that 's the last thing that 's thought of nowadays . Reimann , one shilling .

sp.speaker: REIMANN
sp.p: But there 's always a pound allowed for waste .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: I 've no time . Next man !— What have you to show ?

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Lays his web on the table . While PFEIFER is examining it , he goes close up to him ; eagerly in a low tone .Beg pardon , Mr. Pfeifer , but I wanted to ask you , sir , if you would perhaps be so very kind an ’ do me the favour an ’ not take my advance money off this week 's pay .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Measuring and examining the texture ; jeeringly .Well ! What next , I wonder ? This looks very much as if half the weft had stuck to the bobbins again .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Continues .I 'll be sure to make it all right next week , sir . But this last week I 've had to put in two days ’ work on the estate . And my missus is ill in bed ....

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Giving the web to be weighed .Another piece of real slop-work .Already examining a new web .What a selvage ! Here it 's broad , there it 's narrow ; here it 's drawn in by the wefts goodness knows how tight , and there it 's torn out again by the temples . And hardly seventy threads weft to the inch . What 's come of the rest ? Do you call this honest work ? I never saw anything like it .

div.stage: HEIBER , repressing tears , stands humiliated and helpless .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: In a low voice to BAUMERT .To please that brute you 'd have to pay for extra yarn out o ’ your own pocket .

sp.speaker: WEAVER 'S WIFE
sp.p: Who has remained standing near the cashier 's table , from time to time looking round appealingly , takes courage and once more turns imploringly to the cashier .I do n't know what 's to come o ’ me , sir , if you wo n't give me a little advance this time ... O Lord , O Lord !

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Calls across .It 's no good whining , or dragging the Lord 's name into the matter . You 're not so anxious about Him at other times . You look after your husband and see that he 's not to be found so often lounging in the public-house . We can give no pay in advance . We have to account for every penny . It 's not our money . People that are industrious , and understand their work , and do it in the fear of God , never need their pay in advance . So now you know .

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: If a Bielau weaver got four times as much pay , he would squander it four times over and be in debt into the bargain .

sp.speaker: WEAVER 'S WIFE
sp.p: In a loud voice , as if appealing to the general sense of justice .No one can n't call me idle , but I 'm not fit now for what I once was . I 've twice had a miscarriage . And as to John , he 's but a poor creature . He 's been to the shepherd at Zerlau , but he could n't do him no good , and ... you can n't do more than you 've strength for .... We works as hard as ever we can . This many a week I 've been at it till far on into the night . An ’ we 'll keep our heads above water right enough if I can just get a bit o ’ strength into me . But you must have pity on us , Mr. Pfeifer , sir .Eagerly , coaxingly .You 'll please be so very kind as to let me have a few pence on the next job , sir ?

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Paying no attention .Fiedler , one and twopence .

sp.speaker: WEAVER 'S WIFE
sp.p: Only a few pence , to buy bread with . We can n't get no more credit . We 've a lot o ’ little ones .

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: Half aside to the APPRENTICE , in a serio-comic-tone .“ Every year brings a child to the linen-weaver 's wife , heigh-ho , heigh-ho , heigh . ”

sp.speaker: APPRENTICE
sp.p: Takes up the rhyme , half singing .“ And the little brat it 's blind the first weeks of its life , heigh-ho , heigh-ho , heigh . ”

lg.stage: Not touching the money which the cashier has counted out to him .
lg.l: We 've always got one and fourpence for the web .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Calls across .If our terms do n't suit you , Reimann , you have only to say so . There 's no scarcity of weavers — especially of your sort . For full weight we give full pay .

sp.speaker: REIMANN
sp.p: How anything can be wrong with the weight o ’ this ...!

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: You bring a piece of fustian with no faults in it , and there will be no fault in the pay .

sp.speaker: REIMANN
sp.p: It 's clean impossible that there 's too many knots in this web .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Examining .If you want to live well , then be sure you weave well .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Has remained standing near PFEIFER , so as to seize on any favourable opportunity . He laughs at PFEIFER 'S little witticism , then steps forward and again addresses him .I wanted to ask you , sir , if you would perhaps have the great kindness not to take my advance of sixpence off to-day 's pay ? My missus has been bedridden since February , She can n't do a hand 's turn for me , an ’ I 've to pay a bobbin girl . An ’ so ...

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Takes a pinch of snuff .Heiber do you think I have no one to attend to but you ? The others must have their turn .

sp.speaker: REIMANN
sp.p: As the warp was given me I took it home and fastened it to the beam . I can n't bring back no better yarn than I gets .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: If you 're not satisfied , you need come for no more . There are plenty ready to tramp the soles off their shoes to get it .

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: To REIMANN .Do n't you want your money ?

sp.speaker: REIMANN
sp.p: I can n't bring myself to take such pay .

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: Paying no further attention to REIMANN .Heiber , one shilling . Deduct sixpence for pay it advance . Leaves sixpence .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Goes up to the table , looks at the money , stands shaking his head as if unable to believe his eyes , then slowly takes it up .Well , I never !—Sighing .Oh dear , oh dear !

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Looking into HEIBER 'S face .Yes , Franz , that 's so ! There 's matter enough for sighing .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Speaking with difficulty .I 've a girl lyin ’ sick at home too , an ’ she needs a bottle of medicine .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: What 's wrong with her ?

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Well , you see , she 's always been a sickly bit of a thing . I do n't know ... I need n't mind tellin ’ you — she brought her trouble with her . It 's in her blood , and it breaks out here , there , and everywhere .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: It 's always the way . Let folks be poor , and one trouble comes to them on the top of another . There 's no help for it and there 's no end to it .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: What are you carryin ’ in that cloth , fatter . Baumert ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: We have n't so much as a bite in the house , and so I 've had the little dog killed . There 's not much on him , for the poor beast was half starved . A nice little dog he was ! I could n't kill him myself . I had n't the heart to do it .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Has inspected BECKER 'S web and calls .Becker , one and threepence .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: That 's what you might give to a beggar ; it 's not pay .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Every one who has been attended to must clear out . We have n't room to turn round in .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: To those standing near , without lowering his voice .It 's a beggarly pittance , nothing else . A man works his treadle from early morning till late at night , an ’ when he 's bent over his loom for days an ’ days , tired to death every evening , sick with the dust and the heat , he finds he 's made a beggarly one and threepence !

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: No impudence allowed here .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: If you think I 'll hold my tongue for your tellin ’ , you 're much mistaken .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Exclaims .We 'll see about that !Rushes to the glass door and calls into the office .Mr. Dreissiger , Mr. Dreissiger , will you be good enough to come here ?

div.stage: Enter DREISSIGER . About forty , full-bodied , asthmatic . Looks severe .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: What is it , Pfeifer ?

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Spitefully .Becker says he wo n't be told to hold his tongue .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Draws himself up , throws back his head , stares at BECKER ; his nostrils tremble .Oh , indeed !— Becker .To PFEIFER .Is he the man ?...

div.stage: The clerks nod .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Insolently .Yes , Mr. Dreissiger , yes !Pointing to himself .This is the man .Pointing to DREISSIGER .And that 's a man too !

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Angrily .Fellow , how dare you ?

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: He 's too well off . He 'll go dancing on the ice once too often , though .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Recklessly .You shut up , you Jack-in-the-box . Your mother must have gone dancing once too often with Satan to have got such a devil for a son .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Now in a violent passion , roars .Hold your tongue this moment , sir , or ...

div.stage: He trembles and takes a fere steps forward .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Holding his ground steadily .I 'm not deaf . My hearing 's quite good yet .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Controls himself , asks in an apparently cool business tone .Was this fellow not one of the pack ...?

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: He 's a Bielau weaver . When there 's any mischief going , they 're sure to be in it .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Trembling .Well , I give you all warning : if the same thing happens again as last night — a troop of half-drunken cubs marching past my windows singing that low song ...

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Is it “ Bloody Justice ” you mean ?

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: You know well enough what I mean . I tell you that if I hear it again I 'll get hold of one of you , and — mind , I 'm not joking — before the justice he shall go . And if I can find out who it was that made up that vile doggerel ...

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: It 's a grand song , that 's what it is !

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Another word and I send for the police on the spot , without more ado . I 'll make short work with you young fellows . I 've got the better of very different men before now .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: I believe you there . A real thoroughbred manufacturer will get the better of two or three hundred weavers in the time it takes you to turn round — swallow ‘ em up , and not leave as much as a bone . He 's got four stomachs like a cow , and teeth like a wolf . That 's nothing to him at all !

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: To his clerks .That man gets no more work from us .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: It 's all the same to me whether I starve at my loom or by the roadside .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Out you go , then , this moment !

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Determinedly .Not without my pay .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: How much is owing to the fellow , Neumann ?

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: One and threepence .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Takes the money hurriedly ont of the cashier 's hand , and flings it on the table , so that some of the coins roll off on to the floor .There you are , then ; and now , out of my sight with you !

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Not without my pay .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Do n't you see it lying there ? If you do n't take it and go ... It 's exactly twelve now ... The dyers are coming out for their dinner ...

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: I gets my pay into my hand — here — that 's where !

div.stage: Points with the fingers of his right hand at the palm of his left .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: To the APPRENTICE .Pick up the money , Tilgner .

div.stage: The APPRENTICE lifts the money and puts it into BECKER 'S hand .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Everything in proper order .

div.stage: Deliberately takes an old purse out of his pocket and puts the money into it .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: As BECKER still does not move away .Well ? Do you want me to come and help you ?

div.stage: Signs of agitation are observable among the crowd of weavers . A long , loud sigh is heard , and then a fall . General interest is at once diverted to this new event .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: What 's the matter there ?

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF WEAVERS AND WOMEN
sp.p: “ Some one 's fainted . ” — “ It 's a little sickly boy . ” — “ Is it a fit , or what ? ”

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: What do you say ? Fainted ?

div.stage: He goes nearer .

sp.speaker: OLD WEAVER
sp.p: There he lies , any way .

div.stage: They make room . A boy of about eight is seen lying on the floor as if dead .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Does any one know the boy ?

sp.speaker: OLD WEAVER
sp.p: He 's not from our village .

lg.l: He 's like one of weaver Heinrich 's boys .
lg.stage: Looks at him more closely .
lg.l: Yes , that 's Heinrich 's little Philip .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Where do they live ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Up near us in Kaschbach , sir . He goes round playin ’ music in the evenings , and all day he 's at the loom . They 've nine children an ’ a tenth a coming .

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF WEAVERS AND WOMEN
sp.p: “ They 're terrible put to it . ” — “ The rain comes through their roof . ” — “ The woman has n't two shirts among the nine . ”

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Taking the boy by the arm .Now then , lad , what 's wrong with you ? Wake up , lad .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Some of you help me , and we 'll get him up . It 's disgraceful to send a sickly child this distance . Bring some water , Pfeifer .

sp.speaker: WOMAN
sp.p: Helping to lift the boy .Sure you 're not goin ’ to be foolish and die , lad !

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Brandy , Pfeifer , brandy will be better .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Forgotten by all , has stood looking on . With his hand on the door-latch , he now calls loudly and tauntingly .Give him something to eat , an ’ he 'll soon be all right .

div.stage: Goes out .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: That fellow will come to a bad end .— Take him under the arm , Neumann . Easy now , easy ; we 'll get him into my room . What ?

sp.speaker: NEUMANN
sp.p: He said something , Mr. Dreissiger . His lips are moving .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: What — what is it , boy ?

sp.speaker: BOY
sp.p: Whispers .I 'm h-hungry .

sp.speaker: WOMAN
sp.p: I think he says —

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: We 'll find out . Do n't stop . Let us get him into my room . He can lie on the sofa there , We 'll hear what the doctor says .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER , NEUMANN , and the woman lead the boy into the office . The
sp.p: weavers begin to behave like school-children when their master has left the classroom . They stretch themselves , whisper , move from one foot to the other , and in the course of a few moments are conversing loudly .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: I believe as how Becker was right .

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF WEAVERS AND WOMEN
sp.p: “ He did say something like that . ” — “ It 's nothin ’ new here to fall down from hunger . ” — “ God knows what 's to come of ‘ em in winter if this cuttin ’ down o ’ wages goes on . ” — “ An ’ this year the potatoes are n't no good at all . ” — “ Things 'll get worse and worse till we 're all done for together . ”

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: The best thing a man could do would be to put a rope round his neck and hang hisself on his own loom , like weaver Nentwich .To another old weaver .Here , take a pinch . I was at Neurode yesterday . My brother-in-law , he works in the snuff factory there , and he give me a grain or two . Have you anything good in your kerchief ?

sp.speaker: OLD WEAVER
sp.p: Only a little pearl barley . I was coming along behind Ulbrich the miller 's cart , and there was a slit in one of the sacks . I can tell you we 'll be glad of it .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: There 's twenty-two mills in Peterswaldau , but of all they grind , there 's never nothin ’ comes our way .

sp.speaker: OLD WEAVER
sp.p: We must keep up heart . There 's always somethin ’ comes to help us on again .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Yes , when we 're hungry , we can pray to all the saints to help us , and if that do n't fill our bellies we can put a pebble in our mouths and suck it . Eh , Baumert ? Re-enter DREISSIGER , PFEIFER , AND NEUMANN .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: It was nothing serious . The boy is all right again .Walks about excitedly , panting .But all the same it 's a disgrace . The child 's so weak that a puff of wind would blow him over . How people , how any parents can be so thoughtless is what passes my comprehension . Loading him with two heavy pieces of fustian to carry six good miles ! No one would believe it that had n't seen it . It simply means that I shall have to make a rule that no goods brought by children will be taken over .He walks up and down silently for a few moments .I sincerely trust such a thing will not occur again .— Who gets all the blame for it ? Why , of course the manufacturer . It 's entirely our fault . If some poor little fellow sticks in the snow in winter and goes to sleep , a special correspondent arrives post-haste , and in two days we have a blood-curdling story served up in all the papers . Is any blame laid on the father , the parents , that send such a child ?— Not a bit of it . How should they be to blame ? It 's all the manufacturer 's fault — he 's made the scapegoat . They flatter the weaver , and give the manufacturer nothing but abuse — he 's a cruel man , with a heart like a stone , a dangerous fellow , at whose calves every cur of a journalist may take a bite . He lives on the fat of the land , and pays the poor weavers starvation wages . In the flow of his eloquence the writer forgets to mention that such a man has his cares too and his sleepless nights ; that he runs risks of which the workman never dreams ; that he is often driven distracted by all the calculations he has to make , and all the different things he has to take into account ; that he has to struggle for his very life against competition ; and that no day passes without some annoyance or some loss . And think of the manufacturer 's responsibilities , think of the numbers that depend on him , that look to him for their daily bread . No , No ! none of you need wish yourselves in my shoes — you would soon have enough of it .After a moment 's reflection .You all saw how that fellow , that scoundrel Becker , behaved . Now he 'll go and spread about all sorts of tales of my hard-heartedness , of how my weavers are turned off for a mere trifle , without a moment 's notice . Is that true ? Am I so very unmerciful ?

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF VOICES
sp.p: No , sir .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: It does n't seem to me that I am . And yet these ne'erhYpppHeNdohYpppHeNwells come round singing low songs about us manufacturers — prating about hunger , with enough in their pockets to pay for quarts of bad brandy . If they would like to know what want is , let them go and ask the linen-weavers : they can tell something about it . But you here , you fustian-weavers , have every reason to thank God that things are no worse than they are . And I put it to all the old , industrious weavers present : Is a good workman able to gain a living in my employment , or is he not ?

sp.speaker: MANY VOICES
sp.p: Yes , sir ; he is , sir .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: There now ! You see ! Of course such a fellow as that Becker can n't . I advise you to keep these young lads in check . If there 's much more of this sort of thing , I 'll shut up shop — give up the business altogether , and then you can shift for yourselves , get work where you like — perhaps Mr. Becker will provide it .

sp.speaker: FIRST WEAVER 'S WIFE
sp.p: Has come close to DREISSIGER , and removes a little dust from his coat with creeping servility .You 've been an ’ rubbed agin something , sir .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Business is as bad as it can be just now , you know that yourselves . Instead of making money , I am losing it every day . If , in spite of this , I take care that my weavers are kept in work , I look for some little gratitude from them . I have thousands of pieces of cloth in stock , and do n't know if I 'll ever be able to sell them . Well , now , I 've heard how many weavers hereabouts are out of work , and — I 'll leave Pfeifer to give the particulars — but this much I 'll tell you , just to show you my good will .... I can n't deal out charity all round ; I 'm not rich enough for that ; but I can give the people who are out of work the chance of earning at any rate a little . It 's a great business risk I run by doing it , but that 's my affair . I say to myself : Better that a man should work for a bite of bread than that , he should starve altogether , Am I not right ?

sp.speaker: CHORUS OF VOICES
sp.p: Yes , yes , sir .

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: And therefore I am ready to give employment to two hundred more weavers . Pfeifer will tell you on what conditions .

div.stage: He turns to go .

sp.speaker: FIRST WEAVER 'S WIFE
sp.p: Comes between him and the door , speaks hurriedly , eagerly , imploringly .Oh , if you please , sir , will you let me ask you if you 'll be so good ... I 've been twice laid up for ...

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Hastily .Speak to Pfeifer , good woman . I 'm too late as it is .

div.stage: Passes on , leaving her standing .

sp.speaker: REIMANN
sp.p: Stops him again . In an injured , complaining tone .I have a complaint to make , if you please , sir . Mr. Pfeifer refuses to ... I 've always got one and two-pence for a web ...

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: Interrupts him .Mr. Pfeifer 's my manager . There he is . Apply to him .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: Detaining DREISSIGER ; hurriedly and confusedly .O sir , I wanted to ask if you would p'r ' aps , if I might p'r ' aps ... if Mr. Pfeifer might ... might ...

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: What is it you want ?

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: That advance pay I had last time , sir ; I thought p'r ' aps you would kindly ...

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: I have no idea what you are talking about .

sp.speaker: HEIBER
sp.p: I 'm awful hard up , sir , because ...

sp.speaker: DREISSIGER
sp.p: These are things Pfeifer must look into — I really have not the time . Arrange the matter with Pfeifer .

div.stage: He escapes into the office .
The supplicants look helplessly at one another , sigh , and take their places again among the others .

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: Resuming his task of inspection .Well , Annie , let as see what yours is like .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: How much is we to get for the web , then , Mr. Pfeifer ?

sp.speaker: PFEIFER
sp.p: One shilling a web .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Has it come to that !

div.stage: Excited whispering and murmuring among the weavers .

sp.speaker: END OF THE FIRST ACT
sp.p: THE SECOND ACT A small room in the house of WILHELM ANSORGE , weaver and cottager in the village of Kaschbach , in the Eulengebirge . In this room , which does not measure six feet from the dilapidated wooden floor to the smoke-blackened rafters , sit four people . Two young girls , EMMA and BERTHA BAUMERT , are working at their looms ; MOTHER BAUMERT , a decrepit old woman , sits on a stool beside the bed , with a winding-wheel in front of her ; her idiot son AUGUST sits on a foot-stool , also winding . He is twenty , has a small body and head , and long , spider-like legs and arms . Faint , rosy evening light makes its way through two small windows in the right wall , which have their broken panes pasted over with paper or stuffed with straw . It lights up the flaxen hair of the girls , which falls loose on their slender white necks and thin bare shoulders , and their coarse chemises . These , with a short petticoat of the roughest linen , form their whole attire . The warm glow falls on the old woman 's face , neck , and breast — a face worn away to a skeleton , with shrivelled skin and sunken eyes , red and watery with smoke , dust , and working by lamplight — a long goitre neck , wrinkled and sinewy — a hollow breast covered with faded , ragged shawls . Part of the right wall is also lighted up , with stove , stove-bench , bedstead , and one or two gaudily coloured sacred prints . On the stove rail rags are hanging to dry , and behind the stove is a collection of worthless lumber . On the bench stand some old pots and cooking utensils , and potato parings are laid out on it , on paper , to dry . Hanks of yarn and reels hang from the rafters ; baskets of bobbins stand beside the looms . In the back wall there is a low door without fastening . Beside it a bundle of willow wands is set up against the wall , and beyond them lie some damaged quarter-bushel baskets . The room is full of sound — the rhythmic thud of the looms , shaking floor and walls , the click and rattle of the shuttles passing back and forward , and the steady whirr of the winding-wheels , like the hum of gigantic bees .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: In a querulous , feeble voice , as the girls stop weaving and bend over their webs .Got to make knots again already , have you ?

lg.stage: The elder of the two girls , about twenty-two , tying a broken thread
lg.l: It 's the plagueyest web , this !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Fifteen .Yes , it 's real bad yarn they 've given us this time .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: What can have happened to father ? He 's been away since nine .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: That he has ! yes . Where in the wide world c'n he be ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Do n't you worry yourself , mother .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: I can n't help it , Bertha lass .

div.stage: EMMA begins to weave again .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Stop a minute , Emma !

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: What is it !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: I thought I heard some one .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: It 'll be Ansorge comin ’ home .

div.stage: Enter FRITZ , a little , barefooted , ragged boy of four .

sp.speaker: FRITZ
sp.p: Whimpering .I 'm hungry , mother .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Wait , Fritzel , wait a bit ! Gran'father ' ll be here very soon , an ’ he 's bringin ’ bread along with him , an ’ coffee too .

sp.speaker: FRITZ
sp.p: But I 'm awful hungry , mother .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Be a good boy now , Fritz . Listen to what I 'm tellin ’ you . He 'll be here this minute . He 's bringin ’ nice bread an ’ nice corn-coffee ; an ’ when we stops workin ’ mother 'll take the tater peelin 's and carry them to the farmer , and the farmer 'll give her a drop o ’ good buttermilk for her little boy .

sp.speaker: FRITZ
sp.p: Where 's grandfather gone ?

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: To the manufacturer , Fritz , with a web .

sp.speaker: FRITZ
sp.p: To the manufacturer ?

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Yes , yes , Fritz , down to Dreissiger 's at Peterswaldau .

sp.speaker: FRITZ
sp.p: Is it there he gets the bread ?

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Yes ; Dreissiger gives him money , and then he buys the bread .

sp.speaker: FRITZ
sp.p: Does he give him a heap of money ?

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Impatiently .Oh , stop that chatter , boy .

div.stage: She and BERTHA go on weaving for a time , and then both stop again .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: August , go and ask Ansorge if he 'll give us a light .

div.stage: AUGUST goes out accompanied by FRITZ .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Overcome by her childish apprehension , whimpers .Emma ! Bertha ! where c'n the man be stay-in ’ ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Maybe he looked in to see Hauffe .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Crying .What if he 's sittin ’ drinkin ’ in the public-house ?

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Do n't cry , mother ! You know well enough father 's not the man to do that .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Half distracted by a multitude of gloomy forebodings .What ... what ... what 's to become of us if he do n't come home ? if he drinks the money , an ’ do n't bring us nothin ’ at all ? There 's not so much as a handful o ’ salt in the house — not a bite o ’ bread , nor a bit o ’ wood for the fire .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Wait a bit , mother ! It 's moonlight just now . We 'll take August with us and go into the wood and get some sticks .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Yes , an ’ be caught by the forester .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE , an old weaver of gigantic stature , who has to bend down to
sp.p: get into the room , puts his head and shoulders in at the door . Long , unkempt hair and beard .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: What 's wanted ?

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Light , if you please .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: In a muffled voice , as if speaking ’ in a sick-room .There 's good daylight yet .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Is we to sit in the dark next ?

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: I 've to do the same mayself .

div.stage: Goes out .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: It 's easy to see that he 's a miser .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Well , there 's nothin ’ for it but to sit an ’ wait his pleasure .

div.stage: Enter MRS. HEINRICH , a woman of thirty , heavy with child ; an expression of torturing anxiety and apprehension on her worn face .

sp.speaker: MRS. HEINRICH
sp.p: Good evenin ’ t'you all .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Well , Jenny , and what 's your news ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HEINRICH
sp.p: Who limps .I 've got a piece o ’ glass into my foot .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Come an ’ sit down , then , an ’ I 'll see if I c'n get it out .

div.stage: MRS. HEINRICH seats herself , BERTHA kneels down , in front of her , and examines her foot .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: How are ye all at home , Jenny ?

sp.speaker: MRS. HEINRICH
sp.p: Breaks out despairingly .Things is in a terrible way with us !

div.stage: She struggles in vain , against a rush of tears ; then weeps silently .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: The best thing as could happen to the likes o ’ us , Jenny , would be if God had pity on us an ’ took us away out o ’ this weary world .

sp.speaker: MRS. HEINRICH
sp.p: No longer able to control herself , screams , still crying .My children 's starvin ’ .Sobs and moans .I do n't know what to do no more ! I c'n work till I drops — I 'm more dead'n alive — things do n't get different ! There 's nine hungry mouths to fill ! We got a bit o ’ bread last night , but it was n't enough even for the two smallest ones . Who was I to give it to , eh ? They all cried ; Me , me , mother ! give it to me !... An ’ if it 's like this while I 'm still on my feet , what 'll it be when I 've to take to bed ? Our few taters was washed away . We have n't a thing to put in our mouths .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Has removed the bit of glass and washed the wound .We 'll put a rag round it . Emma , see if you can find one .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: We 're no better off'n you , Jenny .

sp.speaker: MRS. HEINRICH
sp.p: You has your girls , any way . You 've a husband as c'n work . Mine was taken with one o ’ his fits last week again — so bad that I did n't know what to do with him , and was half out o ’ my mind with fright . And when he 's had a turn like that , he can n't stir out o ’ bed under a week .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Mine 's no better . He 's goin ’ to pieces , too . He 's breathin 's bad now as well as his back . An ’ there 's not a farthin ’ nor a farthin 's worth in the house . If he do n't bring a few pence with him today , I do n't know what we 're to do .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: It 's the truth she 's tellin ’ you , Jenny . We had to let father take the little dog with him to-day , to have him killed , that we might get a bite into our stomachs again !

sp.speaker: MRS. HEINRICH
sp.p: Have n't you got as much as a handful o ’ flour to spare ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: An ’ that we have n't , Jenny . There 's not as much as a grain o ’ salt in the house .

sp.speaker: MRS. HEINRICH
sp.p: Well , then , I do n't know ...Rises , stands still , brooding .I do n't know what 'll be the end o ’ this ! It 's more'n I c'n bear .Screams in rage and despair .I 'd be contented if it was nothin ’ but pigs ’ food !— But I can n't go home again empty-handed — that I can n't . God forgive me , I see no other way out of it .

div.stage: She limps quickly out .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Calls after her in a warning voice .Jenny , Jenny ! do n't you be doin ’ anything foolish , now !

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: She 'll do herself no harm , mother . You need n't be afraid .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: That 's the way she always goes on .

div.stage: Seats herself at the loom and weaves for a few seconds .

sp.speaker: AUGUST enters , carrying a tallow candle , and lighting his father ,
sp.p: OLD BAUMERT , who follows close behind him , staggering under a heavy bundle of yarn .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Oh , father , where have you been all this long time ? Where have you been ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Come now , mother , do n't fall on a man like that . Give me time to get my breath first . An ’ look who I 've brought with me .

sp.speaker: MORITZ JAEGER comes stooping in at the low door . Reserve soldier ,
sp.p: newly discharged . Middle height , rosy-cheeked , military carriage . His cap on the side of his head , hussar fashion , whole clothes and shoes , a clean shirt without collar . Draws himself up and salutes .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: In a hearty voice .Good-evenin ’ , auntie Baumert !

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Well , well now ! and to think you 've got back ! An ’ you 've not forgotten us ? Take a chair , then , lad .

lg.stage: Wiping a wooden chair with her apron , and pushing it towards MORITZ .
lg.l: An ’ so you 've come to see what poor folks is like again , Moritz ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: I say , Emma , is it true that you 've got a boy nearly old enough to be a soldier ? Where did you get hold o ’ him , eh ?

div.stage: BERTHA , having taken the small supply of provisions which her father has brought , puts meat into a saucepan , and shoves it into the oven , while AUGUST lights the fire .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: You knew weaver Finger , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: We had him here in the house with us . He was ready enough to marry her ; but he was too far gone in consumption ; he was as good as a dead man . It did n't happen for want o ’ warnin ’ from me . But do you think she would listen ? Not she . Now he 's dead an ’ forgotten long ago , an ’ she 's left with the boy to provide for as best she can . But now tell us how you 've been gettin ’ on , Moritz .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: You 've only to look at him , mother , to know that . He 's had luck . It 'll be about as much as he can do to speak to the likes o ’ us . He 's got clothes like a prince , an ’ a silver watch , an ’ thirty shillings in his pocket into the bargain .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Stretching himself consequentially , a knowing smile on his face .I can n't complain , I did n't get on so badly in the regiment .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: He was the major 's own servant . Just listen to him — he speaks like a gentleman .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: I 've got so accustomed to it that I can n't help it .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Well , now , to think that such a good-for-nothin ’ as you was should have come to be a rich man . For there was n't nothin ’ to be made of you . You would never sit still to wind more than a hank of yarn at a time , that you would n't . Off you went to your tomtit boxes an ’ your robin redbreast snares — they was all you cared about . Is n't it the truth I 'm telling ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Yes , yes , auntie , it 's true enough . It was n't only redbreasts . I went after swallows too .

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Though we were always tellin ’ you that swallows was poison .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: What did I care ?— But how have you all been gettin ’ on , auntie Baumert ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Oh , badly , lad , badly these last four years . I 've had the rheumatics — just look at them hands . An ’ it 's more than likely as I 've had a stroke o ’ some kind too , I 'm that helpless . I can hardly move a limb , an ’ nobody knows the pains I suffers .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: She 's in a bad way , she is . She 'll not hold out long .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: We 've to dress her in the mornin ’ an ’ undress her at night , an ’ to feed her like a baby .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Speaking in a complaining , tearful voice .Not a thing c'n I do for myself . It 's far worse than bein ’ ill. For it 's not only a burden to myself I am , but to every one else . Often and often do I pray to God to take me . For oh ! mine 's a weary life . I do n't know ... p'r ' aps they think ... but I 'm one that 's been a hard worker all my days . An ’ I 've always been able to do my turn too ; but now , all at once ,she vainly attempts to riseI can n't do nothin ’ .— I 've a good husband an ’ good children , but to have to sit here and see them ...! Look at the girls ! There 's hardly any blood left in them — faces the colour of a sheet . But on they must work at these weary looms whether they earn enough to keep theirselves or not . What sort o ’ life is it they lead ? Their feet never off the treadle from year 's end to year 's end . An ’ with it all they can n't scrape together as much as 'll buy them clothes that they can let theirselves be seen in ; never a step can they go to church , to hear a word o ’ comfort . They 're liker scarecrows than young girls of fifteen and twenty .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: At the stove .It 's beginnin ’ to smoke again !

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: There now ; look at that smoke . And we can n't do nothin ’ for it . The whole stove 's goin ’ to pieces . We must let it fall , and swallow the soot . We 're coughin ’ already , one worse than the other . We may cough till we choke , or till we cough our lungs up — nobody cares .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: But this here is Ansorge 's business ; he must see to the stove .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: He 'll see us out o ’ the house first ; he has plenty against us without that .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: We 've only been in his way this long time past .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: One word of a complaint an ’ out we go . He 's had no rent from us this last half-year .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: A well-off man like him need n't be so hard .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: He 's no better off than we is , mother . He 's hard put to it too , for all he holds his tongue about it .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: He 's got his house .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: What are you talkin ’ about , mother ? Not one stone in the wall is the man 's own .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Has seated himself , and taken a short pipe with gay tassels out of one coat-pocket , and a quart bottle of brandy out of another .Things can n't go on like this . I 'm dumfoundered when I see the life the people live here . The very dogs in the towns live better .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Eagerly .That 's what I says ! Eh ? eh ? You know it too ! But if you say that here , they 'll tell you that it 's only bad times .

div.stage: Enter ANSORGE , an earthenware pan with soup in one hand , in the other a half-finished quarter-bushel basket .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Glad to see you again , Moritz !

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Thank you , father Ansorge — same to you !

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Shoving his pan into the oven .Why , lad you look like a duke !

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Show him your watch , Moritz . An ’ he 's got a new suit of clothes , an ’ thirty shillings cash .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Shaking his head .Is that so ? Well , well !

sp.speaker: EMMA
sp.p: Puts the potato-parings into a bag .I must be off ; I 'll maybe get a drop o ’ buttermilk for these .

div.stage: Goes out .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: The others hanging intently and devoutly on his words .You know how you all used to be down on me . It was always : Wait , Moritz , till your soldierin ’ time comes — you 'll catch it then . But you see how well I 've got on . At the end o ’ the first half-year I had my good conduct stripes . You 've got to be willin ’ — that 's where the secret lies . I brushed the sergeant 's boots ; I groomed his horse ; I fetched his beer . I was as sharp as a needle . Always ready , accoutrements clean and shinin ’ — first at stables , first at roll-call , first in the saddle . An ’ when the bugle sounded to the assault — why , then , blood and thunder , and ride to the devil with you !! I was as keen as a pointer . Says I to myself : There 's no help for it now , my boy , it 's got to be done ; and I set my mind to it and did it . Till at last the major said before the whole squadron : There 's a hussar now that shows you what a hussar should be !

div.stage: Silence . He lights his pipe .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Shaking his head .Well , well , well ! You had luck with you , Moritz !

div.stage: Sits down on the floor , with his willow twigs beside him , and continues mending the basket , which he holds between his legs .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Let 's hope you 've brought some of it to us .— Are we to have a drop to drink your health in ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Of course you are , father Baumert . And when this bottle 's done , we 'll send for more .

div.stage: He flings a coin on the table .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Open mouthed with amusement .Oh my ! Oh my ! What goings on to be sure ! Roast meat frizzlin ’ in the oven ! A bottle o ’ brandy on the table !He drinks out of the bottle .Here 's to you , Moritz !— Well , well , well !

div.stage: The bottle circulates freely after this .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: If we could any way have a bit o ’ meat on Sundays and holidays , instead o ’ never seein ’ the sight of it from year 's end to year 's end ! Now we 'll have to wait till another poor little dog finds its way into the house like this one did four weeks gone by — an ’ that 's not likely to happen soon again .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Have you killed the little dog ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: We had to do that or starve .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Well , well ! That 's so !

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: A nice , kind little beast he was , too !

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Are you as keen as ever on roast dog hereabouts ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Lord , if we could only get enough of it !

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: A nice little bit o ’ meat like that does you a lot o ’ good .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Have you lost the taste for it , Moritz ? Stay with us a bit , and it 'll soon come back to you .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Sniffing .Yes , yes ! That will be a tasty bite — what a good smell it has !

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Sniffing .Fine as spice , you might say .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Come , then , Moritz , tell us your opinion , you that 's been out and seen the world . Is things at all like to improve for us weavers , eh ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: They would need to .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: We 're in an awful state here . It 's not livin ’ an ’ it 's not dyin ’ . A man fights to the bitter end , but he 's bound to be beat at last — to be left without a roof over his head , you may say without ground under his feet . As long as he can work at the loom he can earn some sort o poor , miserable livin ’ . But it 's many a day since I 've been able to get that sort o ’ job . Now I tries to put a bite into my mouth with this here basket-mak-in ’ . I sits at it late into the night , and by the time I tumbles into bed I 've earned three-halfpence . I puts it to you as knows things , if a man can live on that , when everything 's so dear ? Nine shillin ’ goes in one lump for house tax , three shillin ’ for land tax , nine shillin ’ for mortgage interest — that makes one pound one . I may reckon my year 's earnin ’ at just double that money , and that leaves me twenty-one shillin ’ for a whole year 's food , an ’ fire , an ’ clothes , an ’ shoes ; and I 've got to keep up some sort of a place to live in . An ’ there 's odds an ’ ends . Is it a wonder if I 'm behindhand with my interest payments ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Some one would need to go to Berlin an ’ tell the King how hard put to it we are .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Little good that would do , father Baumert . There 's been plenty written about it in the news-papers . But the rich people , they can turn and twist things round ... as cunning as the devil himself .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Shaking his head .To think they 've no more sense than that in Berlin .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: And is it really true , Moritz ? Is there no law to help us ? If a man has n't been able to scrape together enough to pay his mortgage interest , though he 's worked the very skin off his hands , must his house be taken from him ? The peasant that 's lent the money on it , he wants his rights — what else can you look for from him ? But what 's to be the end of it all , I do n't know .— If I 'm put out o ’ the house ...In a voice choked by tears .I was born here , and here my father sat at his loom for more than forty year . Many was the time he said to mother : Mother , when I 'm gone , keep hold o ’ the house . I 've worked hard for it . Every nail means a night 's weavin ’ , every plank a year 's dry bread . A man would think that ...

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: They 're just as like to take the last bite out of your mouth — that 's what they are .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Well , well , well ! I would rather be carried out than have to walk out now in my old days . Who minds dyin ’ ? My father , he was glad to die . At the very end he got frightened , but I crept into bed beside him , an ’ he quieted down again . Think of it ; I was a lad of thirteen then . I was tired and fell asleep beside him — I knew no better — and when I woke he was quite cold .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: After a pause .Give Ansorge his soup out o ’ the oven , Bertha .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Here , father Ansorge , it 'll do you good .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Eating and shedding tears .Well , well , well !

div.stage: OLD BAUMERT has begun to eat the meat out of the saucepan .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Father , father , can n't you have patience an ’ let Bertha serve it up properly ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Chewing .It 's two years now since I took the sacrament . I went straight after that an ’ sold my Sunday coat , an ’ we bought a good bit o ’ pork , an ’ since then never a mouthful of meat has passed my lips till to-night .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: We do n't need no meat ! The manufacturers eats it for us . It 's the fat o ’ the land they lives on . Whoever do n't believe that has only to go down to Bielau and Peterswaldau . He 'll see fine things there — palace upon palace , with towers and iron railings and plate-glass windows . Who do they all belong to ? Why , of course , the manufacturers ! No signs of bad times there ! Baked and boiled and fried — horses and carriages and governesses — they 've money to pay for all that and goodness knows how much more . They 're swelled out to burstin ’ with pride and good livin ’ .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Things was different in my young days . Then the manufacturers let the weaver have his share . Now they keeps everything to theirselves . An ’ would you like to know what 's at the bottom of it all ? It 's that the fine folks nowadays believes neither in God nor devil . What do they care about commandments or punishments ? And so they steals our last scrap o ’ bread , an ’ leaves us no chance of earnin ’ the barest living . For it 's their fault . If our manufacturers was good men , there would be no bad times for us .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Listen , then , and I 'll read you something that will please you .He takes one or two loose papers from his pocket .I say , August , run and fetch another quart from the public-house . Eh , boy , do you laugh all day long ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: No one knows why , but our August 's always happy — grins an ’ laughs , come what may . Off with you then , quick !Exit AUGUST with the empty brandy-bottle .You 've got something good now , eh , father ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Still chewing ; his spirits are rising from the effect of food and drink .Moritz , you 're the very man we want . You can read an ’ write . You understand the weavin ’ trade , and you 've a heart to feel for the poor weavers ’ sufferin 's . You should stand up for us here .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: I 'd do that quick enough ! There 's nothing I 'd like better than to give the manufacturers round here a bit of a fright — dogs that they are ! I 'm an easy-goin ’ fellow , but let me once get worked up into a real rage , and I 'll take Dreissiger in the one hand and Dittrich in the other , and knock their heads together till the sparks fly out o ’ their eyes .— If we could only arrange all to join together , we 'd soon give the manufacturers a proper lesson ... we would n't need no King an ’ no Government ... all we 'd have to do would be to say : We wants this and that , and we do n't want the other thing . There would be a change of days then . As soon as they see that there 's some pluck in us , they 'll cave in . I know the rascals ; they 're a pack o ’ cowardly hounds .

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: There 's some truth in what you say . I 'm not a bad woman . I 've always been the one to say as how there must be rich folks as well as poor . But when things come to such a pass as this ...

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: The devil may take them all , for what I care . It would be no more than they deserves .

div.stage: OLD BAUMERT has quietly gone out .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Where 's father ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: I do n't know where he can have gone .

sp.speaker: BERTHA
sp.p: Do you think he 's not been able to stomach the meat , with not gettin ’ none for so long ?

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: In distress , crying .There now , there ! He 's not even able to keep it down when he 's got it . Up it comes again , the only bite o ’ good food as he 's tasted this many a day . Re-enter OLD BAUMERT , crying with rage .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: It 's no good ! I 'm too far gone ! Now that I 've at last got hold of somethin ’ with a taste in it , my stomach wo n't keep it .

div.stage: He sits down on the bench by the stove crying .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: With a sudden violent ebullition of rage .An ’ yet there 's people not far from here , justices they call themselves too , over-fed brutes , that have nothing to do all the year round but invent new ways of wastin ’ their time . An ’ these people say that the weavers would be quite well off if only they was n't so lazy .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: The men as says that are no men at all , they 're monsters .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Never mind , father Ansorge ; we 're makin ’ the place hot for ‘ em . Becker and I have been and given Dreissiger a piece of our mind , and before we came away we sang him “ Bloody Justice . ”

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Good Lord ! Is that the song ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Yes ; I have it here .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: They calls it Dreissiger 's song , do n't they ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: I 'll read it to you ,

sp.speaker: MOTHER BAUMERT
sp.p: Who wrote it ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: That 's what nobody knows . Now listen .He reads , hesitating like a schoolboy , with incorrect accentuation , but unmistakably strong feeling . Despair , suffering , rage , hatred , thirst for revenge , all find utterance .The justice to us weavers dealt Is bloody , cruel , and hateful ; Our life 's one torture , long drawn out : For Lynch law we 'd be grateful . Stretched on the rack day after day , Hearts sick and bodies aching , Our heavy sighs their witness bear To spirit slowly breaking .

div.stage: The words of the song make a strong impression on OLD BAUMERT . Deeply agitated , he struggles against the temptation to interrupt JAEGER . At last he can keep quiet no longer .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: To his wife , half laughing , half crying , stammering .Stretched on the rack day after day . Whoever wrote that , mother , wrote the truth . You can bear witness ... eh , how does it go ? “ Our heavy sighs their witness bear ” ... What 's the rest ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: “ To spirit slowly breaking . ”

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: You know the way we sigh , mother , day and night , sleepin ’ and wakin ’ .

div.stage: ANSORGE had stopped working , and cowers on the floor , strongly agitated . MOTHER BAUMERT and BERTHA wipe their eyes frequently during the course of the reading .

lg.stage: Continues to read .
lg.l: The Dreissigers true hangmen are ,
Servants no whit behind them ;
Masters and men with one accord
Set on the poor to grind them .
You villains all , you brood of hell ...

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Trembling with rage , stamping on the floor .Yes , brood of hell !! !

lg.stage: Reads .
lg.l: You fiends in fashion human ,
A curse will fall on all like you ,
Who prey on man and woman .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes , a curse upon them !

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Clenching his fist , threateningly .You prey on man and woman .

lg.stage: Reads .
lg.l: The suppliant knows he asks in vain ,
Vain every word that 's spoken .
“ If not content , then go and starve —
Our rules cannot be broken . ”

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: What is it ? “ The suppliant knows he asks in vain ” ? Every word of it 's true ... every word ... as true as the Bible . He knows he asks in vain .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Yes , yes ! It 's all no good .

lg.stage: Reads .
lg.l: Then think of all our woe and want ,
O ye who hear this ditty !
Our struggle vain for daily bread
Hard hearts would move to pity .
But pity 's what you 've never known ,
You 'd take both skin and clothing ,
You cannibals , whose cruel deeds
Fill all good men with loathing .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Jumps up , beside himself with excitement .Both skin and clothing . It 's true , it 's all true ! Here I stands , Robert Baumert , master-weaver of Kaschbach . Who can bring up anything against me ?... I 've been an honest , hard-workin ’ man all my life long , an ’ look at me now ! What have I to show for it ? Look at me ! See what they 've made of me ! Stretched on the rack day after day ,He holds out his arms .Feel that ! Skin and bone ! “ You villains all , you brood of hell !! ”

div.stage: He sinks down on a chair , weeping with rage and despair .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Flings his basket from him into a corner , rises , his whole body trembling with rage , gasps .An ’ the time 's come now for a change , I say . We 'll stand it no longer ! We 'll stand it no longer ! Come what may !

sp.speaker: END OF THE SECOND ACT
sp.p: THE THIRD ACT The common-room of the principal public-house in Peterswaldau . A large room with a raftered roof supported by a central wooden pillar , round which a table runs . In the back mall , a little to the right of the pillar , is the entrance-door , through the opening of which the spacious lobby or outer room is seen , with barrels and brewing utensils . To the right of this door , in the corner , is the bar — a high wooden counter with receptacles for beer-mugs , glasses , etc . ; a cupboard with rows of brandy and liqueur bottles on the wall behind , and between counter and cupboard a narrow space for the barkeeper . In front of the bar stands a table with a gay-coloured cover , a pretty lamp hanging above it , and several cane chairs placed around it . Not far off , in the right wall , is a door with the inscription : Bar Parlour . Nearer the front on the same side an old eight-day clock stands ticking . At the back , to the left of the entrance-door , is a table with bottles and glasses , and beyond this , in the corner , is the great tile-oven . In the left wall there are three small windows . Below them runs a long bench ; and in front of each stands a large oblong wooden table , with the end towards the wall . There are benches with backs along the sides of these tables , and at the end of each facing the window stands a wooden chair . The walls are washed blue and decorated with advertisements , coloured prints and oleographs , among the latter a portrait of Frederick William IV .

sp.speaker: WELZEL , the publican , a good-natured giant , upwards of fifty , stands
sp.p: behind the counter , letting beer run from a barrel into a glass .

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL is ironing by the stove . She is a handsome , tidily
sp.p: dressed woman in her thirty-fifth year .

sp.speaker: ANNA WELZEL , a good-looking girl of seventeen , with a quantity of
sp.p: beautiful , fair , reddish hair , sits , neatly dressed , with her embroidery , at the table with the coloured cover . She looks up from her work for a moment and listens , as the sound of a funeral hymn sung by school-children is heard in the distance .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND , the joiner , in his working clothes , is sitting at the same
sp.p: table , with a glass of Bavarian beer before him . His face shows that he understands what the world requires of a man if he is to attain his ends — namely , craftiness , swiftness , and relentless pushing forward . A COMMERCIAL TRAVELLER is seated at the pillar-table , vigorously masticating a beef-steak . He is of middle height , stout and thriving-looking , inclined to jocosity , lively , and impudent . He is dressed in the fashion of the day , and his portmanteau , pattern-case , umbrella , overcoat , and travelling rug lie on chairs beside him .

lg.stage: Carrying a glass of beer to the TRAVELLER , but addressing WIEGAND .
lg.l: The devil 's broke loose in Peterswaldau to-day .

lg.stage: In a sharp , shrill voice .
lg.l: That 's because it 's delivery day at
Dreissiger 's .

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL
sp.p: But they do n't generally make such an awful row .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: It 's may be because of the two hundred new weavers that he 's going to take on .

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL
sp.p: At her ironing .Yes , yes , that 'll be it . If he wants two hundred , six hundred 's sure to have come . There 's no lack of them .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: No , they 'll last . There 's no fear of their dying out , let them be ever so badly off . They bring more children into the world than we know what to do with .The strains of the funeral hymn are suddenly heard more distinctly .There 's a funeral to-day too . Weaver Nentwich is dead , you know .

sp.speaker: WELZEL
sp.p: He 's been long enough about it . He 's been goin ’ about like a livin ’ ghost this many a long day .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: You never saw such a little coffin , Welzel ; it was the tiniest , miserablest little thing I ever glued together . And what a corpse ! It did n't weigh ninety pounds .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: His mouth full .What I do n't understand 's this .... Take up whatever paper you like and you 'll find the most heartrending accounts of the destitution among the weavers . You get the impression that three-quarters of the people in this neighbourhood are starving . Then you come and see a funeral like what 's going on just now . I met it as I came into the village . Brass band , schoolmaster , school children , pastor , and such a procession behind them that you would think it was the Emperor of China that was getting buried . If the people have money to spend on this sort of thing , well ...!He takes a drink of beer ; puts down the glass ; suddenly and jocosely .What do you say to it , Miss ? Do n't you agree with me ?

div.stage: ANNA gives an embarrassed laugh , and goes on working busily .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: Now , I 'll take a bet that these are slippers for papa .

sp.speaker: WELZEL
sp.p: You 're wrong , then ; I would n't put such things on my feet .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: You do n't say so ! Now , I would give half of what I 'm worth if these slippers were for me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL
sp.p: Oh , he do n't know nothing about such things .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: Has coughed once or twice , moved his chair , and prepared himself to speak .You were sayin ’ , sir , that you wondered to see such a funeral as this . I tell you , and Mrs. Welzel here will bear me out , that it 's quite a small funeral .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: But , my good man ... what a monstrous lot of money it must cost ! Where does all that come from ?

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: If you 'll excuse me for saying so , sir , there 's a deal of foolishness among the poorer working people hereabouts . They have a kind of inordinate idea , if I may say so , of the respect an ’ duty an ’ honour they 're bound to show to such as is taken from their midst . And when it comes to be a case of parents , then there 's no bounds whatever to their superstitiousness . The children and the nearest family scrapes together every farthing they can call their own , an ’ what 's still wanting , that they borrow from some rich man . They run themselves into debt over head and ears ; they 're owing money to the pastor , to the sexton , and to all concerned . Then there 's the victuals , an ’ the drink , an ’ such like . No , sir , I 'm far from speaking against dutifulness to parents ; but it 's too much when it goes the length of the mourners having to bear the weight of it for the rest of their lives .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: But surely the pastor might reason them out of such foolishness .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: Begging your pardon , sir , but I must mention that every little place hereabouts has its church an ’ its reverend pastor to support . These honourable gentlemen has their advantages from big funerals . The larger the attendance is , the larger the offertory is bound to be . Whoever knows the circumstances connected with the working classes here , sir , will assure you that the pastors are strong against quiet funerals .

div.stage: Enter HORNIG , the rag dealer , a little bandy-legged old man , with a strap round his chest .

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: Good-mornin ’ , ladies and gentlemen ! A glass o ’ schnapps , if you please , Mr. Welzel . Has the young mistress anything for me to-day ? I 've got beautiful ribbons in my cart , Miss Anna , an ’ tapes , an ’ garters , an ’ the very best of pins an ’ hairpins an ’ hooks an ’ eyes . An ’ all in exchange for a few rags .In a changed voice .An'out of them rags fine white paper 's to be made , for your sweetheart to write you a letter on .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Thank you , but I 've nothing to do with sweethearts .

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL
sp.p: Putting a bolt into her iron .No , she 's not that kind . She 'll not hear of marrying .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: Jumps up , affecting delighted surprise , goes forward to ANNA 'S table , and holds out his hand to her across it .That 's sensible , Miss . You and I think alike in this matter . Give me your hand on it . We 'll both remain single .

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Blushing scarlet , gives him her hand .But you are married already !

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: Not a bit of it . I only pretend to be . You think so because I wear a ring . I only have it on my finger to protect my charms against shameless attacks . I 'm not afraid of you , though .He puts the ring into his pocket .But tell me , truly , Miss , are you quite determined never , never , never , to marry ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Shakes her head .Oh , get along with you !

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL
sp.p: You may trust her to remain single unless something very extra good turns up .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: And why should n't it ? I know of a rich Silesian proprietor who married his mother 's lady 's maid . And there 's Dreissiger , the rich manufacturer , his wife is an innkeeper 's daughter too , and not half so pretty as you , Miss , though she rides in her carriage now , with servants in livery . And why not ?He marches about , stretching himself , and stamping his feet .Let me have a cup of coffee , please .

div.stage: Enter ANSORGE and OLD BAUMERT , each with a bundle . They seat themselves meekly and silently beside HORNIG , at the front table to the left .

sp.speaker: WELZEL
sp.p: How are you , father Ansorge ? Glad to see you once again .

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: Yes , it 's not often as you crawl down from that smoky old nest .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Visibly embarrassed , mumbles .I 've been fetchin ’ myself a web again .

sp.speaker: BAUMER
sp.p: He 's goin ’ to work at a shilling the web .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: I would n't ha ’ done it , but there 's no more to be made now by basket-weaving ’ .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: It 's always better than nothin ’ . He does it only to give you employment . I know Dreissiger very well . When I was up there takin ’ out his double windows last week we were talkin ’ about it , him and me . It 's out of pity that he does it .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Well , well , well ! That may be so .

lg.stage: Setting a glass of schnapps on the table before each of the weavers .
lg.l: Here you are , then . I say , Ansorge , how long is it since you had a shave ?
The gentleman over there would like to know .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: Calls across .Now , Mr. Welzel , you know I did n't say that . I was only struck by the venerable appearance of the master-weaver . It is n't often one sees such a gigantic figure .

sp.speaker: ANSORGE
sp.p: Scratching his head , embarrassed .Well , well !

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: Such specimens of primitive strength are rare nowadays . We 're all rubbed smooth by civilisation ... but I can still take pleasure in nature untampered with .... These bushy eyebrows ! That tangled length of beard !

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: Let me tell you , sir , that them people have n't the money to pay a barber , and as to a razor for themselves , that 's altogether beyond them . What grows , grows . They have n't nothing to throw away on their outsides .

lg.l: My good friend , you surely do n't imagine that I would ...
lg.stage: Aside to WELZEL .
lg.l: Do you think I might offer the hairy one a glass of beer ?

sp.speaker: WELZEL
sp.p: No , no ; you must n't do that . He would n't take it . He 's got some queer ideas in that head o ’ his .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: All right , then , I wo n't . With your permission , Miss .He seats himself at ANNA 'S table .I declare , Miss , that I 've not been able to take my eyes off your hair since I came in — such glossy softness , such a splendid quantity !Ecstatically kisses his finger-tips .And what a colour !... like ripe wheat . Come to Berlin with that hair and you 'll create no end of a sensation . On my honour , with hair like that you may go to Court ....Leans back , looking at it .Glorious , simply glorious !

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: They 've given her a fine name because of it .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: And what may that be ?

sp.speaker: ANNA
sp.p: Laughing quietly to herself .Oh , do n't listen to that !

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: The chestnut filly , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: WELZEL
sp.p: Come now , we 've had enough o ’ this . I 'm not goin ’ to have the girl 's head turned altogether . She 's had a-plenty of silly notions put into it already . She 'll hear of nothing under a count today , and to-morrow it 'll be a prince .

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL
sp.p: Do n't abuse the girl , father . There 's no harm in wantin ’ to rise in the world . It 's as well that people do n't all think as you do , or nobody would get on at all . If Dreissiger 's grandfather had been of your way of thinkin ’ , they would be poor weavers still . And now they 're rollin ’ in wealth . An ’ look at old Tromtra . He was nothing but a weaver , too , and now he owns twelve estates , an ’ he 's been made a nobleman into the bargain .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: Yes , Welzel , you must look at the thing fairly . Your wife 's in the right this time . I can answer for that . I 'd never be where I am , with seven workmen under me , if I had thought like you .

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: Yes , you understand the way to get on ; that your worst enemy must allow . Before the weaver has taken to bed , you 're gettin ’ his coffin ready .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: A man must stick to his business if he 's to get on .

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: No fear of you for that . You know before the doctor when death 's on the way to knock at a weaver 's door .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: Attempting to laugh , suddenly furious .And you know better'n the police where the thieves are among the weavers , that keep back two or three bobbins full every week . It 's rags you ask for but you do n't say No , if there 's a little yarn among them .

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: An ’ your corn grows in the churchyard . The more that are bedded on the sawdust , the better for you . When you see the rows o ’ little children 's graves , you pats yourself on the belly and says you : This has been a good year ; the little brats have fallen like cockchafers off the trees . I can allow myself a quart extra in the week again .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: And supposin ’ this is all true , it still do n't make me a receiver of stolen goods .

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: No ; perhaps the worst you do is to send in an account twice to the rich fustian manufacturers , or to help yourself to a plank or two at Dreissiger 's when there 's building goin ’ on and the moon happens not to be shinin ’ .

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: Turning his back .Talk to any one you like , but not to me .Then suddenly .Hornig the liar !

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: Wiegand the coffin-jobber !

sp.speaker: WIEGAND
sp.p: To the rest of the company .He knows charms for bewitching cattle .

sp.speaker: HORNIG
sp.p: If you do n't look out , I 'll try one of ‘ em on you .

div.stage: WIEGAND turns pale .

sp.speaker: MRS. WELZEL
sp.p: Had gone out ; now returns with the TRAVELLER 'S coffee ; in the act of putting it on the table .Perhaps you would rather have it in the parlour , sir ?

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: Most certainly not !With a languishing look at ANNA .I could sit here till I die .

div.stage: Enter a YOUNG FORESTER and a PEASANT , the latter carrying a whip . They wish the others “ Good Morning , ” and remain standing at the counter .

sp.speaker: PEASANT
sp.p: Two brandies , if you please .

sp.speaker: WELZEL
sp.p: Good-morning to you , gentlemen .

div.stage: He pours out their beverage ; the two touch glasses , take a mouthful , and then set the glasses down on the counter .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: To FORESTER .Come far this morning , sir ?

sp.speaker: FORESTER
sp.p: From Steinseiffersdorf — that 's a good step . Two old WEAVERS enter , and seat themselves beside ANSORGE , BAUMERT , and HORNIG .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
sp.p: Excuse me asking , but are you in Count Hochheim 's service ?

sp.speaker: FORESTER
sp.p: No . I 'm in Count Keil 's .

sp.speaker: TRAVELLER
