sp.p: He might ha ’ spared hisself the trouble — that wo n't help him . It 's something else they 've set their minds on here . It 's the factories . They 're goin ’ to smash up the power-looms . For it 's them that is ruinin ’ the hand-loom weaver . Even a blind man might see that . No ! the good folks knows what they 're after , an ’ no sheriff an ’ no p'lice superintendent 'll bring them to reason — much less a bit of a board . Him as has seen ‘ em at work already knows what 's comin ’ .

sp.speaker: HOUSE INMATES
sp.p: “ Did any one ever see such a crowd ! ” — “ What can these be wantin ’ ? ” —Hastily .“ They 're crossin ’ the bridge ! ” —Anxiously .“ They 're never comin ’ over on this side , are they ? ” —In excitement and terror .“ It 's to us they 're comin ’ ! They 're comin ’ to us ! They 're comin ’ to fetch the weavers out o ’ their houses ! ”

div.stage: General flight . The entry-room is empty . A crowd of dirty , dusty rioters rush in , their faces scarlet with brandy , and excitement ; tattered , untidy-looking , as if they had been up all night . With the shout : “ Weavers , come out ! ” they disperse themselves through the house . BECKER and several other young weavers , armed with cudgels and poles , come into OLD HILSE 'S room . When they see the old man at his loom they start , and cool down a little .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Come , father Hilse , stop that . Leave your work to them as wants to work . There 's no need now for you to be doin ’ yourself harm . You 'll be well taken care of .

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: You 'll never need to go hungry to bed again .

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: The weaver 's goin ’ to have a roof over his head an ’ a shirt on his back once more .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: An ’ what 's the devil sendin ’ you to do now , with your poles an ’ axes ?

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: These are what we 're goin ’ to break on Dittrich 's back .

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: We 'll heat ‘ em red hot an ’ stick ‘ em down the manufacturers ’ throats , so as they 'll feel for once what burnin ’ hunger tastes like .

sp.speaker: THIRD YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: Come along , father Hilse ! We 'll give no quarter .

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: No one had mercy on us — neither God nor man . Now we 're standin ’ up for our rights ourselves .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT enters , somewhat shaky on the legs , a newly killed cock
sp.p: under his arm .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Stretching out his arms .My brothers — we 're all brothers ! Come to my arms , brothers !

div.stage: Laughter .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: And that 's the state you 're in , Willem ?

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Gustav , is it you ? My poor starvin ’ friend . Come to my arms , Gustav !

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Mutters .Let me alone .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: I 'll tell you what , Gustav . It 's nothin ’ but luck that 's wanted . You look at me . What do I look like ? Luck 's what 's wanted . Do n't I look like a lord ?Pats his stomach .Guess what 's in there ! There 's food fit for a prince in that belly . When luck 's with him a man gets roast hare to eat an ’ champagne wine to drink .— I 'll tell you all something : We 've made a big mistake — we must help ourselves .

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.p: Speaking at once .We must help ourselves , hurrah !

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: As soon as we gets the first good bite inside us we 're different men . Damn it all ! but you feels the power comin ’ into you till you 're like an ox , an ’ that wild with strength that you hit out right an ’ left without as much as takin ’ time to look . Dash it , but it 's grand !

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: At the door , armed with an old cavalry sword .We 've made one or two first-rate attacks .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: We knows how to set about it now . One , two , three , an ’ we 're inside the house . Then , at it like lightnin ’ — bang , crack , shiver ! till the sparks are flyin ’ as if it was a smithy .

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: It would n't be half bad to light a bit o ’ fire .

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: Let 's march to Reichenbach an ’ burn the rich folks ’ houses over their heads !

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: That would be nothin ’ but butterin ’ their bread , Think of all the insurance money they 'd get .

div.stage: Laughter .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: No , from here we 'll go to Freiburg , to Tromtra 's .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: What would you say to givin ’ all them as holds Government appointments a lesson ? I 've read somewhere as how all our troubles come from them birocrats , as they calls them .

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: Before long we 'll go to Breslau , for more an ’ more 'll be joinin ’ us .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: To HILSE .Wo n't you take a drop , Gustav ?

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: I never touches it .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: That was in the old world ; we 're in a new world to-day , Gustav .

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: Christmas comes but once a year .

div.stage: Laughter .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Impatiently .What is it you want in my house , you limbs of Satan ?

lg.stage: A little intimidated , coaxingly .
lg.l: I was bringin ’ you a chicken ,
Gustav . I thought it would make a drop o ’ soup for mother .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Embarrassed , almost friendly .Well , you can tell mother yourself .

sp.speaker: MOTHER HILSE
sp.p: Who has been making efforts to hear , her hand at her ear , motions them off .Let me alone . I do n't want no chicken soup .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: That 's right , mother . An ’ I want none , an ’ least of all that sort . An ’ let me say this much to you , Baumert : The devil stands on his head for joy when he hears the old ones jabberin ’ and talkin ’ as if they was infants . An ’ to you all I say — to every one of you : Me and you , we 've got nothing to do with each other . It 's not with my will that you 're here . In law an ’ justice you 've no right to be in my house .

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: Him that 's not with us is against us .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Roughly and threateningly .You 're on the wrong track , old chap , I 'd have you remember that we 're not thieves .

sp.speaker: A VOICE
sp.p: We 're hungry men , that 's all .

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: We wants to live — that 's all . An ’ so we 've cut the rope we was hung up with .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: And we was in our right !Holding his fist in front of the old man 's face .Say another word , and I 'll give you one between the eyes .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Come , now , Jaeger , be quiet . Let the old man alone .— What we say to ourselves , father Hilse , is this : Better dead than begin the old life again .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Have I not lived that life for sixty years an ’ more ?

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: That does n't help us — there 's got to be a change .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: On the Judgment Day .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: What they 'll not give us willingly we 're goin ’ to take by force .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: By force .Laughs .You may as well go an ’ dig your graves at once . They 'll not be long showin ’ you where the force lies . Wait a bit , lad !

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Is it the soldiers you 're meanin ’ ? We 've been soldiers too . We 'll soon do for a company or two of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: With your tongues , maybe . But supposin ’ you did — for two that you 'd beat off , ten 'll come back .

sp.speaker: VOICES
sp.p: Call through the window .The soldiers are comin ! Look out !

div.stage: General , sudden silence . For a moment a faint sound of fifes and drums is heard ; in the ensuing silence a short , involuntary exclamation : “ The devil ! I 'm off ! ” followed by general laughter .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Who was that ? Who speaks of runnin ’ away ?

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: Which of you is it that 's afraid of a few paltry helmets ? You have me to command you , and I 've been in the trade . I knows their tricks .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: An ’ what are you goin ’ to shoot with ? Your sticks , eh ?

sp.speaker: FIRST YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: Never mind that old chap ; he 's wrong in the upper storey .

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: Yes , he 's a bit off his head .

sp.speaker: GOTTLIEB
sp.p: Has made his way unnoticed among the rioters ; catches hold of the speaker .Would you give your impudence to an old man like him ?

sp.speaker: SECOND YOUNG WEAVER
sp.p: Let me alone . ‘ Twas n't anything bad I said .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Interfering .Let him jaw , Gottlieb . What . would you be meddlin ’ with him for ? He 'll soon see who it is that 's been off his head to-day , him or me .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Are you comin ’ , Gottlieb ?

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: No , he 's goin ’ to do no such thing .

sp.speaker: LUISE
sp.p: Comes into the entry-room , calls .What are you puttin ’ off your time with prayin ’ hypocrites like them for ? Come quick to where you 're wanted ! Quick ! Father Baumert , run all you can ! The major 's speakin ’ to the crowd from horseback . They 're to go home . If you do n't hurry up , it 'll be all over .

sp.speaker: JAEGER
sp.p: As he goes out .That 's a brave husband o ’ yours .

lg.l: Where is he ? I 've got no husband !
lg.stage: Some of the people in the entry-room sing :
lg.l: Once on a time a man so small ,
Heigh-ho , heigh !
Set his heart on a wife so tall ,
Heigh diddle-di-dum-di !

sp.speaker: WITTIG , THE SMITH
sp.p: Comes downstairs , still carrying the stable pail ; stops on his way through the entry-room .Come On ! all of you that is not cowardly scoundrels !— hurrah !

div.stage: He dashes out , followed by LUISE , JAEGER , and others , all shouting “ Hurrah ! ”

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Good-bye , then , father Hilse ; well see each other again .

div.stage: Is going .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: I doubt that . I 've not five years to live , and that 'll be the soonest you 'll get out .

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Stops , not understanding .Out o ’ what , father Hilse ?

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Out o ’ prison — where else ?

sp.speaker: BECKER
sp.p: Laughs wildly .Do you think I 'd mind that ? There 's bread to be had there anyhow !

div.stage: Goes out .

sp.speaker: OLD BAUMERT
sp.p: Has been cowering on a low stool , painfully beating his brains ; he now gets up .It 's true , Gustav , as I 've had a drop too much . But for all that I knows what I 'm about . You think one way in this here matter ; I think another . I say Becker 's right : even if it ends in chains an ’ ropes — we 'll be better off in prison than at home . You 're cared for there , an ’ you do n't need to starve . I would n't have joined ‘ em , Gustav , if I could ha ’ let it be ; but once in a lifetime a man 's got to show what he feels .Goes slowly towards the door .Good-bye , Gustav . If anything happens , mind you put in a word for me in your prayers .

div.stage: Goes out .

The rioters are now all gone . The entry-room , gradually fills again with curious onlookers from the different rooms of the house . OLD HILSE knots at his web . GOTTLIEB has taken an axe from behind the stove and is unconsciously feeling its edge . He and the old man are silently agitated . The hum and roar of a great crowd penetrate into the room .

sp.speaker: MOTHER HILSE
sp.p: The very boards is shakin ’ , father — what 's goin ’ on ? What 's goin ’ to happen to us ?

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Gottlieb !

sp.speaker: GOTTLIEB
sp.p: What is it ?

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Let that axe alone .

sp.speaker: GOTTLIEB
sp.p: Who 's to split the wood , then ?

div.stage: He leans the axe against the stove .
Pause .

lg.l: Gottlieb , you listen , to what father says to you .
lg.stage: Some one sings outside the window :
lg.l: Our little man does all that he can ,
Heigh-ho , heigh !
At home he cleans the pots an ’ the pan ,
Heigh-diddle-di-dum-di !

div.stage: Passes on .

sp.speaker: GOTTLIEB
sp.p: Jumps up , shakes his clenched fist at the window .Beast ! Do n't drive me crazy !

div.stage: A volley of musketry is heard .

sp.speaker: MOTHER HILSE
sp.p: Starts and trembles .Good Lord ! Is that thunder again ?

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Instinctively folding his hands .Oh , our Father in heaven ! defend the poor weavers , protect my poor brothers .

div.stage: A short pause ensues .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: To himself , painfully agitated .There 's blood flowin ’ now .

sp.speaker: GOTTLIEB
sp.p: Had started up and grasped the axe when the shooting was heard ; deathly pale , almost beside himself with excitement .An ’ am I to lie to heel like a dog still ?

sp.speaker: A GIRL
sp.p: Calls from the entry-room .Father Hilse , father Hilse ! get away from the window . A bullet 's just flown in at ours upstairs .

div.stage: Disappears .

sp.speaker: MIELCHEN
sp.p: Puts her head in at the window , laughing .Gran'father , gran'father , they 've shot with their guns . Two or three 's been knocked down , an ’ one of ‘ em 's turnin ’ round and round like a top , an ’ one 's twistin ’ hisself like a sparrow when its head 's bein ’ pulled of . An ’ oh , if you saw all the blood that came pourin ’ —!Disappears .A WEAVER 'S WIFE Yes , there 's two or three 'll never get up again .

sp.speaker: AN OLD WEAVER
sp.p: In the entry-room .Look out ! They 're goin ’ to make a rush on the soldiers . A SECOND WEAVERWildly .Look , look , look at the women ! skirts up , an ’ spittin ’ in the soldiers ’ faces already ! A WEAVER 'S WIFE

div.stage: Calls in . ] Gottlieb , look at your wife . She 's more pluck in her than you . She 's jumpin ’ about in front o ’ the bay'nets as if she was dancin ’ to music .

Four men carry a wounded rioter through the entry-room . Silence , which is broken by some one saying in a distinct voice , “ It 's weaver Ulbrich . ” Once more silence for a few seconds , when the same voice is heard again : “ It 's all over with him ; he 's got a bullet in his ear . ” The men are heard climbing the wooden stair . Sudden shouting outside : “ Hurrah , hurrah ! ”

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE ENTRY-ROOM
sp.p: “ Where did they get the stones from ? ” — “ Yes , it 's time you were off ! ” — “ From the new road . ” — “ Ta-ta , soldiers ! ” — “ It 's rainin ’ paving-stones . ”

div.stage: Shrieks of terror and loud roaring outside , taken up by those in the entry-room . There is a cry of fear , and the house door is shut with a bang .

sp.speaker: VOICES IN THE ENTRY-ROOM
sp.p: “ They 're loadin ’ again . ” — “ They 'll fire another volley this minute . ” — “ Father Hilse , get away from that window . ”

sp.speaker: GOTTLIEB
sp.p: Clutches the axe .What ! is we mad dogs ? Is we to eat powder an ’ shot now instead o ’ bread ?Hesitating an instant to the old man .Would you have me sit here an ’ see my wife shot ? Never !As he rushes out .Look out ! I 'm coming !

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Gottlieb , Gottlieb !

sp.speaker: MOTHER HILSE
sp.p: Where 's Gottlieb gone ?

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: He 's gone to the devil .

sp.speaker: VOICES FROM THE ENTRY-ROOM
sp.p: Go away from the window , father Hilse .

sp.speaker: OLD HILSE
sp.p: Not I ! Not if you all goes crazy together !To MOTHER HILSE , with rapt excitement .My heavenly Father has placed me here . Is n't that so , mother ? Here we 'll sit , an ’ do our bounden duty — ay , though the snow was to go on fire .

div.stage: He begins to weave .

Rattle of another volley . OLD HILSE , mortally wounded , starts to his feet and then falls forward over the loom . At the same moment loud shouting of “ Hurrah ! ” is heard . The people who till now have been standing in the entry-room dash out , joining in the cry . The old woman repeatedly asks : “ Father , father , what 's wrong with you ? ” The continued shouting dies away gradually in the distance . MIELCHEN comes rushing in .

sp.speaker: MIELCHEN
sp.p: Gran'father , gran'father , they 're drivin ’ the soldiers out o ’ the village ; they 've got into Dittrich 's house , an ’ they 're doin ’ what they did at Dreissiger 's . Gran'father !The child grows frightened , notices that something has happened , puts her finger in her mouth , and goes up cautiously to the dead man .Gran'father !

sp.speaker: MOTHER HILSE
sp.p: Come now , father , can n't you say something ? You 're frightenin ’ me .

lg.l: THE BEAVER COAT
A THIEVES ’ COMEDY

sp.speaker: LIST OF CHARACTERS
sp.p: VON WEHRHAHN , Justice .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER , Capitalist in a small way
sp.p: DR. FLEISCHER .

sp.speaker: PHILIP , his son
sp.p: MOTES .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: MRS. WOLFF , Washerwoman .

sp.speaker: JULIUS WOLFF , her husband
sp.p: LEONTINE , ADELAIDE , her daughters .

sp.speaker: WULKOW , Lighterman
sp.p: GLASENAPP , Clerk in the Justice 's court .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF , Constable
sp.p: Scene of the action : anywhere in the neighbourhood of Berlin .

sp.speaker: THE FIRST ACT
sp.p: A small , blue-tinted kitchen with low ceiling ; a window at the left ; at the right a door of rough boards leading out into the open ; in the rear mall an empty casing from which the door has been lifted .— In the left corner a flat oven , above which hang kitchen utensils in a wooden frame ; in the right corner oars and other boating implements . Rough , stubby pieces of hewn wood lie in a heap under the window . An old kitchen bench , several stools , etc .— Through the empty casing in the rear a second room is visible . In it stands a high , neatly , made bed ; above it hang cheap photographs in still cheaper frames , small chromolithographs , etc . A chair of soft mood stands with its back against the bed .— It is winter and moonlight . On the oven a tallow-candle is burning in a candle-stick of tin . LEONTINE WOLFF has fallen asleep on a stool by the oven and rests her head and arms on it . She is a pretty , fair girl of seventeen in the working garb of a domestic servant . A woolen shawl is tied over her cotton jacket .— For several seconds there is silence . Then someone is heard trying to unlock the door from without . But the key is in the lock and a knocking follows .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Unseen , from without .Adelaide ! Adelaide !There is no answer and a loud knocking is heard at the window .Are you goin ’ to open or not ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Drowsily .No , no , I 'm not goin ’ to be abused that way !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Open , girl , or I 'll come in through the window !

div.stage: She raps violently at the panes .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Waking up .Oh , it 's you , mama ! I 'm coming now !

div.stage: She unlocks the door from within .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Without laying down a sack which she carries over her shoulder .What are you doin ’ here ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Sleepily .Evenin ’ , mama .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: How did you get in here , eh ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Well , was n't the key lyin ’ on the goat shed ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: But what do you want here at home ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Awkwardly affected and aggrieved .So you do n't want me to come no more at all ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Aw , you just go ahead and put on that way ! I 'm so fond o ’ that !She lets the sack drop from her shoulder .You do n't know nothin ’ , I s'ppose , about how late it 's gettin ’ ? You hurry and go back to your mistress .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: It matters a whole lot , do n't it , if I get back there a little too late ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You want to be lookin ’ out , y'understand ? You see to it that you go , or you 'll catch it !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Tearfully and defiantly .I ai n't goin ’ back to them people no more , mama !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Astonished .Not goin ’ ?...Ironically .Oh , no ! That 's somethin ’ quite new !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Well , I do n't have to let myself be abused that way !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Busy extracting a piece of venison from the sack .So the Kruegers abuse you , do they ? Aw , the poor child that you are !— Do n't you come round me with such fool talk ! A wench like a dragoon ...! Here , lend a hand with this sack , at the bottom . You can n't act more like a fool , eh ? You wo n't get no good out o ’ me that way ! You can n't learn lazyin ’ around , here , at all .They hang up the venison on the door .Now I tell you for the last time ....

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: I ai n't goin ’ back to them people , I tell you . I 'd jump in the river first !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: See that you do n't catch a cold doin ’ it .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: I 'll jump in the river !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Go ahead . Let me know about it and I 'll give you a shove so you do n't miss it .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Screaming .Do I have to stand for that , that I gotta drag in two loads o ’ wood at night !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: In mock astonishment .Well , now , that 's pretty awful , ai n't it ? You gotta drag in wood ? Such people , I tell you !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: An ’ I gets twenty crowns for the whole year . I 'm to get my hands frost-bitten for that , am I ? An ’ not enough potatoes and herring to go round !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You need n't go fussin ’ about that , you silly girl . Here 's the key ; go , cut yourself some bread . An ’ when you 've had enough , go your way , y'understand ? The plum butter 's in the top cupboard .

lg.stage: Takes a large loaf of bread from a drawer and cuts some slices .
lg.l: An ’
Juste gets forty crowns a year from the Schulze 's an ’ ....

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do n't you try to be goin ’ too fast .— You ai n't goin ’ to stay with them people always ; you ai n't hired out to ‘ em forever .— Leave ‘ em on the first of April , for all I care .— But up to then , you sticks to your place .— Now that you got your Christmas present in your pocket , you want to run away , do you ? That 's no way . I have dealin 's with them people , an ’ I ai n't goin ’ to have that kind o ’ thing held against me .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: These bits o ’ rag that I got on here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 're forgettin ’ the cash you got ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Yes ! Six shillin 's . That was a whole lot !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Cash is cash ! You need n't kick .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: But if I can go an ’ make more ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Yes , talkin ’ !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: No , sewin ’ ! I can go in to Berlin and sew cloaks . Emily Stechow 's been doin ’ that ever since New Year .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do n't come tellin ’ me about that slattern ! I 'd like to get my hands on her , that 's all . I 'd give that crittur a piece o ’ my mind ! You 'd like to be promoted into her class , would you ? To go sportin ’ all night with the fellows ? Just to be thinkin ’ o ’ that makes me feel that I 'd like to beat you so you can n't hardly stand up .— Now papa 's comin ’ an ’ you 'd better look out !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: If papa thrashes me , I 'll run away . I 'll see how I can get along !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Shut up now ! Go an ’ feed the goats . They ai n't been milked yet to-night neither . An ’ give the rabbits a handful o ’ hay .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE tries to make her escape . In the door , however , she runs
sp.p: into her father , but slips quickly by him with a perfunctory Evenin ’ .

sp.speaker: JULIUS WOLFF , the father , is a shipwright . A tall man , with dull
sp.p: eyes and slothful gestures , about forty-three years old .— He places two long oars , which he has brought in across his shoulder in a corner and silently throws down his shipwright 's tools .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Did you meet Emil ?

lg.l: MRS. WOLFF
Ca n't you talk ? Yes or no ? Is he goin ’ to come around , eh ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Irritated .Go right ahead ! Scream all you want to !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 're a fine , brave fellow , ai n't you ? An ’ all the while you forget to shut the door .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Closes the door .What 's up again with Leontine ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Aw , nothin ’ .— What kind of a load did Emil have ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Bricks again . What d'you suppose he took in ?— But what 's up with that girl again ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Did he have half a load or a whole load ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Flying into a rage .What 's up with the wench , I asks you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Outdoing him in violence .An ’ I want to know how big a load Emil had — a half or a whole boat full ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: That 's right ! Go on ! The whole thing full .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Sst ! Julius !

div.stage: Suddenly frightened she shoots the window latch .

lg.stage: Scared and staring at her , is silent . After a few moments , softly .
lg.l: It 's a young forester from Rixdorf .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Go an ’ creep under the bed , Julius .After a pause .If only you was n't such an awful fool . You do n't open your mouth but what you act like a regular tramp . You do n't understand nothin ’ o ’ such things , if you want to know it . You let me look out for the girls . That ai n't no part o ’ your concern . That 's a part of my concern . With boys that 'd be a different thing . I would n't so much as give you advice . But everybody 's got their own concerns .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Then do n't let her come runnin ’ straight across my way .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I guess you want to beat her till she can n't walk . Do n't you take nothin ’ like that into your head . Do n't you think I 'm goin ’ to allow anythin ’ like that ! I let her be beaten black an ’ blue ? We c'n make our fortune with that girl . I wish you had sense about some things !

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , then let her go an ’ see how she gets along !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Nobody need n't be scared about that , Julius . I ai n't sayin ’ but what you 'll live to see things . That girl will be livin ’ up on the first floor some day and we 'll be glad to have her condescend to know us . What is it the doctor said to me ? Your daughter , he says , is a handsome girl ; she 'd make a stir on the stage .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Then let her see about gettin ’ there .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You got no education , Julius . Yon ai n't got a trace of it . Lord , if it had n't been for me ! What would ha ’ become o ’ those girls ! I brought ‘ em up to be educated , y'understand ? Education is the main thing these days . But things do n't come off all of a sudden . One thing after another — step by step . Now she 's in service an ’ that 'll learn her somethin ’ . Then maybe , for my part , she can go into Berlin . She 's much too young for the stage yet .During MRS. WOLFF 'S speech repeated knocking has been heard . Now ADELAIDE 'S voice comes in . Mama ! Mama ! Please , do open ! MRS. WOLFF opens the door , ADELAIDE comes in . She is a somewhat overgrown schoolgirl of fourteen with a pretty , child-like face . The expression of her eyes , however , betrays premature corruption .Why did n't you open the door , mama ? I nearly got my hands and feet frozen !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do n't stand there jabberin ’ nonsense . Light a fire in the oven and you 'll soon be warm . Where 've you been all this long time , anyhow ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Why , did n't I have to go and fetch the boots for father ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ you staid out two hours doin ’ it !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Well , I did n't start to go till seven .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , you went at seven , did you ? It 's half past ten now . You do n't know that , eh ? So you 've been gone three hours an ’ a half . That ai n't much . Oh , no . Well now you just listen good to what I 've got to tell you . If you go an ’ stay that long again , and specially with that lousy cobbler of a Fielitz — then watch out an ’ see ! That 's all I says .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Oh , I guess I ai n't to do nothin ’ except just mope around at home .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Now you keep still an ’ do n't let me hear no more .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: An ’ even if I do go over to Fielitz 's sometime ....

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Are you goin ’ to keep still , I 'd like to know ? You teach me to know Fielitz ! He need n't be putting on 's far as I know . He 's got another trade exceptin ’ just repairin ’ shoes . When a man 's been twice in the penitentiary ....

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: That ai n't true at all .... That 's all just a set o ’ lies . He told me all about it himself , mama !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: As if the whole village did n't know , you fool girl ! That man ! I know what he is . He 's a pi —

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Oh , but he 's friends even with the justice !

sp.speaker: MRS WOLFF
sp.p: I do n't doubt it . He 's a spy . And what 's more , he 's a deenouncer !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: What 's that — a deenouncer ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: From the next room , into which he has gone .I 'm just waitin ’ to hear two words more .

div.stage: ADELAIDE turns pale and at once and silently she sets about building a fire in the oven .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE comes in
sp.p: MRS. WOLFF

div.stage: Has opened the stag . She takes out the heart , liver , etc , and hands them to LEONTINE . ] There , hurry , wash that off . An ’ keep still , or somethin 'll happen yet .
LEONTINE , obviously intimidated , goes at her task . The girls whisper together .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Say , Julius . What are you doin ’ in there ? I guess you 'll go an ’ forget again . Did n't I tell you this mornin ’ about the board that 's come loose ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: What kind o ’ board ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You do n't know , eh ? Behind there , by the goat-shed . The wind loosened it las ’ night . You better get out there an ’ drive a few nails in , y'understand ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Aw , to-morrow mornin 'll be another day , too .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , no . Do n't take to thinkin ’ that way . We ai n't goin ’ to make that kind of a start — not we .JULIUS comes into the room growling .There , take , the hammer ! Here 's your nails ! Now hurry an ’ get it done .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: You 're a bit off ’ your head .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Calling out after him .When Wulkow comes what d'you want me to ask ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: About twelve shillin 's sure .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Contemptuously .Aw , twelve shillin 's .A pause .Now you just hurry so that papa gets his supper .

div.stage: A brief pause .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Looking at the stag .What 's that anyhow , mama ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: A stork .

div.stage: Both girls laugh .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: A stork , eh ? A stork ai n't got horns . I know what that is — that 's a stag !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , if you know why d'you go an ’ ask ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Did papa shoot it , mama ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's right ! Go and scream it through the village : Papa 's shot a stag !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I 'll take mighty good care not to . That 'd mean the cop !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Aw , I ai n't scared o ’ policeman Schulz . He chucked me under the chin onct .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: He c'n come anyhow . We ai n't doin ’ nothin ’ wrong . If a stag 's full o ’ lead and lays there dyin ’ an ’ nobody finds it , what happens ? The ravens eat it . Well now , if the ravens eat it or we eat it , it 's goin ’ to be eaten anyhow .A brief pause .Well now , tell me : You was axed to carry wood in ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Yes , in this frost ! Two loads o ’ regular clumps ! An ’ that when a person is tired as a dog , at half past nine in the evenin ’ !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ now I suppose that wood is lyin ’ there in the street ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: It 's lyin ’ in front o ’ the garden gate . That 's all I know .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well now , but supposin ’ somebody goes and steals that wood ? What 's goin ’ to happen in the mornin ’ then ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: I ai n't goin ’ there no more !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Are those clumps green or dry ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: They 're fine , dry ones !She yawns again and again .Oh , mama , I 'm that tired ! I 've just had to work myself to pieces .

div.stage: She sits down with every sign of utter exhaustion .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: After a brief silence .You c'n stay at home tonight for all I care . I 've thought it all out a bit different . An ’ to-morrow mornin ’ we c'n see .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: I 've just got as thin as can be , mama ! My clothes is just hangin ’ on to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You hurry now and go in to bed or papa 'll raise a row yet . He ai n't got no understandin ’ for things like that .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Papa always speaks so uneducated !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , he did n't learn to have no education . An ’ that 'd be just the same thing with you if I had n't brought you up to be educated .Holding a saucepan over the oven : to LEONTINE :Come now , put it in !LEONTINE places the pieces of washed venison into the sauce-pan .So , now go to bed .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Goes into the next room . While she is still visible , she says :Oh , mama , Motes has moved away from Krueger .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I guess he did n't pay no rent .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: It was just like pullin ’ a tooth every time , Mr. Krueger says , but he paid . Anyhow , he says , he had to kick him out . He 's such a lyin ’ loudmouthed fellow , and always so high and mighty toward Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: If I had been in Mr. Krueger 's place I would n't ha ’ kept him that long .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Because Mr. Krueger used to be a carpenter onct , that 's why Motes always acts so contemptuous . And then , too , he quarrelled with Dr. Fleischer .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , anybody that 'll quarrel with him ...! I ai n't sayin ’ anythin ’ , but them people would n't harm a fly !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: They wo n't let him come to the Fleischers no more .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: If you could get a chanct to work for them people some day !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: They treat the girls like they was their own children .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: And his brother in Berlin , he 's cashier in a theatre .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Has knocked at the door repeatedly and now calls out in a hoarse voice .Ai n't you goin ’ to have the kindness to let me in .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , I should say ! Why not ! Walk right in !

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Comes in . He is a lighterman on the Spree river , near sixty years old , bent , with a greyish-yellow beard that frames his head from ear to ear but leaves his weather-beaten face free .I wish you a very good evenin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Look at him comin ’ along again to take in a woman a little bit .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I 've give up tryin ’ that this long while !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Maybe , but that 's the way it 's goin ’ to be anyhow .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: T'other way roun ’ , you mean .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What 'll it be next ?— Here it 's hangin ’ ! A grand feller , eh ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I tell you , Julius ought to be lookin ’ out sharp . They 's gettin ’ to be pretty keen again .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What are you goin ’ to give us for it , that 's the main thing . What 's the use o ’ jabberin ’ ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Well , I 'm tellin ’ you . I 'm straight from Gruenau . An ’ there I heard it for certain . They shot Fritz Weber . They just about filled his breeches with lead .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What are you goin ’ to give ? That 's the main thing .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Feeling the stag .The trouble is I got four o ’ them bucks lyin ’ at home now .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That ai n't goin ’ to make your boat sink .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: An ’ I do n't want her to do that . That would n't be no joke . But what 's the good if I get stuck with the things here . I 've gotta get ‘ em in to Berlin . It 's been hard enough work on the river all day , an ’ if it goes on freezin ’ this way , there 'll be no gettin ’ along to-morrow . Then I c'n sit in the ice with my boat , an ’ then I 've got these things for fun .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Apparently changing her mind .Girl , you run down to Schulze . Say how-dee-do an ’ he 's to come up a while , cause mother has somethin ’ to sell .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Did I say as I was n't goin ’ to buy it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It 's all the same to me who buys it .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Well , I 'm willin ’ to .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Any one that do n't want it can let it be .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I 'll buy this feller ! What 's he worth ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Touching the venison .This here piece weighs a good thirty pounds . Every bit of it , I c'n tell you . Well , Adelaide ! You was here . We could hardly lift it up .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Who had not been present at all .I pretty near sprained myself liftin ’ it .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Thirteen shillin 's will pay for it , then . An ’ I wo n't be makin ’ ten pence on that bargain !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Acts amazed . She busies herself at the oven as though she had forgotten WULKOW 'S presence . Then , as though suddenly becoming aware of it again , she says :I wish you a very pleasant trip .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Well . I can n't give more than thirteen !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's right . Let it alone .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I 'm just buyin ’ it for the sake o ’ your custom . God strike me dead , but it 's as true as I 'm standin ’ here . I do n't make that much with the whole business . An ’ even if I was wantin ’ to say : fourteen , I 'd be puttin ’ up money , I 'd be out one shillin ’ . But I ai n't goin ’ to let that stand between us . Just so you see my good intentions , I 'll say fourteen .... I can n't give no more . I 'm tellin ’ you facts .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's all right ! That 's all right ! We c'n get rid o ’ this stag . We wo n't have to keep it till morning .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Yes , if only nobody do n't see it hangin ’ here . Money would n't do no good then .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: This stag here , we found it dead .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Yes , in a trap . I believe you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You need n't try to get around us that way . That ai n't goin ’ to do no good ! You want to gobble up everythin ’ for nothin ’ ! We works till we got no breath . Hours an ’ hours soakin ’ in the snow , not to speak o ’ the risk , there in the pitch dark . That 's no joke , I tell you .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: The only trouble is that I got four of ‘ em already . Or I 'd say fifteen shillin 's quick enough .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , Wulkow , we can n't do business together today . You c'n be easy an ’ go a door further . We just dragged ourselves across the lake ... a hairbreadth an ’ we would 've been stuck in the ice . We could n't get forward an ’ we could n't get backward . You can n't give away somethin ’ you got so hard .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Well , what do I get out of it all , I want to know ! This here lighter business ai n't a natural thing . An ’ poachin ’ , that 's a bad job . If you all get nabbed , I 'd be the first one to fly in . I been worryin ’ along these forty years . What 've I got to-day ? The rheumatiz — that 's what ! When I get up o ’ mornin 's early , I gotta whine like a puppy dog . Years an ’ years I been wantin ’ to buy myself a fur-coat . That 's what all doctors has advised me to do , because I 'm that sensitive . But I ai n't been able to buy me none . Not to this day . An ’ that 's as true as I 'm standin ’ here .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: To her mother .Did you hear what Leontine said ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: But anyhow . Let it go . I 'll say sixteen .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , it 's no good . Eighteen !To ADELAIDE .What 's that you was talkin ’ about ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Mrs. Krueger has bought a fur-coat that cost pretty near a hundred crowns . It 's a beaver coat .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: A beaver coat ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Who bought it ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Why , Mrs. Krueger , I tell you , as a Christmas present for Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Is that girl in service with the Kruegers ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Not me , but my sister , I ai n't goin ’ in service like that at all .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Well now , if I could have somethin ’ like that ! That 's the kind o ’ thing I been tryin ’ to get hold of all this time . I 'd gladly be givin ’ sixty crowns for it . All this money that goes to doctors and druggists , I 'd much rather spend it for furs . I 'd get some pleasure out of that at least .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: All you gotta do is to go there , Wulkow . Maybe Kruger 'll make you a present of the coat .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I do n't suppose he 'd do it kindly . But 's I said : I 'm interested in that sort o ’ thing .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I believes you . I would n't mind havin ’ a thing like that myself .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: How do we stand now ? Sixteen ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Nothin ’ less'n eighteen 'll do . Not under eighteen — that 's what Julius said . I would n't dare show up with sixteen . No , sir . When that man takes somethin ’ like that into his head !JULIUS comes in .Well , Julius , you said eighteen shillin 's , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: What 's that I said ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Are you hard o ’ hearin ’ again for a change ? You said yourself : not under eighteen . You told me not to sell the stag for less .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I said ?... Oh , yes , that there piece o ’ venison ! That 's right . H-m. An ’ that ai n't a bit too much ; either .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Taking ’ out money and counting it .We 'll make an end o ’ this . Seventeen shillin 's . Is it a bargain ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 're a great feller , you are ! That 's what I said exactly : he do n't hardly have to come in the door but a person is taken in !

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Has unrolled a sack which had been hidden about his person .Now help me shoot it right in here .MRS. WOLFF helps him place the venison in the sack .An ’ if by some chanst you should come to hear o ’ somethin ’ like that — what I means is , just f'r instance — a — fur coat like that , f'r instance . Say , sixty or seventy crowns . I could raise that , an ’ I would n't mind investin ’ it .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I guess you ai n't right in your head ...! How should we come by a coat like that ?

sp.speaker: A MAN 'S VOICE
sp.p: Calls from without .Mrs. Wolff ! Oh , Mrs. Wolff ! Are you still up ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Sharing the consternation of the others , rapidly , tensely .Slip it in ! Slip it in ! And get in the other room !

div.stage: She crowds them all into the rear room and locks the door .

sp.speaker: A MAN 'S VOICE
sp.p: Mrs. Wolff ! Oh , Mrs. Wolff ! Have you gone to bed ?

lg.l: A MAN 'S VOICE
Mrs. Wolff ! Mrs. Wolff ! Are you still up ?
lg.stage: The voice recedes singing :
lg.l: “ Morningre-ed , morningre-ed ,
Thou wilt shine when I am dea-ead ! ”

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Aw , that 's only old “ Morningred , ” mama !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Listens for a while , opens the door softly and listens again . When she is satisfied she closes the door and lights the candle . Thereupon she admits the others again .‘ Twas only the constable Mitteldorf .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: The devil , you say . That 's nice acquaintances for you to have .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Go on about your way now ! Hurry !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Mama , Mino has been barkin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Hurry , hurry , Wulkow ! Get out now ! An ’ the back way through the vegetable garden ! Julius will open for you . Go on , Julius , an ’ open the gate .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: An 's I said , if somethin ’ like such a beaver coat was to turn up , why —

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Sure . Just make haste now .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: If the Spree do n't freeze over , I 'll be gettin ’ back in , say , three or four days from Berlin . An ’ I 'll be lyin ’ with my boat down there .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: By the big bridge ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Where I always lies . Well , Julius , toddle ahead !

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Mama , Mino has been barkin ’ again .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: At the oven .Oh , let him bark !

div.stage: A long-drawn call is heard in the distance . “ Ferry over ! ”

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Somebody wants to get across the river , mama !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , go'n tell papa . He 's down there by the river .—“ Ferry over ! ”An ’ take him his oars . But he ought to let Wulkow get a bit of a start first .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE goes out with the oars . For a little while MRS. WOLFF is
sp.p: alone . She marks energetically . Then ADELAIDE returns .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Papa 's got his oars down in the boat .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Who wants to get across the river this time o ’ night ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I believe , mama , it 's that stoopid Motes !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What ? Who is't you say ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I think the voice was Motes 's voice .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Vehemently .Go down ! Ran ! Tell papa to come up ! That fool Motes can stay on the other side . He do n't need to come sniffin ’ around in the house here .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE exits . MRS. WOLFF hides and clears away everything that
sp.p: could in any degree suggest the episode of the stag . She covers the sauce-pan with an apron . ADELAIDE comes back .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Mama , I got down there too late . I hear ‘ em talkin ’ a'ready .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , who is it then ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I 've been tellin ’ you : Motes .

sp.speaker: MR. and MRS. MOTES appear in turn in the doorway . Both are of medium
sp.p: height . She is an alert young woman of about thirty , modestly and neatly dressed . He wears a green forester 's overcoat ; his face is healthy but insignificant ; his left eye is concealed by a black bandage .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Calls in .We nearly got our noses frozen , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Why do you go walkin ’ at night . You got time enough when it 's bright day .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: It 's nice and warm here .— Who 's that who has time by day ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Why , you !

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I suppose you think I live on my fortune .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I do n't know ; I ai n't sayin ’ what you live on .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Heavens , you need n't be so cross . We simply wanted to ask about our bill .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 've asked about that a good deal more'n once .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Very well . So we 're asking again . Anything wrong with that ? We have to pay sometime , you know ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Astonished .You wants to pay ?

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Of course , we do . Naturally .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: You act as if you were quite overwhelmed . Did you think we 'd run off without paying ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I ai n't given to thinkin ’ such things . If you want to be so good then . Here , we can arrange right now . The amount is eleven shillin 's , six pence .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Oh , yes . Mrs. Wolff . We 're going to get money . The people around here will open their eyes wide .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: There 's a smell of roasted hare here .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Burned hair ! That 'd be more likely .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Let 's take a look and see .

div.stage: He is about to take the cover from the sauce-pan .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Prevents him .No sniffin ’ ‘ round in my pots .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Who has observed everything distrustfully .Mrs. Wolff , we 've found something , too .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I ai n't lost nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: There , look at these .

div.stage: She shows her several wire snares .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Without losing her equanimity in the slightest .I suppose them are snares ?

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: We found them quite in the neighbourhood here ! Scarcely twenty paces from your garden .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Lord love you ! The amount of poachin ’ that 's done here !

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: If you were to keep a sharp lookout , you might actually catch the poacher some day .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Aw , such things is no concern o ’ mine .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: If I could just get hold of a rascal like that . First , I 'd give him something to remember me by , and then I 'd mercilessly turn him over to the police .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Mrs. Wolff have you got a few fresh eggs ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Now , in the middle of winter ? They 're pretty scarce !

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: To JULIUS , who has just come in .Forester Seidel has nabbed a poacher again . He 'll be taken to the detention prison to-morrow . There 's an officer with style about him . If I had n't had my misfortune , I could have been a head forester to-day . I 'd go after those dogs even more energetically .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: There 's many a one has had to pay for doin ’ that !

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Yes , if he 's afraid . I 'm not ! I 've denounced quite a few already .Fixing his gaze keenly on MRS. WOLFF and her husband in turn .And there are a few others whose time is coming . They 'll run straight into my grip some day . These setters of snares need n't think that I do n't know them . I know them very well .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Have you been baking , perhaps , Mrs. Wolff ? We 're so tired of baker 's bread .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I thought you was goin ’ to square your account .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: On Saturday , as I 've told you , Mrs. Wolff . My husband has been appointed editor of the magazine “ Chase and Forest . ”

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Aha , yes . I know what that means .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: But if I assure you , Mrs. Wolff ! We 've moved away from the Kruegers already .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Yes , you moved because you had to .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: We had to ? Hubby , listen to this !—She gives a forced laugh .— Mrs. Wolff says that we had to move from Kruegers .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Crimson with rage .The reason why I moved away from that place ? You 'll find it out some day . The man is a usurer and a cutthroat !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I do n't know nothin ’ about that ; I can n't say nothin ’ about that .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I 'm just waiting to get hold of positive proof . That , man had better be careful where I 'm concerned — he and his bosom friend , Dr. Fleischer . The latter more especially . If I just wanted to say it — one word and that man would be under lock and key .

div.stage: From the beginning of his speech on he has gradually withdrawn and speaks the last words from without .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I suppose the men got to quarrelin ’ again ?

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Apparently confidential .There 's no jesting with my husband . If he determines on anything , he does n't let go till it 's done . And he stands very well with the justice .— But how about the eggs and the bread ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Reluctantly .Well , I happen to have five eggs lyin ’ here . An ’ a piece o ’ bread .MRS. MOTES puts the eggs and the half of a loaf into her basket .Are you satisfied now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Certainly ; of course . I suppose the eggs are fresh ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: As fresh as my chickens can lay ‘ em .

sp.speaker: MRS. MOTES
sp.p: Hastening in order to catch up with her husband .Well , good-night . You 'll get your money next Saturday .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: All right ; that 'll be all right enough !She closes the door and speaks softly to herself .Get outta here , you ! Got nothin ’ but debts with everybody around .Over her sauce-pan .What business o ’ theirs is it what we eat ? Let ‘ em spy into their own affairs . Go to bed , child !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Good night , mama .

div.stage: She kisses her .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , ai n't you goin ’ to kiss papa good-night ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Good night , papa .

div.stage: She kisses him , at which he growls . ADELAIDE , exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You always gotta say that to her special !

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Why do'you go an ’ give the eggs to them people ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I suppose you want me to make an enemy o ’ that feller ? You just go ahead an ’ get him down on you ! I tell you , that 's a dangerous feller . He ai n't got nothin ’ to do except spy on people . Come . Sit down . Eat . Here 's a fork for you . You do n't understand much about such things . You take care o ’ the things that belongs to you ! Did you have to go an ’ lay the snares right behind the garden ? They was yours , was n't they ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Annoyed .Go right ahead ! MRS. WOLFF An ’ , o ’ course , that fool of a Motes had to find ‘ em first thing . Here near the house you ai n't goin ’ to lay no more snares at all ! Y'understan ’ ? Next thing 'll be that people say we laid ‘ em .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Aw , you stop your jawin ’ .

div.stage: Both eat .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Look here , Julius , we 're out of wood , too .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: An ’ you want me to go this minute , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It 'd be best if we got busy right off .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I do n't feel my own bones no more . Anybody that wants to go c'n go . I ai n't .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You men folks always does a whole lot o ’ talkin ’ , an ’ when it comes to the point , you can n't do nothin ’ . I 'd work enough to put the crowd of you in a hole and drag you out again too . If you ai n't willin ’ to go to-night by no means , why , you 've got to go to-morrow anyhow . So what good is it ? How are the climbin ’ irons ? Sharp ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I loaned ‘ em to Karl Machnow .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: After a pause .If only you was n't such a coward !— We might get a few loads o ’ wood in a hurry , an ’ we would n't have to work ourselves blue in the face neither .— No , nor we would n't have to go very far for ‘ em .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Aw , let me eat a bite , will you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Punches his head amicably .Do n't always be so rough , I 'm goin ’ to be good to you now for onct . You watch .Fetching a bottle of whiskey and showing it to him .Here ! See ? I brought that for you . Now you c'n make a friendly face , all right .

div.stage: She fills a glass for her husband .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Drinks .That 's fine — in this cold weather — fine .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , you see ? Do n't I take care o ’ you ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: That was pretty good , pretty good all right .

div.stage: He fills the glass anew and drinks .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: After a pause . She is splitting kindling wood and eating a bite now and then .Wulkow — that feller — he 's a regular rascal —. He always — acts — as if he was hard up .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Aw , he 'd better shut up — he with his trade !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You heard that about the beaver coat , did n't you ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Naw , I did n't hear nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: With assumed carelessness .Did n't you hear the girl tell how Mrs. Krueger has given Krueger a fur coat ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , them people has the money .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's true . An ’ then Wulkow was sayin ’ ... you musta heard ... that if he could get hold of a coat like that some day , he 'd give as much as a seventy crowns for it .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: You just let him go and get into trouble his own self .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: After a pause , refilling her husband 's glass .Come now , you c'n stand another .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , go ahead , go ahead ! What in ...!

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF gets out a little note book and turns over the leaves

lg.l: JULIUS
How much is it we put aside since July ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: About thirty crowns has been paid off .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: An ’ that 'll leave ... leave ...

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 'll still leave seventy . You do n't get along very fast this way . Fifty , sixty crowns — all in a lump ; if you could add that onct ! Then the lot would be paid for all right . Then maybe we could borrow a couple o ’ hundred and build up a few pretty rooms . We can n't take no summer boarders like this an ’ it 's the summer boarders what brings the money .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , go ahead ! What are you ...

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Resolutely .My , but you 're a slow crittur , Julius ! Would you 've gone an ’ bought that lot ? An ’ if we wanted to go an ’ sell it now , we could be gettin ’ twice over what we paid for it ! I got a different kind of a nature ! Lord , if you had one like it !

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I 'm workin ’ all right . What 's the good o ’ all that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You ai n't goin ’ to get very far with all your work .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , I can n't steal . I can n't go an ’ get into trouble !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 're just stoopid , an ’ that 's the way you 'll always be . Nobody here ai n't been talkin ’ o ’ stealin ’ . But if you do n't risk nothin ’ , you do n't get nothin ’ . An ’ when onct you 're rich , Julius , an ’ c'n go and sit in your own carridge , there ai n't nobody what 's goin ’ to ask where you got it ! Sure , if we was to take it from poor people ! But now suppose really — suppose we went over to the Kruegers and put the two loads o ’ wood on a sleigh an ’ took ‘ em into our shed — them people ai n't no poorer on that account !

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Wood ? What you startin ’ after again now with wood ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Now that shows how you do n't take notice o ’ nothin ’ ! They c'n work your daughter till she drops ; they c'n try an ’ make her drag in wood at ten o'clock in the evenin ’ . That 's why she run away . An ’ you take that kind o ’ thing an ’ say thank you . Maybe you 'd give the child a hidin ’ and send her back to the people .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Sure !— That 's what !— What d'you think ...

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Things like that had n't ought to go unpunished . If anybody hits me , I 'll hit him back . That 's what I says .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , did they go an ’ hit the girl ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Why should she be runnin ’ away , Julius ? But no , there ai n't no use tryin ’ to do anything with you . Now the wood is lyin ’ out there in the alley . An ’ if I was to say : all right , you abuse my children , I 'll take your wood — a nice face you 'd make .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I would n't do no such thing ... I do n't give a —! I c'n do more'n eat , too . I 'd like to see ! I would n't stand for nothin ’ like that . Beatin ’ !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , then , do n't talk so much . Go an ’ get your cord . Show them people that you got some cuteness ! The whole thing will be over in an hour . Then we c'n go to bed an ’ it 's all right . An ’ you do n't have to go out in the woods to-morrow . We 'll have more fuel than we need .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , if it leaks out , it 'll be all the same to me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: There ai n't no reason why it should . But do n't wake the girls .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: From without .Mrs. Wolff ! Mrs. Wolff ! Are you still up ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Sure , Mitteldorf ! Come right in !

div.stage: She opens the door .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Enters . He has an overcoat over his shabby uniform . His face has a Mephistophelian cast . His nose betrays an alcoholic colouring . His demeanour is gentle , almost timid . His speech is slow and dragging and unaccompanied by any change in expression .Good evenin ’ , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I guess you mean to say : Good night !

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: I was around here once before a while ago . First I thought I saw a light , an ’ then , all of a sudden , it was dark again . Nobody did n't answer me neither . But this time there was a light an ’ no mistake ; an ’ so I came back once more .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , what have you got for me now , Mitteldorf ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Has taken a seat , thinks a while and then says :That 's what I came here for . I got a message for you from the justice 's wife .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She ai n't wantin ’ me to do washin ’ ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Raises his eye-brows thoughtfully .That she does .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ when ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: To-morrow .— To-morrow mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ you come in tellin ’ me that twelve o'clock at night ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: But to-morrow is the missis ’ wash day .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: But a person ought to know that a few days ahead o ’ time .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: That ’ a fac ’ . But do n't go makin ’ a noise . I just plumb forgot all about it again . I got so many things to think of with my poor head , that sometimes I just naturally forgets things .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , Mitteldorf , I 'll try an ’ arrange it . We always was good friends . You got enough on your shoulders , I suppose , with them twelve children o ’ yours at home , eh ? You ai n't got no call to make yourself out worse'n you are .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: If you do n't come in the mornin ’ , I 'll have a pretty tough time of it !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I 'll come . You need n't go worryin ’ . There , take a drink . I guess you need it this weather .She gives him a glass of toddy .I just happened to have a bit o ’ hot water . You know , we gotta take a trip yet to-night — for fat geese over to Treptow . You do n't get no time in the day . That can n't be helped in this kind of a life . Poor people is got to work themselves sick day an ’ night , an ’ rich people lies in bed snorin ’ .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: I been given notice . Did you know that ? The justice has given me notice . I ai n't keen enough after the people .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: They wants you to be like an old watch dog , I suppose .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: I 'd rather not go home at all . When I gets there , it 'll be nothin ’ but quarrelin ’ . She just drives me crazy with her reproaches .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Put your fingers in your ears !

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: An ’ then a man goes to the tavern a bit , so that the worries do n't down him altogether ; an ’ now he ai n't to do that no more neither ! He ai n't to do nothin ’ . An ’ now I just come from a bit of a time there . A feller treated to a little keg .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You ai n't goin ’ to be scared of a woman ? If she scolds , scold harder ; an ’ if she beats you , beat her back . Come here now — you 're taller'n me — get me down them things off the shelf . An ’ Julius , you get the sleigh ready !JULIUS exit .How often have I got to tell you ?MITTELDORF has taken cords and pulley lines front the high shelf on the wall .Get ready the big sleigh ! You c'n hand them cords right down to him .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: From without .I can n't see !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What can n't you do ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Appears in the doorway .I can n't get that sleigh out alone ! Everythin ’ is all mixed up in a heap here . An ’ there ai n't nothin ’ to be done without a light .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Now you 're helpless again — like always .Rapidly she puts shawls about her head and chest .You must wait , I 'll come an ’ lend a hand . There 's the lantern , Mitteldorf .MITTELDORF slowly takes a lantern and hands it to MRS. WOLFF .There ! thank you .She puts the burning candle into the lantern .We 'll put that in here an ’ then we c'n go . Now I 'll help you drag out the sleigh .She goes ahead with the lantern . MITTELDORF follows her . In the door she turns around and hands the lantern to MITTELDORF .You c'n come an ’ hold the light for us a bit !

lg.stage: Holding the light and humming to himself :
lg.l: “ Morningre-ed , morningre-ed ... ”

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE SECOND ACT Court room of Justice VON WEHRHAHN . A great , bare , white-washed room with three windows in the rear wall . The main door is in the left wall . Along the wall to the right stands the long official table covered with books , legal documents , etc . ; behind it the chair of the justice . Near the centre window are the clerk 's chair and table . To the right is a bookcase of white wood , so arranged that it is within reach of the justice when he sits in his chair . The left wall is hidden by cases containing documents . In the foreground , beginning at the wall to the left , six chairs stand in a row . Their occupants would be seen by the spectator from behind .— It is a bright forenoon in Winter . The clerk GLASENAPP sits scribbling at his table . He is a poverty-stricken , spectacled person . Justice VON WEHRHAHN , carrying a roll of documents under his arm , enters rapidly . WEHRHAHN is about forty years old and wears a monocle . He makes the impression of a son of the landed nobility of Prussia . His official garb consists of a buttoned , black walking coat , and very tall boots put on over his trousers . He speaks in what is almost a falsetto voice and carefully cultivates a military brevity of expression .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: By the way , like one crushed by the weight of affairs .Mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Servant , sir .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Anything happened , Glasenapp ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Standing and looking through some papers .I 've got to report , your honour — there was first , oh , yes ,— the innkeeper Fiebig . He begs for permission , your honour , to have music and dancing at his inn next Sunday .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Is n't that ... perhaps you can tell me . Fiebig ? There was some one who recently rented his hall ...?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: To the liberals . Quite right , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: This same Fiebig ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Yes , my lord .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: We 'll have to put a check-rein on him for a while . The constable MITTELDORF enters .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Servant , my lord .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Listen here : once and for all — officially I am simply the justice .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Yes , sir . As you wish , my — your honour , I meant to say .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I wish you would try to understand this fact : my being a baron is purely by the way . Is not , at all events , to be considered here .To GLASENAPP .Now I 'd like to hear further , please . Was n't the author Motes here ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Yes , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Aha ! So he was here ! I confess that I am very curious . I hope that it was his intention to come back ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: He intended to be back here about half past eleven .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Did he by any chance tell you anything ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: He came in the matter of Dr. Fleischer .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , now , you may as well tell me — are you acquainted with this Dr. Fleischer ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: All I know is that he lives in the Villa Krueger .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And how long has he been living in this place ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Well , I 've been here since Michaelmas .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To be sure , you came here at the same time with me ; about four months ago .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Looking toward MITTELDORF for information .From what I hear the man has been living here about two years .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To MITTELDORF .I do n't suppose you can give us any information ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Beggin ’ your pardon , he came Michaelmas a year ago .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: At that time he moved here ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Exactly , your honour — from Berlin .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Have you any more intimate information about this individual ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: All I know is his brother is cashier of a theatre .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I did n't ask for information concerning his brother ! What is his occupation ?— What does he himself do ? What is he ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: I do n't know as I can say anythin ’ particular . People do say that he 's sick . I suppose he suffers from diabetes .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I 'm quite indifferent as to the character of his malady . He can sweat syrup if it amuses him . What is he ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Shrugging his shoulders .He calls himself a free spear in scholarship .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Lance ! Lance ! Not spear ! A free lance .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: The bookbinder Hugk always does work for him ; he has some books bound every week .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I would n't mind seeing what an individual of that kind reads .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: The postman thinks he must take in about twenty newspapers . Democratic ones , too .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You may summon Hugk to this court some time .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Right away ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: No , at a more convenient time . To-morrow or the next day . Let him bring a few of the books in question with him .To MITTELDORF .You seem to take naps all day . Or perhaps the man has good cigars and knows how to invest them !

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Your honour ...!

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Never mind ! Never mind ! I will inspect the necessary persons myself . My honourable predecessor has permitted a state of affairs to obtain that ...! We will change all that by degrees — It is simply disgraceful for a police official to permit himself to be deceived by any one . That is , of course , entirely beyond your comprehension .To GLASENAPP .Did n't Motes say anything definite ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: I can n't say that he did — nothing definite . He was of the opinion that your honour was informed ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In a very general way , I am . I have had my eye on the man in question for some time — on this Dr. Fleischer I mean . Mr. Motes simply confirmed me in my own entirely correct judgment of his peculiar character .— What kind of a reputation has Motes himself ?GLASENAPP and MITTELDORF exchange glances and GLASENAPP shrugs his shoulders .Lives largely on credit , eh ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: He says he has a pension .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Pension ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Well , you know he got shot in the eye .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: So his pension is really paid as damages .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Beggin ’ your honour 's pardon , but if it 's a question of damages the man inflicts more than he 's ever received . Nobody 's ever seen him have a penny for anything .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Amused .Is there anything else of importance ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Nothing but minor matters , your honour — somebody giving notice —

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That 'll do ; that 'll do . Do you happen ever to have heard any reports to the effect that this Dr. Fleischer does not guard his tongue with particular care ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Not that I know of at this moment .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Because that is the information that has come to me . He is said to have made illegal remarks concerning a number of exalted personages . However , all that will appear in good time . We can set to work now . Mitteldorf , have you anything to report ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: They tell me that a theft has been committed during the night .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: A theft ? Where ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: In the Villa Krueger .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What has been stolen ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Some firewood .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Last night , or when ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Just last night .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: From whom does your information come ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: My information ? It come from ... from ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , from whom ? Out with it !

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: I heard it from — I got it from Dr. Fleischer .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Aha ! You 're in the habit then of conversing with him ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Mr. Krueger told me about it himself too .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: The man is a nuisance with his perpetual complaints . He writes me about three letters a week . Either he has been cheated , or some one has broken his fence , or else some one has trespassed on his property . Nothing but one annoyance after another .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Enters . He laughs almost continually in a nervous way .Beg to bid you a good morning , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Ah , there you are . Very glad you came in . You can help me out with some information at once . A theft is said to have been committed at the Villa Krueger .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I do n't live there any longer .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And nothing has come to your ears either ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Oh , I heard something about it , but nothing definite . As I was just passing by the Villa I saw them both looking for traces in the snow .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Is that so ? Dr. Fleischer is assisting him . I take it for granted then that they 're pretty thick together ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Inseparable in every sense , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Aha ! As far as Fleischer is concerned — he interests me most of all . Take a seat , please . I confess that I did n't sleep more than half the night . This matter simply would n't let me sleep . The letter that you wrote me excited me to an extraordinary degree .— That is a matter of temperament , to be sure . The slumbers of my predecessor would scarcely have been disturbed .— As far as I am concerned I have made up my mind , so to speak , to go the whole way .— It is my function here to make careful tests and to exterminate undesirable elements .— Under the protection of my honourable predecessor the sphere of our activity has become a receptacle for refuse of various kinds : lives that cannot bear the light — outlawed individuals , enemies of royalty and of the realm . These people must be made to suffer .— As for yourself , Mr. Motes , you are an author ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I write on subjects connected with forestry and game .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In the appropriate technical journals , I take it . A propos : do you manage to make a living that way ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: If one is well known , it can be done . I may gratefully say that I earn an excellent competency .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: So you are a forester by profession ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I studied at the academy , your honour , and pursued my studies in Eberswalde . Shortly before the final examinations I met with this misfortune ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Ah , yes ; I see you wear a bandage .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I lost an eye while hunting . Some bird shot flew into my right eye . The responsibility for the accident could not , unfortunately , be placed . And so I had to give up my career .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Then you do not receive a pension ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: No . But I have fought my way through pretty well now . My name is getting to be known in a good many quarters .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: H-m .— Are you by any chance acquainted with my brother-in-law ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Yes , indeed — Chief Forester von Wachsmann . I correspond a good deal with him and furthermore we are fellow members of the society for the breeding of pointers .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Somewhat relieved .Ah , so you are really acquainted with him ? I 'm very glad indeed to hear that . That makes the whole matter easier of adjustment and lays a foundation for mutual confidence . It serves to remove any possible obstacle .— You wrote me in your letter , you recall , that you had had the opportunity of observing this Dr. Fleischer . Now tell me , please , what you know .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Coughs .When I — about a year ago — took up my residence in the Villa Krueger , I had naturally no suspicion of the character of the people with whom I was to dwell under one roof .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Yon were acquainted with neither Krueger nor Fleischer ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: No ; but you know how things go . Living in one house with them I could n't keep to myself entirely .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And what kind of people visited the house ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: With a significant gesture .Ah !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I understand .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Tom , Dick and Harry — democrats , of course .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Were regular meetings held ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Every Thursday , so far as I could learn .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That will certainly bear watching .— And you no longer associate with those people ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: A point was reached where intercourse with them became impossible , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You were repelled , eh ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: The whole business became utterly repulsive to me .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: The unlawful atmosphere that obtained there , the impudent jeering at exalted personages — all that , I take it , you could no longer endure ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I stayed simply because I thought it might serve some good purpose .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: But finally you gave notice after all ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I moved out , yes , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And finally you made up your mind to —

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I considered it my duty —

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To lodge notice with the authorities .— I consider that very worthy in you .— So he used a certain kind of expression — we will make a record of all that later , of course — a certain kind of expression in reference to a personage whose exalted station demands our reverence .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: He certainly did that , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You would be willing , if necessary , to confirm that by oath .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I would be willing to confirm it .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In fact , you will be obliged to make such confirmation .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Yes , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Of course it would be best if we could procure an additional witness .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: I would have to look about . The trouble is , though , that the man is very prodigal of his money .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
