sp.p: Ah , just wait a minute . Krueger is coming in now . I will first attend to his business . At all events I am very grateful to you for your active assistance . One is absolutely dependent on such assistance if one desires to accomplish anything nowadays .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Enters hastily and excitedly .O Lord , O Lord ! Good day , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To MOTES .Pardon me just a moment .In an arrogant and inquisitorial tone to KRUEGER .What is it you want ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER is a small man , somewhat hard of hearing and nearly seventy
sp.p: years old . He is slightly bowed with age ; his left shoulder hangs somewhat . Otherwise he is still very vigorous and emphasises his remarks by violent gesticulations . He wears a fur cap which he is now holding in his hand , a brown winter overcoat and a thick woolen shawl around his neck .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Literally charged with rage , explodes :I 've been robbed , your honour .

div.stage: Getting his breath , he wipes the perspiration from his forehead with a handkerchief and , after the manner of people with impaired hearing , stares straight at the mouth of the justice .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Robbed , eh ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Already exasperated .Robbed is what I said . I have been robbed . Two whole loads of wood have been stolen from me .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Looking around at those present , half-smiling , says lightly :Not the least thing of that kind has happened here recently .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Putting his hand to his ear .What ? Not the slightest thing ? Then perhaps I came into this office for fun ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You need not become violent . What is your name , by the way ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Taken aback .My name ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Yes , your name !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: So my name is n't known to you ? I thought we had had the pleasure before .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Sorry . Ca n't say that I have a clear recollection . And that would n't matter officially anyhow .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Resignedly .My name is Krueger .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Capitalist by any chance ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: With extreme and ironic vehemence .Exactly — capitalist and houseowner here .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Identify yourself , please .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I — Identify myself ! My name is Krueger . I do n't think we need go to any further trouble . I 've been living here for thirty years . Every child in the place knows me .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: The length of your residence here does n't concern me . It is my business merely to ascertain your identity . Is this gentleman known to you — Mr. Motes ?

sp.speaker: MOTES half rises with an angry expression

lg.l: WEHRHAHN
Ah , yes , I understand . Kindly sit down . Well , Glasenapp ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Yes , at your service . It is Mr. Krueger all right .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Very well .— So you have been robbed of wood ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Of wood , exactly . Two loads of pine wood .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Did you have the wood stored in your shed ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Growing violent again .That 's quite a separate matter . That 's the substance of another complaint I have to make .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: With an ironic laugh and looking at the others .Still another one ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Nothing . You may go ahead with your statement . The wood , it appears , was not in your shed ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: The wood was in the garden , that is , in front of the garden .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In other words : it lay in the street .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: It lay in front of the garden on my property .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: So that any one could pick it up without further ado ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: And that is just the fault of the servant-girl . She was to take the wood in last night .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And it dropped out of her mind .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: She refused to do it . And when I insisted on her doing it , she ended by running away . I intend to bring suit against her parents . I intend to claim full damages .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You may do about that as you please . It is n't likely to help you very greatly .— Now is there any one whom you suspect of the theft ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: No . They 're all a set of thieves around here .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You will please to avoid such general imputations . You must surely be able to offer me a clue of some kind .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Well , you can n't expect me to accuse any one at random .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Who lives in your house beside yourself ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Dr. Fleischer .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: As if trying to recall something .Dr. Fleischer ? Dr. Fleischer ? Why , he is a — What is he , anyhow ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: He is a thoroughly learned man , that 's what he is — thoroughly learned .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And I suppose that you and he are very intimate with each other .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: That is my business , with whom I happen to be intimate . That has no bearing on the matter in hand , it seems to me .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: How is one to discover anything under such circumstances ? You must give me a hint , at least !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Must I ? Goodness , gracious me ! Must I ? Two loads of wood have been stolen from me ! I simply come to give information concerning the theft ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: But you must have a theory of some kind . The wood must necessarily have been stolen by somebody .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Wha .... Yes ... well , I did n't do it ! I of all people did n't do it !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: But my dear man ....

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Wha ...? My name is Krueger .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Interrupting and apparently bored .M-yes .— Well , Glasenapp , just make a record of the facts .— And now , Mr. Krueger , what 's this business about your maid ? The girl , you say , ran away ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Yes , that 's exactly what she did — ran off to her parents .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Do her parents live in this place ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Not having heard correctly .I 'm not concerned with her face .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I asked whether the parents of the girl live here ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: She 's the daughter of the washerwoman Wolff .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Wolff — the same one who 's washing for us today , Glasenapp ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: The same , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Shaking his head .Very strange indeed !— She 's a very honest and a very industrious woman .—To KRUEGER .Is that a fact ? Is she the daughter of the woman in question ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: She is the daughter of the washerwoman Wolff .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And has the girl come back ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Up to the present time the girl has not come back .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Then suppose we call in Mrs. Wolff herself . Mitteldorf ! You act as though you were very tired . Well , go across the yard . Mrs. Wolff is to come to me at once . I beg you to be seated , Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Sitting down and sighing .O Lord ! O Lord ! What a life !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Softly to GLASENAPP and MOTES .I 'm rather curious to see what will develop . There 's something more than meets the eye in all this . I think a great deal of Mrs. Wolff . The woman works enough for four men . My wife assures me that if Wolff does n't come she has to hire two women in her place .— Her opinions are n't half bad either .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: She wants her daughters to go on the operatic stage ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Oh , of course , she may have a screw loose in that respect . But that 's no fault of character . What have you hanging there , Mr. Motes ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: They 're some wire snares . I 'm taking them to the forester Seidel .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Do let me see one of those things .He takes one and looks at it closely .And in these things the poor beasts are slowly throttled to death .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF enters , followed by MITTELDORF . She is drying her hands ,
sp.p: which are still moist from the wash tub .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Unembarrassed , cheerfully , with a swift glance at the snares .Here I am . What 's up now ? What 'm I bein ’ wanted for ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Mrs. Wolff , is this gentleman known to you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Which one of ‘ em ?Pointing with her finger at KRUEGER .This here , this is Mr. Krueger . I guess I know him all right . Good mornin ’ , Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Your daughter is in Mr. Krueger 's service ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Who ? My daughter ? That 's so — Leontine .To KRUEGER .But then , she run away from you , did n't she ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Enraged .She did indeed .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Interrupting .Now wait a moment .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What kind o ’ trouble did you have together ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Mrs. Wolff , you listen to me . Your daughter must return to Mr. Krueger at once .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , no , we 'd rather keep her at home now .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That can n't be done quite so easily as you think . Mr. Krueger has the right , if he wishes to exert it , of calling in the help , of the police . In that case we would have to take your daughter back by force .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: But my husband just happened to take it into his head . He 's just made up his mind not to let the girl go no more . An ’ when my husband takes a notion like that into his head .... The trouble is : all you men has such awful tempers !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Suppose you let that go , for the moment , Mrs. Wolff . How long has your daughter been , at home ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She came back last night .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Last night ? Very well . She had been told to carry wood into the shed and she refused .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Eh , is that so ? Refused ? That girl o ’ mine do n't refuse to do work . An ’ I would n't advise her to do that kind o ’ thing neither .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You hear what Mrs. Wolff says .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That girl has always been a willin ’ girl . If she 'd ever refused to lend a hand ....

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: She simply refused to carry in the wood !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Yes , drag in wood ! At half past ten at night ! People who asks such a thing of a child like that —

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: The essential thing , however , Mrs. Wolff , is this : the wood was left out over night and has been stolen . And so ....

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Losing self-control .You will replace that wood , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: All that remains to be seen , if you will wait .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You will indemnify me for that wood to the last farthing !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ is that so ? That 'd be a new way o ’ doin ’ things ! Did I , maybe , go an ’ steal your wood ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You had better let the man calm down , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , when Mr. Krueger comes round me with things like that , payin ’ for wood and such like , he ai n't goin ’ to have no luck . I always been friendly with them people — that 's sure . Nobody can n't complain o ’ nothin ’ ‘ sfar ‘ s I 'm concerned . But if things gets to this point , then I 'd rather up and says my say just exactly how I feel , you know . I do my dooty and that 's enough . There ai n't nobody in the whole village what c'n say anythin ’ against me . But I ai n't goin ’ to let nobody walk all over me !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You need not wear yourself out , Mrs. Wolff . You have absolutely no cause for it . Just remain calm , quite calm . You 're not entirely unknown to me , after all . There is n't a human being who would undertake to deny your industry and honesty . So let us hear what you have to say in answer to the plaintiff .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: The woman can n't possibly have anything to say !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Hol ’ on , now , everybody ! How 's that , I 'd like to know ? Ai n't the girl my daughter ? An ’ I 'm not to have anythin ’ to say ! You gotta go an ’ look for some kind of a fool ! You do n't know much about me . I do n't has to hide what I thinks from no one — no , not from his honour hisself , an ’ a good deal less from you , you may take your oath on that !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I quite understand your excitement , Mrs. Wolff . But if you desire to serve the cause at issue , I would advise you to remain calm .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's what a person gets . I been washin ’ clothes for them people these ten years . All that time we ai n't had a fallin ’ out . An ’ now , all of a sudden , they treat you this way . I ai n't comin ’ to your house no more , you c'n believe me .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You do n't need to . There are other washerwomen .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ the vegetables an ’ the fruit out o ’ your garden — you c'n just go an ’ get somebody else to sell ‘ em for you .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I can get rid of all that . There 's no fear . All you needed to have done was to have taken a stick to that girl of yours and sent her back .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I wo n't have no daughter of mine abused .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Who has been abusing your daughter , I 'd like to know !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: To WEHRHAHN .The girl came back to me no better'n a skeleton .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Then let her not spend all her nights dancing .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She sleeps like the dead all day .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Past MRS. WOLFF to KRUEGER .By the way , where did you buy the wood in question ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Is this thing goin ’ to last much longer ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Why , Mrs. Wolff ?

lg.l: Why , on account o ’ the washin ’ . If I wastes my time standin ’ round here ,
I can n't get done .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: We can n't take that into consideration here , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ your wife ? What 's she goin ’ to say ? You c'n go an ’ settle it with her , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: It will only last another minute , anyhow .— You tell us frankly , Mrs. Wolff — you know the whole village . Whom do you consider capable of the crime in question ? Who could possibly have stolen the wood ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I can n't tell you nothin ’ about that , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And nothing suspicious came to your attention ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I was n't even at home last night . I had to go over to Treptow to buy geese .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: At what time was that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: A little after ten . Mitteldorf , he was there when we started .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And no team carrying wood met you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , nothin ’ like that .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: How about you , Mitteldorf , did you notice nothing ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: After some thought .No , I did n't notice nothin ’ suspicious .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Of course not , I might have known that .To KRUEGER .Well , where did you buy the wood ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Why do you have to know that ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You will kindly leave that to me .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I naturally bought the wood from the department of forestry .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Why naturally ? I do n't see that at all . There are , for instance , private wood yards . Personally I buy my wood from Sandberg . Why should n't you buy yours from a dealer ? One really almost gets a better bargain .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Impatiently .I have n't any more time , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What do you mean by that ? Time ? You have no time ? Have you come to me , or do I come to you ? Am I taking up your time or are you taking up mine ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: That 's your business . That 's what you 're here for .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Perhaps I 'm your bootblack , eh ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Perhaps I 've stolen silver spoons ! I forbid you to use that tone to me . You 're not a corporal and I 'm not a recruit .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , that passes .... Do n't shout so !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: It is you who do all the shouting .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You are half deaf . It is necessary for me to shout .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You shout all the time . You shout at every one who comes in here .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I do n't shout at any one . Be silent .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You carry on as if you were heaven knows what ! You annoy the whole place with your chicanery !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I 'm only making a beginning . I 'll make you a good deal more uncomfortable before I get through .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: That does n't make the slightest impression on me . You 're a pretentious nobody — nothing else . You simply want to cut a big figure . As though you were the king himself , you ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I am king in this place .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Laughs heartily .You 'd better let that be . In my estimation you 're nothing at all . You 're nothing but an ordinary justice of the peace . In fact , you 've got to learn to be one first .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Sir , if you do n't hold your tongue this minute ....

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Then , I suppose , you 'll have me arrested . I would n't advise you to go to such lengths after all . You might put yourself into a dangerous position .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Dangerous ?To MOTES .Did you hear that ?To KRUEGER .And however much you intrigue , you and your admirable followers , and however you try to undermine my position — you wo n't force me to abandon my station .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Good heavens ! I try to undermine your position ? Your whole personality is far too unimportant . But you may take my word for this , that if you do n't change your tactics completely , you will cause so much trouble that you will make yourself quite impossible .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To MOTES .I suppose , Mr. Motes , that one must consider his age .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I beg to have my complaint recorded .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Turning over the papers on his table .You will please to send in your complaint in writing . I have no time at this moment .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER looks at him in consternation , turns around vigorously , and
sp.p: leaves the office without a word .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: After a pause of embarrassment .That 's the way people annoy me with trifles .— Ugh !—To MRS. WOLFF .You 'd better get back to your washing .— I tell you , my dear Motes , a position like mine is made hard enough . If one were not conscious of what one represents here — one might sometimes be tempted to throw up the whole business . But as it is , one 's motto must be to stand one 's ground bravely . For , after all , what is it that we are defending ? The most sacred goods of the nation !—

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE THIRD ACT It is about eight o'clock in the morning . The scene is the dwelling of MRS. WOLFF . Water for coffee is boiling on the oven . MRS. WOLFF is sitting on a footstool and counting out money on the seat of a chair . JULIUS enters , carrying a slaughtered rabbit .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: You better go an ’ hide that there money !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Absorbed in her calculations , gruffly :Do n't bother me !

div.stage: Silence .

sp.speaker: JULIUS throws the rabbit on a stool . He wanders about irresolutely ,
sp.p: picking up one object after another . Finally he sets about blacking a boot . From afar the blowing of a huntsman 's horn is heard .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Listens . Anxious and excited .I axed you to go an ’ hide that there money !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ I 'm tellin ’ you not to bother me , Julius . Just let that fool Motes tootle all he wants . He 's out in the woods an ’ ai n't thinkin ’ o ’ nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: You go right ahead and land us in gaol !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do n't talk that fool talk . The girl 's comin ’ .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Comes in , just out of bed .Good mornin ’ , mama .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Did you sleep well ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: You was out in the night , was n't you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I guess you musta been dreamin ’ . Hurry now ! Bring in some wood , an ’ be quick about it !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE , playing ball with an orange , goes toward the door

lg.l: MRS. WOLFF
Where did you get that ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Schoebel gave it to me out o ’ his shop .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I do n't want you to take no presents from that feller .— Come here , Julius ! Listen to me ! Here I got ninety-nine crowns ! That 's always the same old way with Wulkow . He just cheated us out o ’ one , because he promised to give a hundred .— I 'm puttin ’ the money in this bag , y'understand ? Now go an ’ get a hoe and dig a hole in the goatshed — but right under the manger where it 's dry . An ’ then you c'n put the bag into the hole . D'you hear me ? An ’ take a flat stone an ’ put it across . But do n't be so long doin ’ it .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I thought you was goin ’ to pay an instalment to Fischer !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Ca n't you never do what I tell you to ? Do n't poke round so long , y'understand ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Do n't you go an ’ rile me or I 'll give you somethin ’ to make you stop . I do n't hold with that money stayin ’ in this here house .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , what 's goin ’ to be done with it ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: You take it an ’ you carry it over to Fischer . You said we was goin ’ to use it to make a payment to him .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 're stoopid enough to make a person sick . If it was n't for me you 'd just go to the dogs .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Go on with your screamin ’ ! That 's right .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: A person can n't help screamin ’ , you 're such a fool . If you had some sense , I would n't have to scream . If we go an ’ takes that money to Fischer now , you look out an ’ see what happens !

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: That 's what I say . Look at the whole dam ’ business . What 's the good of it to me if I gotta go to gaol !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Now it 's about time you was keepin ’ still .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: You can n't scream no louder , can you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I ai n't goin ’ to get me a new tongue on your account . You raise a row ... just as hard as you can , all on account o ’ this bit o ’ business . You just look out for yourself an ’ not for me . Did you throw the key in the river ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Has I had a chanst to get down there yet ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Then it 's about time you was gettin ’ there ! D'you want ‘ em to find the key on you ?JULIUS is about to go .Oh , wait a minute , Julius . Let me have the key !

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: What you goin ’ to do with it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Hiding the key about her person .That ai n't no business o ’ yours ; that 's mine .She pours coffee beans into the hand-mill and begins to grind .Now you go out to the shed ; then you c'n come back an ’ drink your coffee .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: If I 'd ha ’ known all that before . Aw !

div.stage: JULIUS exit . ADELAIDE enters , carrying a large apron full of firewood .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Where d'you go an ’ get that wood ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Why , from the new blocks o ’ pine .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You was n't to use that new wood yet .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Dropping the wood on the floor in front of the oven .That do n't do no harm , mama , if it 's burned up !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You think you know a lot ! What are you foolin ’ about ? You grow up a bit an ’ then talk !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I know where it comes from !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What do you mean , girl ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I mean the wood .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do n't go jabberin ’ now ; we bought that at a auction .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Playing ball with her orange .Oh , Lord , if that was true ! But you just went and took it !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What 's that you say ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: It 's just taken . That 's the wood from Krueger 's , mama . Leontine told me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Cuffs her head .There you got an answer . We ai n't no thieves . Now go an ’ get your lessons . An ’ do ‘ em nice ! I 'll come an ’ look ‘ em over later !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Exit . From the adjoining room .I thought I could go skatin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ your lessons for your confirmation ? I guess you forgot them !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: That do n't come till Tuesday .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It 's to-morrow ! You go an ’ study your verses . I 'll come in an ’ hear you say ‘ em later .

lg.stage: Loud yawning is heard from the adjoining room . Then she says :
lg.l: “ Jesus to his disciples said ,
Use your fingers to eat your bread . ”
MRS. WOLFF
Well , Julius , did you go an ’ do what I told you ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: If you do n't like my way o ’ doin ’ , go an ’ do things yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: God knows that is the best way — always .She pours out two cupfuls of coffee , one for him and one for herself , and places the two cups with bread and butter on a wooden chair .Here , drink your coffee .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Sitting down and cutting himself some bread .I hope Wulkow 's been able to get away !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: In this thaw !

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Even if it is thawin ’ , you can n't tell .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ you need n't care if it do freeze a bit ; he ai n't goin ’ to be stuck . I guess he 's a good way up the canal by this time .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , I hope he ai n't lyin ’ under the bridge this minute .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: For my part he can be lyin ’ where he wants to .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: You c'n take it from me , y'understan ’ ? That there man Wulkow is goin ’ to get into a hell of a hole some day .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's his business ; that ai n't none o ’ ours .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Trouble is we 'd all be in the same hole . You just let ‘ em go an ’ find that coat on him !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What coat are you talkin ’ about ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Krueger 's , o ’ course !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do n't you go talkin ’ rot like that , y'understan ’ ? An ’ do n't go an ’ give yourself a black eye on account o ’ other people 's affairs !

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I guess them things concerns me !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Concerns you — rot ! That do n't concern you at all . That 's my business an ’ not yours . You ai n't no man at all ; you 're nothin ’ but an old woman !— Here you got some change . Now hurry an ’ get out o ’ here . Go over to Fiebig and take a drink . I do n't care if you have a good time all day Sunday .A knocking is heard .Come right in ! Come right in , any one that wants to !

sp.speaker: DR. FLEISCHER enters , leading his little son of five by the hand
sp.p: FLEISCHER is twenty-seven years old . He wears one of the Jaeger reform suits . His hair , beard and moustache are all coal-black . His eyes are deep-set ; his voice , as a rule , gentle . He displays , at every moment , a touching anxiety for the child .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Jubilantly .Lord ! Is little Philip comin ’ to see us once more ! Now , ai n't that fine ? Now I really feel proud o ’ that !She gets hold of the child and takes off his overcoat .Come now an ’ take off your coat . It 's warm back here an ’ you ai n't goin ’ to be cold .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Mrs. Wolff , there 's a draught . I believe there 's a draught .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , he ai n't so weak as all that . A bit o ’ draught , ai n't goin ’ to hurt this little feller !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Oh , but it will , I assure you . You have no idea . He catches cold so easily ! Exercise , Philip ! Keep moving a little .

sp.speaker: PHILIP jerks his shoulders back with a pettish exclamation
sp.p: FLEISCHER Come now , Philip . You 'll end by being ill. All you have to do is to walk slowly up and down .

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Naughtily .But , I do n't want to .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Let him do like he wants to .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Well , good morning , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Good morning , Doctor . I 'm glad to see you comin ’ in onct more .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Good morning , Mr. Wolff .

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Good mornin ’ , Mr. Fleischer .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 're very welcome . Please sit down .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: We have just a few minutes to stay .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , if we has such a fine visit paid us so early in the mornin ’ , we 're sure to have a lucky day this day .Kneeling down by the child .Ai n't it so , my boy ? You 'll bring us good luck , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: Excitedly .I went to ze zological darden ; I saw ze storks zere , an ’ zey bit each ozzer wis zeir dolden bills .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well now , you do n't mean to say so ! You 're tellin ’ me a little fib , ai n't you ?Hugging and kissing the child .Lord , child , I could just eat you up , eat you right up . Mr. Fleischer , I 'm goin ’ to keep this boy . This is my boy . You 're my boy , ai n't you ? An ’ how 's your mother , eh ?

sp.speaker: PHILIP
sp.p: She 's well an ’ she sends her redards an ’ you 'll please tome in ze morning to wash .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well now , just listen to that . A little feller like that an ’ he can give all that message already !To FLEISCHER .Wo n't you sit down , just a bit ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: The boy bothers me about boating . Is it possible to go ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , sure . The Spree is open . My girl there c'n row you out a way .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: The boy wo n't stop about it ! He 's just taken that into his head .

lg.stage: Showing herself in the door that leads to the next room , beckons to PHILIP .
lg.l: Come , Philip , I 'll show you somethin ’ real fine !
FLEISCHER
Now , Philip , you mus n't be naughty !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Just look at that fine orange !

sp.speaker: PHILIP 'S face is wreathed in smiles . He takes a few steps in
sp.p: ADELAIDE 's direction .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Go ahead , but do n't beg !

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Come on ! Come on ! We 'll eat this orange together now .

div.stage: She walks in the child 's direction , takes him by the hand , holds up the orange temptingly , and both go , now quite at one , into the next room .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Following the child with her eyes .No , that boy , I could just sit an ’ look at him . I do n't know , when I see a boy like that ...She takes up a corner of her apron and wipes her eyes .I feel as if I had to howl right out .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Did you have a boy like that once ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That I had . But what 's the use o ’ all that . You can n't make people come back to life . You see — things like that — that 's life ....

lg.l: FLEISCHER
One can n't be careful enough with children ,

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You can go an ’ be as careful as you want to be . What is to be , will be .A pause .— Shaking her head .What trouble did you have with Mr. Motes ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I ? None at all ! What trouble should I have had with him ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , I was just thinkin ’ .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: How old is your daughter anyhow ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She 'll be out o ’ school this Easter . Why ? Would you like to have her ? I would n't mind her goin ’ into service if it 's with you .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I do n't see why not . That would n't be half bad .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She 's grown up to be a strong kind o ’ body . Even if she is a bit young , she c'n work most as well as any one , I tell you . An ’ I tell you another thing . She 's a scamp now an ’ then ; she do n't always do right . But she ai n't no fool . That girl 's got genius .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: That 's quite possible , no doubt .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You just let her go an ’ recite a single piece for you — just once — a pome , or somethin ’ . An ’ I tell you , Doctor , you ai n't goin ’ to be able to get through shiverin ’ . You c'n possibly call her in some day when you got visitors from Berlin . All kinds o ’ writers comes to your house , I believe . An ’ she ai n't backward ; she 'll sail right in . Oh , she does say pieces that beautiful .—With a sudden change of manner .Now I want to give you a bit o ’ advice ; only you mus n't be offended .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I 'm never offended by good advice .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: First thing , then : Do n't give away so much . Nobody ai n't goin ’ to thank you for it . You do n't get nothin ’ but ingratitude .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Why , I do n't give away very much , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's all right , I know . An ’ the more you talk , the more scared people gets . First thing they says : that 's a demercrat . Yon can n't be too careful talkin ’ .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: In what way am I to take all that , Mrs. Wolff ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Yon c'n go an ’ you c'n think what you please . But you gotta be careful when it comes to talkin ’ , or you sit in gaol before you know it .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Turns pale .Well , now , look here , but that 's nonsense , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , no . I tell you that 's serious . An ’ be careful o ’ that feller , whatever you do !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Whom do you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: The same man we was talkin ’ about a while ago .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Motes , you mean ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I ai n't namin ’ no names . You must ha ’ had some kind o ’ trouble with that feller .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I do n't even associate with him any longer .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , you see , that 's just what I 've been think-in ’ .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Nobody could possibly blame me for that , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ I ai n't blamin ’ you for it .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: It would be a fine thing , would n't it — to associate with a swindler , a notorious swindler .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That man is a swindler ; you 're right there .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Now he moved over to Dreier 's . That poor woman will have a hard time getting her rent . And whatever she has , she 'll get rid of it . Why , a fellow like that — he 's a regular gaol-bird .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Sometimes , you know , he 'll say things ...

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Is that so ? About me ? Well , I am curious .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I believe you was heard to say somethin ’ bad about some high person , or somethin ’ like that .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: H-m. You do n't know anything definite , I dare say ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: He 's mighty thick with Wehrhahn , that 's certain . But I tell you what . You go over to old mother Dreier . That old witch is beginnin ’ to smell a rat . First they was as nice as can be to her ; now they 're eatin ’ her outta house and home !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Oh , pshaw ! The whole thing is nonsense .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You c'n go to the Dreier woman . That do n't do no harm . She c'n tell you a story ... He wanted to get her into givin ’ false witness .... That shows the kind o ’ man you gotta deal with .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Of course , I might go there . It can do no harm . But , in the end , the whole matter is indifferent to me . It would be the deuce of a world , if a fellow like that .... You just let him come !— Here , Philip , Philip ! Where are you ? We 've got to go .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE 'S VOICE
sp.p: Oh , we 're lookin ’ at such pretty pictures .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: What do you think of that other business , anyhow ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What business ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Have n't you heard anything yet ?

lg.stage: Restlessly .
lg.l: Well , what was I sayin ’ ?...
lg.stage: Impatiently .
lg.l: Hurry , Julius , an ’ go , so 's you c'n get back in time for dinner .
lg.stage: To FLEISCHER .
lg.l: We killed ’ a rabbit for dinner to-day . Ai n't you ready yet ,
Julius ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: Well , give me a chanst to find my cap .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I can n't stand seein ’ anybody just foolin ’ round that way , as if it did n't make no difference about to-day or to-morrow , I like to see things move along .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Why , last night , at Krueger 's , they ...

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do me a favour , Doctor , an ’ do n't talk to me about that there man . I 'm that angry at him ! That man hurt my feelin 's too bad . The way we was — him an ’ me , for so long — an ’ then he goes and tries to blacken my character with all them people .To JULIUS .Are you goin ’ or not ?

sp.speaker: JULIUS
sp.p: I 'm goin ’ all right ; do n't get so huffy . Good mornin ’ to you , Mr. Fleischer .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Good morning , Mr. Wolff .

div.stage: JULIUS exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , as I was sayin ’ ...

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: That time when his wood was stolen , I suppose he quarreled with you . But he 's repented of that long since .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That man and repent !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: You may believe me all the same , Mrs. Wolff . And especially after this last affair . He has a very high opinion of you indeed . The best thing would be if you were to be reconciled .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: We might ha ’ talked together like sensible people , but for him to go an ’ run straight to the police — no , no !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Well , the poor little old couple is having bad luck : only a week ago their wood , and now the fur coat ....

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Are you comin ’ to your great news now ? Out with it !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Well , it 's a clear case of burglary .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Some more stealin ’ ? Do n't make fun o ’ me !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Yes , and this time it 's a perfectly new fur coat .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well now , you know , pretty soon I 'll move away from here . That 's a crowd round here ! Why , a person ai n't sare o ’ their lives . Tst ! Tst ! Such folks ! It ai n't hardly to be believed !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: You can form an idea of the noise they 're making .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , you can n't hardly blame the people .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: And really , it was , a very expensive garment — of mink , I believe .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Ai n't that somethin ’ like beaver , Mr. Fleischer ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Perhaps it was beaver , for all I know . Anyhow , they were real proud of it .— I admit , I laughed to myself over the business . When something like that is discovered it always has a comic effect .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You 're a cruel man , really , Doctor . I can n't go an ’ laugh about things like that .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: You must n't think that I 'm not sorry for the man , for all that .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Them must be pretty strange people . I do n't know . There ai n't no way o ’ understandin ’ that . Just to go an ’ rob other people o ’ what 's theirs — no , then it 's better to work till you drop .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: You might perhaps make a point of keeping your ears open . I believe the coat is supposed to be in the village .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Has they got any suspicion o ’ anybody ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Oh , there was a washerwoman working at the Krueger 's ....

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: By the name o ’ Miller ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: And she has a very large family ...?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: The woman 's got a large family , that 's so , but to steal that way ... no ! She might take some little thing , yes .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Of course Krueger put her out .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Aw , that 's bound to come out . My goodness , the devil hisself 'd have to be back o ’ that if it do n't . I wish I was justice here . But the man is that stoopid !— well ! I c'n see better'n the dark than he can by day with his glass eye .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I almost believe you could .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I c'n tell you , if I had to , I could steal the chair from under that man 's behind .

lg.stage: Has arisen and calls , laughingly , into the adjoining room .
lg.l: Come ,
Philip , come ! We 've got to go ! Good-bye , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You get dressed , Adelaide . You c'n go an ’ row Mr. Fleischer a ways .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Enters , buttoning the last buttons at her throat and leading PHILIP by the hand .I 'm all ready .To PHILIP .You come right here ; I 'll take you on my arm .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Anxiously helping the boy on with his coat .He 's got to be wrapped up well ; he 's so delicate , and no doubt it 's windy out on the river .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I better go ahead an ’ get the boat ready .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Is your health better these days ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Much better since I 'm living out here .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Calls back in from the door .Mama , Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Who 's comin ’ ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It ai n't possible !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: He meant to come to you during the forenoon .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Throws a swift glance at the heap of fire wood and vigorously sets about clearing it away .Come on , now , help me get this wood out o ’ sight .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Why , mama ? Oh , on account o ’ Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , what for d'you suppose ? Is this a proper way for a place to look , the way this one is look-in ’ ? Is that decent an ’ on Sunday mornin ’ , too ? What is Mr. Krueger goin ’ to think of us ?KRUEGER appears , exhausted by his walk . MRS. WOLFF calls out to him .Mr. Krueger , please do n't look ‘ round . This place is in a terrible state !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Impetuously .Good morning ! Good morning ! Do n't worry about that at all ! You go to work every week and your house can n't be expected to be perfect on Sunday . You are an excellent woman , Mrs. Wolff , and a very honest one . And I think we might do very well to forget whatever has happened between us .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Is moved , and dries her eyes from time to time with a corner of her apron .I never had nothin ’ against you in the world . I always liked to work for you . But you went an ’ got so rough like , you know , that a person 's temper could n't hardly help gettin ’ away with ‘ em . Lord , a person is sorry for that kind o ’ thing soon enough .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You just come back and wash for us . Where is your daughter Leontine ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She went to take some cabbage to the postmaster .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You just let us have that girl again . She can have thirty crowns wages instead of twenty . We were always quite satisfied with her in other respects . Let 's forgive and forget the whole affair .

div.stage: He holds out his hand to MRS. WOLFF , who takes it heartily .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: All that had n't no need to happen . The girl , you see , is still foolish like a child . We old people always did get along together .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Well , then , the matter is settled .Gradually regaining his breath .— Well , then , my mind is at rest about that , anyhow .— But now , do tell me ! This thing that 's happened to me ! What do you say to that ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , well , you know — what can a person say about such things ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: And there we got that Mr. von Wehrhahn ! He 's very well when it comes to annoying honest citizens and thinking out all sorts of chicanery and persecution , but — That man , what does n't he stick his inquisitive nose into !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Into everything exceptin ’ what he ought to .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I 'm going to him now to give formal notice . I wo n't rest ! This thing has got to be discovered .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You ought n't by no means to let a thing o ’ that kind go .

lg.l: And if I 've got to turn everything upside down — I 'll get back my coat ,
Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What this place needs is a good cleanin ’ out . We wo n't get no rest in the village till then . They 'll end up by stealin ’ the roof from over a person 's head .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I ask you to consider , for heaven 's sake — two robberies in the course of two weeks ! Two loads of wood , just like the wood you have there .He takes up a piece that is lying on the floor .Such good and expensive wood , Mrs. Wolff .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It 's enough to make a person get blue in the face with rage . The kind o ’ crowd we gotta live with here ! Aw , things like that ! No , you know ! Just leave me alone with it !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Irately gesticulating with the piece of wood .And if it costs me a thousand crowns , I 'll see to it that those thieves are hunted down . They wo n't escape the penitentiary this time .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ that 'd be a blessin ’ too , as sure 's we 're alive !

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE FOURTH ACT The court room . GLASENAPP is sitting at his table . MRS. WOLFF and ADELAIDE are waiting for the justice . ADELAIDE holds on her lap a small package wrapped in linen .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: He 's takin ’ his time again to-day .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Writing .Patience ! Patience !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , if he 's goin ’ to be so late again to-day , he wo n't have no more time for us .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Goodness ! You an ’ your trifles ! We got different kinds o ’ things to deal with here .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Aw , I guess they 're fine things you got to do .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: That 's no way to talk . That ai n't proper here !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Aw , act a little more grand , will you ? Krueger hisself sent my girl here !

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: The same old story about the coat , I suppose .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ why not !

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Now the old fellow 's got somethin ’ for sure . Now he can go stirrin ’ things up — the knock-kneed old nuisance .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You c'n use your tongue . You better see about findin ’ out somethin ’ .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Appears in the doorway .You 're to come right over , Glasenapp . His honour wants to ax you somethin ’ .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Has I got to interrupt myself again ?

div.stage: He throws down his pen and goes out .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Good mornin ’ , Mitteldorf .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: Good mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What 's keepin ’ the justice all this while ?

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: He 's writin ’ pages an ’ pages ! An ’ them must be important things , I c'n tell you that .Confidentially .An ’ lemme tell you : there 's somethin ’ in the air .— I ai n't sayin ’ I know exactly what . But there 's somethin ’ — I know that as sure ‘ s ... You just look out , that 's all , and you 'll live to see it . It 's goin ’ to come down — somethin ’ — and when it do — look out . That 's all I say . No , I do n't pretend to understand them things . It 's all new doin 's to me . That 's what they calls modern . An ’ I do n't know nothin ’ about that . But somethin 's got to happen . Things can n't go on this way . The whole place is got to be cleaned out . I can n't say ‘ s I gets the hang of it . I 'm too old . But talk about the justice what died . Why , he wa n't nothin ’ but a dam ’ fool to this one . I could go an ’ tell you all kinds o ’ things , but I ai n't got no time . The baron 'll be missin ’ me .He goes but , having arrived at the door , he turns back .The lightenin ’ is goin ’ to strike , Mrs. Wolff . Take my word for that !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I guess a screw 's come loose somewhere with him .

div.stage: Pause .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: What 's that I gotta say ? I forgot .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What did you say to Mr. Krueger ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Why , I said that I found this here package .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , you do n't need to say nothin ’ but that here neither . Only say it right out strong an ’ sure . You ai n't such a mouse other times .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Comes in .I wish you a good morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Stares at WULKOW . She is speechless for a moment . Then :No , Wulkow , I guess you lost your mind ! What are you doin ’ here ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Well , my wife , she has a baby ...

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: What 's that she 's got ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: A little girl . So I gotta go to the public registry an ’ make the announcement .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: I thought you 'd be out on the canal by this time .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: An ’ I would n't mind it one little bit if I was ! An ’ so I would be , if it depended on me . Did n't I go an ’ starts out the very minute ? But when I come to the locks there was n't no gettin ’ farther . I waited an ’ waited for the Spree to open up . Two days an ’ nights I lay there till this thing with my wife came along . There was n't no use howlin ’ then . I had to come back .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: So your boat is down by the bridge again ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: That 's where it is . I ai n't got no other place , has I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , do n't come to me , if ...

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I hope they ai n't caught on to nothin ’ , at least .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Go to the shop an ’ get three cents ’ worth o ’ thread .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I 'll go for that when we get home .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Do 's I tell you an ’ do n't answer back .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Aw , I ai n't no baby no more .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Eagerly .An ’ so you lay there by the locks ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Two whole days , as I been tellin ’ you .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , you ai n't much good for this kind o ’ thing . You 're a fine feller to go an ’ put on that coat in bright daylight !

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Put it on ? Me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Yes , you put it on , an ’ in bright daylight , so 's the whole place c'n know straight off what a fine fur coat you got .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: Aw , that was ‘ way out in the middle o ’ the —

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It was a quarter of a hour from our house . My girl saw you sittin ’ there . She had to go an ’ row Dr. Fleischer out an ’ he went an ’ had his suspicion that minute .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I do n't know nothin ’ about that . That ai n't none o ’ my business .

div.stage: Some one is heard approaching .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Sh ! You want to be on the lookout now , that 's all .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Enters hurriedly with an attempt to imitate the manner of the justice . He asks WULKOW condescendingly :What business have you ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Still without .What do you want , girl ? You 're looking for me ? Come in , then .WEHRHAHN permits ADELAIDE to precede him and then enters .I have very little time to-day . Ah , yes , are n't you Mrs. Wolff 's little girl ? Well , then , sit down . What have you there ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I got a package ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Wait a moment first ...To WULKOW .What do you want ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I 'd like to report the birth of ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Matter of the public registry . The books , Glasenapp . That is to say , I 'll attend to the other affair first .To MRS. WOLFF .What 's the trouble about your daughter ? Did Mr. Krueger box her ears again ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , he did n't go that far no time .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What 's the trouble , then ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It 's about this here package ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To GLASENAPP .Has n't Motes been here yet ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Not up to this time .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That 's incomprehensible . Well , girl , what do you want ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: It 's in the matter of the stolen fur coat , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Is that so ? Ca n't possibly attend to that today . No one can do everything at once .To MRS. WOLFF .She may come in to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She 's tried to talk to you a couple o ’ times already .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Then let her try for a third time to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: But Mr. Krueger do n't give her no peace no more .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What has Mr. Krueger to do with it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: The girl went to him with the package .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What kind of a rag is that ? Let me see it .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It 's all connected with the business of the fur coat . Leastways that 's what Mr. Krueger thinks .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What 's wrapped up in those rags , eh ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: There 's a green waist-coat what belongs to Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And you found that ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: I found it , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Where did you find it ?

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: That was when I was goin ’ to the train with mama . I was walkin ’ along this way and there ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Never mind about that now .To MRS. WOLFF .Make your deposition some time soon . We can come back to this matter to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Oh , I 'm willin ’ enough ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , who is n't then ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Mr. Krueger is so very anxious about it .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Mr. Krueger , Mr. Krueger — I care very little about him . The man just simply annoys me . Things like this cannot be adjusted in a day . He has offered a reward and the matter has been published in the official paper .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: You can n't never do enough for him , though .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What does that mean : we can n't do enough for him ? We have recorded the facts in the case . His suspicions fell upon his washerwoman and we have searched her house . What more does he want ? The man ought to keep quiet . But , as I said , to-morrow I 'm at the service of this affair again .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It 's all the same to us . We c'n come back .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Very well , then . To-morrow morning .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Good mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: ADELAIDE
sp.p: Dropping a courtsey .Good mornin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF and ADELAIDE exeunt
sp.p: WEHRHAHN

div.stage: Turning over some documents . To GLASENAPP . ] I 'm curious to see what the result of all this will be . Mr. Motes has finally agreed to offer witnesses . He says the Dreier woman , that old witch of a pastry cook , once stood within earshot when Fleischer expressed himself disrespectfully . How old is the woman , anyhow ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Somewhere around seventy , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: A bit confused in her upper story , eh ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Depends on how you look at it . She 's fairly sensible yet .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I can assure you , Glasenapp , that it would be no end of a satisfaction to me to flutter these dove-cotes here pretty thoroughly . These people ought to be made to feel that they 're dealing with somebody , after all . Who absented himself from the festivities on the emperor 's birthday ? Fleischer , of course . The man is simply capable of anything . He can put on all the innocent expressions he pleases . We know these wolves in sheep 's clothing . They 're too sweet-tempered to harm a fly , but if they think the occasion has come , the hounds can blow up a whole place . Well , here , at least , it will be made too hot for them !

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Comes in .Your servant .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , how are things going ?

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Mrs. Dreier said that she would be here around eleven .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: This matter will attract quite a little notice . It will , is fact , make a good deal of noise . I know what will be said : “ That man Wehrhahn pokes his nose into everything . ” Well , thank heaven , I 'm prepared for that . I 'm not standing in this place for my private amusement . I have n't been put here for jest . People think — a justice , why he 's nothing but a superior kind of gaoler . In that case they can put some one else here . The gentlemen , to be sure , who appointed me know very well with whom they are dealing . They know to the full the seriousness with which I conceive of my duties . I consider my office in the light of a sacred calling .Pause .I have reduced my report to the public prosecutor to writing . If I send it off at noon to-day , the command of arrest can reach us by day after to-morrow .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Now everybody will be coming down on me .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You know I have an uncle who is a chamberlain . I 'll talk to him about you . Confound it all ! There comes Fleischer ! What does that fellow want ? Does he smell a rat by any chance ?A knocking is heard and WEHRHAHN shouts :Come in !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Enters , pale and excited .Good morning !He receives no answer .I should like to lodge information which has reference to the robbery recently committed here .

lg.stage: With his most penetrating official glance .
lg.l: You are Dr. Joseph
Fleischer ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Quite right . My name is Joseph Fleischer .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And you come to give me some information .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: If you will permit me , that is what I should like to do . I have made an observation which may , quite possibly , help the authorities to track down the thief in question .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Drums on the table with his fingers . He looks around at the others with an expression of affected surprise which tempts them to laughter .What is this important observation which you have made ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Of course , if you have previously made up your mind to attach no importance to my evidence , I should prefer ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Quickly and arrogantly .What would you prefer ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: To hold my peace .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Turns to MOTES with a look expressive of inability to understand FLEISCHER 'S motives . Then , in a changed tone , with very superficial interest .My time is rather fully occupied . I would request you to be as brief as possible .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: My time is no less preempted . Nevertheless I considered it my duty ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Interrupting .You considered it your duty . Very well . Now tell us what you know .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Conquering himself .I went boating yesterday . I had taken Mrs. Wolff 's boat and her daughter was rowing .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Are these details necessarily pertinent to the business in hand ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: They certainly are — in my opinion .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Drumming impatiently on the table .Very well ! Very well ! Let 's get on !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: We rowed to the neighbourhood of the locks . A lighter lay at anchor there . The ice , we were able to observe , was piled up there . The lighter had probably not been able to proceed .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: H-m. Is that so ? That interests us rather less . What is the kernel of this whole story ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Keeping his temper by main force .I must confess that this method of ... I have come here quite voluntarily to offer a voluntary service to the authorities .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Impudently .His honour is pressed for time . You are to talk less and state what you have to say briefly and compactly .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Vehemently .Let 's get to business at once . What is it you want ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Still mastering himself .I am concerned that the matter be cleared up . And in the interest of old Mr. Krueger , I will ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Yawning and bored .The light dazzles me ; do pull down the shades .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: On the lighter was an old boatman — probably the owner of the vessel .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Yawning as before .Yes , most probably .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: This man sat on his deck in a fur coat which , at a distance , I considered a beaver coat .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Bored .I might have taken it to be marten .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I pulled as close up to him as possible and thus gained a very good view . The man was a poverty-stricken , slovenly boatman and the fur coat seemed by no means appropriate . It was , in addition , a perfectly new coat ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Apparently recollecting himself .I am listening , I am listening ! Well ? What else ?

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: What else ? Nothing .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Waking up thoroughly .I thought you wanted to lodge some information . You mentioned something important .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I have said all that I had to say .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You have told us an anecdote about a boatman who wears a fur coat . Well , boatmen do , no doubt , now and then wear such coats . There is nothing new or interesting about that .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: You may think about that as you please . In such circumstances I have no more to say .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well now , did you ever see anything like that ? Moreover , the fellow is a thorough fool . A boatman had on a fur coat ! Why , has the man gone mad ? I possess a beaver coat myself . Surely that does n't make me a thief .— Confound it all ! What 's that again ? I suppose I am to get no rest to-day at all !To MITTELDORF , who is standing by the door .Do n't let anyone else in now ! Mr. Motes , do me the favour of going over to my apartment . We can have our discussion there without interruptions . There 's Krueger for the hundred and first time . He acts as though he 'd been stung by a tarantula . If that old ass continues to plague me , I 'll kick him straight out of this room some day . In the open door KRUEGER becomes visible , together with FLEISCHER and MRS. WOLFF .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: To KRUEGER .His honour can n't be seen , Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Nonsense ! Not to be seen ! I do n't care for such talk at all .To the others .Go right on , right on ! I 'd like to see ! All enter , KRUEGER leading the way .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I must request that there be somewhat more quiet . As you see , I am having a conference at present .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Go right ahead with it . We can wait . Later you can then have a conference with us .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To MOTES .Over in my apartment , then , if you please . And if you see Mrs. Dreier , tell her I had rather question her there too . You see for yourself : it is n't possible here .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Pointing to FLEISCHER .This gentleman knows something about Mrs. Dreier too . He has some documentary evidence .

sp.speaker: MOTES
sp.p: Your honour 's servant . I take my leave .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: That 's a good thing for that man to take .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You will kindly omit remarks of that nature .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I 'll say that again . The man is a swindler .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: As though he had not heard , to WULKOW .Well , what is it ? I 'll get rid of you first . The records , Glasenapp !— Wait , though ! I 'll relieve myself of this business first .To KRUEGER .I will first attend to your affair .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Yes , I must ask you very insistently to do so .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Suppose we leave that “ insistently ” quite out of consideration . What request have you to make ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: None at all . I have no request to make . I am here in order to demand what is my right .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Your right ? Ah , what is that , exactly ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: My good right . I have been robbed and it is my right that the local authorities aid me in recovering my stolen possessions .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Have you been refused such assistance ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Certainly not . And that is not possible . Nevertheless , it is quite clear that nothing is being done . The whole affair is making no progress .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You imagine that things like that can be done in a day or two .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I do n't imagine anything , your honour . I have very definite proofs . You are taking no interest in my affairs .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I could interrupt you at this very point . It lies entirely beyond the duties of my office to listen to imputations of that nature . For the present , however , you may continue .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You could not interrupt me at all . As a citizen of the Prussian state I have my rights . And even if you interrupt me here , there are other places where I could make my complaint . I repeat that you are not showing any interest in my affair .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Apparently calm .Suppose you prove that .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Pointing to MRS. WOLFF and her daughter .This woman here came to you . Her daughter made a find . She did n't shirk the way , your honour , although she is a poor woman . You turned her off once before and she came back to-day ...

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: But his honour did n't have no time , you know .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Go on , please !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I will . I 'm not through yet by any means . What did you say to the woman ? You said to her quite simply that you had no time for the matter in question . You did not even question her daughter . You do n't know the slightest circumstance : you do n't know anything about the entire occurrence .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I will have to ask you to moderate yourself a little .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: My expressions are moderate ; they are extremely moderate . I am far too moderate , your honour . My entire character is far too full of moderation . If it were not , what do you think I would say ? What kind of an investigation is this ? This gentleman here , Dr. Fleischer , came to you to report an observation which he has made . A boatman wears a beaver coat ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Raising his hand .Just wait a moment .To WULKOW .You are a boatman , are n't you ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I been out on the river for thirty years .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Are you nervous ? You seem to twitch .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: I reely did have a little scare . That 's a fac ’ .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Do the boatmen on the Spree frequently wear fur coats ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: A good many of ‘ em has fur coats . That 's right enough .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: This gentleman saw a boatman who stood on his deck wearing a fur coat .

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: There ai n't nothin ’ suspicious about that , your honour . There 's many as has fine coats . I got one myself , in fac ’ .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You observe : the man himself owns a fur coat .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: But then he has n't exactly a beaver coat .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You were not in a position to discover that .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: What ? Has this man a beaver coat ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: There 's many of ‘ em , I c'n tell you , as has the finest beaver coats . An ’ why not ? We makes enough .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Filled with a sense of triumph but pretending indifference .Exactly .Lightly .Now , please go on , Mr. Krueger . That was only a little side-play . I simply wanted to make clear to you the value of that so-called “ observation . ” — You see now that this man himself owns a fur coat .More violently .Would it therefore occur to us in our wildest moments to assert that he has stolen the coat ? That would simply be an absurdity .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Wha —? I do n't understand a word .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Then I must talk somewhat louder still . And since I am talking to you now , there 's something else I might as well say to you — not in my capacity as justice , but simply man to man , Mr. Krueger . A man who is after all an honourable citizen should be more chary of his confidence — he should not adduce the evidence of people ...

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Are you talking about my associates ? My associates ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Exactly that .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: In that case you had better take care of yourself . People like Motes , with whom you associate , were kicked out of my house .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: I was obliged to show the door to this person whom you receive in your private apartment !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: He cheated me out of my rent .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: There ai n't many in this village that that man ai n't cheated all ways — cheated out o ’ pennies an ’ shillin 's , an ’ crowns an ’ gold pieces .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: He has a regular system of exacting tribute .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Pulling a document out of his pocket .More than that , the fellow is ripe for the public prosecutor .He places the document on the table .I would request you to read this through .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Mrs. Dreier has signed that paper herself . Motes tried to inveigle her into committing perjury .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: She was to give evidence against me .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Putting his hand on FLEISCHER 'S arm .This gentleman is of unblemished conduct and that scoundrel wanted to get him into trouble . And you lend your assistance to such things ! ** All speak at once . **

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: My patience is exhausted now . Whatever dealings you may have with Motes do n't concern me and are entirely indifferent to me .To FLEISCHER .You 'll be good enough to remove that rag !

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Alternately to MRS. WOLFF and to GLASENAPP .That man is his honour 's friend : that is his source of information . A fine situation . We might better call him a source of defamation !

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: To MITTELDORF .I 'm not accountable to any one . It 's my own business what I do ; it 's my own business with whom I associate ; it 's my own business what I choose to think and write !

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Why you can n't hear your own words in this place no more ! Your honour , shall I go an ’ fetch a policeman ? I can run right over and get one . Mitteldorf !...

sp.speaker: ** End all **
sp.p: WEHRHAHN Quiet , please !Quiet is restored . To FLEISCHER .You will please remove that rag .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Obeys .That rag , as you call it , will be forwarded to the public prosecutor .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You may do about that exactly as you please .He arises and takes from a case in the wall the package brought by MRS. WOLFF .Let us finally dispose of this matter , then .To MRS. WOLFF .Where did you find this thing ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: It ai n't me that found it at all .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , who did find it ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: My youngest daughter .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , why did n't you bring her with you then ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: She was here , all right , your honour . An ’ then , I c'n go over an ’ fetch her in a minute .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That would only serve to delay the whole business again . Did n't the girl tell you anything about it ?

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You said it was found on the way to the railway station .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In that case the thief is probably in Berlin , That wo n't make our search any easier .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I do n't believe that at all , your honour , Mr. Fleischer seems to me to have an entirely correct opinion . The whole business with the package is a trick meant to mislead us .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , well . That 's mighty possible .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Now , Mrs. Wolff , you 're not so stupid as a rule . Things that are stolen here go in to Berlin . That fur coat was sold in Berlin before we even knew that it was stolen .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , your honour , I can n't help it , but I ai n't quite , not quite of the same opinion . If the thief is in Berlin , why , I ax , does he have to go an ’ lose a package like that ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Such things are not always lost intentionally .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Just look at that there package . It 's all packed up so nice — the vest , the key , an ’ the bit o ’ paper ...

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I believe the thief to be in this very place .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Confirming him .Well , you see , Mr. Krueger .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I firmly believe it .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Sorry , but I do not incline to that opinion . My experience is far too long ...

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: What ? A long experience ? H-m !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Certainly . And on the basis of that experience I know that the chance of the coat being here need scarcely be taken into account .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Well , well , we should n't go an ’ deny things that way , your honour .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: Referring to FLEISCHER .And then he saw the boatman ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Do n't bother me with that story . I 'd have to go searching people 's houses every day with twenty constables and policemen , I 'd have to search every house in the village .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Then you better go an ’ start with my house , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , is n't that ridiculous ? No , no , gentlemen : that 's not the way . That method will lead us nowhither , now or later . You must give me entire freedom of action . I have my own suspicions and will continue to make my observations . There are a number of shady characters here on whom I have my eye . Early in the morning they ride in to Berlin with heavy baskets on their backs , and in the evening they bring home the same baskets empty .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I suppose you mean the vegetable hucksters . That 's what they do .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Not only the vegetable hucksters , Mr. Krueger . And I have no doubt but that your coat travelled in the same way .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That 's possible , all right . There ai n't nothin ’ impossible in this world , I tell you .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , then ! Now , what did you want to announce ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: A little girl , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I will do all that is possible .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: I wo n't let the matter rest until I get back my coat .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , whatever can be done will be done . Mrs. Wolff can use her ears a little .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: The trouble is I do n't know how to act like a spy . But if things like that do n't come out — there ai n't no sayin ’ what 's safe no more .

sp.speaker: KRUEGER
sp.p: You are quite right , Mrs. Wolff , quite right .To WEHRHAHN .I must ask you to examine that package carefully . The handwriting on the slip that was found in it may lead to a discovery . And day after to-morrow morning , your honour , I will take the liberty of troubling you again . Good morning !

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: FLEISCHER
sp.p: Good morning .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To WULKOW .How old are you ?— There 's something wrong with those two fellows up here .He touches his forehead . To WULKOW .What is your name ?

sp.speaker: WULKOW
sp.p: August Philip Wulkow .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To MITTELDORF .Go over to my apartment . That Motes is still sitting there and waiting . Tell him I am sorry but I have other things to do this morning .

sp.speaker: MITTELDORF
sp.p: An ’ you do n't want him to wait ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Harshly .No , he need n't wait !

div.stage: MITTELDORF , exit .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To MRS. WOLFF .Do you know this author Motes ?

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: When it comes to people like that , your honour , I 'd rather go an ’ hold my tongue . There ai n't much good that I could tell you .

lg.stage: Ironically .
lg.l: But you could tell me a great deal that 's good about
Fleischer .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: He ai n't no bad sort , an ’ that 's a fac ’ .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I suppose you 're trying to be a bit careful in what you say .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , I ai n't much good at that . I 'm right out with things , your honour . If I had n't always gone an ’ been right out with what I got to say , I might ha ’ been a good bit further along in the world .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That policy has never done you any harm with me .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: No , not with you , your honour . You c'n stand bein ’ spoken to honest . Nobody do n't need to be sneaky ‘ round you .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In short : Fleischer is a man of honour .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: That he is ! That he is !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , you remember my words of to-day .

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: An ’ you remember mine .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Very well . The future will show .He stretches himself , gets up , and stamps his feet gently on the floor . To WULKOW .This is our excellent washerwoman . She thinks that all people are like herself .To MRS. WOLFF .But unfortunately the world is differently made . You see human beings from the outside ; a man like myself has learned to look a little deeper .He takes a few paces , then stops before her and lays his hand on her shoulder .And as surely as it is true when I say : Mrs. Wolff is an honest woman ; so surely I tell you : this Dr. Fleischer of yours , of whom we were speaking , is a thoroughly dangerous person !

sp.speaker: MRS. WOLFF
sp.p: Shaking her head resignedly .Well , then I do n't know no more what to think ...

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALLS
sp.p: THE CONFLAGRATION

sp.speaker: PERSONS
sp.p: FIELITZ , Shoemaker and Spy . Near sixty years old .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ , formerly MRS. WOLFF , his wife . Of the same age
