sp.p: LEONTINE , her oldest daughter by her first marriage ; unmarried ; near thirty .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI , Architect
sp.p: LANGHEINRICH , Smith . Thirty years old .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT , retired Prussian Constable
sp.p: GUSTAV , his oldest son , a congenital imbecile .

sp.speaker: MIEZE , LOTTE , TRUDE , LENCHEN , LIESCHEN , MARIECHEN , TIENCHEN , HANNCHEN ,
sp.p: his daughters .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER , a vigorous man of thirty-six . Physician . Of Jewish birth
sp.p: VON WEHRHAHN , Justice .

sp.speaker: EDE , Journeyman at LANGHEINRICH 'S
sp.p: GLASENAPP , Clerk in the Justice 's Court .

sp.speaker: SCHULZE , Constable
sp.p: MRS. SCHULZE , his aunt .

sp.speaker: TSCHACHE , Constable
sp.p: A FIREMAN .

sp.speaker: A BOY
sp.p: JANITOR OF THE COURT .

sp.speaker: VILLAGE PEOPLE
sp.p: Scene : Anywhere in the neighbourhood of Berlin .

sp.speaker: THE FIRST ACT
sp.p: The work shop of the shoemaker FIELITZ . A low room with blue tinted walls . A window to the right . In each of the other walls a door . Under the window at the right a small platform . Upon it a cobbler 's bench and a small table . On the latter a stand upholding three spheres of glass filled with water . Near them stands an unlit coal-oil lamp . In the corner , left , a brown tile oven surrounded by a bench and kitchen utensils of various kinds .

sp.speaker: SHOEMAKER FIELITZ is still crouching over his work . On the platform
sp.p: and around it old shoes and boots of every size are heaped up . FIELITZ is hammering a piece of leather into flexibility .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: formerly MRS. WOLFFis thoughtfully turning over in her hands a little wooden box and a stearin candle . It is toward evening , at the end of September .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You get outta this here shop . Go on now !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Briefly and contemptuously .Who d'you think 'll come in here now ? It 's past six .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You get outta the shop with that trash o ’ yours .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I wish you would n't act so like a fool . What 's wrong about this here little box , eh ? A little box like this ai n't no harm .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Working with enraged violence .It 's somethin ’ good , ai n't it now ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Still thoughtfully and half in jest .The sawdust comes up to here ... An ’ then they go an ’ put a candle plumb in the middle here ...

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Look here , ma , you 're too smart for me ! If that there smartness o ’ yours keeps on , I see myself in gaol one o ’ these days .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Harshly .I s'ppose you can n't listen a bit when a person talks to you . You might pay some attention when I talks to you . Things like that interest a body .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I takes an interest in my boots , an ’ I do n't take no interest in nothin ’ else .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: That 's it ! O Lordy ! That 'd be a nice state for us . We 'd all go an ’ starve together . Your cobblin ’ — there 's a lot o ’ good in that !— They puts the candle in here . Y'understand ? This here little box ai n't big enough neither . That one over there would be more like . Let 's throw them children 's shoes out .

div.stage: She turns a box full of children 's shoes upside down .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Frightened .Do n't you go in for no nonsense , y'understand ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ then when they 've lit the candle —... then they stands it up in the middle o ’ the box , so 's it can n't burn the top , o ’ course . Then you puts it , reel still , up in some attic — Grabow did n't do that different neither — right straight in a heap o ’ old trash — an ’ then you goes quiet to Berlin , an ’ when you comes back ...

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Ssh ! Somebody 's comin ’ ! Ssh !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ the devil hisself can n't go an ’ prove nothin ’ against you .

div.stage: A protracted silence .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: If it was as simple as all that ! But that ai n't noways as easy as you thinks . First of all there 's got to be air-holes in here . O ’ course this here awl —: that 'll do for a drill . That thing 's got to have a draught , if you want it to catch ! If there ai n't no draught , it just smothers ! Fire 's gotta have a draught or it wo n't burn . Somebody 's got to lend a hand here as knows somethin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , that 'd be an easy thing for you !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Forgetting his point of view in his growing zeal .There 's gotta be a draught here an ’ another here ! An ’ it 's all gotta be done just right ! An ’ then sawdust an ’ rags here . An ’ then you go an ’ pour some kerosene right in .— There ai n't nothin ’ new in all that . I was out in the world for six years .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , exactly . That 's what I been sayin ’ .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You c'n do that with a sponge an ’ you c'n do that with a string . All you gotta do is to steep ‘ em good an ’ hard in saltpetre . An ’ you c'n light that with burning glasses . It c'n be done twenty steps away !— All that 's been done before now . There ai n't nothin ’ new in all that to me . I know all about it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ Grabow 's built up again . If he had n't gone an ’ taken his courage in both hands , he 'd ha ’ been in the street long ago .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: That 's all right , if a man 's in trouble like water up to his neck an ’ is goin ’ to be drowned . Maybe then ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ there 's many as lets the time slip till he is drowned .

div.stage: The doorbell rings .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Go an ’ put the box away an ’ then open the door .

sp.speaker: JUSTICE VON WEHRHAHN enters , wearing a thick overcoat , tall boots
sp.p: and a fur cap .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Evening , Fielitz ! How about those boots ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: They 's all right , your honour .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You better go an ’ get a little light so 's Mr. von Wehrhahn can see somethin ’ .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , how is everything and what are you doing , Mrs. Wolff ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I ai n't no Mrs. Wolff no more .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: She 's grown very proud , eh , Fielitz ? She carries her head very high ? She feels quite set up ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Hear that ! Marryin 's gone to my head ? I could ha ’ lived much better as a widder .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Who has drawn the lasts out of WEHRHAHN 'S boots .Then you might ha ’ gone an ’ stayed a widder .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: If I 'd ha ’ known what kind of a feller you are , I would n't ha ’ been in no hurry . I could ha ’ gotten an old bandy-legged crittur like you any day o ’ the week .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Gently , gently !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Never you mind her .With almost creeping servility .If you 'll be so very kind , your honour , an ’ have the goodness to pull off your right boot . If you 'll let me ; I c'n do that . So . An ’ if you 'll be so good now an ’ put your foot on this here box .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Holding the burning lamp .An ’ how is the Missis , Baron ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Thank you , she 's quite well . But she 's still lamenting her Mrs. Wolff ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , you see , I could n't do that no more reely . I washed thirty years an ’ over for you . You c'n get enough o ’ anything in that time , I tell you . I c'n show you my legs some day . The veins is standin ’ out on ‘ em , thick as your fist . That comes from the everlastin ’ standin ’ up at the tub ! An ’ I got frost boils all over me and the rheumatiz in every limb . They ai n't no end to the doctorin ’ I gotta do ! I just gotta wrap myself up in cotton , an ’ anyhow I 'm cold all day .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Certainly , Mrs. Wolff , I can well believe that .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: There was a time an ’ I 'd work against anybody . I had a constitootion ! You could n't ha ’ found one in ten like it . But nowadays ... O Lord ! Things is lookin ’ different .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You c'n holler a little louder if you want to .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I can n't blame you , of course , Mrs. Fielitz . Any one who has worked as you have may well consider herself entitled to some rest .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ then , you see , things keep goin ’ . We got our livin ’ right along .She give FIELITZ a friendly nudge on the head .An ’ he does his part all right now . We ai n't neither of us lazy , so to speak . If only a body could keep reel well ! But Saturday I gotta go to the doctor again . He goes and electrilises me with his electrilising machine , you know . I ai n't sayin ’ but what it helps me . But first of all there 's the expenses of the trip in to Berlin an ’ then every time he electrilises me that costs five shillin 's . Sometimes , you know , a person , do n't know where to get the money .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You go ahead an ’ ram your money down doctors ’ throats !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Treads firmly with his new shoe .None of us are getting any younger , Mrs. Fielitz . I 'm beginning to feel that quite distinctly myself . Perfectly natural . Nothing to be done about it . We 've simply got to make up our minds to that .— And , anyhow , you ought n't to complain . I heard it said a while ago that your son-in-law had passed his examinations very well . In that case everything is going according to your wishes .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: That 's true , of course , an ’ it did make me reel happy too . In the first place he 'll be able to get along much better now that he 's somethin ’ like an architect ... an ’ then , he deserved it all ways .— The kind o ’ time he had when he was a child ! Well , I ai n't had no easy time neither , but a father like that ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Schmarowski is a fellow of solid worth . I never had any fears for him . Your Adelaide was very lucky there .— You remember my telling you so at the time . You came running over to me that time , you recall , when the engagement was almost broken , and I sent you to Pastor Friederici :— that shows you the value of spiritual advice . A young man is a young man and however Christian and upright his life , he 's apt to forget himself once in a while . That 's where the natural function of the spiritual adviser comes in .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Yes , yes , I s'ppose you 're right enough there . An ’ I 'll never forget what the pastor did for us that time ! If Schmarowski had gone an ’ left the girl , she 'd never have lived through it , that 's certain .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: There we 've got an instance of what happens when a church and a pastor are in a place . The house of God that we 've built together has brought many a blessing . So , good evening and good luck to you .— Oh , what I was going to say , Fielitz : the celebration takes place on Monday morning . You will be there surely ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Naturally he 'll come .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Sure an ’ certain .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I would hardly know what to do without you , Fielitz . In the meantime , come in for a moment on Sunday , I 'm proposing certain points ... certain very marked points , and we must pull together vigorously . So , good evening ! Do n't forget — we 've got to have a strong parade .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: That 's right . You can n't do them things without one .

div.stage: Exit WEHRHAHN .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You go an ’ take that candle out ! Will you , please ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You 're as easy scared as a rabbit , Anton ! That 's what you are — a reg'lar rabbit . She takes the candle out of the little box . Almost at the same moment RAUCHHAUPT opens the door and looks in .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Good evenin ’ . Am I intrudin ’ ?

lg.l: MRS. FIELITZ
Aw , come right into our parlour !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Ai n't Langheinrich the smith come in yet ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Was he goin ’ to come ? No , he ai n't been here .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: We made a special engagement .— I brought along the cross too . Here , Gustav ! Bring that there cross in !GUSTAV brings in a cross of cast iron with an inscription on it .Go an ’ put it down on that there box .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Quickly .No , never mind , Edward , that 'll break .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Then you c'n just lean it against the wall .

lg.l: So you got through with it at last .
lg.stage: Calls out through the door .
lg.l: Leontine ! You come down a minute !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Trouble is I had so much to do . I 'm buildin ’ a new hot house , you know .

lg.l: Another one , eh ? Ai n't that a man for you ! You 're a reg'lar mole ,
Rauchhaupt . The way that man keeps diggin ’ around in the ground .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: A man feels best when he 's doin ’ that . That 's what we 're all made of — earth : an that 's what we 're all goin ’ to turn to again . Why should n't we be diggin ’ around in the earth ?He helps himself from the snuff-box which FIELITZ holds out to him .That 's got a earthy smell , too , Fielitz . That smells like good , fresh earth .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE enters . A pair of scissors hangs by her side ; she has a
sp.p: thimble on her finger .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Here I am , mama . What 's up ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: He just brought in papa his hephitaph .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE and MRS. FIELITZ regard the cross thoughtfully
sp.p: MRS. FIELITZ Light the candle for me , girl .She hands her the tallow-candle with which she has been experimenting .We wants to study the writin ’ a bit .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I fooled around with that thing a whole lot . But I got it to please me in the end . You c'n go an ’ look through the whole cemetery three times over and you 'll come away knowin ’ this is the finest inscription you c'n get . I went an ’ convinced myself of that .

div.stage: He sits down on the low platform and fills his nose anew with snuff .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ holds the lighted lamp and puzzles out the
sp.p: inscription .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Here rests in ...

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Reading on .In God .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: That 's what I said : in God . I was goin ’ to write first : in the Lord . But that 's gettin ’ to be so common .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Reads on with trembling voice .Here rests in God the unforgotten carpenter ...Weeping aloud .Oh , no , I tell you , it 's too awful ! That man — he was the best man in the world , he was . A man like that , you c'n take my word for it , you ai n't likely to find no more these days .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Reading on .the unforgotten carpenter Mr. Julian Wolff ...

div.stage: She snivels .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: — Do n't you be takin ’ on now , y'understand ? No corpse ai n't goin ’ to come to life for all your howlin ’ .He hands the whiskey bottle to RAUCHHAUPT .Here , Edward , that 'll do you good . Them goin 's on do n't .

div.stage: He gets up and brushes off his blue apron with the air of a man who has completed his day 's work .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Pointing with the bottle .Them lines there I made up myself . I 'll say ‘ em over for you ; listen now : “ The hearts of all to sin confess ” ... ‘ Tai n't everybody c'n do that neither !— “ The hearts of all to sin confess , The beggar 's and the king 's no less . But this man 's heart from year to year Was spotless and like water clear . ”The women weep more copiously . He continues .I gotta go over that with white paint . An ’ this part here about God is goin ’ to be Prussian blue .He drinks .The smith LANGHEINRICH enters .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Regarding LEONTINE desirously .Well now , look here , Rauchhaupt , old man , I been lookin ’ for you half an hour ! I thought I was to come an ’ fetch you , you chucklehead .— Well , are you pleased with the job ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Oh , go an ’ do n't bother me , any of you ! If a person loses a man like that one , how 's she goin ’ to get along with you jackasses afterwards !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Come on , man , an ’ pull up a stool . You just let her get back to her right mind .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: With sly merriment .That 's right , I always said so myself : this here dyin ’ is a invention of the devil .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: We was married for twenty years an ’ more . An ’ there was n't so much as one angry word between us . An ’ the way that man was honest . Not a penny , no ,— he never cheated any man of a penny in all his days . An ’ sober ! He did n't so much as know what whiskey was like . You could go an ’ put the bottle before him an ’ he would n't look at it . An ’ the way he brought up his children ! What d'you think about , but playin ’ cards and swillin ’ liquor ...

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Gustav is poking out his tongue at me .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Takes hold of a cobbler 's last and throws himself enragedly upon GUSTAV , who has been making faces at LEONTINE and has poked out his tongue at her .You varmint ! Ill break your bones !— That rotten crittur is goin ’ to be the death o ’ me yet . I just gets so mad sometimes I think it 's goin ’ to be the death o ’ me .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: The poor crittur ai n't got his right senses .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I wish to God the dam ’ brat was dead . I 'll get so dam ’ wild some day , if he ai n't , that I 'll go an ’ kill my own flesh an ’ blood .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'd go an ’ have him locked up in the asylum . Then you do n't have the worry of him no more . D'you want me to write out a petition for you ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Do n't I know all about petitions ? What does they say then : he ai n't dangerous bein ’ at large .— The whole world ai n't nothin ’ but a asylum . It ai n't dangerous , o ’ course , that he fires bricks at me , an ’ unscrews locks and steals house keys — oh , no , that ai n't considered dangerous . No , an ’ it 's all right for him to eat my tulip bulbs . I c'n just go ahead an ’ do the best I can .

lg.l: How did that happen at Grabow 's the other day — I mean when his inn the
“ Prussian Eagle ” burned down ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Aw , Grabow , he needed just that . It was n't no Gustav that set that there fire . He was n't needed there .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: They say he 's always playin ’ with matches .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Gustav an ’ matches ? Aw , that 's all right . If he c'n just go an ’ hunt up matches some place , trouble ai n't very far off . You know I needs coverin 's for my hot house plants ; so I built a kind of a shed . I stored the straw in there . Well , I tell you , Mrs. Fielitz , that there idjit went an ’ burned the shed down . It was bright day an ’ o ’ course nobody was n't thinkin ’ , an ’ I got loose boards all over my lot . The shed crackled right off . It was n't more'n a puff ! But Grabow — he took care o ’ his fire hisself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'd give notice about a thing like that , Rauchhaupt — I mean burnin ’ down the shed .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I do n't get along so very well with Constable Schulze . That 's often the way with people in your own profession . I was honourably retired . He do n't like that . He ai n't sooted with that . All right ; all that may be so . An ’ that I own my own lot , an ’ that my old woman died . Sure , it ai n't no use denyin ’ it ! I made a few crowns outta all that . An ’ that my gardenin ’ brings in somethin ’ — well , he do n't like to see it . So then it 's easy to say : Rauchhaupt ? He do n't need no help . He c'n take care o ’ hisself . An ’ that 's the end of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Fred Grabow , he 's all right now !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Eagerly .An ’ he 's got me to thank for it . Only thing is , I pretty near got into a dam ’ mess myself that time . You see , I 'm captain of the hook an ’ ladder . Well , I says to my boys , says I :— I do n't know but I must ha ’ had more'n I could carry . The whole crowd was pretty well full !— Well , I says to my boys : Sail right in an ’ see that there ai n't a stone left standin ’ , ‘ cause if there is , Grabow 'll get one reduction of insurance after another an ’ then the whole thing ai n't no good to him . I guess I hollered that out a bit too loud . So when I takes a step or two backward I thinks all hell 's broke loose , ‘ cause there stands Constable Schulze an ’ stares at me . Your health , says I , your health , captain !— Grabow , you know , was treatin ’ to beer !— An ’ then Schulze was real sociable and took a drink with me .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: It 's queer that nothin ’ do n't come out there . That fellow ai n't a bit cute . How did he manage to do it ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Everybody likes Fritz Grabow .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: He ai n't got sense enough to count up to three . An ’ anyhow he had to go an ’ take oath .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Takin ’ oath ? Aw , that ai n't so much ! I 'll just tell you how ‘ tis , ‘ cause you never can n't tell . Who knows about it ? Anybody might have to do that some day . All you do is to twist off one o ’ your breeches buttons while you goes ahead and swears reel quiet . You just try it . That 's easy as slidin ’ .

div.stage: General laughter .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: He 's got one o ’ his jokin ’ spells again . I wo n't have to go an ’ twist off a button , I c'n tell you . Things can n't get that way with me .— But tell me this : whose turn is it goin ’ to be now ? It 's about time for somebody , you know . Somethin 's got to burn pretty soon now .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: It could be most anybody . Things is lookin ’ pretty poor over at Strombergers . The rain 's comin ’ right down into his sittin ’ room ,— Well , good evenin ’ . A man 's got to have his joke .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: But who 's goin ’ to drink my hot toddy now ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You stay right where you are !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Ca n't be done . I gotta be goin ’ .He puts an arm around LEONTINE , who frees herself carelessly and with a contemptuous expression .— If mother do n't hear my hammerin ’ downstairs she 'll be swimmin ’ away in tears an ’ the bed with her when I gets home .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: That 's nothin ’ but jealousy , mama .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Maybe it is , an ’ maybe she 's got reason . You go on up to your work .— How is the Missis ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Pretty low . What c'n you expect ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: You 'll be drivin ’ me to work till I gets consumption .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: If you get consumption , it wo n't be your dress-makin ’ that 's the cause of it . You act as much like a ninny as if you was a man .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Putting his arms around MRS. FIELITZ .Come now , young woman , do n't be so cross ! Young people wants to have their fling — that 's all . An ’ they 'll have it , if it 's only with Constable Schulze .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Now what 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Wait there a minute an ’ I 'll join you .

div.stage: He gets up and motions to GUSTAV , who lifts the iron cross again .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Why d'you go an ’ run off all of a sudden ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I gotta go an ’ get rid o ’ some work .

div.stage: Exit with GUSTAV .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: What 's the trouble with you an ’ Langheinrich again ? You act like a fool — that 's what you do !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: There ai n't no trouble . I want him to leave me alone .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: He 'll be willin ’ to do that all right ! If you 're goin ’ to turn up your nose an ’ wriggle around that way , you wo n't have to take much trouble to get rid o ’ him . He do n't need nothin ’ like that !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: But he 's a married man .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: So he is . Let him be . You got no sense ‘ cause you was born a fool . You got a baby and no husband ; Adelaide 's got a husband an ’ no baby .

div.stage: LEONTINE goes slowly out .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: If she 'd only go an ’ take advantage o ’ her chances . There ai n't no tellin ’ how soon Langheinrich 'll be a widower .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I do n't know 's I like to see the way Constable Schulze runs after that girl .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Sententiously .You can n't run your head through no stone walls .She sits down , takes out a little notebook and turns its leaves .You got a office . All right . Why should n't you have ? Things is as they is . But havin ’ a office you got to look out all around . You just let Constable Schulze alone ! Did you read the letter from Schmarowski ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Aw , yes , sure . I got enough o ’ him all right . I wish somebody 'd given me the money — half the money — that feller 's had the use of . But no : nobody never paid no attention to me . Nobody sent me to no school o ’ architecture .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'd like to know what you got against Schmarowski ! You 're pickin ’ at him all the time .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Hold on ! Not me ! He ai n't no concern o ’ mine . But every time you open your mouth I gets ready to bet ten pairs o ’ boots that you 're goin ’ to talk about Schmarowski .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Did he do you any harm , eh ? Well ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: No , I can n't say as he has . Not that I know . An ’ I would n't advise him to try neither . Only when I sees him I gets kind o ’ sick at my stomick . You oughta have married him yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: If I had been thirty years younger — sure enough .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , why do n't you go an ’ move over to your daughter then ! Go right on ! Hurry all you can an ’ go to Adelaide 's . Then they got hold of you good and tight an ’ you c'n get rid o ’ your savin 's .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: That 's an ambitious man . He do n't have to wait , for me ; that 's sure !— there ai n't no gettin ’ ahead with your kind . Instead o ’ you fellows helpin ’ each other , you 're always hittin ’ out at each other . Now Schmarowski — he 's a wide-awake kind o ’ man . No money ai n't been wasted on him . You need n't be scared : he 'll make his way all right .— But if you knew just a speck o ’ somethin ’ about life , you 'd know what you 'd be doin ’ too .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Me ? How 's that ? Why me exactly ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: What was it that there bricklayer boss told me ? I saw him one day when he was full ; they was just raisin ’ that church . He says : Schmarowski , says he , that 's a sly dog . An ’ he knew why he was sayin ’ that . Them plans o ’ his takes ‘ em all in .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I ai n't got no objection to his takin ’ ‘ em in .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: He ai n't the kind o ’ man to sit an ’ draw till he 's blind an ’ let the bricklayers get all the profit .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , I ai n't made the world .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: No , nor you ai n't goin ’ to stop it neither .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ I do n't want to .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You ai n't goin ’ to stop it , Fielitz — not the world an ’ not me . That 's settled .—

div.stage: She has said this in a slightly ironical way , yet with a half embarrassed laugh . She now puts away her little book excitedly .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I can n't get to understand reel straight . I 'm always thinkin ’ there 's somethin ’ wrong with you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Maybe there was somethin ’ wrong with Grabow too , eh ? I s'ppose that 's the reason he 's livin ’ in his new house this day .— I wish there 'd be somethin ’ like that wrong with you onct in a while . But if somebody do n't pull an ’ poke at you , you 'd grow fast to the stool you 're sittin ’ on .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: With decision .Mother , put that there thing outta your mind . I tell you that in kindness now . I ai n't goin ’ to lend my help to no such thing . Because why ? I knows what that means . Is I goin ’ to jump into that kind of a mess again ? No , I ai n't young enough for that no more .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Just because you 're an old feller you oughta be thinkin ’ about it all the more . How long are you goin ’ to be able to work along here . You do n't get around to much no more now . You cobbled around on Wehrhahn 's shoes ! It took more'n two weeks .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , mother , you need n't lie that way .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: That cobblin ’ o ’ yours — that ai n't worth a damn . I ai n't much good no more an ’ you ai n't . That 's a fact . I do n't excep ’ myself at all . An ’ if people like us do n't go an ’ get somethin ’ they c'n fall back on , they got to go beggin ’ in the end anyhow . You c'n kick against that all you want to .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: It 's a queer thing about you , mother . It 's just like as if the devil hisself got a hold o ’ you . First it just sort o ’ peeps up , an ’ God knows where it comes from . Sometimes it 's there an ’ sometimes it 's gone . An ’ then it 'll come back again sudden like an ’ then it gets hold o ’ you an ’ do n't let you go no more . I 've known some tough customers in my time , mother , but when you gets took that way — then I tell you , you makes the cold shivers run down my back .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Has taken out her notebook again and become absorbed in it .What did you think about all this ? We 're insured here for seven thousand .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: What I thought ? I did n't think nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , there ai n't any value to this place excep ’ what 's in the lot itself .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Gets up and puts on his coat .You just leave me alone , y'understand ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , ai n't it true ? You just stop your foolin ’ . I seen that long ago , before we was ever married . Schmarowski told me that ten times over , that this here is the proper place for a big house . An ’ anybody as has any sense c'n see that it 's so . Now just look for yourself : over there , that 's the drug shop ! An ’ a bit across the way to the left is the post office . An ’ then a little ways on is the baker an ’ he 's built hisself a nice new shop . Four noo villas has gone up and if , some day , we gets the tramway out here — we 'll be right in the midst o ’ things .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: About to go .Good evenin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Are you goin ’ out this time o ’ day ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Yes , ‘ cause I can n't stand that no more .— If I 'd known the kind of a crittur you are ... only I did n't know nothin ’ about it ... I 'd ha ’ thought this here marryin ’ over a good bit — yes , a good bit .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You ? Is that what you 'd ha ’ thought over , eh ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Is I goin ’ to let myself be put up to things like that ?...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: A whole lot o ’ thinkin ’ over you 'd ha ’ done ! You ai n't done any thinkin ’ all the days o ’ your life . A great donkey like you ... an ’ thinkin ’ . Well ! A fine mess would come of it if you took to thinkin ’ .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Mother , I axes you to consider that ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Put you up ? To what ? What is I puttin ’ you up to ?— This here old shed is goin ’ to burn down sometime . It 's goin ’ to burn down one time or ‘ nother , if it do n't first come topplin ’ down over our heads . It 's squeezed in here between the other houses in a way to make a person feel ashamed , if he looks at it .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Mother , I axes you to consider ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Aw , I wish you 'd clear out o ’ the front door this minute ! I 'm goin ’ to pack up my things pretty soon too . An ’ you c'n go over to the justice for all I care . I been puttin ’ you up to things , you know !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Mother , I axes you to consider that ... Look out that you do n't go an ’ get a black eye ! ‘ Cause I , if I ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: With a gesture as though about to push him out .Get out ! Just get out ! It 'll be good riddance ! The sooner the better ! What are you dawdlin ’ for ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Beside himself .Mother , I 'll hit you one across the ... You 're goin ’ to put me out , eh ? What ? Outta my shop ? Is this here your shop ? I 'll learn you ! Just wait !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , I 'm waitin ’ . Why do n't you start ? You 're that kind of a man , are you ? Come right on ! Come on now ! You got the courage ! I 'll hold my breath or maybe I 'd blow you right into Berlin .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Hurls a boot against the wall in his impotent rage .I 'll break every stick in this here shop ! To hell with the whole business : that 's what I says ! I must ha ’ been just ravin ’ mad ! There I goes an ’ burdens myself with a devil of a woman like that , an ’ I might ha ’ lived as comfortable as can be ! She killed off one husband an ’ now I 'm dam ’ idjit enough , to take his place ! But you 're goin ’ to find out ! It ai n't goin ’ to be so easy this time ! I 'll first kick you out before I 'll let you get the best o ’ me ! Not me ! No , sir ! You c'n believe that !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You need n't exert yourself that much , Fielitz ...

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Not me ! Not me ! You c'n depend on that ! You ai n't agoin ’ to down me ! You c'n take my word for it .

div.stage: He sits down , exhausted .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Maybe you might like throwin ’ some more boots . There 's plenty of ‘ em around here — I s'ppose you married me for love , eh ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: God knows why I did !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: If you 'll go an ’ study it out , maybe you 'll know why . Maybe it was out o ’ pity ? Eh ? Maybe not .— Or maybe it was the money I had loaned out ?— Well , you see ! I s'ppose that was it .— You c'n live a hundred years for my part ! But it 's always the same thing . ‘ Twas n't much different with Julius neither . If things had gone his way , I would n't have nothin ’ saved this day neither . The trouble is a person is too good to you fellers .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ outta goodness you want me to go an ’ take a match an ’ set fire to the roof over my head ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You knew that you 'd have to go an ’ build . I said that to myself right off , an ’ buildin ’ costs money . There ai n't no gettin ’ away from that fact . An ’ the few pennies we has ai n't more'n a beginnin ’ . If we had what you might call a real house here ... Schmarowski , he 'd build us one that 'd make all the others look like nothin ’ ... you could have a fine shop here . We might put a few hundred dollars into it an ’ sell factory shoes . If you 'd want to take in repairing you could get a journeyman an ’ put him here . An ’ if you wanted to go an ’ make some new shoes yourself , you could take the time for all I care .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I do n't know ! I s'ppose I ai n't got sense enough for them things . I thought I 'd get hold o ’ a bit o ’ money ... I thought I 'd be able to lay out a bit o ’ money ! Buildin ’ a little annex of a shop — that 's good fun . I thought it all out to myself like — with nice shelves and things like that ... an ’ I planned to hang up a big clock an ’ such . An ’ now you sit on your money bag like an old watch dog .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: That money — it ai n't to be thrown away so easy . ‘ Twas earned too bitter hard for that .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You forgets that I 've been in trouble before . Is I to go an ’ get locked up again ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Never mind , Fielitz , to-morrow is another day . A person must n't go an ’ take things that serious ! I was more'n half jokin ’ anyhow .— Go over to Grabow 's an ’ drink a glass o ’ beer !... We must all be satisfied 's best we can . An ’ even if you can n't go an ’ open a shoe shop , an ’ even if you gotta worry along cobblin ’ an ’ can n't buy no clock — well , a good conscience is worth somethin ’ too .

div.stage: THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: THE SECOND ACT

stage.stage: The smithy of LANGHEINRICH . The little house protrudes at an angle into the village street . The shed that projects over the smithy is supported by wooden posts . The empty space below the shed is used for the storage of tools and materials . Wheels are leaned against the wood , a plough , wheel-tyres , pieces of pig iron , etc . An anvil stands in the open , too , and several working stools . From behind the house , jutting out diagonally , a wooden wagon is visible . The left front wheel has been taken off and a windlass supports the axle .
Through the door that leads to the shop one sees smithy fires and bellows .
Opposite the smithy , on the left side of the village street which , taking a turn , is lost to view in the background , there is a board fence . A small locked gate opens upon the street .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER , in a slouch hat and light overcoat , stands holding a
sp.p: heavy smith 's hammer at arm 's length . EDE has a horseshoe in his right hand , a smaller hammer in his left , and is looking on .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Counts .twenty-two , twenty-three , twenty-four an ’ one makes twenty-five an ’ another makes twenty-six .— Great guns , you 're ahead o ’ me now . An ’ twenty-seven , an ’ twenty-eight , an ’ twenty-nine an ’ thirty . My respects , Doctor . That 's all right . Is that the effect o ’ the sea air ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: It may be . You see I have n't quite forgotten the trick .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: No , you have n't . That 's pretty good . Now let 's try it with weights , though . I c'n hold up a hundred an ’ fifty pounds , Doctor . How about yourself ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I do n't know . It remains to be seen .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: What ? You think you c'n lift a hundred weight an ’ a half ? You 're a little bit of a giant , ai n't you ? You did n't learn that on board ship . I thought you travelled as a sawbones an ’ not as a strong man !— Look at that little man over there goin ’ into Mrs. Fielitz ’ house . That 's her son-in-law .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: He looks very much like a bishop .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Right enough ! That 's what he is — Bishop Schmarowski .— You c'n knock ! The old woman 's out and she took her cobbler with her . There wo n't be nothin ’ to get there to-day .— You see , Doctor , when that fellow goes there he wants money . If he were n't hard up he would n't come .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: The Fielitzes went in to Berlin to-day ; I met them this morning at the railway station . Tell me : he is n't quite right in his mind , is he ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: How so ? That was n't never noticed . He 's a pretty keen fellow ... No , I could n't say that he 's crazy .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: He talked a mixture of idiotic nonsense and looked away from me while he was talking . The fellow looked like an evil conscience personified . But I do n't suppose he has a conscience .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: By the way : that time they came down on you an ’ made a search in your house — that fellow Fielitz had his hand in it . He helped get you into that pickle .

div.stage: MRS. SCHULZE puts her head out at the attic window .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: Ede !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: Ai n't Mr. Langheinrich back yet ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Well , o ’ course he is , naturally .MRS. SCHULZE disappears and EDE withdraws under the shed .Quick ! Take this hammer , will you , Doctor , an ’ hammer away a bit . If you kept up your strength the way you have , you ai n't forgot about that neither .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I went at locksmith 's work like the deuce when there was nothing to do on board ship . That gave me a very good chance .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: You 're a doctor an ’ you 're a smith an ’ ... I guess you 're a sausage maker too !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I even made sausages once .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Nobody did n't want to eat them , I guess .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I would n't have advised any one to do so either . The sausages were mainly filled with arsenic . The rats scarcely left us space to turn around in .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: About to set to work .Ugh ! That would n't be no kind o ’ sausage for me . Come now , Doctor , go at it ! We wants the missis to think that two people is workin ’ here or she 'll never stop axin ’ questions .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Where did Langheinrich go so early ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: That 's a secret all right — the kind o ’ secret that all the sparrows on the gutters is chirpin ’ .— Doctor , roll that wheel over here , will you ? You got a chance now to deserve well , as they says , o ’ the Prussian state , ‘ cause this here waggon belongs to the government forester .— That sort o ’ thing can n't do you no harm .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: No . And anyhow I ought to stand in with people .

div.stage: He rolls the wheel slowly along ; it escapes him and glides backwards .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: That ai n't so easy . Them people has long memories .He catches the wheel .Hold on there ! No goin ’ backward ! I 'm for progress , I am , Doctor ! I 'm willin ’ to fight for that !

lg.l: But you must be careful of your fingers .
lg.stage: He puts on a leathern apron .
lg.l: Is Langheinrich going to be gone long ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Whistles .That depends on how hard it is !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Why do you whistle so significantly ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: That 's a gift o ’ my family . All my eleven brothers an ’ sisters is musicians . I 'm the only one that 's a smith .For a space both work at the wheel in silence . Then EDE continues .‘ Twould n't be a bad stage play , I tell you . You would n't have to be scared o ’ riskin ’ somethin ’ on that . You 'd make money ! That 's somethin ’ fine — specially for young people ! You been away here a good long while , that 's the reason you do n't know what 's what . I could tell you a few little things that happen around here in bright daylight .— D'you know that Leontine ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Very sorry indeed , but I do n't .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: No ? An ’ then you pretend that this is your home an ’ do n't know that girl . Somethin ’ wrong with you !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Oh , yes , yes , Leontine ! Mrs. Wolff 's daughter ! I once got the deuce of a flogging on her account .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Well , I wish you 'd ha ’ been here two hours ago . Well , first of all that same girl slouched by here ... No ! First of all her mother an ’ father went away ...' twas n't more'n dawn yet ! Then Leontine at about eight . She looked all around an ’ waited an ’ made lovin ’ eyes in this direction an ’ then walked by . You should ha ’ seen Langheinrich . “ Sweetheart , where are you goin ’ ? ” — Then , after a while comes Constable Schulze and goes after her .— That was too much for Langheinrich . Off with his apron an ’ there he goes , quick ‘ s a stag . That 's the way it was . You could ha ’ observed that : the rest ai n't to be observed .— There 's Langheinrich hurryin ’ back now .He at once sets zealously to work and pretends to discover LANGHEINRICH , who is approaching hastily and vigorously at this moment .Well , at last ! Good thing you 're here ! No end o ’ askin ’ after you . Did you catch her ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Brusquely .Catch what ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: I meant the ‘ bus .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Hold your ...! I had business to attend to .— Well now , I 'll give a dollar if this here ai n't Dr. Boxer ! Why , how are you ? How are things goin ’ ? An ’ what are you doin ’ nowadays ? Did your ship come in ? You been away now — lemme see — that must be three years , eh ? Sure . That 's ... well , time passes .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I want to settle down here , Langheinrich . That is to say , I have that intention if it 's possible . I should like to try my luck at home for a change .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Things is best at home , that 's right . O ’ course , there 's one here now , a doctor I mean , but he ai n't good for much . They say somethin ’ queer happened to him onct — got his ears boxed too hard or somethin ’ . An ’ they say that made him kind o ’ melancholious . That ai n't much good for his patients ! No sick man can n't get well through that . I 'll send for you , Doctor , if I need help .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I 'll extract my first dozen wisdom teeth free of charge . So you 'll be glad if you do n't need me soon .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Well , I ... fact is ... my wife is sick .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE comes hurriedly from the house
sp.p: MRS. SCHULZE It 's a mighty good thing that you 're here . D'you hear ? That whimperin ’ goes right on .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Doctor , I 'm goin ’ to ax you somethin ’ now : d'you know any cure for jealousy ? You see , it 's this way : We had a baby , an ’ I 'd be lyin ’ if I said I was n't mighty well pleased . An ’ why should n't I be ? But now my wife is sick . She can n't get up an ’ she do n't want me to budge from the side o ’ her bed . She screams an ’ she scolds an ’ she reproaches me . Sometimes I reely do n't know what to do no more .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: You better go upstairs a bit first .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Do give him a chance to get his breath !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Oh , pshaw ! Never you mind ! I c'n attend to that right off .

div.stage: After he has taken off his hat and coat and slipped on wooden shoes he hurries into the house .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Well , what d'you think o ’ that ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: He 's a cheerful soul — more so , if possible , than he used to be . It does one good to find a man that way .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Only that I axed after Leontine , that riled him more'n a little bit all right .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: To EDE , watchfully :Where was the boss so early this mornin ’ ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: In Lichtenberg , attendin ’ a dance .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: The treatment that woman 's gettin ’ is all wrong , Doctor . I do n't mix in what do n't concern me . But the way she 's treated , that ai n't no kind o ’ treatment , I c'n tell you . I told that Majunke man too that the missis was goin ’ to the dogs this way .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: But Dr. Majunke is very capable . I know him to be an excellent physician .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: Interrupting .Sure , sure , an ’ that 's true . ‘ Course he 's capable . That 's right , an ’ so he is . But , you see , he just wo n't prescribe nothin ’ ...

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: What should he prescribe ? Let the people save their money .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: But that 's just what people do n't want to do . It 's like this : medicine 's got to be . If there ai n't none they says : how c'n the doctor help us ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Mrs. Langheinrich never was strong . Even years ago when she used to sew for us ...

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: That 's the way it is . She 's a little bit humpbacked ; that 's right . That 's the way women is , though , Doctor ! A seamstress — that 's what she was ...! She sewed an ’ she sewed and saved up a little money ...! An ’ what kind of a bargain is it she 's got now . A handsome feller an ’ sickness an ’ worry an ’ no rest no more by day or night .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH returns from the house
sp.p: LANGHEINRICH

div.stage: Tapping MRS. SCHULZE 'S shoulder somewhat roughly . ] Hurry now ! Go on up ! It 's all arranged an ’ settled . To-morrow I 'm goin ’ to take her to the clinic .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: That ai n't goin ’ to be no easy work !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Lifts a great can of water to his mouth .I can n't help that . Things is as they is .He takes an enormously long draught from the tin can . Putting it down :Ede , drive them ducks away !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Acting as though he were driving away ducks , flaps his leathern apron and rattles his wooden shoes .Shoo ! Shoo ! Shoo ! Chuck ! Chuck ! Chuck !

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE retires into the house , shaking her head
sp.p: LANGHEINRICH Them ducks is your regular fire eaters . There do n't need nothin ’ but for some sparks to fly off an ’ , right straight off , they gobbles ‘ em down . Then we gets what you might call roast duck that never meant to be roasted . An ’ my old woman she ai n't no friend o ’ that .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT looks over the fence to the left
sp.p: LANGHEINRICH There 's been a big fire again over there behind Landsberg . All the houses on a great estate is ashes .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Did you maybe see Gustav anywhere ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Mornin ’ , old boy ! No , not me ! Has he gone an ’ run off again ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I ordered him to go over to the Fielitzes .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: The Fielitzes have all gone in to town .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I do n't know , but there 's a kind o ’ burned smell in the air ... Ouch !He distorts his face in pain and grasps his leg .Ai n't Leontine here ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Naw , she had to go to court to-day . Always the same trouble with the alimony . That confounded feller , he do n't pay .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Calls out .Gustav !He listens and then turns leisurely back to the little gate . The wind worries and drives him .Gustav !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Stiff wind coming up , all right !RAUCHHAUPT disappears .Ede !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Let 's get to work now !He spits into his hands and sets to work vigorously .Well , Doctor , where 've you been runnin ’ about ? Did you get as far as the Chinese ? You gotta tell us all about that some day when we got plenty o ’ time for it .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Surely , I 've been all over .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Did you see the sea-serpent too ?

sp.speaker: Da . BOXER
sp.p: Surely , Langheinrich , far down in the South Seas .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: An ’ it 's true that it feeds on dill pickles ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Several hundred dozen a day .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Laughing .That 's all right then . An ’ when , you see that serpent again , just give her my best regards .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I doubt whether I 'll ever get so far again in life .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: I guess you got all you wanted o ’ that ? Now you see . Doctor , you just got to the point where I am exactly an ’ I did n't have to move from this spot .— Well , I guess your old mother , she 'll be glad . She 's gettin ’ along all right . Doin ’ reel well . I always looked in a bit now an ’ then , helpin ’ to see that things was all right .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: And that was very good in you , Langheinrich .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Naw ! Pshaw ! I ai n't sayin ’ it on that account . By the way , though , before I forget . I got a little account standin ’ with your good mother — for taffeta an ’ silk an ’ needles an ’ thread . Some cloth , too . My wife used ‘ em sewing . I 'll straighten that up very soon .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Deprecatingly .Never mind . That matter will be arranged .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Ede !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: All right ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Hurry along now !He takes up a heavy hammer .If I do n't go right on workin ’ I 'll end by bustin ’ out o ’ my skin .

sp.speaker: EDE approaches with a white hot piece of iron in the tongs and holds
sp.p: it on the anvil .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Now we 're goin ’ to start , Doctor ! Down on it ! Hit it now !He and DR. BOXER beat the iron , keeping time with each other .Well , you see ! It 's got to go evenly . Doctor ! Then I tell you the work 's smooth as butter .

div.stage: They stop hammering ; EDE takes up the iron again , takes it into the smithy and holds it into the flame .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Takes up the water can again and sets it to his lips .There ai n't much to this !

div.stage: Drinks .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Things like that makes you thirsty .

lg.l: LANGHEINRICH
You c'n believe me , Doctor : it was fine anyhow .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: What was it that was go very fine ?

lg.l: Lord ! I do n't know ! I do n't know nothin ’ much . But when I met Constable
Schulze I had a devil of a good time — that 's what !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: An ’ now a glass o ’ beer from Grabow over there . That 's what I could stand fine just now .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Hurry ! Get three steins ! Dr. Boxer will pay for ‘ em .

sp.speaker: EDE wipes his hands on his apron and goes
sp.p: LANGHEINRICH An ’ so you want to settle down here now ! That ai n't no bad idea neither . Only this : you got to be up to all kinds o ’ tricks here . An ’ if you want my advice , Doctor , do n't go to people for nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Do you think that I 'll be unmolested in other respects ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Aw , them old stories ! Them 's all outlawed by now . An ’ then , nowadays they can n't worry people so much no more as they used to do under the old laws .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Well , at all events I 'll make the attempt ... My political ardour has cooled off . If these people annoy me in spite of that , I 'll simply trudge off again . I 'll go back to sea , or I 'll let myself be engaged ...

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Pretty easy drownin ’ on water !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Continuing .Then I 'll let myself be engaged to go to Brazil with the Russian Jews .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: What would you get out o ’ that ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Yellow fever , perhaps .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Anything else . Doctor ? That would n't be nothin ’ for me !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I believe that .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Me go an ’ wear myself out for other people ? Not me ! No , sir ! I do n't do nothin ’ like that . An ’ why should I ? Nobody do n't give me nothin ’ . I tell you people in this world is a pretty sly set . I 've had time to find that out .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: You 're a regular heathen : you 're not a Christian at all !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That kind o ’ talk do n't do much good with me . I 'm a Christian just like all the rest is ! The people that sit in the new church here ... ‘ cause they built a new church here now !... if them is Christians , the Lord forgive ‘ em .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: That 's easily said , Langheinrich . But one ought not to be a Pharisee . Where is your Christian long-suffering ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: No , I ai n't goin ’ in for long-sufferin ’ . I 'm a sinner myself ; that 's true all right . But now you take this Dalchow here for instance ! It 'd take the devil to be long-sufferin ’ where he 's concerned ! What did he do with that son o ’ his . He kicked him out , that 's what , by night , in winter . Then he tied him up and beat him till he could n't gasp . An ’ then he apprenticed the little feller to a butcher so that he had to drive out the sheep ! An ’ all the time jabbin ’ at him an ’ overworkin ’ him till in the end the poor little crittur went an ’ drowned hisself in the lake . Just shook his head an ’ kept still an ’ then dived down an ’ that was the end .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Ironically .I do n't see what you 've got against Dalchow , Langheinrich ? He 's a man who seems to understand his business magnificently .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Yes , ruinin ’ girls an ’ that sort o ’ thing , that 's what . An ’ then beatin ’ his hat around their heads an ’ sayin ': Out with the low strumpet ! That 's what they is all of a sudden when it 's he that made ‘ em — what they is !— Oh , an ’ then he 's a great friend o ’ Wehrhahn 's an ’ grunts out like a swine in public meetin 's : There ai n't no more morality these days ... an ’ there ought to be laws against such doin 's ... an ’ so on , an ’ so on ... an ’ if you 'd like to go to church , there the old rotten sinner sits an ’ turns up his eyes .A distant ringing of church bells if heard .Listen to that ! The sparrow is singin ’ .— I always calls that the sparrow , Doctor . I always says : the sparrow sings . I mean when them bells is ringin ’ . An ’ ai n't I right that it 's the sparrow that sings ? ‘ Cause since Wehrhahn got that bird in his buttonhole them bells has begun to ring . An ’ if the bells did n't go an ’ ring , why he would n't have no decoration neither .

sp.speaker: EDE comes in grinning and carrying three steins of beer

lg.l: EDE
Oho , listen there , the sparrow is singin ’ .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Well , you see , he do n't call it nothin ’ else no more .Each of the three holds a stein . They knock them together .Your health ! An ’ welcome back to the old country !They drink .That 's a fine evenin ’ this mornin ’ . I 'd like to see this night by day .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Now I 'm goin ’ to blaspheme a bit . I 'm not opposed to the building of churches at all .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: An ’ I ai n't neither . People gets work ! I did n't get any this time , though . An ’ even if there 's a little trouble now an ’ then , Pastor Friderici an ’ a bit o ’ nonsense with coloured windows an ’ altar cloths — that do n't do no harm . People has to have a little .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Yes , those people are entitled to cultivate their own pleasures . And then , Langheinrich , a higher principle has to be represented somehow .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Sure , an ’ it brings people out here too , you c'n believe me . Buildin ’ lots has gone up considerable .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: That 's so . An ’ there was a man onct that did n't have no roof over his head ... No , that ai n't the way to begin what I want to say .— I was onct out on the heath — far out . All of a sudden : what d'you think I heard , Doctor ! I heard a dickens of a screechin ’ .— I goes up to it . Crows ! Yes , sir . There was a feller hangin ’ high up in a pine tree — tailor 's journeyman from over in Berkenbruck : he hanged hisself on account o ’ starvation — hanged hisself high up .— Yes , there 's always got to be somethin ’ higher !

div.stage: While they finish drinking their beer the long-drawn cries of pain of a man 's voice are heard from some distance . The wind has risen considerably .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: What is that ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Rauchhaupt . Nothin ’ to worry about .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Sounds kind o ’ gruesome , do n't it ? ‘ Tai n't nothin ’ very lovely neither . When that feller 's pains in his leg gets hold o ’ him an ’ he roars out that way o ’ nights — that goes right through an ’ through any one . No , before I 'd stand pain like that I 'd go an ’ put a bullet through my head .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Gee-rusalem ! That 's a wind again . Look out , Doctor , that your hat do n't fly away . A hat is whirled by the wind along the street . SCHMAROWSKI , hatless , a roll of paper in his hand , runs chasing it .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Run along , sonny ! Right on there ! Show us what you c'n do !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: That hat is tired of his position : wants a holiday .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Who has recovered his hat , turns angrily to DR. BOXER .What was that very appropriate remark you made just now ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: That you are an excellent runner .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Schmarowski !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Boxer !

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Much pleased .— Now I 'd like to ask you a question . Do you know what a fathead is ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: No .

lg.l: You do n't ? Neither do I . But now tell me : you know what a schlemihl is ,
I suppose .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Nothin ’ broke loose here ? What 's all this about ? Easy now , easy ! Howdy do , Mr. Schmarowski ? How are you ? Have you come to visit your mother-in-law ?

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: I have business here !— And before I forget it , I should like to say : Have the goodness to be more careful .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Who is this amusing gentleman , Langheinrich ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: That 's Mrs. Wolff 's son-in-law .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: I 'll have no dealings with you at all .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Naw , you better not .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Not with you —Turning to DR. BOXER .But if you do n't know who I am , you can get information from Baron von Wehrhahn , the Right Reverend Bishop , the Baroness Bielschewski and the Countess Strach .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: You want me to go around and get information from all those people ?

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: That 's what you 're to do — just that an ’ nothing else . Then maybe you can be more careful in future an ’ look people over before you talk .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: What 's gotten into you to-day ? You 're so dam ’ touchy !

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: To DR. BOXER , who has glanced at EDE and LANGHEINRICH alternately with serene laughter .You just be so good an ’ be more careful : we ai n't so soft . We do n't take jokes so easy , especially not from the race to which you ...

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Hold on , Mr. Schmarowski ! That 's enough ! Nothin ’ like that here . That 's enough an ’ too much , Mr. Schmarowski . You just see about gettin ’ along on your way now .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Do you know where I am going straight from here ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: You c'n go straight ahead to the Lord hisself ! You c'n go where you want to , Schmarowski ; only , do n't be keepin ’ me from my work . We ai n't got no time to lose here !— Ede , put that axle in !

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI exit , enraged
sp.p: EDE

sp.speaker: Good-bye !
sp.p: DR. BOXER So that was Mr. Schmarowski , the envied pillar of the church ? Why , he 's a poisonous little devil !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Yes , you 're right there ! Pois'nous is what he is . So you did n't , know him , Dr. Boxer ? Well , then you 've seen him now — nothin ’ but a little , sly , venomous pup ! But you ought to go an ’ watch him when he gets in with that pious crowd . Then he lets his ears hang , so ‘ umble his own mother would n't hardly know him , like as if he was sayin ': I ai n't goin ’ to live more'n two weeks at — most an ’ then I 'm goin ’ to heaven to be with Jesus . Yes ! Likely ! There 's another place where he 's goin ’ . But that wo n't be soon . He ai n't thinkin ’ of it much yet . An ’ in the meantime he rolls his eyes upward ‘ cause somethin ’ might be hangin ’ round that he c'n make a profit on .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Well , you c'n look out now ! Yon ai n't goin ’ to get no work on the new institution .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: I know that . Ca n't be helped . Things is as they is . Ca n't hold ’ my tongue at things like that . I wo n't learn that in a lifetime .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Have you many of that kind hereabouts now ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: So , so . Enough to last for the winter .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT has come out of the little gate . He faces the wind ,
sp.p: shades his eyes with his hand and peers around .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Lord A'mighty ! Well , well ! Things is goin ’ the queerest way to-day ! When is they comin ’ back — them Fielitzes ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That ai n't goin ’ to be so very soon to-day . They 've gone to buy a seven-day clock , a regulator . What are you upset about to-day ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Wha ’ ? Fielitz goin ’ to buy that kind of a clock ? I do n't believe 's he c'n survive that .Calls .Gustav !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Ai n't he come back yet ? I guess he 's listenin ’ to the bells . You know how he sits an ’ listens when they ring .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I do n't know . Things is goin ’ queer to-day . Mrs. Fielitz sent for him to come over . Horseradish seed is what she said she wanted . An ’ then she goes an ’ leaves for the city .

div.stage: Exit , shaking his head .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: They been stalkin ’ about since four o'clock in the mornin ’ . Up an ’ down they went with their bull'shYpppHeNeye lantern . I do n't believe they went to bed at all .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Well , if Fielitz has gone to buy a clock you can n't expect him to eat or drink or sleep .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Behind the fence .Gustav !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: The boy is coming now , running along .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That 's right . Rauchhaupt ! Here 's Gustav !

sp.speaker: GUSTAV comes prancing up , highly excited , gesticulating violently
sp.p: He points in the direction from which he has come .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Is that there a war dance you 're tryin ’ to perform ? Looks like the cannibals ’ goin 's on . I believe that brat feeds on human flesh .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Hurry now an ’ run to your father .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Go on now !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Get along with your horse-radish .

sp.speaker: GUSTAV gesticulating , puts his hollow hand to his mouth and toots in
sp.p: imitation of a trumpet . Laughter .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Where 's the fire , you little firebrand ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Ede , catch hold o ’ him !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: All right .He tries to creep up to GUSTAV . The latter observes this , gives a loud toot and , still tooting , hurries away , dropping a box of matches as he does so .Hallo !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: What 's that ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Just what I need .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: What ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Safetys ! A whole box full .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE comes rushing down the stairs

lg.l: MRS. SCHULZE
Mr. Langheinrich !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Well , what ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: Mr. Langheinrich !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Here I is !

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: It 's ... it 's ... it 's ... over at ...

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Anything about the missis ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: No , at Fielitzes ’ .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Is that so ? Nothin ’ about my wife ? Well , then ,—he shakes her— just stop to get your breath . Things is as they is . I 'm prepared for anythin ’ — life an ’ death . I gotta stand it .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: The engine !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: What kind o ’ talk is that ? Anythin ’ wrong with you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: No ; it 's burnin ’ !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Go an ’ blow it out then !— Where is it burnin ’ !

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: At the Fielitzes ’ !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Good Lord ! That ai n't possible !

div.stage: He drops the iron file and some nails which he has been holding .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Where 's the fire ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: At Fielitzes ’ ; the flame is comin ’ out o ’ the skylight .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Has stepped forward .Confound it all , but it 's smoky ! Come here ! You can see it well from here .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Also stares in the direction of the fire . His expression shows that a complete understanding of the situation has come to him , which he expresses by a conscious whistling .There ai n't no words for this ; I just gotta whistle .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Ede ! Run over to Scheibler 's ! Run ! Get the horses for the engine ! That smoke 's comin ’ up thick over the gable .

div.stage: He rushes into the smithy , throws his apron aside , puts on a fireman 's helmet , belt , etc .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: An ’ nobody at home there , goodness gracious !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: That 's the lucky part of it , after all . The roaring of the fire alarm trumpet is heard .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: You hear , Doctor ? They 're tootin ’ already !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Reappears in his fireman 's uniform .You get out o ’ the way here , old lady . Go an ’ attend to things upstairs . Nothin ’ to be done here with a syringe . You go up to my wife . Hold on ! We gotta have the key to the engine house . The devil !

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE withdraws into the house . RAUCHHAUPT 'S head reappears
sp.p: on the other side of the fence .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: My , but there 's a smell o ’ burnin ’ in the air .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Sure it smells that way . There 's a fire at the Fielitzes ’ .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: The devil ! I did n't know nothin ’ about that !

lg.l: That 's all right , old man . Was n't you a constable onct ?
lg.stage: He rushes away .
lg.l: A fourteen-year-old boy comes madly hurrying up .

sp.speaker: THE BOY
sp.p: To DR. BOXER .Master ! The key to the engine house ! They can n't get in to the engine .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I 'm not the fireman ! Just keep cool !

sp.speaker: THE BOY
sp.p: They wants you to come to the engine right off .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: You did n't hear what I told you .

sp.speaker: THE BOY
sp.p: There 's a fire !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I know that . The engine master has left . He 's reached the engine long ago .

sp.speaker: THE BOY
sp.p: There 's a fire . They wants you to come down to the engine !

div.stage: He runs away .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT appears at the gate . Two LITTLE GIRLS cling to his rags
sp.p: RAUCHHAUPT I 'm used to that ! It do n't excite me a bit ! Mieze ! Lottie ! You c'n come an ’ see somethin ’ .— I seen hundreds an ’ hundreds o ’ fires ,

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Takes off the leathern apron .It 's a very sad thing for those people , though !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Everythin ’ is sad in this here world . It 's all a question o ’ how you looks at it ! The same thing that 's sad c'n be mighty cheerin ’ . Now there 's me : I raises pineapples , an ’ my hothouse wall ... it 's right up against Fielitzes ’ back wall . Now I wo n't have to keep no fire goin ’ for three days . A somewhat OLDER GIRL also comes out through the gate and nestles close up to the others . MRS. SCHULZE leans out from the window in the gable .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: Addressing someone in the room behind her .Missis , you c'n be reel quiet ! The wind 's blowin ’ from the other side .

div.stage: She disappears .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Did you see that there old witch ? She always knows where the wind comes from .— I retired from all that , yessir ! I did n't want to be a old bloodhound right along . I do n't mix in them things no more . But that woman — she could be a keen one .A fireman , blowing his horn very excitedly , walks by .Go it easy , August ! Patience ! Look out , or your breeches will bust !

sp.speaker: THE FIREMAN
sp.p: Enraged .Aw , shut up ! Go an ’ hide yourself in the holes you 're always diggin .Exit .A FOURTH and a FIFTH GIRL , aged nine and ten years respectively , join the old man .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Laughing .That 's quite a fierce fellow .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Gussie , Nelly , gimme your hand .— That 's all nothin ’ but hurry . That feller do n't know what 's goin ’ on in this world . He 's blowin ’ the trumpet of Jericho , I 'm thinkin ’ , or maybe even the trump o ’ Judgment Day !—

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I do n't think I quite take your meaning , Mr. Rauchhaupt .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Maybe Mrs. Wolff was only tryin ’ to scorch roaches . All right . Maybe , for all I care , ‘ twas somethin ’ else . But if Mrs. Wolff ever puts her hand to somethin ’ — there ai n't very much left .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: What do you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Oh , I was just thinkin ’ .

div.stage: He withdraws , together with the children .
THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: THE THIRD ACT

stage.stage: The court-room of JUSTICE VON WEHRHAHN . A large , white-washed room level with the ground . The main door is in the left wall . Along the wall to the right is the large official table covered with books , documents , etc . Behind it stands the chair of the justice . By the middle window , small table and chair for the clerk of the court . In the foreground , right , a book case of soft wood , and on the left wall , shelves for documents and records . A small door in the background . Several chairs .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP sits at his small table . The JUSTICE 'S chair is
sp.p: unoccupied . In front of the official table DR. BOXER , LANGHEINRICH in his uniform of a captain of the fire brigade , EDE and THREE FIREMEN are waiting . They are engaged in a rather excited conversation . All are red with heat , stained with mud , wet and sooty .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE , somewhat pale , is resting in a chair and waiting
sp.p: likewise . She is in a very thoughtful mood . Repeatedly she takes off her headkerchief and puts it on again and arranges her grey hair . The action takes place on the same day as that of the first act , five hours later . The conversation suddenly ceases .

sp.speaker: JUSTICE VON WEHRHAHN enters betraying a high degree of official
sp.p: zeal . He covers his left eye with his left hand as though in pain , sits down behind the table , takes his hand from his eye , which twitches painfully , and begins .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , what 's the result of this wretched mess ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Noticeably stimulated by exertion , whiskey and beer .I 've come to announce , Baron , that the whole business is burned down .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Throwing down on the table an object which he has brought with him . It is seen to be a photograph in a frame of deer feet .That 's because you 're all only half awake ! You 're all made that way . Yon drowse around and do nothing . We 're not three miles distant from Berlin ; our entire activity should have a different air !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Softly to DR. BOXER .The fire did have air enough , eh ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Your honour ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Never mind . I know all about it .

div.stage: He pulls out his handkerchief , wipes the perspiration from his forehead and taps his eye .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Your honour , I 'd like to lay claim , humbly , to some credit ... We did our part honestly . We was on the spot with the engine .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Then get a better engine !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: But if you can n't get no water !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You managed to get plenty of beer .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Puttin ’ out a fire makes you thirsty !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That seems undoubtedly to have been the case .— Glasenapp , will you come and look ? Something flew into my eye .GLASENAPP jumps up and investigates .I had just examined Mrs. Schulze when the north gable caved in . It must have been a spark or something like that .— By the way , has n't Mrs. Schulze been here ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: Here I is .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Yes , Baron .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN motions him away . GLASENAPP steps back and goes over to his
sp.p: table .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To proceed , then . It has come to my ears ... Mrs. Schulze has informed me , that a certain incident took place in front of your smithy .— It seems that you saw that worthless boy immediately before the flame rose and that he had a box of matches . How is it now with this story of the matches ? Tell us what you know !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: He had a box o ’ matches . That 's so .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: And he let it fall .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: An ’ I picked it up . Yessir .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Me . Same person you see . Here 's the box . All the matches ai n't there no more ‘ cause I smoked several times ...

div.stage: He places the box of matches on the official table .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Unpleasantly impressed by EDE 'S manner , takes up the box and fixes his eyes upon him .You helped along vigorously , I suppose ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: You bet ! ‘ Tai n't no fun otherwise .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I meant especially in the consumption of beer .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: That 's what I thought you meant . Yessir !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You seem to be in a very playful mood .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Merry an ’ larky — that 's my motto , your honour !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Delighted to hear that , I must say .— Look here , are you Dr. Boxer ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Quite right . Dr. Boxer .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: So you are he ! Aha ! I would hardly have recognised you . Your mother still has the little notion shop here .... Your father was a — er — tradesman —?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Voluntarily misunderstanding him .Yes , my father was in the reserve forces and was decorated with the Iron Cross in 1870 .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Ah , yes . Of course . I recall .— Your mother came running to my office recently and brought along several stones . Her kitchen windows had been broken , I believe . Mischievous boys , no doubt . I investigated , of course . I 'm told you want to settle down here ?— There 's a very good physician here now — formerly of the army staff — very capable .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I do n't doubt that for a moment .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To be quite frank — as things are now — I wonder whether this is an appropriate territory for you ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I can take some time to discover that .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Naturally . So can we . So continue , please .— What was it that you observed , Dr. Boxer ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: The incident of the matches certainly .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: The incident of the horn blowing and of the matches .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Certainly .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Where were you when all this took place ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I stood in front of Langheinrich 's smithy .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Did you have any particular business there ?— You need n't get impatient at all . I understand that it does n't concern me at present . Your sympathetic affinity for the working classes is known to us from of old .— The boy will be arrested now . I imagine that Constable Tschache has captured him . At all events — is on his trail . He was seen , in Rahnsdorf too . Please call in Sadowa !

div.stage: GLASENAPP withdraws by the rear door .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Am I dismissed now , your honour ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Extremely sorry ; no . Kindly wait .— Mrs . Schulze , where is your nephew keeping himself today ? I have n't seen him all day long . Does any one know where Constable Schulze is ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Softly .He might send out a warrant after him .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Does n't any one know where Constable Schulze is ?— Has any one interviewed Mrs. Fielitz ? Or has n't she returned from Berlin yet ?— I want somebody to go to Councillor Reinberg .—To GLASENAPP , who is just returning .Mr. Schmarowski , Mrs. Fielitz 's son-in-law , is there submitting his building-plans . The news should be broken to him gently .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Softly to BOXER and LANGHEINRICH .Yes , gently , so he do n't stumble over the church steeple .

div.stage: DR. BOXER and LANGHEINRICH restrain their laughter with difficulty .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
