sp.p: Observing this .Does that strike you as very amusing ?— I do n't know what other reason you should have to laugh , Langheinrich . When people are hardworking and ambitious and a fright like this comes to them — a visitation from God — we might properly say : God protect us from such things ! I see nothing to laugh at .— Did you have the impression ... did the boy seem to you ... I mean , in reference to this affair — as if things were not quite right with him ?

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Softly to BOXER and LANGHEINRICH .We knows where he ai n't quite right !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Did he arouse your suspicion ? Yes or no ? Or did the thought actually occur to you that he might have started the fire ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: No . I have become too much of a stranger here . The conditions seem to overwhelm me .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In what respect ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: With assumed seriousness .I have returned from a very narrow life . Out on the ocean one becomes accustomed to a certain narrowness of outlook . And so , as I said , I hardly feel capable of any comment for the present and must ask for the necessary consideration .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: We 're not discussing conditions . The thing that lies before us is a concrete case . For instance : whether the boy tootled or not — what has that to do with narrowness or breadth of outlook ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Quite right . I have n't been able to get a general view yet . I can n't so suddenly find my way again . I feel , naturally , the importance , the seriousness of the conditions here at home and that makes me feel hesitant .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: He did tootle this way , through his hand , did n't he ? You heard that too , did n't you , Langheinrich ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Sure , he did it right out loud .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: When a feller tootles so tootin'ly that you c'n rightly say he 's tootlin ’ , then you c'n hear that there tootlin ’ tootin'ly .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To LANGHEINRICH .Did you observe anything else that aroused your suspicions ? I mean , while you were extinguishing the fire ? Were there any indications that pointed in another direction , or that might , at least , point in another direction ?LANGHEINRICH thinks for a moment , then shakes his head .You did n't get inside of the house , did you ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: I just barely glanced into the room . Then the ceiling came crashin ’ down . A hair 's breadth sooner an ’ I 'd ha ’ been smothered .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: The fire was started from without . Constable Tschache is quite right in that supposition . Probably from behind where the goatshed is . That would also be in agreement with your evidence , Mrs. Schulze ! You saw him creep around the house . Right above the goatshed there is a window from which , as a rule , straw was sticking out . I myself made that observation . And this window gives on Rauchhaupt 's garden . This window tempted the boy . It tempted him because he had it daily before his eyes . So he simply climbed on the roof of the shed and from there reached the sky-light . Very pleasant neighbour to have — I must say !— Who 's that crossing the street and howling so ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: Looks through the window .Shoemaker Fielitz and his wife .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: What ? Is that Mrs. Fielitz who comes howling so ? It 's enough to melt the heart of a stone .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ , whose loud , convulsive weeping has been audible before
sp.p: she appeared , enters , leaning upon the SEXTON and followed by HER HUSBAND , who carries a large , new clock carefully in his arms . FIELITZ and HIS WIFE are both in their Sunday clothes .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , heavens and earth , Mrs. Fielitz ! Trust in the Lord ! Our trust in the Lord — that 's the main thing ! This is n't a killing matter .— Get a drink of brandy , Nickel ! Go over and ask my wife for it . Mrs. Fielitz has got to be brought to her senses first .— Do me a favour , Mrs. Fielitz , and stop your outburst of tears . I can feel for you , when it comes to that . Quite a severe blow of fate . Have any valuables been destroyed ?MRS. FIELITZ weeps more violently .Mrs. Fielitz ! Mrs. Fielitz ! Listen to me ! Please listen to what I say to you ! Kindly do n't lose your reason ! D'you understand ? Do n't lose your head ! You 're generally a sensible woman .— Well , if you wo n't , you wo n't .—NICKEL , who has been gone for a moment , returns with a brandy bottle and a small glass .— Give her the brandy ; quick ,— I 'll address myself to you , Fielitz . I see that you 're quite collected , at least . That 's the way a man ought to be , you understand . In any situation — be that what it may . So , Fielitz , you give me some information ! I 'll put the same question to you first : Have any valuables been destroyed ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: He is only partially successful in restraining the convulsive sobs that attack him while he speaks .Yes . Six bills ... banknotes !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , I 'll be blessed ! Is that true ? And , of course , you do n't even know the numbers ! My gracious , but you 're careless people ! One ought to think of such things ! But that does no good now . Fielitz , do you hear me ! One ought to take some thought .— Now he 's beginning to howl too ! Do you understand me ? The place for ready money is a bank ! And anyhow — the whole business ! One does n't leave one 's property alone like that ! One should n't leave it quite unprotected , especially with such a crowd in the neighbourhood as we have here !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I ... aw ... who 'd ha ’ thought o ’ such a thing , your honour ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Why do n't you lay that clock down ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'm a peaceable man , your honour . I — I — I — I — Oh , Lordy , Lordy ! I can n't tell you nothin ’ , how that there thing happened .— I 'm on good terms with people ; I do n't quarrel with nobody ... I has made mistakes in my life . That happens when a man ai n't got no good companions . But that people should go an ’ treat me this way ! No , I ai n't never deserved that .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Weeping .Fielitz , what has I always been tellin ’ you ? Who 's right now , eh ? Tell me that : who 's right now ? You did n't make no enemies on our account . Them 's very different stories — them is . An ’ I guess Mr. von Wehrhahn knows somethin ’ about that !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Aw , mother , keep still . That there , that was my dooty .

div.stage: EDE , half seriously , half in jest , makes a threatening gesture behind FIELITZ . WEHRHAHN observes this .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Look here , you there ! What 's that you did ? You stood behind Fielitz and shook your fist over his head .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Maybe I 'm weak in the chest , but I do n't rightly know .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Listen : I 'll tell you something . The place for insane people is the asylum . But if you behave with any more impudence , you 'll first be taken to gaol !— I did n't understand you quite rightly , Mrs. Fielitz . You insinuated something just now . Have you any suspicions in that direction ? I do n't care to express myself more clearly . But do you suspect a — how shall I express it — an act of , so to speak , political reprisal ? In that case you must be absolutely open . We shall then certainly get to the bottom of it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: No , no , no ! I ai n't got no suspicion . I 'd rather go an ’ beg on the public roads . I do n't want to accuse no human being . I do n't know . I can n't make nothin ’ of it at all . That 's what I says again an ’ again . I do n't know nothin ’ .— Everythin ’ was locked up . We went away . The kitchen fire was out ; the top o ’ the oven was cold . Well , how did it happen ? I can n't understand it , nohow . I do n't know . But you see , that a feller like that there feller c'n sit here an ’ make insinerations — that does hurt a body right to the soul !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Do n't permit that to make any impression on you ! Where would any of us be , if we let such things affect us ? Any one who goes to church nowadays has the whole world hooting him . You just stick to me .He rummages among the papers on his table .By the way , I succeeded in saving something here — a picture of your late husband . At least , I believe that that 's what it is . It was framed in deer 's feet .He finds the picture and hands it to MRS. FIELITZ .Here !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ takes the picture , grasps WEHRHAHN 'S hand with a swift
sp.p: motion and kisses it , weeping .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Audibly .Has anybody maybe got a bit o ’ sponge in his pocket , ‘ cause , you see , stockin 's do n't absorb so much water .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Make a note of that fellow , Glasenapp ! Out with him ! At once ! You are to withdraw !

sp.speaker: EDE withdraws with absurd gestures of his arms and legs . Suppressed
sp.p: laughter .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I 'm really very much surprised at you , Langheinrich . That fellow has a regular felon 's face . One of those knife ruffians ; a regular socialist . He 's been in gaol several times on account of street brawls . And that 's the kind of a man that you take into your shop and home .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: All that do n't concern me , your honour . I do n't mix in politics .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Oh , is that so ? We can afford to wait and see .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: If a feller goes an ’ does his work all right ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Nonsense ! Mere twaddle ! Let any one tell me with whom he associates and I will tell him who he is . The murmuring and chattering of a crowd is heard . Constable SCHULZE enters in full uniform .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Where have you been all day ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: Utterly disconcerted for some moments . Then :We nabbed the boy , your honour .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Is that so ? Who did it ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: Me and Tschache .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Where ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: Right near here ; by the church .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: He always sits there and listens to the bells .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Why did n't you tell us that before ? Did he try to escape ? Did he run from you ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: He sat in the ditch an ’ did n't notice us . Tschache could ride close up to him . An ’ then we got him by the scruff an ’ had him tight .

div.stage: He steps back and grasps GUSTAV , whom TSCHACHE is leading in . Members of the crowd press forward .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: H-m ! At all events he is here . I 'm rather sorry , I must say . He 's the son of a former Prussian constable ... Has any one informed old Rauchhaupt ? Somebody had better go for him .

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: I 'm takin ’ care of a sick person , your honour . Maybe I might be able to get off now ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Prepare the record , Glasenapp . No , Mrs. Schulze , you 'll have to remain here for the present . The matter will be finished soon enough .— So let us prepare the record ...

div.stage: He leans back in his chair and stares at the ceiling as if collecting his thoughts for the purpose of dictating .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Softly to DR. BOXER .Look at Mrs. Fielitz , will you , Doctor ? Eh ? Ai n't she grown yellow as a lemon peel ?— If only that thing do n't go crooked , I tell you .He shows to DR. BOXER , who wards him off with a gesture , something secretly in his hollow hand .D'you want to see somethin ’ ? Eh ? That 's a fuse , that 's what .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Softly .Where did you get that from ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: It ai n't me that knows ! That might come from anywhere in the world . It might even come from Fielitz 's cellar . Yessir . Maybe you do n't believe that ? An ’ if I wanted to be nasty , Doctor ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Private conversation is not permitted here .

lg.stage: Tugs at LANGHEINRICH 'S sleeve and asks softly :
lg.l: Did n't you meet
Leontine to-day ? Where was it ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: With a triumphant glance at SCHULZE .Over in Woltersdorf .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , then , Glasenapp ... This is a horrible state of affairs — the seventh conflagration this Autumn . And these people pretend to constitute a civilised society ! These firebrands pretend to be Christians . One need merely step out on one 's balcony to see the reflection of a fire somewhere in the heavens . Now and then in clear nights I have counted the reflections of as many as five . Contempt of judges and laws — that 's what it is ! And that has taken such hold of these scoundrels that arson has become a kind of diversion .— But they had better go slow . Just a little patience , ladies and gentlemen ! We know the tracks ! We are on the right scent ! And the people in question will have a terrible awakening when , quite suddenly , discovery and retribution come upon them . Any one who is at all versed in the procedure of criminal justice knows that it goes ahead slowly and surely and finally lays hold upon the guilty .— But as Commissioner von Stoeckel quite rightly observed : The whole moral downfall of our time , its actual return to savagery is a consequence of the lack of religion ! Educated people do not hesitate to undermine the divine foundations upon which the structure of salvation rests .— But , thank God , we 're always to be found at our place ! We are , so to speak , always on our watch-tower !— And , I tell you , boy : There is a God ! Do you understand ? There is a God in Heaven from whom no evil deed remains hidden . Brotherly love ! Christian spirit ! What your kind needs is to have your breeches drawn tight and your behind flogged ! I 'd make you sick of playing with fires , you infamous little scamp !— Yes , Dr. Boxer , that is exactly my conviction . You can shrug your shoulders all you please ; that does n't disturb me in the slightest degree . You can even take up your pen and raise the cry of cruelty and unfeelingness in the public prints ! Flogging ! Christian discipline — that 's what is needed , and no sentimental slopping around ! You understand !

sp.speaker: GUSTAV
sp.p: Has become more and more excited by the rising enthusiasm of the speaker . At the end of WEHRHAHN 'S oratorical effort he can restrain himself no longer and breaks out in a loud , deceptively exact imitation of an ass 's bray .I ! a ! a ! a ! I ! a ! a ! a !

div.stage: General embarrassment .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Also embarrassed .What does that mean ?

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP
sp.p: I really do n't know .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That 's Gustav 's art , your honour . He 's famous for imitatin ’ animals ’ voices .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Is that so ? And what animal was this supposed to be ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: I guess a lion , all right .—

div.stage: General laughter .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN shrugs his shoulders , laughs jeeringly and goes to his
sp.p: seat . Silence . Then renewed laughter .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I must request silence . This is no place for laughter ! We are not indulging in horse-play for your benefit . We are not trying to amuse any one . The things we are discussing here are of a deadly seriousness . This is n't a circus .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT enters and stares helplessly about him
sp.p: MRS. FIELITZ

div.stage: Tugs at the coat of SCHULZE , who stands near her but with his back turned . He faces her and she asks with a sorrowful expression . ] Did you see my girl to-day ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE nods and turns back again
sp.p: MRS. FIELITZ

div.stage: As before . ] You did see Leontine this morning ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE nods again and turns away
sp.p: MRS. FIELITZ

div.stage: Repeating the action . ] An ’ where did you meet her , Constable ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: Almost without moving his lips .It was over beyond Woltersdorf .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: To LANGHEINRICH .What 's the matter here ? What 's all this here about ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Observes RAUCHHAUPT .You are a retired Prussian constable ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Having failed to hear the question .Say , Schulze , what 's all this for ?

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: His honour axed you somethin ’ . I can n't go an ’ give you no information . That 's against orders . If you 'd only ha ’ kept a better watch on that there boy ! I preached to you about that often enough .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I do n't know what you been preachin ’ ! You ol ’ mush head ! Go on preachin ’ !

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: I begs to have it recorded that Rauchhaupt insulted me officially .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: What ? ‘ Cause you 're such a old idjit ? That 's the reason why I insults you officially ....

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Man alive ! Do you know where you are ? Or have you just dropped here out of the clouds ! Confound it all ! Stand still ! Obey orders !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Here I is , your honour , an ’ I humbly announces ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: That you are recalcitrant and disorderly ! You are trying to get into trouble ! How long have you been retired ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Eleven years .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In addition your memory is probably injured . And anyhow — your whole appearance ! The devil ! To think of a former constable looking like that ... I thought I knew all types !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: That 's ‘ cause I am ... You 'll kindly excuse ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Nothing is excused here ! D'you understand ? You actually smell ! You contaminate the air !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: ‘ Tai n't nothin ’ but the smell o ’ earth ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Horse dung !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: That must be from them pineapples .—

div.stage: Laughter .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: In short : make haste to get out as soon as possible ; otherwise , as I said ... Out ! Out ! You have probably seen now what is taking place here , and now you have nothing further to do .— Here are the papers . Constable ! Take them right over to the court .

div.stage: He hands the papers to SCHULZE . The officers clash their sabres , grasp GUSTAV more firmly and prepare to lead him out . RAUCHHAUPT glares about in helpless and growing terror .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I have the impression , your honour , that this boy is really a patient . You will forgive me for mingling ...

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: The boy 's a imbecile — clean daft !

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: No , no , Doctor ! Oh , no , Mr. Langheinrich , that there boy knows what he 's doin ’ . I had a hen onct an ’ she went an ’ hatched out eleven little chicks and he goes an ’ takes bricks an ’ kills seven of ‘ em .

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: That 's right , aunt . An ’ how about that other business , about the little purse what he stole ?

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: The little purse , yes , an ’ what was in it . An ’ the way he went about that there thing ... nobody as is well could ha ’ done it more clever .

sp.speaker: SCHULZE
sp.p: An ’ then , aunt , the shawl ...

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE
sp.p: Naw , an ’ then that there pistol . That boy 's got all the good sense he needs . I 'm a old an ’ experienced woman .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: What 's that you is ? What ? A ole witch with a low , lousy tongue in her head ! You go an ’ sweep in front o ’ your own door before you go an ’ accuse other people . If somebody was to go an ’ watch your trade — takin ’ care o ’ babies an ’ such like an ’ seein ’ to it that there ai n't no shortage o ’ angels in heaven — all kinds o ’ things might come out an ’ you would n't know how to see or hear no more .— What 's this ? What 's the matter with Gustav ? I gotta know that — what all this here is !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Hold your tongue !To the constable .Right about — march !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Hold on , I says ! Hold on , now ! That 's no way ! Things like that ai n't mentioned in Scripter ! I 'm the father o ’ this here child ! What 's he done ? What do people think he 's done ? Gustav ! What is they accusin ’ you of ? I went through the Schleswig-Holstein campaign ; I was under fire in ‘ sixty-six ; I was wounded in ‘ seventy . Here 's my leg an ’ here is my scars . I served the King of Prussia ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Those are old stories that you 're telling us .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: With God for King and Fatherland ! But this thing here , no , sir ; I can n't allow that . I wants to know what this thing here with Gustav is about !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Look here , my man , you had better come to your senses ! I have told you that once before . In consideration of your service to the state I have overlooked several things as it is . Well now , I 'll do one thing more . Listen to me ! This fine little product — this son of yours , has committed arson . At least , he is under the very strongest suspicion . Now step out of the way and do n't interfere with the officers in the performance of their duty . Go on , Schulze !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Committed arson ? That there boy ? Over there ? At Fielitz 's ? Gustav ? This here boy ? This here little feller ? O Lordy ! But that makes me laugh ! An ’ that they ai n't all laughin ’ — that 's the funny part . Here , Schulze , do n't you go in for no foolishness ! I wore them brass buttons myself onct !— Howdy-do , Mrs. Fielitz ! Well , Fielitz , how are you ? Where are you goin ’ to hang up that clock o ’ yours ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Now he 's jeerin ’ at us atop o ’ our troubles .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Not a bit . Why should I be jeerin ’ at you anyhow ? It 's a misfortune , you think ! Lord , Lord , so it is ! Cats die around in sheds an ’ the birds they falls down dead to the earth . No , I ai n't jeerin ’ at you ! Anyhow : I ai n't scared o ’ many things . I 've gone for some tough customers in my time — fellers that none o ’ the other constables wanted to tackle ! This here finger is bitten through . Yessir ! But before I tackles any one like you — I 'll go an ’ hang myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Almost grey in the face , with trembling lips , yet with considerable vehemence and energy .What 's that man goin ’ for me like that for ? What did I ever do to him , I 'd like to know ! Can I help it that things has turned out this way ? I ai n't seen nothin ’ ! I was n't there ! I ai n't cast no suspicions on no one ! An ’ if they went an ’ arrested that boy o ’ yours — I did n't know no more about that than you !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Woman ! Woman ! Look at me !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Rot ! Stop botherin ’ me . Leave me in peace an ’ do n't go showin ’ off that way ! I got enough trouble to go through . The doctor tells a person not to get excited , ‘ cause you might go just like that ! An ’ a man like you ... We do n't know where to lie down ! We do n't know where we 're goin ’ to sleep to-night ! We 're lyin ’ in the street , you might say , half dead an ’ all broken up ...

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Woman ! Woman ! Can you look at me ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Leave me alone an ’ go where you belongs . I do n't let nobody treat me like that ! I c'n look at you all right ! Why not ? I c'n look at you three days an ’ three nights an ’ see nothin ’ but a donkey before me ! If this here thing is put off on your boy now , whose fault is it mostly ? How did you go an ’ talk about the boy ? You says , says you : he steals , he sets fire to your straw shed — an ’ now you 're surprised that things turns out this way ! You beat this here poor boy ... he used to come runnin ’ over to me with so many blue spots on his body that there was n't a place on him that was n't sore . An ’ now you acts all of a sudden like a crazy man !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN has motioned the officers who grasp GUSTAV more firmly and
sp.p: lead him toward the door . RAUCHHAUPT observes this and jumps with lightning-like rapidity in front of GUSTAV , placing his hands on the latter 's shoulders and holding him fast .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Ca n't be done ! I can n't allow that , your honour . My Gustav ai n't no criminal ! I lived along reel quiet all to myself an ’ now I got into this here conspiracy . There 's got to be proofs first of all !To LANGHEINRICH .Could it ha ’ been he , d'you think ?LANGHEINRICH shrugs his shoulders .Them 's all a crowd o ’ thieves around here — that 's what ... Gustav , do n't you cry ! They can n't , in God 's name — they can n't do nothin ’ to you ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Hands off ! Or ... Hands off !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Your honour , I 'll take my oath o ’ office , that 's what I 'll take , that my boy here is innercent !

lg.l: Tempi passati . You 're getting yourself into trouble . For the last time :
Hands off !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Then I 'd rather kill him right here on the spot , your honour !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Steps between and separates RAUCHHAUPT from his son .Move ’ on ! You 're not to touch the boy ! If you dare the constable will draw his sabre !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: White as chalk , half maddened with excitement , has loosened his hold on GUSTAV and plants himself in front of the main door .Do n't do that to me , your honour , for God 's sake , for Christ 's sake — do n't ! That 's a point o ’ honour with me — a point o ’ honour ! Anythin ’ exceptin ’ that ! I 'll go instead . I c'n furnish bail . I 'll run an ’ get bail . I c'n get back here right away ! Eh ? C'n I ? Or can n't that be done now ?

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Stuff and nonsense . Move out of the way !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I knows who it was that did it !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN thrusts RAUCHHAUPT aside and the two officers conduct
sp.p: GUSTAV out . DR. BOXER and LANGHEINRICH support and restrain RAUCHHAUPT at the same time . He falls into a state of dull collapse . Silence ensues . Without saying a word WEHRHAHN returns to his table , blows his nose , glances swiftly at RAUCHHAUPT and MRS. FIELITZ and sits down .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Let us have some light , Glasenapp .

sp.speaker: GLASENAPP lights a lamp on the table
sp.p: MRS. FIELITZ No , no , I tell you ; it 's bad , bad ! A man like that ! He goes an ’ accuses everybody in the whole place .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: You ! Mrs. Schulze ! You can go your ways !

sp.speaker: MRS. SCHULZE withdraws rapidly
sp.p: MRS. FIELITZ I 'd like to ax your honour ... we do n't even know where we 're goin ’ to sleep to-night .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Are you asleep now , Fielitz ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Frightened from the contemplation of his clock .Not me , your honour !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I thought you were because your head drooped so .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: With childish bashfulness .I was just lookin ’ at the hands .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: To MRS. FIELITZ .You want to go ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: If it 's maybe possible ... I can n't hardly stand on them two legs o ’ mine no more .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: I believe that . When did you get up this morning ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: We both got up around eight o'clock .

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Do you always get up so late ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Sure not ! That there man is confused to-day in his mind . We got up at five . We always get up at five !

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Well , Mrs. Fielitz , you go on home now .— I should be mighty sorry in some respects ... However , justice goes its way . Murder will out . Criminals come to a fearful end ! The eternal Judge does n't forget . And — youTo RAUCHHAUPT .might as well go home . Go home and wait to see how things turn out . I 'll let things go this time . Your paternal feeling robbed you of your senses .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Steps forward .I should like ‘ umbly to report , your honour ...

sp.speaker: WEHRHAHN
sp.p: Go on ! Go on ! What else do you want ? Let us have no more nonsense , my good man .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Goes close up to MRS. FIELITZ .God is my witness ! I 'll show you up !

div.stage: THE CURTAIN FALLS

div.head: THE FOURTH ACT

stage.stage: The attic room over LANGHEINRICH 'S smithy . To the left , two small , curtained windows . At one of the windows an arm-chair on which MRS. FIELITZ is sitting . She has aged perceptibly and grown thinner .— At the second window stands a sewing-machine with a chair beside it . A skirt at which some one has been working is thrown across the chair . A bodice lies on the machine itself . A door in the rear wall leads to a little sleeping-chamber immediately under the roof . To the left of this door a brown tile-oven ; to its right , a yellow wardrobe . In the right wall there is likewise a door which opens upon the hall . Behind this door a neatly made bed and a yellow chest of drawers . Above this chest hangs a seven-day clock . The SHOEMAKER FIELITZ stands in his stocking feet upon the chest of drawers and winds the clock .

In the middle of the room an extension table . A hanging lamp above it . Four yellow chairs surround the table , a fifth — of the same set stands near the bed . LANGHEINRICH and EDE , dressed in their working-clothes , are busy at the table . LANGHEINRICH holds an iron weather-vane which EDE is painting red .

sp.speaker: EDE and LANGHEINRICH break out in loud laugh
sp.p: FIELITZ

div.stage: Who has been minding the clock while the others have been laughing . ] Somebody 's been pokin ’ around here again .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: You c'n bet on that . I s'ppose that 's what 's happened . You 'd better watch out more .

div.stage: Renewed laughter .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: All I say is : let me catch some one at it ! An ’ I wo n't care what happens neither !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That 's right ! That 's the way ! Do n't you care who it is , neither . I think it was Leontine .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: The girl ai n't been near that there clock !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Oh , oh !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Somethin 's goin ’ to happen some day . I do n't take no jokes o ’ that kind .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: You gotta save that to put it in the shop .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That 's the truth ! That 's what I always been sayin ’ ! That corner shop 'll soon be built now , an ’ then maybe he wo n't have no clock to hang up in it . How could he go an ’ start a business then !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Firebrands ! Pack o ’ thieves ! Laugh if you wants to ! You can n't never get the better o ’ me !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Not a bit , can they ! An ’ that would n't do . How many contracts has you been makin ’ ? I mean about furnishin ’ people with shoes . You got to have somethin ’ to start with !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Ca n't you leave the man in peace !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You just go in my room ; there you c'n see letters an ’ contracts lyin ’ around — packages an ’ heaps o ’ them !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Looks into the adjoining room .I do n't see nothin ’ .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Tear up the floorin ': you 'll find the docyments hidden there . People has got to have their business secrets !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: O ’ course they has ! An ’ whippersnappers do n't know much about that . Go an ’ learn how to read an ’ write before you go an ’ mix in my business .

lg.l: Come , Fielitz , let them be ! Do n't lose your temper . You know as
Langheinrich has got to have his joke ! That 's the way the man is made .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: I do feel pretty jolly to-day , an ’ that 's a fac ’ ! I got a piece o ’ work done . An ’ if I do n't go an ’ fall down from the steeple when I puts it up — I 'll go an ’ christen this here occasion . An ’ I wo n't use water .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Are you goin ’ to put it up yourself ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: You c'n take your oath on that ! An ’ why not ? Schmarowski , he designed it . But I forged it an ’ I 'll put it up .

lg.l: LEONTINE
You better let Schmarowski do that himself .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Schmarowski ai n't afraid o ’ anything shaky .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: No , that 's as true as can be , I know . He ai n't afraid o ’ God nor the devil . That little man ... I tell you , Bismarck is just a coward alongside o ’ him !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'd like to make a inquiry : who is it that built that there new house ?

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Well , who did ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Me ! An ’ not Schmarowski .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Well , that 's certain ! We all knows that , Mr. Fielitz .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Right up from the foundation ! Me an ’ nobody but me ! That there is my land , my bricks , my money ! All the insurance money 's been sunk into that . Ax mother here if that ai n't the fac ’ !

div.stage: Laughter .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Oh , Lord , Fielitz ! Ca n't you let that be ? Has you got to tell them old stories all over again ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: That I has ! I got to prove that , mother ! I got to let them people know who I is ! Watch out , I tell you , when I makes my speech to-day !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Schmarowski says there ai n't goin ’ to be no speech makin ’ .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You can n't go an ’ tie up my tongue , an ’ Schmarowski can n't do it neither !

div.stage: He withdraws into the adjoining little room .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: You better look out , ole lady , an ’ see that there ai n't no bloody row raised . There 's talk now o ’ some people wantin ’ to get ugly . Better be a bit careful !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: All you gotta do is to keep your eye on him a bit . Treat him to drinks from the beginnin ’ . I can n't keep that man in order to-day . He 's bound to go to the festival .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: Schmarowski got a drubbin ’ yesterday .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Last night , yes , after the people 's meetin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Maybe he went an ’ gave it to ‘ em a bit too hot .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That 's what he did . That little scamp talked , Mrs. Fielitz ! The whole meetin ’ just shouted ! An ’ he did n't mind callin ’ a spade a spade neither .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: He ought n't to be so hot , I think .

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That he ought , just that ! An ’ why not ? Do what you can an ’ go ahead ! That 's the way ! That whole crowd do n't deserve no better . Not Wehrhahn an ’ not Friderici . An ’ anyhow , it was a good thing , Mrs. Fielitz . It was done just in the nick o ’ time ! Now he 's gone an ’ broken with them fellers , an ’ everybody knows it . There ai n't no goin ’ back now . Now he belongs to us , Mrs. Fielitz , an ’ I never would ha ’ thought it of him !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You got reason to be satisfied with him , I 'm thinkin ’ . Look at the noise in your workshop with four journeymen ...

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH
sp.p: That 's true , too , an ’ I 'm not denyin ’ it . He put money in circulation . I could n't make friends with Pastor Friderici 's collection plate . Could n't do it . Now everything 's arranged .— Now I want you to keep your eyes open at the window when I gets up to the top o ’ the steeple . I 'll wave an ’ sing out an ’ — jump down !

sp.speaker: LANGHEINRICH and EDE exeunt with the weather vane . A brief silence

lg.l: MRS. FIELITZ
I wonder if Rauchhaupt will be comin ’ in to-day ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: I do n't see , mother , why you 're so frightened all the time . Rauchhaupt ai n't nothin ’ but an old fool . Let him come all he pleases an ’ jabber away ! Let him , mother . Nobody do n't pay no attention to his nonsense !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: They says as he 's been talkin ’ around a lot .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Well , let him ! I got letters too . Here 's one of ‘ em again , mother .She throws down a letter in its envelope .But I do n't worry about that . An ’ anyhow it 's only that assistant at the railroad .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: It might ha ’ been Constable Schulze , too .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Or that assistant teacher Lehnert — if you want to go on guessin ’ !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , let ‘ em ! Them fellers is jealous — an ’ envious o ’ Schmarowski an ’ his new house ! They 'd like to go an ’ lay somethin ’ at our door . But no ! ‘ Tai n't so simple as that !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Who has been sewing at her machine for a moment .Look , mama , I found this here !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Hurry now , hurry ! Do n't go an ’ lose time now . That dress has got to be ready by two . Adelaide has been sendin ’ over again !— The one thing you ought to do is to go down to the cellar an ’ get that couple o ’ bottles o ’ wine , so 's we can drink their health when they come up ! You c'n see , they 'll soon be through .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: That thing was the Missis ’ spine supporter .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: She was a poor , wretched crittur : strappin ’ herself an ’ tyin ’ herself an ’ squeezin ’ herself , an ’ yet she could n't get rid o ’ her hump .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Well , why did she have to be so vain !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Do n't grudge her her rest . She 's deserved it .

lg.l: They says that her ghost keeps rappin ’ up in the top attic where
Langheinrich sleeps .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Let her be ! Let her be ! Do n't talk no more . Maybe he was a bit rough with her for all she brought money to him . She had to sew an ’ sew an ’ earn money .... No wonder she can n't find no rest .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Why did she have to go an ’ marry Langheinrich ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Let them old stories be ! I do n't like to hear about ‘ em . My head 's full enough o ’ trouble without ‘ em . I do n't know what 's wrong with me anyhow . A body sees ghosts enough now an ’ then without thinkin ’ o ’ the past .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: I must say , though , that if he 's unfaithful to me that way ....

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Langheinrich ? Let him go an ’ be . When it comes to that , there ai n't no man that 's any good . If there was to be a single one whom you could go an ’ depend on when it comes to that — it 'd be somethin ’ new to me .— Main thing is to be at your post . The man ai n't bad . He means reel well . Be savin ’ . You know how careful he is ! An ’ take care o ’ his bit o ’ clothes an ’ be good to his little girl . He do n't object to your boy .FIELITZ re-enters clad in his long , black Sunday coat .You can n't go to that dinner lookin ’ like that . Come here an ’ I 'll sew on that there button .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: ‘ Tai n't possible you 'll do that much ! Do n't go an ’ hurt yourself now .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Holds his garment with her left hand and sews , still seated .It ai n't nobody 's fault if a body can n't get around so quick no more . You gets well enough taken care of .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Aw , them times is past ! You need n't lie atop of it all ! I 'm like a old bootjack — kicked in a corner .— Has anybody been shovin ’ my clock ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: It 's likely . He 's got a screw loose .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You just wait !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Langheinrich was just jokin ’ ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'll show the whole crowd o ’ you somethin ’ now that I got on top . I c'n go an ’ stand up to any man yet !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , o ’ course . There ai n't nobody doubts that .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: I just want you to wait two years an ’ see who it 'll be that has made the most money : Schmarowski , Langheinrich or me !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I do n't see what grudge you got against Langheinrich ? He went an ’ took us into his house ....

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: He did that ‘ cause he 's got his reason an ’ ‘ cause he wants a high rent .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You better be glad he is the way he is .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: On account o ’ that bit o ’ business with the fuse ? You go right ahead an ’ let him trample on you .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: What was that there about a fuse ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: That business ? What d'you s'ppose ? Dr. Boxer talked about it too .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I do n't know nothin ’ about them affairs o ’ yours .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Mother , I got a good conscience .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You c'n go an ’ put it in a glass case .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Mother , I ai n't sayin ’ nothin ’ else right now ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: That 's all foolishness !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: All right .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Schmarowski was here . How 's that now with , the mortgage ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: You mean that my mortgage is now the fourth ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Anybody knows that a buildin ’ like that costs money .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Schmarowski is sinkin ’ all his money in bricks an ’ mortar .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Nonsense !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: It 's a fac ’ ! That thing has taken hold o ’ him like a sickness .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Main thing is that you agrees . Do n't you ?

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Not a bit ! I do n't agree to nothin ’ . I been a agent in my time an ’ took care o ’ the most complexcated affairs . Yes , an ’ Wehrhahn patted me on the back an ’ was mighty jolly ‘ cause I 'd been so sly ... No , mother , I ai n't so green .— I c'n keep accounts ! I knows how to use my pen ! I 'm more'n half a lawyer ! That feller ai n't goin ’ to get the better o ’ me .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI enters very bustling . He has changed the style of his
sp.p: garments considerably — light Spring overcoat , elegant little hat and cane . He carries a roll of building plans .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Mornin ’ , Mrs. Fielitz . How are you now ? Did you get over that slight cold ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Thank you kindly ; I gets along . Take a seat .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Yes , I will . I 've reely deserved it . I 've been on my feet since four o'clock this morning ! Lord only knows how I succeed in staggerin ’ along .

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Mornin ’ . I 'm here too , you know .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Good mornin ’ . Did n't notice you at all . I have my head so full these days ...

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Me too .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Certainly . Do n't doubt it ! Have you anything to say to me ? If so , go ahead , please !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Not this here moment ! I got other things to attend to just now . I gotta go an ’ meet a gentleman at the station on account o ’ them Russian rubber shoes . Later . Sure . But not just now .

div.stage: He stalks out excitedly .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: That cobbler makes us all look ridiculous . He plays off in all the public houses . The other day this thing happened out there in the waiting-room where all the best people were sittin ': he just made his way to ‘ em an ’ talked all kinds of rot about the factories he was goin ’ to build and such like .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: The man acts as if he did n't have his right mind no more .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: But you 're gettin ’ along all right .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Tolerable . Oh , yes . Only I can n't hardly stand the hammerin ’ no more . I wish we was out o ’ this here house !

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Patience ! For Heaven 's sake , have patience now ! Things have gone pretty smoothly so far . Do n't let 's begin to hurry now . Just a little patience . I 'm as anxious as any one for us to get settled . But I can n't do no wonders . I 'm glad the roof is on . I know what that cost me — an ’ then all these annoyances atop o ’ that .He shows her a number of opened letters .Anonymous , all of ‘ em , of course . The meanest accusations of Fielitz , of you , an ’ , of course , of myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I do n't know what them people wants . When you got trouble you need n't go huntin ’ for insult . That 's the way things is , an ’ different they wo n't be . They questioned us up an ’ down . Three times I had to go an ’ run to court . If there 'd been anythin ’ to find out , they 'd ha ’ found it out long ago .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: I do n't want to offer no opinion about that . That 's your affair ; that do n't concern me . ‘ S far as I 'm concerned , I gave the people to understand what I am . When people want to get rid o ’ me , they got to take the consequences . That 's what Pastor Friderici had better remember . I saw through his game .— But to come to the point , as I 'm in a hurry , as you see . Everything 's goin ’ very ‘ well — but cash is needed — cash !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: But Fielitz ai n't willin ’ .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Mr. Fielitz will have to be !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: He 's still thinkin ’ about that corner shop o ’ his . Ca n't you keep a bit o ’ space for it ?

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Ca n't be done ! How 'd I end if I begin that way ? You got sense enough to see that yourself . No . There was n't no such agreement . We can n't be thinkin ’ o ’ things like that .— A banker is comin ’ to this dinner , Mrs. Fielitz , an ’ I ought to know what to expect exactly . Everything is bein ’ straightened out now . If I 'm left to stick in the mud now ...!

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'll see to it . Do n't bother .

lg.l: Very well . An ’ now there 's something else . Have you heard anything from
Rauchhaupt again ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Yes , I hears that he do n't want to hold his tongue an ’ that he goes about holdin ’ us up to contempt . That 's the same thing like with Wehrhahn . I never did nothin ’ but kindnesses to Rauchhaupt . An ’ now he comes here day in an ’ day out an ’ makes a body sick an ’ sore with his old stories that never was nowhere but in his head . Maybe ... my goodness ... a man like that ... he c'n go an ’ keep on an ’ on , till , in the end ... well , well ...

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Do n't be afraid , Mrs. Fielitz . Things do n't go no further now that the noise is quieted down .— By the way , I see that the carpenters are assemblin ’ . I got to go over there an ’ rattle off my bit o ’ speech . It 's just this : if Rauchhaupt should come in again , you just question him carefully a little . There 's a new affair bein ’ started . Got a political side to it . Immense piece o ’ business . ‘ Course I got my finger in that pie , as I has in all the others now . We 'd like to get Rauchhaupt 's land ... He bought it for a song in the old days . If we c'n get it — the whole of it an ’ not parcelled — there 'd be a cool million in it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ here I got two savin 's bank books .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI
sp.p: Thank you . Just what I need . There are times when a man can n't be sparin ’ o ’ money ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: The girl is comin ’ . Hurry an ’ slip ‘ em into your pocket .

sp.speaker: SCHMAROWSKI hastily puts the bankbooks into his pocket , nods to MRS
sp.p: FIELITZ and withdraws rapidly .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Half rising from her chair and looking anxiously out through the window .If only they do n't go ’ an ’ make trouble this day . There 's a great crowd o ’ people standin ’ around .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE returns with the three bottles of wine and the glasses
sp.p: LEONTINE Mama ! Mama ! He 's downstairs again . That fool of a Rauchhaupt is down there .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Frightened .Who ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Rauchhaupt . He 's comin ’ in right behind me .

div.stage: She places the bottles and glasses on the table .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: With sudden determination .Let him ! He c'n come up for all I cares . I 'll tell him the reel truth for onct .

div.stage: RAUCHHAUPT puts his head in at the door .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Is I disturbing you , Mrs. Fielitz ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: No , you ai n't disturbin ’ me .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Is I disturbin ’ anybody else then ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I do n't know about that . It depends .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Enters . His appearance is not quite so neglected as formerly .My congratulations . I 'm comin ’ in to see if things is goin ’ right again .

lg.stage: With forced joviality .
lg.l: You got a fine instinct for them things ,
Rauchhaupt .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Staring at her , emphatically .That I has , certainly ! That I has !— I just met Dr. Boxer , too . He 's goin ’ to come up and see you in a minute , too . An ’ I axed him about a certain matter , too .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: What kind o ’ thing was that ?

lg.l: About that time , you know ! They says that he said somethin ’ to
Langheinrich that time an ’ Langheinrich said somethin ’ to him , too .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I ai n't concerned with them affairs o ’ yours . Leontine ! Go an ’ get a piece o ’ sausage so that they c'n have a bite o ’ food when they comes over afterwards .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: The world do n't stop movin ’ .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: No , it do n't . That 's so .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Would n't you like for me to stay here now ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Yon better be goin ’ an ’ buy some silk stockin 's .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: What 's the meanin ’ o ’ that ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: That do n't mean , nothin ’ much . You might think she was a countess — standin ’ there at Mrs. Boxer 's :— Adelaide , I mean , what 's now Mrs. Schmarowski . There she stood in the shop an ’ chaffered about a yellow petticoat . She 's a great lady nowadays an ’ one as wears red silk stockin 's .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: People like us do n't hardly have enough to buy cotton , ones .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I wonder what people will say about Adelaide in the end ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: That ai n't just talkin ’ . Them 's facts . T'other day the beer waggon unloaded some beer at Mrs. Kehrwieder 's — Mrs. Kehrwieder that 's a washerwoman hereabouts . Well , my lady comes rustlin ’ up — that 's what she does — an ’ turns up her nose — she ai n't no beastly snob , oh , no !— an ’ then she asks Mrs. Kehrwieder : is it reely true that the poor drinks beer ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You need n't come to me with your rot an ’ your gossip .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Anyhow , what I was goin ’ to tell you is this : I 'm on a new scent !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: What kind of a scent is that you 're on ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Mum 's the word ! I gotta be careful . I can n't say nothin ’ ; I do n't pretend to know nothin ’ . But I kept my eyes open pretty wide , I tell you . There 's detectives workin ’ , too . I been to Wehrhahn , too , an ’ he told me to go right on !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Knitting .O Lordy ! Wehrhahn . He 's goin ’ to do you a lot o ’ good , ai n't he ? It 'll cost some more o ’ your money — that 's what !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Mrs. Fielitz , the things we has found out , I 'll show ‘ em up clear as day , I tell you . You c'n get hold o ’ the smallest secret . The public prosecutor hisself pricked up his ears . An ’ the way you does it is this : first you draws big circles , Mrs. Fielitz , an ’ then you draws littler ones an ’ littler ones an ’ then — then somebody is caught ! Who ? Why , them criminals what set fire to the house . O ’ course I do n't mean you , Mrs. Fielitz .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I 'd give the matter a rest if I was you . Nothin ’ ai n't goin ’ to come out .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: How much you bet , Missis ? I 'll take you up .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: If nothin ’ did n't come out at first ...

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: How much you bet , Missis ? Come now , an ’ bet . All a body 's gotta be is patient . You ordered Gustav to come over at eleven o'clock with the seeds . An ’ just then Mrs. Schulze passed by your door . No , I do n't take my nose off the scent .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Now I 'll tell you something Rauchhaupt . I do n't care nothin ’ about your nose . But I tell you , if you do n't stop but go on sniffin ’ around here all the blessed time .... I tell you , some day my patience 'll be at an end !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Why do n't you go an ’ sue me , Mrs. Fielitz ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: For my part you c'n say right out what you has to say . Then a person 'll know what to answer you . But do n't go plannin ’ your stinkin ’ plans with that Schulze woman ! I put that there woman outta here ! She comes here an ’ tries to talk me into lettin ’ Leontine come over to her . The constable , he 'd like that pretty well . My girl ai n't that kind , though . An ’ now , o ’ course , the old witch 'd like to give us a dig . Before that she wanted to do the same to you !— I do n't know anyhow what you 're makin ’ so much noise about ! I do n't see as anythin ’ bad has happened to that boy o ’ yours ! He 's taken care of . He 's got a good home ! He gets nursin ’ an ’ good food !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: No , no , that do n't do me no good inside . I do n't let that there rest on me — not on me an ’ not on Gustav . Ca n't be done ! That keeps bitin ’ into me . I can n't let that go . It cost me ten years o ’ my life . I knows that ! I knows what I went through that time when I tried to hang myself . I ai n't never goin ’ to get over that , ‘ s long 's I live ! I 'll find out who was at the bottom of it all ! I made up my mind to that !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ
sp.p: Good Lord , an ’ why not ? Go ahead an ’ do it ! Keep peggin ’ away at it . What business is it o ’ mine ? Has I got to have myself excited this way all the time when , the doctor told me how bad it is for me ....

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Missis , there ai n't a soul as knows what that was . I knows it . I just ran home , blind .... could n't see nothin ’ ! I did n't know nothin ’ no more o ’ God or the world . I just kept pantin ’ for air ! An ’ then there I lay — like a dead person on the bed . They rubbed me with towels an ’ they brushed me with brushes , an ’ sprayed camphor all over me an ’ such stuff ! Then I came back to life .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: How many hundreds o ’ times has you been tellin ’ me that ? I knows , Rauchhaupt , that you went off o ’ your head . Well , what about that ? Look at me ! My hair did n't get no blacker from that there business ; I did n't get no stronger from it neither . Who 's worse off right now — you or me ? That 's what I 'd like to know . You got your health ; you 're lookin ’ prosperous ! An ’ me ? What am I to-day ? An ’ how does I look ? Well , then , what more d'you want ?— I dreamed o ’ my own funeral , already !— What do you want more'n that ? I ai n't goin ’ to bother nobody much longer . There ai n't much good to be got by houndin ’ me !... An ’ that 's the truth .— An ’ anyhow , you 're a foolish kind o ’ a man , Rauchhaupt . You 're so crazy , nobody would n't hardly believe it . First you was always wantin ’ to get rid o ’ the boy ...

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Oh , you do n't know Gustav , that you do n't ! What that there boy could do when I had him ... an ’ the way he was kind to children an ’ such like ! An ’ the way he c'n sing ! An ’ the thoughts he 's got in his head ! That there time when he ran away from the asylum , he went an ’ he sat down in front o ’ the church where he was always listenin ’ to the bells , an ’ there he sat reel still , waitin ’ . You ought to ha ’ seen the boy then , Mrs. Fielitz , the way all that shows in his face . That 's somethin ’ ! Only thing is , he can n't get it out the way the likes o ’ us c'n do it .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Rauchhaupt , I had worse things ‘ n that . Yes . I lost a boy — an ’ he was the best thing I had in this world . Well , you see ? You c'n go an ’ stare at me now ! My life — it ai n't been no joke neither .— Go right on starin ’ at me ! Maybe you 'll lose your taste for this kind o ’ thing the way you did onct before .

lg.l: Mrs. Fielitz , I 'm a peaceable man , but that there ... I 'm peaceable ,
Missis . I never liked bein ’ a constable , but ...

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well , then ! Everybody knows that ! On that very account ! An ’ now there ai n't nobody as bad as you ! You 're actin ’ like a reg'lar bloodhound ! Why ? You 've always been as good as gold , Rauchhaupt ! Every child in the place knows that ! An ’ now , what 's all this about ?— You c'n go an ’ open one o ’ them there bottles . Why should n't we go an ’ drink a bit o ’ a drop together ?RAUCHHAUPT wipes his eyes and then walks across to draw the cork of one of the bottles .— Fightin ’ c'n begin again afterwards . I s'ppose life ai n't no different from that .— An ’ we can n't change it . There ai n't nothin ’ but foolishness around . An ’ when you want to go an ’ open people 's eyes — you can n't do it ! Foolishness — that 's what rules this world .— What are we : you an ’ me an ’ all of us ? We has had to go worryin ’ and workin ’ all our lives — every one of us has ! Well , then ! We ought to know how things reely is ! If you do n't join the scramble — you 're lazy : if you do — you 're bad .— An ’ everythin ’ we does get , we gets out o ’ the dirt . People like us has to turn their hands to anythin ’ ! An ’ they , they tells you : be good , be good ! How ? What chanct has we got ? But no , we do n't even live in peace with each other .— I wanted to get on — that 's true . An ’ ai n't it natural ? We all wants to get out o ’ this here mud in which we all fights an ’ scratches around ... Out o ’ it ... away from it ... higher up , if you wants to call it that ... Is it true as you 're wantin ’ to move away from here , Rauchhaupt ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Yes , Mrs. Fielitz , I been havin ’ that in my mind . An ’ why ? Dr. Boxer an ’ me , we knows why .He groans sorrowfully .It ai n't only on account o ’ my wantin ’ to be nearer to Gustav . No , no ! I do n't feel well in this here neighbourhood no more . Everybody looks at me kind o ’ queer nowadays .

div.stage: The bottle has now been uncorked and RAUCHHAUPT fills two glasses .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: That 's another thing . Why does we care what people think ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: No , no ! When a man has done what I has — that 's different . When a man 's gone that length — an ’ a former officer at that — that he 's gone an ’ taken a rope an ’ tried .... I do n't understand , Missis , I do n't understand how I could ha ’ done that .— But they cut me down ... that they did .

div.stage: He drinks .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Is it reely true what people says about it ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: You see , it got out , an ’ people knows ! An ’ that — me bein ’ a former officer — when I think o ’ that ! No , no rain an ’ no wind can n't wash that blot off o ’ me .

div.stage: He drinks .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: I say : let 's drink to our health . I do n't care about people nor what they thinks .— But if , maybe , you do want to sell some day — who knows ?... I c'n talk to Schmarowski . You two might agree .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER , EDE and LEONTINE enter

lg.l: DR. BOXER
You 're having a very jolly time here , Mrs. Fielitz .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Just to-day . It 's an exception ; that it is !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Young lady ! Hey , there ! You want to see somethin ’ ? Langheinrich is dancin ’ around on the church-steeple !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ rises with difficulty and looks out

lg.l: LEONTINE
I can n't bear to look at things like that even .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Let him fall ! He wo n't fall nowhere but on his feet ; he 's just like a cat .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Softly and half-humorously threatening RAUCHHAUPT .Stop exciting my patient all the time . A deuce of a lot of good all my doctoring will do then !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You c'n leave the man be , Doctor . People has put him up to things . Otherwise he 's the best feller in the world .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Very well , then ! And beyond that , Mrs. Fielitz , how do you feel ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Well enough . ‘ Tis true ,—she points to her breast— somethin 's cracked inside o ’ here . But then ! Everybody 's gotta get out o ’ the world sometime . I 've lived quite a while !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: You mus n't talk so much ! You must keep still longer .To RAUCHHAUPT .I 've got an invitation for you . Mr. Schmarowski saw you going in here , and so he stopped me and asked me to say that he 'd like to have you come over to the dinner !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Rauchhaupt — well , o ’ course . Why not ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: An ’ I wo n't go givin ’ nothin ’ away yet .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: And you , Doctor ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Quickly .Heaven forbid ! Not I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ why not ? Do you bear him a grudge about anythin ’ ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: I ? Bear a grudge ? I never do that . But , do you see , I 'm a lost man as far as all this is concerned . I do n't deny that it amuses me to watch all these doings here , but I can n't join in them . I 'll never learn to do that .— I will probably go away again , too .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: An ’ give up such a good practice ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Sea-faring — that gives a man true health . That is the best practice for one , Mrs. Fielitz , who is in some respects so little practical .

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: You ai n't very practical , that 's true .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: No , I am not .— Listen , listen , how they 're letting themselves go !Many voices are heard in enthusiastic shouting .Great enthusiasm again ! In a moment they will raise Schmarowski and carry him on their shoulders . They were about to do it a moment ago .A great , confused noise of huzzaing voices floats into the room .Well , do you see ? Is n't that truly uplifting ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Mother , look , look who the workin'men is raisin ’ up ! The workin'men is raisin ’ him up !

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Who ?

div.stage: She rises convulsively and stares out .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Do n't you see who it is ?

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: Schmarowski .

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: That 's how it is . I could n't bear to see that there feller . But now ... well ... he 's got some sense an ’ he 's fightin ’ for sensible ideas — against arbitrary an ’ police power — now , well , I 'll drink to his health , too .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Well , of course , Ede , naturally you will !

sp.speaker: FIELITZ enters highly excited
sp.p: FIELITZ Me ... me ... me ... me ... it was me that did it ! Go on an ’ shout , an ’ shout ! It 's that there feller that they lifts up ! Let ‘ em . But I do n't make no speeches like that ! Character , conscience — them 's the main things . Yes , it was me as paid an ’ me as built . But even if Wehrhahn went an ’ dropped me — I do n't let go my sound opinions ! There 's gotta be order ! There 's gotta be morality ! I 'm for the monarchy right down to my marrow ! I do n't envy him that there triumph !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Look here , Fielitz ! Come over here to the light , will you ? I 'd like to examine your eyes .— Do n't your pupils move at all ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Pants swiftly and convulsively , throws her hands high up as if in joy , and cries out half in rapture , half in terror :Julius !

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Mama ! Mama !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: She 's gone to sleep .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Appealing to the DOCTOR .Mother is swingin ’ her arms around so !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Who ? Where ? Mrs. Fielitz ?

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: Look ! Look !

sp.speaker: EDE
sp.p: Laughing .Is she tryin ’ to catch sparrows in the air ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER has turned from FIELITZ to MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: DR. BOXER

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fielitz !
sp.p: FIELITZ unconcerned by the events in the room , walks excitedly up and down in the background . RAUCHHAUPT is tensely watching from the window what takes place without .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: What is it ? Mother wo n't answer at all !

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: I believe they 're goin ’ to end by comin ’ over here !

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: What is it , Mrs. Fielitz ? What are you trying to do ? Why do you move your hands about in that way ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: Reaching out strangely with both hands .You reaches ... you reaches ... always this way ...

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: After what ?

sp.speaker: MRS. FIELITZ
sp.p: As before .You always reaches out after ... somethin ’ ...

div.stage: Her arms drop and she falls silent .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: To DR. BOXER .Is she sleepin ’ ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Seriously .Yes , she has fallen asleep . But keep all those people back now .

sp.speaker: RAUCHHAUPT
sp.p: The whole crowd is comin ’ over here .

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Emphatically .Keep them back ! Ede ! Turn them back at once !

lg.l: LEONTINE
Doctor , what 's happened to mother ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Your mother has ...

sp.speaker: LEONTINE
sp.p: What , what ?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Significantly .Has fallen asleep .

sp.speaker: LEONTINE 'S
sp.p: Face assumes an expression of horror ; she is about to shriek . DR. BOXER takes hold of her vigorously and puts his hand over her mouth . She regains a measure of self-control .But , Doctor , she was talkin ’ just now ...?

sp.speaker: DR. BOXER
sp.p: Gently draws LEONTINE forward with his left hand and places his right upon the forehead of the dead woman .So she was . And from now on she takes her fill of silence . In the background FIELITZ , careless of what has happened , regards his eyes sharply and intently in a hand mirror .

sp.speaker: THE CURTAIN FALL
sp.p: S
